column10:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Assassin's Creed Syndicate is the ninth major installment in the Assassin's Creed franchise.
Set in Victorian London during the Industrial Revolution, you play as twins Jacob and Evie Frye as they attempt to regain control of the city from Templar Grand Master Crawford Starrick.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Beautiful graphics.
[*]London looks great.
[*]Combat is pretty good and more fast-paced than Unity.
[*]Stealth is pretty good and more polished than Unity.
[*]Good mission design.
[*]Optional objectives are actually fun this time even if some are annoying.
[*]Fun side activities, although they get old after the third or fourth time.
[*]Decent soundtrack.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Microtransactions, because f*ck you, we want your money!
[*]Frequent crashes. I stopped counting after the tenth time.
[*]Dreadful Crimes DLC is not included with the Season Pass or Gold Edition.
[*]Cloth physics are locked to 30 fps. Can be fixed in the .ini file.
[*]Depth of field can't be turned off in-game. Can be fixed in the .ini file.
[*]Mediocre story with a generic Assassin vs. Templar plot.
[*]There aren't many missions where you play with both characters. There are only two, and one of them is the last mission.
[*]Uninteresting modern-day story.
[*]Parkour is too restrictive. Can't do unsafe jumps.
[*]Rope launcher makes parkour completely useless. Would've been better if it only worked horizontally so it wouldn't be too op.
[*]Yet again, there are more f*cking collectibles.
[*]Most DLCs are filled with bugs. Jack the Ripper was the worst as it reset 2 hours of progress after fast traveling.
[*]AI rubberbands like crazy during races. It will even teleport if you get too far away from it.
[*]Teleporting disables waypoints.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
While I think Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a better game than Unity, it's still a generic Ubisoft title. Its story is shallow, its villains are generic, and its DLCs make Unity look like a polished game.
There are also microtransactions for some stupid reason. Don't waste your money on that garbage, they give you nothing of value.

A worthy entry in the AC franchise, though not without some drawbacks. I don't recommend this one for new players since it will spoil you with how easy it is to traverse compared to past AC games. Story was weak and I found myself much more interested in clearing the map of rival gangs. Game play was fun but not as strong as it's predecessors Unity, Black Flag, and Rogue.
Music was great though, I would find myself swaying to the gentle but intense soundtrack as I swung between the rooftops. Setting was super cool and while I don't think I'll play it again, I'm glad I played it once.

So it turns out that you can get past the shitty Uplay launcher if you play the game using Geforce NOW. Not having to worry about launcher issues, I loaded up the game and played it, and I had a damn good time. Truly, if this game actually runs, it's visually beautiful, it's probably one of the best AC games mechanically speaking, and the writing is pretty good. 

Of course, all that being said, you may have noticed that this is a negative review. That's because during sequence 7, FIFTEEN FUCKING HOURS INTO THE GAME, there exists a bug in the mission, "Playing Politics", in which Jacob Frye must tackle a spy and press him for information about the attempt on the prime minister's life or something. The thing is, when you tackle the spy, NOTHING HAPPENS. He just gets up and stands there, and you cannot progress further in the mission. Apparently there's a solution where you open task manager during the mission and mess around with your CPU, and then the mission works as intended, but as I said before, I was streaming the game on Geforce NOW, meaning it wasn't running on my PC, meaning I can't fix it in task manager. The only other option would be to run the game natively on my PC, which, aside from just not running as well, means I would have to deal with the Uplay launcher, which I have made no progress with.

I normally don't like to fault games for bugs. Every game of this size is gonna have bugs. Hell, AC Unity was filled to the brim with glitches. The difference is that those were at least mostly visual bugs, and the game could still be played to completion. So either Ubisoft fixes the glitch, or I get the Uplay launcher working, neither of which will likely ever happen.

This is all so sad because the game is probably the best (traditional) AC game up until that point where it doesn't work. I would recommend it if not for the launcher and that one bug. If you want to play an Assassin's Creed game, get Unity. Syndicate is ever-so-slightly better, but at least Unity is fully functional.
Still a great game, holds up well.
I don't recall ever owning or playing this lol

Alright, so let me tell you about my experience with Assassin's Creed Syndicate. First off, diving into Victorian London was like stepping into a time machine. The attention to detail in the city blew me away. From the crowded streets to the grand landmarks, they really nailed the vibe of the era.

Combat in Syndicate felt smoother than ever. The rope launcher was a game-changer, letting me zip around buildings like a Victorian Batman. Taking down enemies felt satisfying, especially when I got creative with the environment.But it wasn't all perfect. Some missions started feeling a bit repetitive after a while. Sneak in, assassinate the target, get out. Rinse and repeat. It would've been nice to see more variety in the objectives to keep things fresh.Lastly, the bad guys could've used a bit more oomph. They felt kinda one-dimensional compared to the rich world around them. A bit more depth to the villains would've made the story feel more gripping.

Overall, though, Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a blast. Exploring Victorian London as a badass assassin is an experience I won't forget anytime soon. If you're into historical settings and sneaky, stabby gameplay, give it a shot. It's not perfect, but it's definitely worth the ride.

Lastly, this franchise does this all the time with its series they release multiple games if its a hit do some innovation with constant releases they slowly whittle the innovation until they start to feel the money drain due to people not being interested anymore, THEN innovate and eventually whittle away yet again. I'm not saying i would never buy another assassin's creed game but only until they innovate again and once innovations stop then just i'll wait until they restart the innovation.

Severely underrated ac game. First of all. The graphics look insane for a game that came out 9 years ago. At least on max settings, though it's also surprisingly demanding for a 9-year-old game (5800x3d, 6950xt, 1440p, ~100fps). The story is fine, nothing special. Gameplay is really interesting with the 2 siblings, cause you can feel a difference in the movement and combat. Also, the grappling hook is really cool. I also think it's good that it's not a game like Valhalla, where you need to sacrifice your whole life to finish it. Just a nice "classic" AC game with a few new ideas compared to the old old AC games. Definitely worth a try. For me, top 3 in the franchise.

When it comes to Assassin's Creed games, I find that basically no one talks about Syndicate... After playing it I really don't understand why? Apart from the Ezio saga (AC 2, Brotherhood and Revelations) I think this might be my favourite Assassin's Creed game.

The setting is in London, which is a city I'm quite familiar with and I just enjoyed looking at the monuments, the streets and the overall atmosphere of 19th century England. There's plenty of historical throwbacks to popular people of the era and the story (whilst not unique in any way) was interesting.
Ubisoft have done well to refresh the formula a little bit compared to the older games, but still stayed faithful to the franchise as a whole.

Overall, if you like Assassin's Creed games, this one will definitely not disappoint!

Overall I think this game is a very good addition to anyone who likes Assassins Creed's library.

First of all, I had so much fun while playing it. I liked driving around in carriage, drifting if you could say that, also involving Rooks and creating some chaos on streets was entertaining, their never ending repeating of the same phases was silly. I appreciate the addition of Treasure maps, it was easier to find collectables. The rope launcher made it easier to travel bigger distances more conveniently. Upgraded lock picking was so nice in comparison to Unity. That also goes to longer usage of Eagle vision. The virtual London was amazing. 
The idea of changing between two characters was interesting. There as a clear difference between them, as one is devoted to the Brotherhood while the other one has something different on his mind. As both of them had their flaws, I liked Jacob more as he was entertaining to me, while Evie was kind of bland.
The story was interesting but not something extraordinary. Also I feel like there was times when game just expects you to know what to do with no explaining.
WW1 segment was solid addition.
Everthing is excellent of this game except optimization.

First time playing after years setting it aside because of potential and Ubisoft's tendencies to fuck up big time...
Well, it turns out that i played past 13 hours pretty much in a go !

It seemed top tier at first but it all came crashing down... and fast !

I have not finished the game yet but here's what I can say :

The tone of the game is a huge disservice given the time period. It was a grim period with a lot of pollution, child labor, poverty and so on but this game feels sunshine and rainbows, constant banter between characters (while enjoyable) ruin the setting, days last ages while night is just a few minutes (if you fast travel at the beginning of night it'll likely be day again)... The lack of consequence for pretty much anything is another bad element of the story's delivery. The ending is not satisfactory either.

Collectibles are a chore : You can buy maps to reveal them. However, said maps won't show them (animus fragments now called animus glitch).
Map markers are broken.
Fast traveling breaks markers.
Replaying missions can put you in an animus loading loop until you give up and Alt+F4...

Controls are unresponsive, the grappling hook should be awesome but it's far from it :
Do you remember when back then instead of climbing up you would sometimes jump to your death ?
It's more annoying even though you don't die EVERY SINGLE F*CKING TIME !
AI can and will shoot you across buildings 100m over if not far more.
Some perks straight up don't work.

Also another thing that by itself would flip from 10/10 to begative is that it is an inferior port and is not feature complete (lacks badges/cards and achievements).

There's also uplay which straight up doesn't work and an in-game store which i couldn't explore.
Even then, I can deduct that part of the idea was shoving way too many collectables and grind in order to make the game next to impossible to enjoy :
like a f2p except a total price of at best 70 bucks or maybe 112 which I can't verify through the steam page AND there's microtransactions adding to that !
The whole experience is made miserable to push the purchase of microtransactions (that can't be purchased anymore). This is beyond pathetic !

When it comes to performance, the game tends to crash a lot, there are a lot of visual glitches (texture, npcs, clipping...), some missions are bugged and in case i didn't mention it yet some collectibles are glitched too, add to that more glitches the higher the framerate, framerate settings in the game not working, capping framerate manually causes minor performance issues (sub 60fps while over 90fps uncapped) !
Some textures are really bad (for instance, hair was significantly better in Assassin's creed 2). How did they f*ck that up ? Overall, textures are far worse than Unity and more glitchy than most other games in the series.

Story : 4/10
Gameplay 3.5/10
Graphics 3.5/10
Performance : 2/10

Total = 3.25 - 1 (lack of steam features implementation) - 1 (removed achievements) = 1.25/10

I love this game. I first played it a few years ago, and had an equally -if not better- time playing it again now.

First of all, I love the setting. Victorian London has always intrigued me, and I enjoyed how AC: Syndicate handled it.

Secondly, the characters were also a big part of my enjoyment of this experience.
Evie is my favourite by a long shot, but Jacob grew on me throughout the story. Their dynamic as siblings is entertaining, and I love their banter. The side characters like Abberline and Henry Green were pretty cool too, and I liked their interactions with the Frye twins.

The combat was nothing too special, but it was easy enough without being boring, so I can't really complain. The stealth was fun, however the melee fighting was a bit lackluster for me.

I nearly got 100% completion, but because of some optional objectives in the quests that I didn't complete I ended up with 98%. I did get all the collectables around the map. For someone like me who loves exploration, it's nice to just put on a podcast and get all the chests and helix glitches.

I haven't played many other Assassin's Creed games, so I can't vouch for how good it is compared to the rest of the series, but by itself I really enjoyed this game.
This is a great game about being an assassin in old-timey Britain. I love the story it is really good and had a lot of character put into it.
One of the best Assassin's Creed games I have played (it's also the most recent one for me) I also liked Assassin's Creed 3 a lot.

Very confusing format.  Unlike the others in the AC series, where the main story missions are clear and easy to tell apart from the "unnecessary" or "optional" side missions, AC:S missions don't seem to lead you anywhere.  You get to Sequence 4 where Jacob and Evie have their differences.  But then there's no path to follow after that.

There's a bunch of missions all over the map, none of which seem to be associated with the main story.  You can roam the map for hours on end, switching between to two protagonists, and still not figure out what to do next.  I've completed every mission on the map with every "Associate" that you need to gain loyalty with, but I'm still in Sequence 4.

Also, I have yet to see the present day characters "pull you back" from your time travels to talk to you about how you're doing either, as is the case with the other AC games.

Most of the Associate missions are severely buggy.  You can do exactly what the mission tells you to do, including the usual tasks that give you extra credit.  But 90% of the time, you won't get credit for one thing or another even if you accomplished every task with incredible ease.

There an Assassination Target map in your hideout train, but it serves no purpose other than to tell you what Sequence you're in.

I've given up on trying to figure it out, and went on to collect all the collectables on the map.  But now that's even finished, and nothing left to do on the map, and STILL in sequence 4.

I was really hoping for this one to be a winner, mostly because of my British heritage and my fascination with the 19th century Industrial Revolution era (where the concept of Steampunk came from).  But it's time to move on.

Oh and BTW, I did all of the things I've listed in only 32 hrs gameplay in about a week's time.  Unlike AC Unity, Rogue, Black Flag, etc. that took about a month or more (each) to accomplish the same amount of tasks.

Moving on to Origins and Odyssey.  I hope they'll be worth the hype they were given.  This one certainly was not.

While the story and scenery is good - and the game itself is also quite enjoyable there are a few things that really puts me off on this game:
 - The grappling hook does kill a bit of the Assassin's Creed DNA in my opinion as you now can scale tall church towers in few seconds; yes it makes it much easier and makes our heroes less prone to suddenly decide to commit suicide because they choose to jump away from the wall although you are pretty sure that was not what you commanded them to do, and it also makes it easier to get some of the collectables. However it makes it feel a bit tame. It is 1860's so perhaps some good. old development is just what was needed...?

Now for the major issues: Stuttering (especially when driving), freezing up - which gives some scares as it some times may end up in the third issue: game crash - thank you for closing down my game after I spent a long time sneaky-peaky killing enemies before moving in on the boss... one of the best ac games

Alright, first things first, I loved this game from start to finish. The interactions between Jacob and Evie were one of the best parts of playing, and their differing missions kept things interesting with new perspectives and goals that I won't spoil here. The other characters were also interesting, despite not getting much screen time, so to speak, to interact with them.
The grappling hook was a lot of fun to play around with, and makes traversing London far easier than it would've been otherwise.
For Templar hunts, the varied methods to approach and assassinate a target were extremely interesting and were a breath of fresh air for me after previous AC games (I believe this is also a mechanic in Unity, but I haven't played it yet). Each hunt was different, something that I felt other games somewhat failed at, and I'll definitely be going back to replay them and see what other routes there were to take.

Now, a couple complaints that didn't ruin the experience for me, but were a little annoying: The buildings are quite uneven and can make movement a little tricky at times, especially on tailing missions, but luckily these are few and far between. The multi-kill mechanic is a little inconsistent, but people still die so not too much of a problem overall. Using carriages can be equally fussy since your lowest speed is still faster than all the NPCs', but you can get around this alright by weaving through traffic.
A common thing I hear about this game is that the story is weak compared to the other games, but I honestly can't say I minded very much. I prefer good characters to a strong, perfect narrative, so I had a fun time overall regardless.

I think Assassin's Creed Syndacate is a really refined and very beautiful title.
I confirm my opinion also in numerical terms: I would say between 9 and 9.5 points out of 10.
Unfortunately it doesn't seem possible to have multiple saved games (maybe I'm wrong, I'll search the internet for more information and correct these words accordingly): these are things that annoy me quite a bit; who knows if it might be possible to do something from the file system.
Nonetheless, Assassin's Creed Syndacate is certainly a very notable result of videogaming in our era: an old-school structure in its pure state, identical to what a San Andreas could be, that meets extremely refined graphics, an aesthetic taste which combines moving panoramas with musics but free from any languid sentimentalism, and two different but complementary and pleasant protagonists, with their own strong personalities, their irreducible individuality, and that profound fraternal bond that keeps them in balance, even intimately, spiritually, morally, over the difficult thread of the events they must run.
A hymn to freedom, the freedom of all, including that of children, with a simple but severe and undaunted criticism of child exploitation, here joins the usual journey between fiction and reality that has always characterized the Assassin' Creed Saga.

Victorian London served as an excellent backdrop to this AC installment. Syndicate is slick, with fluid movements, engaging combat and beautiful graphics even given its age. 
With the addition of a grappling hook, you can Spiderman your way around the city with ease and escape just about any sticky situation in seconds. While fun, the grappling hook does nearly eliminate the challenge and perception needed to parkour effectively around the game's city. That daunting viewpoint all the way at the tippy top of a massive structure that will challenge your vertigo?  No sweat with the hook.

In terms of gameplay, hands down my least favorite aspect of the game were the carriage races. I felt the rage monster from decades long past bubbling up inside of me watching opponents suddenly have bursts of speed to win a race in the final seconds.

Some quick comments and observations:
[list]
    [*]After a lot of RDR2, the carriage driving was quite comical in comparison. I know this isn't fair criticism, but I was chuckling as I flew around corners wreaking havoc on anything unfortunate enough to be in my way.
    [*]The story was decent, though predictable. 
    [*]The typical AC gameplay loop is there complete with plenty of climbing (grappling), jumping, diving, running, stealthing, and murdering (quite a lot of that). Collectibles? of course. Not as many as some past games, but still plenty if you're vibing. 
    [*]The WW1 DLC wasn't bad, though like the main story, just a little bland. An intriguing setting, but maybe a little empty.
    [*]The game crashed or bugged out at least a dozen times throughout my playthrough. Not an unplayable amount, but the last few AC games seem to be a little janky like that. 
[/list]

Despite its flaws, Syndicate was definitely one of my favorite AC games so far. Other than what was already mentioned, no notable changes to the game experience when compared to other titles. You had 2 protagonists for the first time however and I can't decide if I liked playing as Jacob or Evie more. I tend to favor a stealthy approach so I was on Evie a lot once I had all of her skills trained up, but I certainly didn't mind having Jacob's additional combat abilities to mow down enemies. 

On to Origins...eventually...

I feel like this was the original 7/10 "it was pretty ok" Assassin's Creed game. 

The story was...fine. Forgettable, moustache twirling villain, uninteresting plot with one of the protagonists just derailing the main story for most of the first act because he wanted to start a gang or something instead of like, doing his job. 

The combat was...fine. Enemy design didn't really improve or worsen compared to any of the other older titles. Both protagonists have different weapons with decent combat animations but the RPG elements both hinder and help the combat.

The aforementioned leveling and RPG system exists and it's...fine. Both characters have their own skill trees and specialise in different things. Jacob can smacks and shoot, Evie can sneak and stab. They both feel distinct but character-locked missions made this effect grating, getting locked into playing Jacob in a stealth mission or low-level Evie getting completely bodied in a combat-heavy mission. You will sometimes get rolled by an enemy simply because the number above his head is higher than yours and that's dumb. Also you outscale most of your weapons faster than you can upgrade them. 

The character writing was actually pretty decent most of the time but your mileage absolutely depends on how much you like the dumbass vs straight-man trope.

The city was...weirdly forgettable considering it's industrial era England. None of the burrows felt distinct other than arbitrary difficulty levels and you're basically locked inside just regular old timey England. Not the usual sprawling landscapes previous titles offered while also not having any of the content density (or quality) a smaller scale usually brings. 

The parkour was fun. You get a grappling hook and can zip around like old timey Batman.

The stealth was better than Unity.

The side content was boring.

The level design could be interesting sometimes but for others you could just sort of walk in, smoke bomb, kill your target then leave in under 30 seconds. This was possible for multiple main missions.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is considered to be the last old-school Assassin‚Äôs Creed title before the series shifted into the Action RPG genre. When released, it also flew under the radar after the messy launch of the previous title, Unity. People got burned and lost faith in the series after that, and Ubisoft had to take a break before the shift, so Syndicate is in a weird spot.
With all that aside, I found this game to be disappointingly average. I don‚Äôt know exactly what it is, but it‚Äôs simply not very interesting. The setting is nice, taking place in Victorian London. It has a steampunk vibe to it, taking place after the first industrial revolution. Some may not like that, but at least it‚Äôs something the series hasn't seen before.
You play as twins Jacob and Evie Frye, and outside the story, you can freely swap between them. Jacob is supposed to be a better brawler, and Evie better in stealth, but in practice, they play almost the same. The story is generic, mostly finding and executing the various Templar members in London until you eventually confront the leader.
They are disappointing, especially the leader since you have no connection with him, and he only appears in some cutscenes until the end. In most AC games, you have a more personal reason to deal with them, but this time it‚Äôs just a bad guy must die.
Gameplay is also average. Combat lacks the multi-kill sequences, and the cool kill animations are locked until enemies are put into a near-death state, which makes them much harder to trigger. You could argue that means combat is harder, but it‚Äôs just attack, counter, and break defense until you win. Enemies lack variety as well.
Parkouring feels a bit off. The first thing I noticed is that you have fewer opportunities for seamless parkour on rooftops because the streets are so wide compared to past games. The game gives you a grappling hook, which feels good to use, but at the same time feels like a band-aid to cover the mediocre parkouring.
Besides the story, you have the usual collectible hunting and side missions, which aren‚Äôt so bad. Historical figures are present as usual, this time featuring the likes of Charles Dickens, Charles Darwin, and Karl Marx.
However, collectibles have a HUGE catch. You can buy maps for most of them; however, two of them aren‚Äôt available in-game. Instead, they‚Äôre only available in the microtransactions store, with real money. A scummy tactic, since without those maps, you‚Äôll need an external resource to find everything.
Stupid microtransactions, but at least besides these maps, there isn‚Äôt anything useful to buy. I bought the Gold Edition with the Season Pass, so I started with enough currency to buy one map, but I couldn‚Äôt naturally get enough to buy the other one. You can get more premium currency in-game, but it wasn‚Äôt enough for me to buy the other map. There is a way to farm slowly with temporary collectibles, but of course, most of the time, they are bugged and won‚Äôt count‚Ä¶
Speaking of the Season Pass, it doesn‚Äôt even give you all the content. Ten detective missions are available to buy, but it‚Äôs not included. They aren‚Äôt special but offer a different gameplay style you won‚Äôt find in the base game.
The main DLC content is the Jack the Ripper storyline, but it‚Äôs also disappointing. Very early on, you‚Äôre spoiled about its identity, and there‚Äôs only one new mechanic where you can fear your enemies. At least that feels satisfying to pull off.
The game also has a lot of small bugs, but nothing game-breaking I could find. The DLC, however, had one game-breaking bug that made me replay a side mission multiple times because a carriage would fly out of nowhere at the very end, killing an NPC and resulting in a fail. That was incredibly frustrating until after a few tries it worked fine.
The Ubisoft Connect also has its problems, mainly the lack of achievements and statistics in the in-game overlay. You can check the achievements in the desktop app, but the stats are only available on the web app. They at least work correctly, but having to check them in specific places is ridiculous, at the time of writing this review.
It looks like I‚Äôm being too harsh on the game, but it‚Äôs not bad, just average. I‚Äôve had fun with other Ubisoft titles, including other AC games, but playing this one simply felt like a chore most of the time.
I can recommend it on sale but only after you‚Äôve played some of the other, better AC titles. It‚Äôs not a good introduction to the series, and it was a disappointing title to me. I would give this an average rating if I could.

So for three days I've been trying to run this game on my rather new computer. It doesn't connect to Ubisoft server, so the DRM won't let me. I've been googling solutions online, disabling my IPv6, flushing my dns, restarting my pc several times, and it doesn't work. And since the internet is full with tutorials on how to solve the "can't connect to Ubisoft" issue which offer dozens of different solutions, expecting you to try all of them in turn and to compromise your computer's security in process, I'm sure I'm not the only one.

So I oaid money for a product that is harder to use than a p!rated copy would have been. If I still wanted to play this game, I'd probably go ahead and look for a cracked version instead of jumping through even more hoops, wasting even more hours of my rather scarce free time on DRM gone absolutely wild. This doesn't prevent p!racy, this induces it. This is certainly the last time I paid any money for anything released by UbiSoft.

Full disclosure: I only got into AC with Odyssey because the vast open world arpg was my jam (still is). I had no beef with more stuff like that being made and did not care at all that it was under the AC name. Odyssey is still my personal favorite comfort game. But after spending even a small amount of time in Syndicate, I think I finally [i] get [/i] what "the fans" of the originals felt like they were suddenly deprived of when the style changed. It's clear this is a stealth game first and foremost and, to my delight, it also happens to be a huge open world arpg. But it's the fact that the game is as fleshed-out as any other aaa game but focused on that assassin lifestyle is what makes it special. Well, actually the world of this game is also so dang special. It's really a beautiful city. I've never seen anything quite like the Thames, with all its boats blasting through it, in any other game. They nailed the scale of the city and made it seem overflowing with life. The music jumps OFF when things get intense and it's excellent. What a delight. And on top of it all the structure and flow of the whole game is right in line with my favorite game: the Ubisoft open world. Engaging, immersive, mechanically sound - can't ask for more. It's a very classy production all-around. I really slept on this one.

I was able to play this game on my Steam Deck. I've played all the Assassin's Creed games up to this point. This game allows you to switch between two characters, one with more strength, one with more stealth. I had a good time ziplining my way through London's Industrial Revolution.
If you enjoy Assassin's Creed games, chances are you'll enjoy this. Same formula, different time period.

The game is great from what I've seen on YouTube and I love the characters. It would be nice if I could actually play it, though. You'll run into so many launch problems it crushes your motivation to do anything about it. Uninstall this, launch that, delete those files, go offline... Give me a break. A launcher should work properly. Ubisoft, do something about it.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate brought Victorian London to life in a way that amazed me. The attention to detail in recreating the city, from the landmarks to the gritty streets, was incredible. Exploring the bustling city while taking in the era's ambiance felt authentic and immersive. The dual-protagonist dynamic between Jacob and Evie Frye added depth to the story, and their distinct personalities made the game enjoyable. The fluid combat mechanics and the introduction of new gameplay elements, like the rope launcher, kept the action fresh and exciting. Syndicate felt like a refreshing take on the series, and I loved every moment of my stealthy adventures through the Victorian era.

I have played all AC games in sequence so far. AC: Syndicate took some time to get used to. At times, it was more like playing an Arkham game than an AC game. The organized-crime element of the game reminded me of Mafia or The Godfather games. This is the most modern setting of the AC games, and there is some initial awkwardness with the juxtaposition of an ancient order of assassins doing their business in 1868 London. In my opinion, this installment of the AC franchise does very little, if anything, to advance the overall plot and narrative of the Assassins vs. Templars. Eventually, I was able to enjoy the Victorian-Era experience. It was a fun game, and I definitely got more than $8 (sale price) worth of enjoyment from it.

I think Syndicate as a whole is not a good game. The game is an assassins creed title yet doesn't feel like an assassins creed game. To keep this short, the game doesn't do much to compliment the setting other than the classic steampunk, carriage riding, gun slinging vibe. even if this wasnt an assassins creed title i still will say this game is pretty much stale and limited to the lack of creativity the dev used to have. the only good thing about the game is not the base game but the WWI bit and the Jack the ripper DLC. honestly if the game had more of the WWI portion or was set in that setting i would probably enjoy the game much more. Its either they did a poor job representing a steampunk, Victorian era world or im just not really interest in it.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is one masterpiece of the game. London in 1868 during the industrial revolution looks stunning and city feels alive. Parkour is smooth and diverse. Definite game play improvements over Unity but the issue of being able to abuse the economy and have top tier equipment relatively quickly persists. Yes, stuff is level locked but it's extremely easy to XP farm just doing associate activities (that you need to do for crafting unlocks/schematics) and collecting chests, flowers, etc.

It's particularly easy once you've got the ability to do radiant jobs like cargo hijacks/projects and cargo theft/destroy on the river which can come quite early on. I wasn't even playing to do that, just wanted schematics and equipment that was locked behind loyalty levels for some people.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a brilliant addition to the series. With an engaging story, charming characters, and a meticulously crafted historical backdrop in Victorian London, the game beautifully captures the essence of the era. Innovative gameplay elements, including the dual protagonists Evie and Jacob Frye, breathe new life into the Assassin's Creed experience. Syndicate is a true delight for fans of the series and those who relish historical adventures.

Really weak opening hours, even by Ubisoft standards.
Briliant Assassin's Creed. Kinda similar to Assassin's Creed: Unity, but much more polished. There are many cool new features, gameplay is very smooth and graphics are amazing.

The intro was just stupid, I mean who would derail and crash a whole train of supplies to get one person? The damages of a full train with wagons and the damage to the bridge would be in the millions. I also seriously doubt that the english railroad ever had live train traffic on tracks with one active switch leading into a ravine dead drop. That kind of wily coyote stuff is just stupid.

The actual game however was kind of good. I was surprised but the game actually works quite well. The missions are fun and the grappling hook makes traversing the city a joy. 

There are some stupid stuff that's very annoying though. The horse carts are too fast, if someone escapes with them you can't really catch up easily. And you can't aim your gun while "driving" for some reason. Only quickshot seems to work while driving a carriage but it's so bad.
The last mission in a area where you fight to the death with a miniboss is kind of retarded. You often meet the miniboss earlier during some kind of event but at that point they always seem to run away. The miniboss is scared out of his mind and runs away from you only to agree to fight to the death 5 minutes later on a one on one? Is this a joke?

At one point in the story you work tirelessly to find a secret key, you solve some ancient riddle high up on a building and the final secret hiding place is located even higher. After some time freeclimbing the building you finally enter the inaccessible located entrance to the secret room you just opened... And at that point the villian suddenly appears behind you. Is this some kind of joke? How re*arded would you have to be to even consider this kind of stupid sh*t? 

Some of the run and tackle missions are stupid to the point of insulting the player. The game says that you need to catch a enemy but at the same time the whole event is scripted making the enemy run faster always getting away until a certain point. It's painfully obvious when this happens since they suddenly run extra fast and it's just so stupid since it's obvious you are 
not supposed to be able to catch them dispite being told to do that.

Can't say I enjoyed the henry and evie bits, henry looks like he's 40-50 years old while evie looks like a young teenager. The thing felt so strange and not giving the player any sort of control or interactivity at all just felt stupid. The whole thing just happened without much backstory and since you control both siblings the whole thing felt very weird and forced.

Duleep Singh DLC missions are can be encountered and played through before he is introduced into the story. That is no problem, the problem is that Ubisoft hasn't patched or made any checks for this so if you encounter him after playing his DLC he will still act like it's the first time you meet. A showcase of Ubisofts disregard and sloppy practice of story elements of assassins creed.

Despite all that it's still a decent game and one of the better assassins creed i've tried. 
It just strikes me how simple and crude the stories are from assassins creed despite being such a long series of AAA games. Compared to other big name games they are so unrefined and bland. The reuse of the same templar vs assassins setup in every game just doesn't do it for me.

Although the story is quite boring but, both interactions between the siblings is interesting. Whole new experience of assassins where its more closer to the present days. Steampunk concept in this game is an eye catching idea. FUN GAME

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate is a masterpiece in the gaming world. The game takes us on a thrilling journey through Victorian London, offering a deeply immersive experience. The protagonists, Jacob and Evie Frye, are charming and engaging, each bringing their unique style to the game.

The meticulous detail of the city is astounding, from the grimy back alleys to the grand architecture of the landmarks. The game‚Äôs rich storyline is filled with intrigue and suspense, keeping players on their toes.

The combat system is fluid and dynamic, making each encounter exciting. The stealth mechanics are refined, offering players multiple ways to approach a mission. The addition of the rope launcher for traversing the city is a game-changer, making exploration even more enjoyable.

The side missions are as compelling as the main story, providing a glimpse into the lives of Londoners during that era. The game also does an excellent job of integrating historical figures into the narrative, adding an extra layer of authenticity.

In conclusion, Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate is an exhilarating experience that blends history and fiction seamlessly. It‚Äôs a must-play for any fan of the series or anyone looking for a deep, engaging gaming experience.
terrible

This is maybe an unpopular opinion because many people dislike the game, but I love it. It's not my favorite Assassin's Creed by any means, but it's still a great game. I enjoyed it, and, you know, the fifth time I played it wasn't any different. What I really appreciate is the more modern and fast-paced gameplay. The city is huge and meticulously detailed, with lots of tall buildings that are wonderfully designed.

However, the story isn't particularly strong; it feels recycled from older games, and the characters only seem to have one personality each. The villains are forgettable, but the one character that stands out in this game is Evie Frye. She really gives off those old Ezio and Altair vibes.

All in all, it's a very good game, especially with the best DLC in all the Assassin's Creed games. Seriously, this DLC is so good; I highly recommend playing it. The DLC is S Tier, for real.

While it's a matter of personal preference, I consider Syndicate to be the last true AC game. If you prefer the classic formula, this is a very solid game.

The most direct comparison is AC Unity, which I would consider to be better than this. Unity had overall better parkour and the setting itself is more interesting to me - but Syndicate still holds up. Having 2 characters with fairly distinct gameplay is a fresh change, and as far as Ubisoft side activities go these are some of the most fun that I've ever done.

Overall Syndicate is not the greatest AC ever, but it absolutely holds up as a classic AC experience.

Having devoted over 75 hours to the game, acquiring all the DLCs, and even buying the artbook, I can confidently say that I've embraced Assassin's Creed Syndicate as a true fan. This game became my cherished realm - a comforting place I could revisit time and again.

For me, Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a dream fulfilled, allowing us to step into the shoes of the intelligent Evie Frye, a refreshing and formidable female lead in the Assassin's Creed universe, and her charismatic sibling, Jacob Frye, who happens to be the funniest assassin ever. This adventure unfolds amidst the historically rich tapestry of 19th-century London - a city I've always yearned to explore.

Playing through the narrative, I found myself deeply invested in the Frye siblings' journey, their struggles, and their aspirations. Evie's dedication to preserving the Assassin's Creed with precision and intellect beautifully contrasts with Jacob's more impulsive and flamboyant approach. The world is meticulously designed, with landmarks like Big Ben and the River Thames brought to life with astounding accuracy. The downloadable content enhanced the gameplay experience by providing additional storylines and challenges, allowing me to extend my adventure in this fascinating world.

Let me guide you through each DLC in case you're still deciding on buying any:

[b] Jack the Ripper DLC: [/b]
A Must-Buy. This one is a true game-changer. It's like stepping into a whole new thrilling world within the familiar one. The atmosphere is dark, evil, and intense, immersing you in an adrenaline rush and stress that is surprisingly incredible.

[b] The Last Maharaja DLC: [/b]
There's a mission with drunk Jacob. Need I say more?

[b] The Dreadful Crimes DLC: [/b]
A fantastic brain teaser. The mysteries are tough in a good way, keeping you engaged and making you think hard to solve them. If you love challenges, this one's for you! It also prepares you well for some of Jack the Ripper's gameplay, so I'd recommend playing it first.

[b] Is the Season Pass Worth Buying? [/b]
It can be quite helpful especially when you're just stepping into the game, offering a lot of weapons, cool suits, double XP for faster development, and a few unique missions. Definitely a great addition to own if you're a fan. I got mine after finishing the main story and didn't regret it for a second. I simply liked the feeling of owning everything. Note that the Dreadful Crimes DLC isn't included in the Season Pass.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate became more than a game for me; it transformed into a treasured realm where history meets fantasy, where Evie and Jacob Frye's journey became my own, and where the allure of Victorian London never fades. I wholeheartedly recommend taking a look for yourself if you haven't already.

Assassin's Creed: Syndicate took me by surprise, especially after my mixed feelings about Assassin's Creed: Rogue and the ups and downs of Assassin's Creed: Unity. I must say, I absolutely love Assassin's Creed: Syndicate.

One of the standout features of Syndicate is the introduction of two main characters: the Frye brothers, Evie and Jacob. The freedom to switch between them during roaming, except for most story missions, is a brilliant idea. Evie, the more serious and focused sibling, feels like the perfect assassin, while Jacob, with his not-so-serious personality, takes some time to get used to, but he grows on you. I must admit that Evie is my favorite of the two, and her presence was a breath of fresh air after the last two main protagonists in the series.

The story is captivating and set in a unique period, the industrial revolution. The English atmosphere and the dark side of the era, including child labor, adds depth to the narrative. London is beautifully designed, with grand buildings waiting to be scaled. The grappling hook, a new addition, fits seamlessly with the vast cityscape. Although it makes combat and escape a bit too easy, I found it to be a perfect fit for this setting.

However, parkour in Syndicate feels somewhat scripted and restricted compared to the previous titles, taking away some of the freedom we once had. This may not be a major issue for me, but I understand it can be a significant concern for others. On the animation front, Syndicate outshines its predecessors, offering more realistic movements.

Yet, there are some elements that stray from the traditional Assassin's Creed style. The GTA-like aspects, such as stealing carriages from random people on the street, don't feel quite right for the franchise. Additionally, the focus on gangs, while fun gameplay-wise, might not align perfectly with the essence of being an assassin.

Nonetheless, the stealth and assassination mechanics are outstanding, surpassing even Unity's excellence. The combat has also undergone significant changes, making it feel fresh and enjoyable. While this combat style may not be suitable for a medieval AC game, it fits perfectly in the Syndicate setting.

Regarding the present time story, while better than Unity and Rogue, it doesn't match the depth of previous entries. The shrinking importance of the present-day gameplay and story across the series is disheartening for those of us who loved that aspect of the games.

For achievement hunters: they are not implemented on Steam, but on Ubisoft Connect. It's frustrating to work towards unlocking all 56 achievements, only to have no way for others to witness your accomplishments. Ubisoft Connect is currently the only place where you alone can view your achievements. Where only you can see them, having no way to share your progress with others. I am planning to complete this game in the near future. I will then come back with an edit.

To sum up, Assassin's Creed: Syndicate is a standout title in the series, offering a fresh perspective with two compelling main characters and an intriguing story set in the industrial revolution. The gameplay is fantastic, with excellent stealth, assassination, and combat mechanics. However, some elements may feel out of place for the franchise. Despite these minor setbacks, Syndicate remains a must-play for Assassin's Creed enthusiasts, delivering an entertaining and immersive experience in Victorian London.

[h2]7/10 (+0.5 for funny glitches)[/h2]
Environment is great: full of crime, sadness, industrial London. NPCs living their best lives, and the variety of their actions is truly fascinating. Hats off. The new mechanics of traveling through the city, the original assassin's base, are also pretty great. The chemistry between the two playable characters (twins) feels natural.

There are also cons. The acquisition of territory (different districts have about 6-8 quests with different goals, all to defeat the gang named Blighters) becomes repetitive after a few times, and it feels like chores. There are also a lot of collectibles that don't make much sense.

Considering all the cool stuff Ubisoft did, as mentioned above, there is a huge trade-off with the story. And the final boss, which is stupid. The final mission is nice, but the boss fight could be replaced with a cutscene, and I feel offended by this. The objectives of story-driven side quests, except for Detective DLC, are poorly written. I can't relate to the story, I don't find it interesting. I liked the story in AC: Unity, the character development and his chemistry and conflict with his girlfriend, but I don't see any progression in Syndicate's story. It just isn't there, but it could be, considering that there are a few good chapters that I really enjoyed.

Anyway, if you are a fan of the AC franchise and don't expect much of an interesting storyline, I would recommend this game. The world and gameplay are astonishing and worth playing.

The perfect game to start with if you want to get into the Assassin's Creed series, not necessarily because it's the easiest ( though if you're not going for 100% sync it'd be close), but because it has perhaps the most realised gameplay and story. Movement, especially stealth, is polished so having missed inputs are rare, and actively encouraged, which will become less and less the case in later iterations. Story wise very fun and engaging; Syndicate does a good job showing what it means to be an Assassin fighting for the little guy, while also showing the consequences for using such methodology with too little care. 
Base game is excellent by itself, but if you're going for DLC, the Jack the Ripper campaign is by far you're best bet, with the Dreadful Crimes being slower paced but in a respectable 2nd place.

I've always considered the AC franchise as an interactive history experience, and Syndicate delivers on that premise. 1868 London is beautifully recreated in this game and it is a lot of fun to explore, learn about the period and eliminate your enemies. Unfortunately, the story is kind of bland and not as memorable as previous AC titles. The main villain, Starrick, is so forgettable and cookie-cutter, even the boss fight is disappointing.  Despite that, Syndicate remains a good game and I highly recommend it to action/adventure fans.

Also, this would be a good video game version of Peaky Blinders.

Graphics are great, the London scenery is awesome and close to how it probably really was. The game itself is for me at lest very annoying due to the limitation to movements - you can't just simply jump off a wall or onto something, it is all only following pre-defined attachment points that you can climb up or down. Great on high vantage points, but If you like 3D shooters and free movement, it fries your brain if you simply can't make a character jump. It feels like "guided gaming" where the computer tells you to push a button now so that the next sequence can begin. The storyline is also quite flat and the humour really awkwardly bad. But most annoying is Ubisoft and their outdated launcher that firstly doesn't work until you install it and then, second day Ubisoft launcher says it can't verify the purchse. How could games become so painful I ask myself...

Almost perfect & certainly amongst the top AC's. 

Loved it when it originally released & now having played it all these years later i still had the same feelings. Such a shame that this game hit with the big AC fatigue with it's yearly releases & right after the Unity fiasco. The sales showed that a lot of people avoided this when they likely wouldn't have without those issues.

The characters, setting, story, writing, music, progression system, side missions & general atmosphere are brilliant. Going back to this after the newer RPG AC's felt like a breath of fresh air. [b] No [/b] +100hr slog, [b] no [/b] overly enormous & mostly empty world, [b] no [/b] horrible levelling progression in which you need to spend forever doing monotonous & boring side quests in order to continue through the main story.

Whilst Syndicate does hold up really well considering it's now 8yrs old. It would still highly benefit from a remaster. Higher resolutions, improved lighting, better LOD's, better draw distance, more character models for the gang members, better sky-box & rain effects, improved combat system (even if that's just more combat animations) etc. 

I think a lot of people that missed out on this the first time round would pick up a remaster. It's also probably the closest will get to an open world Peaky Blinders game which it definitely felt like at times.

I highly recommend Syndicate if you never picked it up at launch.

I am a huge AC fan, this game is entertaining, I highly suggest playing First Black Flag, Rogue and then Syndicate because they are similar in terms of timelines. The game controls are very much alike to AC Rogue. The story is fun, you happen to immerse into the character, the new mechanic of weaponery distribution is based on how you would train an apprentice asssassin on previous AC series which for me is understandable and makes more sense. The game is intended for new AC fans that are more opened to changes and mechanics, which is why, I highly recommend playing Black Flag, Rogue and then this game for long time AC fans. 

For Ezio Auditore fans, Graphics are marvelous and attention to detail is very nice. Only side note: You will have to get used to the new combat mechanics and get into the idea of having to go through Levels to unlock or use weapons. The game technology (Weapons) is fresh and you may find some of it appealling. It still feels like Ezio collection weapon technology was more advanced than Syndicate but that is just me.  

I am grading this game a rock solid 7 out of 10. I would have given it an 8 but it has combat bugs (Mostly happens when you are getting attacked by 8 or 10 enemies at the same time - The amount of enemies will depend solely on you, most of the time, you face a max of 5 or 6), jumping bugs ( Some times, It never jumps unless you go back, agarras impulso y saltas - Specially on trains or Ledges) and world bugs (Carriages flying away when you fight some big bosses, NPCs walking into walls) and even though it does not hinder your gaming experience, I was not expecting these types of mishaps on newer AC series games.  

Overall, Syndicate is a great game with some areas of opportunities. Would I personally buy it for a friend as a present gift? Yes. Would I stream it? Yes. Would I recommend the game to people? Yes. Would I feel satisfied after completing the game and say: it was worth the money? Yes.

I could not get past the lack of manual save/load feature. Even manual load alone would have been sufficient.

I'd get to the point where I know I'm going to fail a mission, but the fastest way to get back to the last checkpoint is to just walk up to an enemy and let it kill you. The only other alternative is to quit to the title screen and then re-enter the game, which is usually even slower.

Go buy AC Odyssey instead, they created a good balance there between rapid feedback and tension by preventing quicksaves in hostile zones. This game is just frustrating.

65/100  I've finished every Assassin's Creed game except Valhalla.  Syndicate is the second worst after the original game.  

Gorgeous Victorian London setting with amazing palaces and parks.  Missions are frequently frustrating and always boring.  The Victoria missions crash the game if you get de-synched.  The child liberation side missions were fun however.  

Movement is frustrating, including taking ages to get down from buildings, having to press E dozens of times.  

The storyline is over the top Wokeness, with starting splash screens about gender diverity, and a female protagonist who throws out lines telling Queen Victoria to stop expanding the British Empire and telling Winston Churchill to give women the vote.  

Ubisoft needs to spend more time on making an enjoyable game and less time pushing Woke agendas.

I will say this. This has been in my backlog for a long time, and I felt like I really needed to go back and play this, as I had been a fan of AC1 through Revelations. Fell off after that and this was the one people talked about that I kept thinking that I should play from the older style AC games.   This wasn't worth the time or attention in my backlog. It was fine but if your backlog looks anything like mine, play the other stuff first. 

- Story is predictable, and pretty much meh.
- Combat is fine, but very repetitive. 
- Stealth can be frustrating at times for a variety of reasons. Finicky controls being one (where you go climbing up something in the wrong direction). Another is that it doesn't feel like several were designed for stealth. Instead, it's frequently better to just start smashing people in the face until they are all dead. Eventually when you get more upgrades, this gets better. And Evie can be played pretty well as stealth. But honestly, you will spend more time doing it and there is rarely a downside to charging in and just punching people in the face.
- Toward the end, several missions are trying to drag out the game and it shows. Things where you have to spend a LOT of time just traveling back and forth.

Bugs
- In 2023, still lots of bugs. One, I had to lookup a fix for, which was a game breaking bug that wouldn't let me finish a mission. The character I was supposed to tackle, would stop responding, or attack me.  After 10-15 tries, I looked it up, and the only solution, was setting CPU affinity to use a single CPU. It caused it to be extremely choppy, but I was able to get through it.
- Multiple times during climbing, my character climbed into no where, and then would launch off in to the air, and die.  
- Multiple bug where people and carriages went flying, which was more funny than anything, but definitely pulled you out of the game. 

And I realize that is a ton of cons, yet a positive review. The reason is that, it's fine. But just fine.  The recreation of England is awesome.  Evie, and to a much less extend Jacob, are semi interesting characters.  And the gameplay is moderately fun, when it isn't frustrating.

AC Syndicate is very underwhelming. I like its technological side - I think what Ubisoft's studios managed to achieve with London is still extremely impressive, even almost 8 years later. However, even on technical side it's far from perfect with occasional bugs that will kill your progress (especially when playing with grappling hook) and extremely unresponsive movement. What's worse - the whole implementation of RPG-like weapon stats and progression is just not fun, making every fight that is above your equipment or character level - a tedious grind.

Story wise - the game is a bit of a mess as well, stretched thin with its plot over 9 and half chapters of mostly uninspired quests that we have seen hundreds of times already in previous Assassin's Creed games. Consistently throwing famous people from history as the replacement for the lackluster plot and lacking overall objective. The split between 2 characters doesn't help much either, as their gameplay is near identical and none of them is really likable or written to have any depth. New additions like train system or horse carriages don't do enough to address all of the pacing and variety issues these games had from the very beginning.

Worse - with the whole cheesiness and ever increasing absurd setups, Ubisoft kind of killed the motivation for actually being an assassin and trying to be quiet (not that these games ever truly succeeded at it, with Ubisoft consistently being desperate to force players into combat scenarios). Finally there is a problem of essentially "nothing" happening in modern times, as pretty much everything that's happening is now restricted to a few seconds of pre-rendered cutscenes poorly tying them to actions of the player in the past.

It's a shame really that Ubisoft with its greed has gotten the series to a point, where everything is stretched to maximum, lacking motivation and grand goal, with the whole idea of overarching plot connecting the games being pretty much dead since Assassin's Creed 3. I don't know - if you want to see how Ubisoft recreated London - I guess you might check it - it's not an awful game... just a game with a content stretched incredibly thin that failed to address issues carried over pretty much from the first game in the series. But other than that - play something else... especially if you are in mood for a stealth game, as this is horrible as stealth game.

A brilliant Assassin's Creed game. First played on Xbox One in 2016. It captures the atmosphere of the Industrial Revolution very effectively, with great historical cameos, detailed map, interesting main characters and an immersive story.

Gave the Assassins Creed Franchise a miss for a number of years because of the frequent releases as I was getting a little fatigued with playing the franchise and i had played them all up to that point so this was first foray back in the series after a 4 year absence and i'm glad i ventured back as this title ended up being one of my favourite games in the franchise!

The Frye twins are likeable protagonists but the real star of the show was Victorian London. 
Being a Londoner myself i apprenticed the attention to detail the developers put into this living world. It truly is beautiful.
The soundtrack should also get a mention as the subtle strings that play throughout really do set the mood. In my opinion the best soundtrack in the series (At the time of writing i haven't played Valhalla)

This is the first AC game I ever bothered to finish. I usually play for a bit then get worn out with it, but this one kept me entertained the whole way through for whatever reason. I really like the setting of Industrial Revolution London. I think the characters are some of the best out of the AC games that I have played. The traversal mechanics with the hookshot/zipline is pretty fun. And it's still a really great looking game to this day imo. It's not really a "steampunk" game, but it kind of gives that vibe at times due to the setting, hookshot mechanic, and a few of the weapons. It's not without its fair share of bugs tho. Still to this day this thing is riddled with npc bugs and a few mission bugs that are otherwise game breaking without reconfiguring cpu affinities in the task manager mid mission (wtf ubisoft). All in all, and bugs aside, I really enjoyed this one.

The only thing I appreciated about this game are the exceptional visuals and graphics. The story, on the other hand, is predictable with no new elements; the rest is an utter disappointment. There are numerous bugs, erratic physics, and random crashes that occur during missions or upon their completion. Speaking of the physics, carriages and horses would inexplicably fly and spin even without collisions. The Dreadful Crimes DLC is not included in the Gold edition, forcing a separate payment. It should have been part of the Gold edition. The rewards from missions often lack real value. And the level 7 equipment surpasses level 8-9 gear and even approaches the effectiveness of level 10 gear.

After the Ezio trilogy, ACIII, and Black Flag, the subsequent AC games lack the worthiness of playtime or even purchase. They simply don't justify the expense. If your intention is to invest in graphics, then by all means proceed. Odyssey, however, deviates when it comes to being an "Assassin's" game, but I still find it a commendable game.

I was going to make a whole essay, but I already wasted more than enough hours to tell you to not buy it. 
If you are aching to "play" in a Victorian era London that badly, by the end of it you'll understand that it doesn't really scratch that itch. In my eyes, this concept was wasted on Ubisoft. The collectathon and the repetitiveness of the gameplay makes it a chore and a complete snoozefest to get through. The bugs didn't help either.
[hr][/hr]
[b]If you decide to ignore my warnings or you are a masochist like myself:[/b]

-The Season Pass excludes "The Dreadful Crimes" DLC. Enough said.

-You need to install Ubisoft Connect and create an account (if you don't have one) to play. If you try to boot up the game without doing so, it will try to open through the uplay launcher (even though it was discontinued).

-If the game doesn't register your controller: go to the Steam settings, controller settings and disable (yes [b]disable[/b]) your controller's steam imput (disable Playstation controller steam imput, in my case).

-You may get softlocked if the fightclub missions bug out. Same if the train decides to kill you before you start a new memory in-between memories (although for this one you can try to track the train, hop on it and  interact with the board).

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate is an action adventure game developed and published by Ubisoft, releasing in October 2015 for the PS4, Xbox One and PC. This is the 9th game in the Assassin‚Äôs Creed series so far.

For the game play, most will probably be already well aware of what to expect from an Assassin‚Äôs Creed game. You play as one of two playable characters, Evie and Jacob Frye. A new, welcome mechanic to the game is a rope launcher, allowing the characters to quickly scale larger buildings and to create their own zip-lines for easier travel between buildings too. The combat system is at its best again with a very easy to use control set. The game is set in London, and you are able to freely roam the city completing all kinds of quests, finding collectables and locating treasure scattered around the world.

this is probably one of my favorite ac games. the story between the 2 characters pairs very well with each other. they make sure that even though they have their different styles that both character focused missions are fun in their own ways. i love the setting of this game. its the furthest into time we've ever been inside the animus and i like that. the time period selected goes very well with the setting of london. the jump between the 1890's and early 1900's WWI era is a nice change of pace and the game does its best to keep the two eras connected story wise. along with that the easter eggs and references to the previous games are very satisfying for avid players of the series. im not the type of person to play games like this and try to 100% the game. i usually play the game's story and do whatever side quests look interesting or could help me in the main story. all the extra things required in games to 100% usually seem boring or repetitive to me. but for some reason this game made me want to complete those extra things. i even completed some of the extra things the game had to offer before finishing the story. which is something i never thought i would do.

For some reason, the relatively modern setting of Syndicate threw me a bit off when it released, even as an Assassin's Creed fan, so I never bothered to play it. Now that I have played it, I wish I had at least tried it when it released. It's a lot of fun, the missions were great and Victorian London makes for a beautiful and engaging sandbox. I only have one minor complaint, which is the fact that I didn't always like the way missions started in terms of storytelling. In some missions, you just have to complete a certain task without a proper introduction. Come to think of it, the story left some things to be desired in general. Our main characters weren't as fleshed out as I wanted them to be in the end. Other than that, if you were like me and therefore a bit hesitant to give this instalment in the franchise a try, go for it! It's definitely worth it.

Among all AC games I loved this one's stealth mode the most. Almost all the quests here can be completed in a stealth mode. Loved it. The characters are also very memorable. Recommend. 

PS. The game is a bit buggy. The most annoying bug was almost game breaking. If you're playing this game in 2023 and you get stuck on "Tackle the spy", go to game settings, turn VSync on, set the frequency to 60Hz and it should be resolved.

Assassins Creed Syndicate is an overall really lovely game. The setting is beautiful and running through the streets of victorian London is amazing. I love all the tiny missions you can do, especially everything surrounding Dickens and Darwin. It's nice to have variety, simple as it may be. 

Having two different characters to choose from is extremely fun, seeing as it requires a bit of forethought on who you want to pick. (/[spoiler] Albeit I hated having to pick Evie, simply because she's a stuck up bitch. God, she's so annoying. Shut up and live a little, lady, you're barely of age. Jesus. - Jacob, however, was a joy and a charm. [/spoiler]) 

There is nothing that's truly irksome about this game, but there is one thing I really wish they'd done a bit different. 
The rope launcher is my own personal nemesis. One of the things I adore about the Assassins Creed games is the whole climbing and jumping from roof to roof thing. It's one of the things I enjoy the most - and it's one of the reasons I don't mind walking even though I have the option to quick travel. That, however, wasn't the case for Syndicate. Jesus fucking Christ, that god forbidden rope launcher is so annoying. Don't get me wrong, it has it's uses and there are moment's when I'm thankful it's there but it takes a lot of steam out of the parcour bits - because you absolutely [i] have [/i] to use it. There's no way around it, lest you want to climb up a building, down again to cross the street and up to the next. I really wish they'd made the streets just that tiny bit narrower, just enough to give you the option to jump and climb instead of slide. 

All in all, that is a very small complain to have and it's definitely overshadowed by the return of a very classic Assassins Creed game. One town, not a whole lot of travelling to do and more in line with what I would expect of an Assassins Creed than, for example. Black Flag.

Bought this game in the current sale, I'd have asked for a refund if it was full price.
I  am playing on PC and comment on that alone. PC controls are seriously poor - very slow in response IF they work at all, they barely target your intended victim. Gameplay is over-complicated, you need to press 3 buttons at once for a leap of faith - why?? There's a 'press f for quickshot' - yeah, and what's that do? The throwing knives are more accurate. The parkour is 'meh' at best, I end up shouting at the screen 'get down you twat!' Here I am dancing pigeon-toed on a roof edge that I should be able to jump off or running sideways along a fence I am trying to get over. The ziplines might be fun IF you could place them where you want, in the event of an air assassinate they are never over your targets, and that's IF you can release in time to drop down (on pc that's E to drop, might work if yur lucky, otherwise you just end up spinning on your zipline).
Other reviews comment that this game is better than AC Unity, I'd agree with that but not by much. The game is very similar, story progression is the same, locked behind unending emptying of chests, killing pple in the streets, getting collectables, some random kidnap and  a bit of gang warfare (and that's getting tedious real fast)
I also dislike the 'bad dog' red mark system for not completing a mission according to what the game wants - that's red marks for you and you don't get all the gear, that's be ok if you knew what they wanted. There's a Kenway mission for example, examine 7 items - so I stealthed my first 4, number 5 is the piano puzzle, the last were in the room that opened, all hell broke loose and I couldn't get the last ones - red marks. Oh and look away for this slight spoiler, the piano puzzle on pc - you cannot use the numeric pad or mouse pointer, use the numeric keys above qwerty - the code is 212342 - just so's you don't get red marks like I did (bad dog!).
But hey folks there is one thing that is very amusing - on pc the carriages are almost uncontrollable - drive those things at full speed, and use the boost - kill everyone on the streets, mash the opposition, smack down light poles, run up walls, go careering out of control - it' so dumb it's hilarious, I nearly cried I was laughing so hard, but I did 'deliver' my kidnap person.
For the company that made AC Odyssey, AC Origins , the 3 earlier Ezio games, and even Valhalla, I dunno why they can't stick to good story, good skills, good weapons, combat and interesting missions, that's gotta be a winning combo one would thunk......wouldn't one? 
At this point I have no idea what the story is - who are these people, why are they assassins, who is the father they keep referring to, who's the mentor guy at the start? I will complete the game because I always do, but I currently have no investment in the characters or the story - just fingers crossed it'll improve.
London is very atmospheric, the music is annoying at times. 
At this stage, it's a 3/10 from me, I agree 7 hours is not long into it perhaps, but if I wasn't a completionist i'd put it in the 'finish it sometime in the never-never' basket.
So Steam asked me if I wanted to change my review since I have played additional hours - uh, that's a big fat NO - character movement is seriously poor, frustrating and beyond annoying.Could have been great, just isn't. Caveat Emptor!

[h1]6/10[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]
     - Decent graphics
     - Really cool setting
     - Still has some of that Assassin's Creed charm
     - Interesting concept in adding 2 playable main characters with slightly differing skillsets
     - Train HQ is an interesting change

[b]Cons[/b] 
     - Possibly the worst Assassin's Creed game to be released
     - The most bland characters in any of the series (at least to this point, from my knowledge of all the 
        games)
     - No significant utilization of the plethora of interesting side characters at their disposal
     - Weird RPG element that felt half baked 
     - Moving HQ was a little annoying to deal with and served no real purpose
     - Worst combat in the entire series, feels extremely arcade like
     - Worst villain in the series to date
     - Worst storyline of the franchise
     - Weird Hitman style assassination missions that feel tacked on

Obviously a long list of cons, this being my second playthrough I really wanted to enjoy it more than my first. After my first playthrough when it first came out, it left me with the feeling of it being the worst in the series and that hasn't changed. As I'm playing through them all again I was hoping that with a second take I'd feel differently, similarly to my experience with AC Unity. All this did was solidify my though that this is indeed the worst Assassin's Creed game to be released, IMO ever.

The story on all fronts is boring, the characters are paper cut outs with no real personality, which includes the villains which is a shame. They continually try to paint him as this awful character and while that's successful, there's no real interaction with him so it feels meaningless. The main characters are also just so boring and the worst of the entire series. No real redeemable qualities or anything that makes them stand out. 

The gameplay is also the worst, the tacked on RPG element feels bad and pointless (not like the later 3 titles that are full blown RPGs and are generally decent at that). The combat is weirdly sped up and feels like an arcade game. The climbing is still awful feeling, only made slightly better by a ridiculous tool you get relatively early on in the game. It also is the first to have these truly "forced" side missions to finish the game which I personally hate. They also seemed to tack on the "Hitman" style assassination missions for unique kills and whatnot. This also just feels like it was added for no real reason and seemed to provide no real benefit to the actual game. 

Overall it's the worst game of a great series, and it still is an Assassin's Creed game. It still has that charm and still has it's moments of good fun. If you're already this invested into the series it's a recommend, but only because it's a piece of the story. If you're just in it for that, watching a play through might be for the best.

Its a Ubisoft release... games that are at a Beta at BEST are released full-price because they try to squeeze every ounce of "productivity" out of their developers. The game is a mess. Movement is clunky, combat is awful, and the game just seems too broken to enjoy the otherwise fun story and premise. I want to love this game, i really do, but installing and uninstalling 3 times just wont let me. Block bars wont appear but enemies will randomly become immune to damage (not even showing the blocking animation, just straight-up denying damage like they have god-mode), the reaction time varies all the time which makes consistent gameplay a foreign concept, and the target tracking is so bare-bones it can cost you the game. Doing a bounty hunt and have the target knocked out on the ground? Enemy comes up and you need to fight them so you can escape with the target? No Problem! Let the game targeting just unalive your target so you fail the bonus objectives! I kinda expected a top-shelf company to employ common sense mechanics into their game, but i guess thats impossible when said company hasn't had a good actually-finished-game release in... ever? I want to love this game because its story is fun, the newer mechanics (zipline, train, horse coaches, character swapping, etc.) are so promising but they only came halfway to completing even the most basic of game mechanics, making this game impossible to love. It just feels like suffering. I'm going back to the small-developer indie games that took half as long to make with a fraction of the budget and still provide a STABLE and ACTUALLY ENJOYABLE experience. Ubisoft is the embodiment of a company being so out-of-touch with their players that they think anything will do.

TL;DR- Game mechanics suck, makes game impossible to enjoy. Its a Ubisoft game.

I haven't played the AC since "Brotherhood" and ~15 years old. Now I'm 27 and don't remember whether "Brotherhood" was as dumb and buggy as this one.

Decided to try out Syndicate as AC was my favorite game growing up. I loved the open world and the freedom to get anywhere I wanted. I loved the movement and stealth mechanics. I liked the style of AC, its story, and the idea. But this one just disappointed me. The best mechanics of older games fortunately have been intact. London itself is beautiful. But the story is boring. The characters are flat. Bugs are so prominent and frequent that you can't be immersed in the world for longer than 2 minutes. NPCs are so dumbed-down that you feel like you are fighting against ants, not humans. The logic is missing. "Assasins didn't kill the civilians"... but riding through them with a carriage was a daily routine for them. "My fellow guard has been stabbed to death, I guess I'll look at him for a moment and get back to my default position".

I'd think I was being picky, it's just a game after all. But I'm coming here after a similarly priced RDR2... That's a completely different story.
