Okay, First things first. this game has some of the WORST Anti-cheat i have yet to see in a game that isn't obviously a multiplayer only game like COD or BF or something like that. I mean like, If you try changing almost ANY files for this game, it will either not load, or it will let you get to the main menu and then crash. and yes I'm one of those people who enjoy using mods for my SINGLE PLAYER games, I'm the only person it has any effect on, so who cares right...well apparently It affects Ubisoft. god forbid they miss out on selling their shitty in game currency for a game that already cost $60 dollars, we should be happy that they want to milk every last penny from their player-base. 

sorry about the tangent, but any way, the second big thing is the controls for the free-running, you have to either hold A or B on an Xbox controller while holding RT to free run, with A being to 'free-run up' and B for 'free-run down'. who in their right mind thought that was a good idea to put in an assassin's creed game? is so stupid.

Just don't buy this game, stick with Odyssey, origins, and MAYBE Valhalla, or AC: 2, Brotherhood, and MAYBE 3, and Blackflag. the rest are just absolute trash that ubisoft shoved out just to keep sucking on the artery that is the Assassin's creed series.

I advise everybody to skip this heaping pile of buggy garbage. It was bad before, but latest updates have either just been coded by morons, or was %100 intentionally to break the game to drive sales to other newer titles, either way, I just had a mission fail 11 times due to BUGS, not lack of skill, but bugs suck as key prompts not showing up, your gang randomly spawns between you and your target, they get in the way of you and your target, or kill your target, every respawn they are already %100 alert from last time somehow, you can't put him in the carriage by just pressing be or holding b, because either way it would choke out the target and de-synchronize you. Other times, enemies who usually would never bother you due to being maxed out on levels, usually they ignore you in the street, all of a sudden break ALL CODE! and randomly start attacking, causing your men to attack even if you never recruited them, and you failt he mission! You go upstairs, to smoke the hypnotist, and he somehow not only gets smoked and is coughing, but runs in a half broken animation to come and hypnotize you and restart the mission again, and again, and again, and again...

Seriously...this was not like this before...but after the last few updates more and more missions have been what seems to me, intentionally bugged and broken on purpose. Wouldn't put it past Ubisoft to sabotage older titles so they have an excuse to take down all servers as well, save money, pocket it, and demand their employees save their company while they bleed it dry....

Either way, unless you want a buggy mess, do not buy this game even on sale. The amount of glitches and bugs is absolutely inexcusable.

First, some pros:
-Being able to have your own gang and give them upgrades
-New tech like trains and revolvers
-Carriges are a fun way to get around
-Open world is very interesting
-It runs better than Unity, which mattered a lot to the younger me playing on a shitty PC.
-you can switch characters
-interesting side activities
-more modern day story than Unity, although that's the bare minimum
-awesome black box assassination missions

One mechanical con is the lack of weapons. There are only three melee weapon types (cane-swords, kukris, and brass knuckles), pistols, and tools you have in other Assassin's Creed titles like smoke bombs. Having more weapon variety would have been interesting, and they would have had many options considering this is the furthest into the future Assassin's Creed has gone excluding the modern-day story.

Now onto the story. The story and narrative is lackluster, it is not as strong as the older titles. When I first finished this game in May 2016, I liked the story, but editing this review later, I gave it way more credit than it deserved. It was corny, campy, and too lighthearted. That goes for all the main characters, as they all represent simple personalities for most of the game, and just as [spoiler]character development starts to happen with Jacob in Sequence 8, the game ends in Sequence 9, and we only see him for a little bit in the Jack the Ripper DLC. He could have been an awesome, memorable protagonist like Ezio, but they never focused much on developing his character. The only good villain was Maxwell Roth, the rest are scarcely explored, including the simplistic main antagonist, Crawford Starrick. [/spoiler] Ubisoft said Jacob is canonically bisexual, but unlike his twin, him having any love life is not hinted at anywhere in the game, making this announcement meaningless. It is superficially Assassin's Creed, because while the story has all the traditional elements, a big bad Templar and his goons you need to assassinate, with a piece of Eden macguffin involved, the story lacks heart and soul, it does not give you enough reason to care or be invested until [spoiler]the last two sequences[/spoiler], which is not good enough because the story beforehand did not develop up to there properly. This game had the potential for a great narrative and cast of characters, they could have done it if they just took longer. If they want to learn how to write enjoyable stories, they need only look to the Ezio Trilogy of Assassin's Creed Games. But at least unlike later titles (looking at you Odyssey and Valhalla), you actually play as assassins.

Another problem is while the open world is overall good, it can feel dead in places. The London Stories, where you do side missions for famous historical figures who were in London at the time, were great. The gang activities have their fun parts, especially raiding Blighter hideouts, but since most of them are just copies of each other, with only the kidnapping missions have unique dialogue, they get stale fast. There are far less buildings you can go inside than the previous game, Assassin's Creed Unity. There are plenty of skyscrapers in the City of London, barrack-like apartments for factory workers in Southwark, and upscale penthouses in Westminster, and they look like such a natural and realistic part of the Victorian open world, but you cannot go into them, interact with them, or get a quest from people inside them, or as I should say, the overwhelming majority of them, I would say ninety percent, and this kills the immersion.

This game had a great and mostly enjoyable open world with plenty of fun things to do, but heavily fell short when it comes to an enjoyable narrative and world depth. It was good but not great. While it had a better release than Unity, it did little to innovate. Final verdict: 7/10
shi was fun what can I say

This is the only "pure" AC game I've played (plus Odyssey from the "next gen" AC) so I can't comment on the hardcore AC fans hating the zipline and dissing the parkour. 
Full disclosure I got this on sale for ¬£6.50 and for that price you get a lot.  The storyline is pretty good: fun side quests for Charles Dickens, Alexander Bell and Charles Darwin plus a good variety of quests to get through the main storyline.  Aside from that, in order to unlock items and gain levels, you need to capture a number of London boroughs.  This part is a bit stodgy as the same basic tasks are repeated in each borough and there's a lack of variety in the gang members and gang leaders (they all look like perpetually angry Butlins redcoats) but if you want to steam through the main storyline then capture all of the boroughs first and you'll have enough XP to power through every quest.  The combat is a bit disappointing: you're basically spamming left click and if you're on MnK then the movement mechanic is not the easiest (you'll need to press 3 keys or 2 keys plus a side button to climb a wall) and the game hates it when you try to climb down even if its showing the key prompt to do just that.  There is no real difference between Jacob and Evie until you get near the end of the skill tree when you can unlock some character-specific special abilities.  The game is pretty fun though (i'm 89% of the way through the main storyline at time of writing) and for ¬£6.50 I can't complain.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is so bad. The fact that people call it "the last good Assassin's Creed game" is fucked.

The combat is good, but different. It doesn't follow any kind of formula, old or new, and it's an outlier in the series.
The parkour is the same as Unity, and it is so bad. The buildings in London are super spaced out and that makes the parkour even less fluid, that they had to introduce a grappling hook that doesn't want to function when you're on the ground. It's fun to use, but only when it's usable. 
The story is probably the most brain dead AC story so far, following Jacob and Evie Frye who are twins. They're good characters in my opinion, but the story would've been better if they had a dynamic rather than it trying to split them apart. Evie's story was definitely the better of the two, but then the last two sequences kinda just give up on her and rush everything to an end. And I think it's weird that they've been assassin's for this long, and they suck this bad at it. Especially Jacob, who just causes problems for everybody. The story outside of their dynamic would be good if they tried taking it more seriously instead of just making character like Alexander Graham Bell and Charles Darwin as fucking goofy as possible. It's a disservice to how historical figures are treated in this series, looking back on someone like Leonardo Da Vinci from the Ezio trilogy who was handled far better. I cannot recommend this game, as not even the side activities were ever very exciting. Just all the same. I gotta say it, this was also worse than Unity.

Syndicate has the best writing and characters I've encountered in an Assassin's Creed game. i enjoyed my entire play-through. My two quibbles are technical issues.

I can't really say if Syndicate is a good game.

On one hand, it's a masterpiece when it comes to how well they recreated the industrial revolution of London. It is beautifully crafted, with no street looking the same and everything being amazingly pretty at the same time.

On the other hand, it clearly showcases where Ubisoft went down as a company. It doesn't feel like an Assasin's Creed game, I have no backstory when it comes to the main characters and most of the time, it feels more like a Peaky Blinders Assassin's Creed crossover than an Assassin's Creed game.

More so, I completely despise Jacob (one of the main characters), him being a poorly written character and it shows, with toilet-grade humor and conversations reminiscent of the worst tinder dates you can get. Evie is, however, sweet and charming, and at the same time, interested in preserving the history and culture of the assassins. She's more of a main character than Jacob is, even if it feels like she was added at a later point in the development of the game (you barely get to play with her in the latter part of the game).

The character customisation is mediocre, at best. Nothing really looks good, and the good looking outfits are the ones borrowed from other assassin's creed games. The graple mechanic that has been added had me questioning it at first, but I believe it is one of the best additions to the franchise, given how fast it is now to climb a building. It keeps you swinging like a steampunk Spiderman in London.

The main story is somewhat short, and the pacing is all over the place, with sidequests feeling more like main quests given how big they are. They are no fun.

Syndicate is a great improvement from Unity, adding on top of what made Unity good, but still, a very lackluster story experience. I would recommend it at a hefty discount, but you shouldn't pay more than 10 euros for it. Still better than Odyssey, and more fun than Origins since it lacks the RPG element that made the latter a pain in the ass for me to play.

7/10.

[code]Assassin‚Äôs Creed: Syndicate is a farewell to the classic Assassin‚Äôs Creed formula, with all the ups and downs one might expect from that by now[/code]

At its launch in 2015, [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate[/i] might‚Äôve been met with a more critical reception amongst some players than it might receive today. The reason is simple: At this point in time, there had been at least one [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] release every year (since 2009) and ‚Äì not surprisingly, considering the short development time ‚Äì each of these iterations differed very little from another. Players understandably grew tired of playing through the same game every year and especially after the [url= https://steamcommunity.com/id/dreamylotus/recommended/289650/]rough launch of Unity[/url] one year prior, the general anticipation for a new [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] title ‚Äì which would be [i]Syndicate[/i] ‚Äì was not particularly high.

As a result, publisher Ubisoft decided that the franchise was in need of some major reinvention, which in turn led to a two-year break before the next main title released in 2017: [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed Origins[/i]. And indeed, [i]Origins[/i] was a completely overhauled [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] game in many regards, including a different gameplay loop, which now featured many RPG elements. This makes [i]Syndicate[/i] the last main game in the franchise to feature the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] gameplay (until the upcoming release of [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed Mirage[/i] in October 2023, that is).

This could mean that [i]Syndicate[/i] ‚Äì being the last of its kind ‚Äì is the classic [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] formula honed to its perfection, both in terms of gameplay and story. But while [i]Syndicate[/i] might be an improvement upon its predecessor [i]Unity[/i], it‚Äôs really not much different (or even better) than what came before. In fact, almost all of the usual criticism applies to [i]Syndicate[/i] as well.

What could‚Äôve been a gamechanger is the new protagonist duo, the assassin twins Evie and Jacob Frye. Evie‚Äôs strength lies in being stealthy, while Jacob is more focused on combat. They both got separate equipment and skill trees, which sounds bigger than it really is: The skill trees are the same save for a few unique ones, experience points are shared, and you‚Äôll share most of the equipment as well (e.g. guns). But what‚Äôs most disappointing is that this supposed duo only acts as a duo during exactly one (!) story mission, where you‚Äôll switch between both characters. All other story missions are focused on one of twins and the game forces you to play as said twin during these missions.

This would‚Äôve been disappointing but fine if the twins had equal screentime at least. But looking at the base game, this [url=https://gamerant.com/assassins-creed-syndicate-evie-jacob-screentime/]isn‚Äôt the case either[/url]: You‚Äôll play as Jacob for roughly two-thirds of the main missions, while Evie is only left with the remaining third. [i]Syndicate[/i] clearly has a favorite twin and it isn‚Äôt shy about that.

Story-wise, the whole twin dynamic is quite messy as well, with forced character arcs and a lot of ‚Äúbut father said‚Ä¶‚Äù. There aren‚Äôt a lot of games with twins both being playable protagonists, so it‚Äôs a shame that [i]Syndicate[/i] doesn‚Äôt really make use of this opportunity at all, in both gameplay and story. Though considering the story is riddled with its own problems, that‚Äôs hardly surprising.

[i]Syndicate[/i] does not only suffer from the usual story problems of open-world games (mainly pacing issues and unnecessary roadblocks like ‚Äúdo X side activities in order to continue the main story‚Äù) but also fails as an [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] story. The brotherhood is mentioned at the beginning as Jacob & Evie take things into their own hands, going against their orders, but that whole plot point never comes up again. Including the twins, there are only three assassins present in the entirety of London, [i]Syndicate[/i]‚Äôs setting, when even the Caribbean Sea was filled with assassins in [i]Black Flag[/i]. There‚Äôs a lot of templars to take down, sure, but they‚Äôre forgettable villains with the only templar connection of being called one.

As for the modern-day story, the Phoenix Project story of the [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] games since [i]Black Flag[/i] continues ‚Äì through small cutscenes between story chapters. But considering the entire Phoenix Project story was only continued (& finished) through a [url=https://assassinscreed.fandom.com/wiki/Assassin%27s_Creed:_Uprising]comic book series[/url] after the release of [i]Syndicate[/i], it should already be clear that Ubisoft didn‚Äôt really care about it in the end.

Overall, the main story of [i]Syndicate[/i] works in terms of telling you where to go next and why but it‚Äôs not much more than that. I feel like it could‚Äôve been so much more if the twins were properly used and the villains (as well as the assassins) more fleshed out but in the end, it‚Äôs the usual quest to take down a bad guy‚Äôs minions in order to finally tackle the bag guy himself. While I‚Äôm on the topic: [i]Syndicate[/i] also got one of the most boring final battles I ever encountered in a videogame. I couldn‚Äôt help but think ‚Äúwait, that‚Äôs it??‚Äù as the final cutscenes started rolling.

In terms of gameplay, [i]Syndicate[/i] is basically [i]Unity[/i] with some improvements. Instead of being stuck running around the city, [i]Syndicate[/i] offers horse carriages and a grappling hook to get through the city of London. Both are well appreciated since the city‚Äôs big and the fast travel points are few. The grappling hook is more of a hit-or-miss, however, since you can‚Äôt really properly control its target.

The rest of the game is really the usual mix of chasing people, tailing people, killing people and interacting with certain objects. There‚Äôs a lot of side content one could indulge in but considering it‚Äôs all just the same few objectives repeated over and over again, I don‚Äôt really see any reason to do so. That said, combat and parkour works fine as usual ‚Äì it‚Äôs not particularly complex and I definitely don‚Äôt want to keep doing it for hours, but it‚Äôs fun for a few hours and offers some great animation work.

Unfortunately, [i]Syndicate[/i] also suffers from a weird technical problem where the game sometimes renders in higher resolution than set in the graphics options. This might lead to distracting black bars during cutscenes. Follow [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=806615157]this guide[/url] to fix it.

Concluding, [i]Syndicate[/i] is less of a ‚Äúgreatest hits mix‚Äù and just ‚Äúmore of what worked before‚Äù. It‚Äôs a good [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] game that maybe got treated a bit too harshly at launch ‚Äì but it‚Äôs also nothing more than that. Fans of the franchise will enjoy it and even newcomers might consider taking a look as there are only few ties to the previous games. But in the end, it‚Äôs no surprise that Ubisoft went for a major reinvention of the franchise next, as the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù [i]Assassin‚Äôs Creed[/i] formula had really run its course by that point in time.

Syndicate betrays more traditional AC elements than it is loyal to. Jacob and Evie are already assassins when we meet them, so it‚Äôs not an origin story like Black Flag or Unity. Even so, their immaturity is reminiscent of those very games. 

The game allows you to play as both Jacob and Evie, to alternate between them outside and during some missions. I like that they aren‚Äôt just the same character gameplay wise, Jacob specialises in combat, while Evie in stealth, but Jacob is annoying. Unfortunately, for some reason, the game wants you to play as Jacob more and towards the end, most main missions are played as him. Evie deserves more screen time. The romance between Evie and Henry would have been acceptable if not for its lazy writing.

Syndicate‚Äôs Victorian London matches Unity‚Äôs Revolutionary Paris in attention to detail. However, unlike Paris, London‚Äôs tone is less on inequality between classes and more on how it was just a horrible place to live in in general. The city is monotonous enough that this message is successfully conveyed, yet has enough depth to make it interesting. The sky is polluted with smoke from factories in which children work and crime is rampant, yet through enough exploration, you‚Äôll find people playing cricket, kids playing football, and couples taking photos. The game manages to draw a city so depressing and lifeless yet so immersive and full of life, and it looks incredible. Its size can be intimidating though, I found myself fast travelling a lot compared to in Unity.

However, London is not fit for parkour. Its buildings are too far apart and its streets are too wide. Without the rope launcher, which doesn‚Äôt even work right half the time, it would be impossible to traverse through usual AC means. At the same time, the rope launcher also takes away from the parkour experience. Other than that, parkour is further simplified and doesn‚Äôt have the same charm as its predecessor. Carriages give life to the city, and are nice to ride recreationally, but not very functional in chases and carriage-fights. 

I have mixed feelings about the combat. It looks amazing; the violent successive punches, cuts, stabs and revolver shots as well as the brass knuckles, cane-swords and kukri fit perfectly with the setting of Victorian London. My problem with it is there seems to be no rhythm to it. I don‚Äôt know how long it‚Äôs going to take to kill an enemy, or how many hits it takes to deal damage to an enemy. Other than that, I didn‚Äôt have a problem with the levelling system or the skill tree. Stealth is improved. The kidnapping mechanic is fun, albeit unrealistic.

My biggest gripe is how the game doesn't take itself seriously. What could be important and emotionally heavy scenes are often interrupted by bad jokes, both in the historical setting and modern-day. There‚Äôs little emotional connection between the twins and the story, the missions, or the city and that reduces the gravity of the story the game is trying to tell. We know that their father was an assassin operating in London, but all the game does with his character is use him as argument fuel between the twins, and the game completely forgot about George, whose orders the twins defy in the first place to end up in London. The game just doesn‚Äôt feel like a main AC game.

Syndicate isn‚Äôt a bad game, but is definitely the worst AC game I‚Äôve played so far. 

5/10

I enjoyed the Ezio collection and Black Flag the most (so far). AC Syndicate, like all AC games, is visually attractive and makes "time travel" through periods of history very fun. I really enjoyed playing between TWO different assassins-- the brother/sister combo. This game, in particular, has the most beautiful classical arrangements of music ranging from Baroque to the Romantic periods, with a heavier emphasis on the Classical and Romantic periods. The in-game musical experience is true to the Classical and Romantic periods in which the game takes place. I LOVED the quartet bands found throughout the game! Horn quartets, string quartets, mixed woodwind/strings/brass... THAT is what most blew me away about this game! The fingering and playing of the instruments was simulated very well. I was so happy to hear some great Bach pieces played by the street musicians!!! If you enjoy AC games, this is plenty fun. I did purchase at 50% off, so that played a role in my enjoyment (bang for your buck enjoyment).

One of the first novelties in Assassin's Creed: Syndicate is precisely the duo of protagonists, Jacob and Evie Frye. Brother and sister are introduced to us as already initiated into the ranks of the Assassins, thus sparing tedious prologues and investing precious time in characterization that is all in all well done, and, above all, functional in context. Although undoubtedly stereotypical - impulsive and restless he, more thoughtful and pragmatic she - the two embody very well the two souls of the proposed gameplay, and above all they live a relationship based on an entertaining chemistry of constant bickering and contrasts. The plot pits them against an insane and idealistic Templar, who is convinced that he can turn London into a "paradise" by settling internal turmoil with violence and exploiting the flourishing of industry to subjugate the souls. The atmosphere is fascinating, and in its own way (fanta)historically convincing, although the chain of events leading up to the finale has no particular twists. What works more than anything else is the characterization of the individual characters, which also goes to include historical figures of the period, including Dickens, Darwin, Marx, and Queen Victoria. Although the latter's are only unlocked once the story is completed, this quartet of characters (reproduced with particular verve and a touch of humor) will ensure a good overall number of "memories" to be experienced parallel to the nine sequences of the main campaign, providing a nice cross-section of London at the height of industrialization. So if the validity of the glimpse was already confirmed from the first appearances of the game, what is striking is the excellent characterization work done on the historical moment, narrated on the streets of a city that at the time really represented "the center of the world." The gangs, the cultural, technological and political restlessness, the unstoppable expansionism. An industrious empire but also full of contrasts, between the first technological marvels and the brutality of the slums. The good reproduction is complemented by a thorough level design work, offering interesting paths to exploit through traditional parkour: as for the latter, compared to Unity there is an improvement in the fluidity of the animations and in the recognition of the controls, with a latching on to the handholds that still generates some headaches in some frantic moments, but it rediscovers itself to be more accurate.
The two separate buttons for ascent and descent, to which moreover we have become accustomed by now, return, flanked by a brand new feature, namely the grappling hook. The latter can be used either to rise in a matter of seconds or to stretch a rope between two points so that it can be used to move quickly from one building to another. Although it makes the task easier when it comes to escaping from enemy alerts, the tool proves to be a lot of fun to use during the action, and it alternates very naturally with the

I have been an AC fan and have surprised myself that in spite of the repetitive formula I have kept playing them. Maybe there has always been something special about each which maintains my enthusiasm, for example I did like sailing ships around in Black Flag. I hadn't bought Syndicate because to me it was always too expensive. But I played Unity back in 2019 and 4 years later I just had to scratch the itch and got the full package for about ¬£15.

Initially I was a bit disappointed because right from the start the gamer is forced to complete a linear mission, whereas I was looking forward to the open world play style. But I did like the chance to play both Evie and Jacob. At first the idea of the train seemed interesting but since it can't be steered, and there's no way to FFWD to a location it seems to become a bit pointless. So then I was left with the open world style that I have been used to. I did enjoy it but maybe I have finally lost my enthusiasm for AC. The designers have still not improved the controls so I was often frustrated that Evie or Jacob would go the wrong way or take the wrong action just because I was slightly off alignment. There are indeed a lot of bugs so it seems impossible to get 100% in many missions. I had a few crashes but I guess no worse than many other games.

As I had the full package I can't really assess the value of the DLCs much. I did have to pay ¬£1.45 for dreadful crimes which was worth it, even though it was a bit "cheesy". Jack the Ripper was mostly fun, but seemed not much more that a simple extension of the game with new tools and modified missions. But I found the parts when I had to play Jack irritating and somewhat pointless in terms of value to the game.

I guess I will play the next AC which I think is Origins, but I'll definitely wait for a sale because if its the same formula then maybe I'll have finally had enough of AC.

The last of the "classic" Assassin's Creed games, Syndicate is up there with Black Flag as being one of the best and most fun-to-play titles of the franchise (pre-Origins). 

If Batman lived in Victorian London, had his secret lair on a train, and had a twin sister partner-in-crime - you wouldn't be far off. Combat is dirty AF, fast paced and pulls from all the gritty English street fighting stereotypes. Once you get the rhythm down, you can take on whole crowds of enemies like you fell out of the movie Equilibrium and know Gun Kata. 

**Spoiler** Queen Victoria has cake.
do many bugs

Pros:

-> London looks absolutely stunning in this game, with detailed graphics and a great sense of atmosphere.
-> The addition of two playable characters, Evie and Jacob Frye, is a great change of pace and adds some variety to gameplay.
-> The grappling hook is a fantastic addition to the series and makes traversal much more fluid and fun.
-> The side activities are plentiful and varied, from gang wars to street racing to taking over enemy strongholds.
-> The soundtrack is amazing, with a great mix of classical and contemporary music that perfectly fits the game's setting.

Cons:

-> The main story can feel a bit disjointed and lacking in focus at times.
-> The combat can be repetitive and frustrating, especially when facing off against large groups of enemies.
-> The AI can be a bit wonky, with enemies sometimes not reacting to your presence or behaving in strange ways.
-> Some of the side activities can feel a bit tedious or uninteresting, especially if you've done them before in other Assassin's Creed games.
-> The game's performance can be a bit choppy at times, especially on lower-end hardware.

Overall, Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a fun and engaging addition to the series, with some great new features and a gorgeous setting. While it has its flaws, it's still a solid entry in the franchise and well worth checking out for fans of open-world action games.

I really expected to hate this game.

From the moment I launched AC: Syndicate I thought it looked visually boring and I thought the characters weren't believable... but I was so very wrong. I am very glad I decided to stick to this game and really give it a chance, because by the end of it I loved the story, the setting, and most importantly, the characters. Jacob and Evie take a little time to get fun, as they are semi-standoffish, but by the end I found myself audibly laughing at Jacob's jokes and Evie's cleverness.

The actual gameplay itself was also an incredible step up from AC: Unity, not just with the obvious (but awesome) zipline mechanic, but the game UI was far cleaner, parkour was cleaner, and the map was also actually enjoyable to look at. The music was also very well written, having a chipper or dark tone when necessary.

The only gripes I can think of with this game are as follows:
1. Ned Wynert's missions were boring and repetitive.
2. There are only so many times you can look at the same Big Ben loading screen and think it's pretty.
3. There are a few kinks in combat that detract from the fun of fighting a bunch of enemies at once.
4. Obligatory "Karl Marx and Charles Darwin were totally unbelievable" complaint.

Overall, an 8.75/10, would recommend.

TL;DR: Give this game the chance to blow your expectations out of the water and you won't be disappointed. The gameplay is awesome, the characters are fun, and the story is classic.

To put it bluntly: it is an Arkham spin with less depth and a story that parodies the franchise it finds itself in. That's not to say you won't be having fun with the game. I certainly enjoyed my first playthrough but on replays the shallowness of everything really made it so that I rarely finished any of those. The latest Assassin's Creed game that feels like an actual Assassin's Creed game.

A solid evolution of the Assassin's Creed formula with a cool twist. A solid story (although not unique). And really engaging characters, world, and combat.

I played this entirely on Steam Deck. I completed the campaign and most of the side activities (currently at 71% total synchronization). It had some performance issues, even on Proton Experimental, causing crashes ever hour or so and needing to limit the framerate to 30fps. I also had issues launching the game and had to update Ubisoft Connect manually and move the newer version into the games folder.

I have reall enjoyed the evolution of the Assassin's Creed games, and I vividly remember all the ads for this one when it came out. I did not know a whole lot about it going in, but knew that it was one most people really enjoyed. I really liked the twist of having two controllable characters in the game with their own strengths and weaknesses. It made the game feel fresh (Evie was definitely my favorite though). The addition of a zipline/grappling hook was pretty awesome as well.

The story was a solid entry in the series, although didn't really bring anything new to the table. It felt like an AC story. However, the side content was blended into the game very well this time around. This includes the collectibles (which I appreciated having to "hunt" for them), the territory activities for the "gang war", and the NPC quests (looking at your Bell and Marx). It never felt like a chore doing any of the content, which is a first for me in an AC game. Although fun, most of the previous game "gave" you all the side quest/collectible locations when you synchronized an areas viewpoint. This one you had to work for it a bit and the discovery felt good.

The characters and world felt alive and vibrant. Most people were pretty generic but some of the characters you encounter felt really unique. The most engaging ones to me were Roth (a true madman), and Alexander Graham Bell. 19th century London felt awesome to just roam around in from the industrial zones to the sprawling urban neighborhoods. It was just fun to explore the city. Lastly the combat felt REALLY satisfying, most of the time. I see now why people make the comparison to the Arkham games. When you combine the combat and the grappling hook, it is hard not to feel like Batman.

Overall, I really enjoyed this entry into the franchise and plan to revisit the game to finish out all the side content. A very solid entry into this franchise.

Coming after the sad state of Unity's launch (under which there is a seriously fantastic game), comes a reduction in everything that unity was, into a more comprehensive and chill package. dumbed down parkour so much that it pains me (but still better than val-ah-a), faster, grindier combat, and a levelling system that makes any side activity during the course of the game too easy, Syndicate still manages to be pretty awesome. The game's graphics aren't better than unity, but they are different and still very beautiful, except some parts of London looks really rather awful. On the bright side, they certainly run better. the stealth is faster paced and actually feels functional, as the slow and clunky feel of detection and stealth moves in unity somewhat kills the mood. The main characters have great chemistry but somewhat lack conviction compared to previous assassins. The setpieces were incredible though, with the WW1 segment and the tower of london both being really cool and interesting to look at. The blackbox missions too were very well designed, and executing (literally) unique kills never fails to entertain me. For everything this game lost, it gained a new coat of polish, a new feel of that london spirit, the always present passion that this seriously awesome series has. There is a great game here, and it is well worth a play.

I'm really indecisive about this game at the moment. On one hand it's a really good, fun & robust game that's a great way to show people the charms of Assassin's Creed. That being the historically accurate and immersive worlds. But on the other hand the game falls at it's own detriment by not taking itself seriously in the slightest, especially when you view it as a part of the whole series. All in all I'd really recommend this game for someone who's new to AC, but ask them to not look too deep into it. As soon as you start to ask the logic questions like "why the fuck did I just bump into Charles Darwin in the street and why did he greet me like I was his life long friend?", things start falling apart and you forget to have fun. 
Otherwise the gameplay's great and Syndicate seriously has the best stealth missions the series has ever gotten.

tldr: game barely changed from previous iterations (as usual) and the story is pretty uninteresting.


The Assassin's Creed franchise is known for barely for making any changes into their game, this has been a known thing since AC Brotherhood or Revelation. But the thing that keeps people from coming back in my opinion are the stories. From Ezio's pursuit of the truth and liberation, to Conor's internal conflict regarding his father, to Edward's pirate adventures, to Shay's revenge, to Arno's Romeo and Juliet story. And in syndicate? I have no idea! There's nothing special about it, it's just Jacob Frye fighting the templar and Evie Frye pursuing the pieces of eden, very very bland. To really see how bland the sequences are in Syndicate, in Black flag, in one of the first sequences, you accidentally infiltrated the templar's order and to get the reward they promised you, you have to act as if you are in character, in syndicate, you have to burn omnibuses of the templar order, wow very exciting. 

In terms of game play, the only note worthy thing to talk about is the grappling hook, I mean it's cool and all but it's not like it's the ship in the past games, it's cool but it doesn't really change a lot. I've seen some people complained that the ship mechanics in the past games are gone, I mean in makes sense because the setting doesn't really fit, the themes in the past games can fit a ship mechanic, AC3? Yeah it's at the time of 18th century colonial america, black flag? obviously there's a ship. So what does Syndicate have? it's London industrial revolution, time for some street razor gangs! Now that's something that you can expand on and make something interesting about it, and the game supports the idea, Jacob's out there to make a gang, the rooks! And how significant are they in the game? Barely almost nothing! Other than the open world missions (which are checklist gaming) there's almost no missions in concern about gang related stuff. And if there are, then it's the most uninteresting uninspiring missions out there. I don't really know what to expect in this type of theme, maybe some criminal organization like in other stories like the godfather, peaky blinders perhaps but you know it's london industrial revolution, it's a whole pack of disappointment, that's all there is to know.

I really enjoyed this game, I absolutely love free-flow combat mechanics and once you have the timing down, similar to the Batman Arkham series, you do attain and enter god mode really early on into the game. And altho you can just charge into a pack of 10+ mobs and enter your free flow god mode, once the mobs are alerted you do have to individually beat down each mob quite a lot to kill them, so after a while god mode novelty wears off and i found myself using stealth to get in and out unseen like a real assassin to complete missions. 

FYI, this was my very first play through of an Assassin's Creed game. I know hard core AC fans have their opinions and ideas on how these games should be, but as a first game in the franchise I was impressed. The city is absolutely amazing, it's so rich in detail and graphically it holds up to 2023 standards, the character models do show their age but it's an 8 year old game. I did do a lore catch up on YouTube before tucking in, but tbh, i don't care about the set up and the whole future thing going back into memories etc. I just treated this as a one off title about Jacob and Evie's story, and i was left itching to tuck into another AC game, where i'll probably do the same, paying no attention to future stuff, and just enjoying the story of that game's Assassin.

Amazing steampunk experience. Experience the true feel of ancient London whilst soaring from building to building like Micheal Jordan on steroids this game is one of my favorites of all time and favorite of the assassins creed series. The transitions between the 2 main leads from time to time are very refreshing and the balance and freedom of changing characters ads to the aesthetic. (I also LOVE the 2 main characters.) 

The graphics are amazing on its own and for a game made 8 years ago (2015.) The variety of skills there are to choose from while keeping it easy to get skill points is awesome. Most assassins creed games focus too much on the main story and this game is the most open world in the series. Exploration is really fun with historical sights like big ben and more. On top of that if you choose to main the story even that is super enjoyable since the missions for the story have open-world aspects too. The auto saving mechanics crafting, collecting, weapon variety, armor, resources to collect, and so much more in the game helps you feel like the world is realistic if it weren't for the fact that you can jump from big ben into a box of hay and survive.

The combat in this game is the first time in the series I felt like I wasn't a guy in the center of a circle of enemies just spamming counter. The combat is a mix of hand-to-hand combat with your weapon and gun. The combat is fluid and fun. It is super satisfying to successfully pull off a win against enemies higher leveled than you. Pull of execution in the middle of a fight to then dodge a bullet counter of punch and stab two enemies at the same time is so satisfying. Also, the executions are all so well animated and brutal that I never got bored watching them.

You can freely switch between Jacob and Evie at most points, with side missions and open-world activities open equally to both. Campaign missions, however, are different, with Jacob taking the lead in the majority of the core assassinations. This is frustrating, especially since Evie is pitched as the more stealthy of the pair. But I soon realised that Syndicate is just not that interested in exploring forgotten tombs in search of dusty relics; it wants to liberate the great city of London from its terrible oppressors. And to be blunt, Syndicate‚Äôs a much better experience for identifying more closely with the goals of Jacob.

Most Assassin Creed games have just a copious amount of side missions that clutter the entirety of the map (looking at you AC: Unity) but, this game had fun side quests with colorful historical figures like Charles Dickens and Karl Marx. They were usually silly and lighthearted. And the side quests that weren't all that exciting were easy to run into and complete in under 3 minutes. Plus, as said before it was fun going from mission to mission. Especially crossing the river like a pirate.

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate is the most fun I‚Äôve had with an Assassin‚Äôs game since Black Flag. In fact, I liked it more. Apart from its ill-fitting conclusion, it never takes itself too seriously and delights in the rich possibilities of its Victorian setting and great new grapple gun. As you explore its contrasting boroughs, you glean some sense of what powered this great city in the 19th century. The story missions capitalise on this by exploring different spheres of influence, which when combined with elements like mass transit, heavy industry, and law enforcement, make this feel like a different type of city than has been featured in the series to date. Best of all, Syndicate asks you to take London back in a way puts the last few games to shame.

This game is underrated. Syndicate stands alongside Origins and Black Flag among the best games in the series. Like all open world games, this one reuses a lot of general elements you've seen before (and will see again), but the gameplay is smooth and things are paced nicely. What's here works--and works well. Switching between the two characters was a nice change of pace; although you won't always get to choose which sibling to use. There's plenty to do and see; I found it easy to work my way to the end without the game becoming a chore. The game was fun and it didn't feel like a grind chore. 

At release, this game was met with a collective shrug from the community, but never mind that. It's a good purchase. Not as fun as playing pirate in Black Flag, but nothing ever has been. Origins took the franchise is a new direction, but this one (Syndicate) probably represents the best (and most polished) iteration of the old Assassin's Creed gameplay (with the well worn WB Games Batman-flavored combat and old school parkour).

It's lightning in a bottle. This one just works. Recommended. As of this writing, it's still a decent looking game, as well. Ubisoft got a better handle on their new game engine after the issues with Unity. Syndicate really makes it shine. Don't miss it. Not that the graphics are the main reason to play it; the game is good because it's fun.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a stunning addition to the Assassin's Creed series, and it has completely redefined the gameplay mechanisms that were present in previous titles. As someone who has been away from the series for almost a decade, I can confidently say that Syndicate has brought me back into the fold and hooked me like never before.

One of the most notable changes in Syndicate is the introduction of a dual-protagonist system. Players control both Jacob and Evie Frye, who are twin siblings fighting against the corrupt Templars in Victorian-era London. This new approach not only adds variety to the gameplay but also allows for a more immersive narrative experience. Both characters have their own unique skills and playstyles, and players can switch between them on the fly.

Another significant change is the addition of a grappling hook, which completely alters the way players approach traversal. The grappling hook allows for faster, more fluid movement around the city, and it opens up a whole new world of exploration opportunities. The parkour system has also been refined, making it smoother and more intuitive than ever before.

The combat system in Syndicate is also a departure from previous titles. While the basic mechanics remain largely the same, the addition of more weapons and gadgets, as well as the ability to counter multiple enemies at once, makes combat feel more dynamic and engaging.

One of the things that I appreciate most about Syndicate is the attention to detail in the world-building. Victorian-era London is brought to life in stunning detail, and the city feels alive with activity and bustling crowds. The historical accuracy and attention to detail extend beyond the city itself, with characters based on real-life figures such as Charles Darwin and Charles Dickens.

Overall, Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a fantastic addition to the series and a must-play for fans of the franchise. The changes to the mechanics and the attention to detail make it a standout title, and it's easy to see why it has rekindled my love for the series after so many years away.

In my opinion this is the best new age assassins creed to date. It incorporates the signature free running into the game play with a beautiful city scape to explore. the combat system is simple enough while also fun and diverse. the game boasts a leveling systems which is not overly complicated however are rewarding and adds desirable features passive and active. The story is rich and playful with characters that are vibrant in personality. Over all I describe this as the best modern assassins creed because it captures the original games mechanics and preserves the core concepts of the games while bringing new age features and play styles without selling the original game builds short by creating an open world RPG that has the play style of a game like skyrim IE origins and odyssey. When you care for the core mechanics a franchise originally presents you make it feel like it belong in the series while also bringing it to a new era of gaming and i feel the new games lack this subtlety. I've heard bad things about Ubisoft but my goodness, it only took my 10 minutes to realise it's all true. I got syndicate on sale, installed it pressed play and that's where the problems begun.

A separate launcher Uplay popped up and asked me to make an account. I typed in all my details only for the launcher to tell me account creation isn't available at this time. I did a bit of googling and found it you can get around this by making an account on the Ubisoft website, So that's what i did.

I then re-launched the game and typed in my credentials only to be told there are no ubisoft servers at the moment. I tried a few more times over 10 minutes and still couldn't play. It had the option to play in offline mode, which i clicked only to be stuck on initialising for 10 minutes. I closed the launcher tried again and was stuck again.

Then i went on a google deep dive and found a few tricks to get around this. One was change the launcher to always launch in offline mode but this made the problem worse and now the launcher is stuck in initialising.

I then tried reinstalling the launcher but had the same problems and. Then i totally reinstalled Syndicate and still had the same problems.

I've spent the best part of an hour trying to actually this game i've purchased. I've seen many people have this problem and some haven't been able to play the game for months. Ubisoft support is giving generic automated responses.
Avoid avoid.

VERDICT:
Being a British fellow myself, I found this game very relatable when it came to London itself. Most things were in the right place, with the atmosphere being how I would picture it back in the 1800 (Aside from Assassin's running around). The story didn't live up to some of the other Assassin's Creeds but the gameplay was very smooth and adding my new favourite gimmick (The Zipline) gave it a more fresh approach. 

What I enjoyed the most out of this game would be the voice acting and how the characters reacted to certain things, just walking across the street was entertaining! This is the closest they get to the modern era and i'm very relieved that they stopped it here... in London.
Total Score = 81/100.

GAMEPLAY:
It is the ninth major instalment in the Assassin's Creed series, and the successor to 2014's Assassin's Creed Unity.

The plot follows the premise of the Assassin's Creed franchise, involving a fictional history of real-world events where a secret war has been fought for centuries between two factions: the Brotherhood of Assassins, who promote peace and liberty, and the Templar Order, who desire peace through control. The framing story is set in the 21st century and follows the same unnamed and unseen protagonist from Assassin's Creed Unity, who assists the Assassins in their race against the Templars to find an artefact hidden in London. The main story is set in London in 1868, at the onset of the Second Industrial Revolution, and follows twin Assassins Jacob and Evie Frye as they navigate the corridors of organised crime and take back the city from Templar control.

The game is played from a third-person perspective and its open world is navigated on foot or by carriage. The game introduces new travelling systems and refined combat and stealth mechanics. Players control the two lead protagonists throughout the game's story, switching between them both during and outside of missions

After seeing so many positive reviews, I expected so much better from this game. Syndicate falls short of its predecessors, with dull visuals, and boring gameplay. While the game does have its moments, they are few and far between, and it ultimately fails to capture the imagination of the player.

VISUAL
Set in the sprawling metropolis of London in the Victorian era, the game boasts a beautifully realised city. Despite this, the visual design of the world is ultimately lacklustre. Environments are detailed and historically accurate, but the overall appearance of the city is dull and bland, lacking memorable sights and screenshot-worthy moments. This may be a result of the game's England setting and time period, but was still underwhelming visually and lacked those views that made previous entries into the series so visually striking.


AUDIO
Unfortunately, the soundtrack in the game falls flat, being far less memorable than other games in the series.

The protagonists' dialogue is also one of the weakest and most boring aspects of the game. The main characters' conversations are often tedious and uninspired, making it difficult for players to connect with them on an emotional level. Moreover, the game makes the mistake of repeating the same generic dialogue far too often, which can quickly become irritating and repetitive.

GAMEPLAY
The gameplay is some of the most boring in the series, failing to offer anything new or exciting to keep players engaged. The game's story feels rushed and disconnected, introducing characters and relationships out of nowhere, and dropping them just as quickly.

Syndicate has very few memorable missions, with the only real standout moments occurring in the last two sequences. None of this is helped by one of the protagonists, Jacob, being a one-dimensional character with poor dialogue. They've tried to make the character funny, but his humour often falls flat, making it difficult to connect with the character on any level. Evie was far more enjoyable to play as and connect with but still doesn't compare to leads in past games.

Navigating the streets of London is a chore, with wide streets and clunky parkour mechanics making it slow and uninteresting to move through the game world. The grappling hook, which seems like an afterthought, is often required to navigate the environment quickly, but it doesn't feel like a well-thought-out mechanic that does little to make traversal enjoyable.

Combat is average at best, and it fails to introduce anything that would make it feel fresh or exciting. Carriage riding/combat is also a major problem, as it is often required to travel quickly across the game world, but the mechanics are so poorly implemented that it can become frustrating and unenjoyable.

After all, is said and done, the game's conclusion doesn't do enough to tip the scale. The ending is rather disappointing, failing to offer the satisfying conclusion that players might expect after investing so much time and effort into the game.


POOR PACING
The pacing of the game is uneven, with long stretches of tedious gameplay and poorly executed storylines that leave players feeling unfulfilled. The game's world is not engaging enough to keep players interested for long periods of time, and many of the missions are uninspired and repetitive.

The story is also a major issue, as it feels rushed and disconnected, with characters being introduced and dropped without much explanation or development. As a result, it's hard to become invested in the story or the characters, and it's difficult to find the motivation to push through and greatly overstayed its welcome for me.

CONCLUSION
With all the previous points in mind, I can't say I had much fun playing through the game and the most satisfying part of reaching the conclusion is that it was over. This is a game that even die-hard fans could probably skip without missing much. While the game has its moments, they are few and far between. Overall, this makes the game an unworthy addition to the series and one I will not be returning to.

I honestly don‚Äôt get the hate people give this game, in my opinion it‚Äôs the best game is the series by far. 
The stealth is a huge step up from previous games that improves drastically from previous games in many different ways.
The parkour is similar to unity in regards to its freeing movement, however it sacrifices the dedicated jump button and a slight bit of vertical movement in return for fixing a large multitude of transition/animation bugs.
The combat, while nothing truly amazing, is fully functional 100% of the time, which is a huge step up from unity. The multi kill animations are also pretty fun and they reward you for setting up multiple enemies for finishers while thinking about your next move.
The map design is great, having a great deal of variety, while at the same time focusing on and complementing the new stealth systems, along with the new grappling hook mechanic (although the grappling hook can invalidate the parkour in many areas, it‚Äôs not required for you to use and it spices up stealth/parkour gameplay when combined with arial assassinations.)
There‚Äôs a lot of side activities that fill up the world as well, which is a nice change of pace when compared to many other Ubisoft games where the world is almost completely barren.
The setting is another great aspect that they take full advantage of, having many missions related to Victorian English folklore that was commonplace during the Industrial Revolution. 
Overall I‚Äôd give this game a solid 9/10, it‚Äôs nearly perfect, with the only thing I really have any complaints about being the story. Starrick is a very stereotypical antagonist that wasn‚Äôt fleshed out at all until the last few missions, if they gave him that kind of personality throughout the whole game, the story would be much more compelling.

I feel like AC Syndicate is an abundantly AVERAGE Assassin's Creed game, with abundantly average characters & an abundantly average story. It's not bad, but not great. It has all the fun, classic "Assassin's Creed" type gameplay you'd expect, but not much really sticks out in this entry of the series here either.

What is outstanding though is Ubisoft's depiction of late 1800's London in the Industrial Revolution. Ubisoft has always done well in this regard to mastercrafted, historically accurate locations, but this one was one of my all-time favorite cities they have ever produced. Also must say, the traveling Train Headquarters is one of the coolest HQs/Bases in the franchise.

The game is worth it alone just for the "Virtual Tourism" experience of exploring around, walking the city & soaking in the atmosphere.
only buy this if you're looking for some superhero dumb fun. stealth is not good (very cheese able), combat is ridiculous and lacks depth, story is whatever

While I can't say it's my favourite Assassin's Creed game, I'd put it somewhere near the top. I really like the setting, which is London in the 19th century, was recreated very believably, being very smoky and fumy everywhere, extremely dirty and filthy and most essentially, poor. At least, that is how most of the places look like. However, there is a rich few, ruling the city and taking advantage of the poor - Crawford Starrick and his comrades. And I won't lie, the villain is pretty damn epic, and very satisfying to fight against. What is worth noting, it is the only AC in which you can actually ride a train. That being said, I can recommend this game with a clear conscience.

I think that ACS is the last game where the feel of the AC franchise is still there. Without compromising its true nature in Assassins Creed, Syndicate is able to deliver a new form of AC while still remaining true to the franchise. It offers new skills, characters and gadgets to explore Victorian London, England and is a top 5 game for myself as it even offers SOME replayability.

Definitely one of the stronger games in the series. It felt like an amazing breath of fresh air when I played it. I really liked the hookshot that helps you climb faster. For me, as I get farther and farther into the series, I get more and more impatient when it comes to climbing the walls. While the parkour/climbing isn't perfect in this game, I felt like they hit the nail on the head. It feels pretty smooth for the most part.

I really like the Skill tree in this game. In Unity, they took away basic gameplay mechanics from previous games, but in Syndicate they actually added to it this time and kept the same core mechanics from previous games. Also really liked the gang upgrades too.

The side quests felt important when playing them. While most, if not all, of the side quests weren't important plot wise, there was a sense of importance when you're either making more of London "less red" on the map to get more territory for your gang or talking to an important historical figure.

The story was pretty solid. Unlike Unity and Rogue, it felt like there was a sense of purpose when doing every mission when all of the templar leaders are laid out in front of you in the pause menu. It was interesting getting to know the enemy and your two protagonists as you journeyed through the main story. I also really liked the ending. While it seemed weird for the story, the final cutscene felt just right for an ending. Also the story for the Jack the Ripper DLC was fun.

My couple of gripes is that I wish Ubisoft polished the game a little better. Lots of glitches, especially in the Jack the Ripper DLC; however, the game is playable. Only other gripe is that on the box art. Evie deserves better.

If you are thinking about buying it, I would say it's worth getting.

Syndicate is great. Not perfect, not the best game since AC 2 and AC Black Flag, but pretty awesome. The city is huge, detailed and beautiful. There are many activities performed by the NPCs that I found nice such as B. Playing cricket in the park. The main characters are charming and make a good duo. I enjoyed playing with Evie Frye, who I grew to love as well. The gameplay is basically the same as always. Something has stayed the same, something has been added and become interesting.
When I first saw the rope I thought the all too beloved parkour was going to be destroyed but 5 minutes later found myself happily swinging back and forth on the whole thing along the parkour course.
The story quality isn't the best, but I enjoyed it. A step back from epic battles and world-shattering revolutions felt good. The game looks great too, just as good as Unity but a bit more optimized this time.

I think it was worth it and I recommend it. In addition to Evie, you can also play Jacob and thus have 2 assassins to choose from.

Out of the Multiple Games in the AC series ... Black Flag is my favourite, very closely followed by Syndicate, then Origins. Definatly buy this one if you are an AC fan. The character Movement has once again Encapsulated in what this game was supposed to be about!

Immersive city-scapes , Victorian era London, the industrial revolution, and a charming pair of protagonists make this game a definite must try.
The common gripes for this game usually come in the form of the contrasting environment and storyline/characters. The drab, polluted skylines of London during the industrial revolution set a darker mood than the characters seem to be in. But I am of the opinion that this very contrast serves to bring a sense of balance that makes the player want to explore every nook and cranny of this city.
If every aspect of this game was set to a dark tone, I doubt it would have been able to draw as much play-time and more specifically exploration time out of its players. The characters being witty, some missions that are more light hearted, give more depth to the game's atmosphere highlighting both the grim and the gleeful.

Overall, this game should definitely be tried once for both regular gamers as well as fans of the Assassin's Creed franchise.

Coming after the highly enjoyable AC Odyssey, I had my expectations high. Suffice to say that they were shattered. And now that I have played ACII and Brotherhood, I can see the overall drop in quality for the franchise. Watching paint dry is a more interesting prospect. Combat is weak and uninsipiring, and the game has a lot grinding for levels, money and xp. The map is monotonous and boring, being grim and filled with bricky industry and row-houses, but maybe that's because that London was during the time period. The main storyline has excessive cutscenes and rail-roaded content, and suffers from genericness and lack of memorability. It feels like a weak imitation of much better games and stories.

Still, the model of Victorian London is well-executed, and racing the streets around with horse carriages is the most fun aspect of the game. Overall, I found the side activities and exploration much more fun than the actual storyline. Beneath the surface, you have a great walking simulator of Victorian London, you just need to bear with the story and gameplay to get there and unlock all districts, meh. Wish there was a Discovery mode for London, so one could explore without being bothered by boring enemies. And for once I love hearing voice actors speaking with a proper posh British accent instead of a forced foreign accent that nobody speaks like in reality. But that's about it. On top of that, the game crashes a lot.

And the modern day storyline - oh boy, if one can even speak of it, so brief it is - is entirely made of scripted cutscenes and is probably the weakest in the whole series. The game would probably suffer no consequences if it was left out entirely.
One of my favorite Assassin's Creed titles. Can't wait for the newest game to come back to the roots which made this franchise so great!

Played this on Xbox a few years ago when they released it for free with Live Gold, played it again, this time completing every side quest in both the main story and DLC. It's one of the most enjoyable Assassin's Creed games I've played. From the graphics being really very good, to being able to summon a whole squad car of gang members to attack anyone you want, the game feels almost like industrial-era GTA in ways. I found the story to be very good, along with all the post main campaign content that was free to play. The bugs that were existent when the game came out seem to not be all there anymore. I came across a couple bugs here and there, but nowhere near breaking gameplay. If it's on sale, definitely snag the Gold Edition, it really is worth it.

So this is the last "Real" AC game before the RPG series
Every AC game thus far has  different mechanics and gameplay style and the one thing that is constant is the linear storyline which i dont mind

Story 7/10 - The storyline is decent as usual , Evie & Jacob lacks depth yes , but dont mind it at all as both of the characters has different motivations and has its own mini subplot. it's entertaining enough. Side mission story is a good improvement as well , worth playing.

Gameplay 9/10 - AGAIN changed with every AC game and I dont mind. Great Improvement on combat albeit simple mechanics. Plenty of upgrades as well as crafting to change approach for each mission , the variation is satisfying. Although the combat is cool , every hit lacks a bit of "weight" with each hit. Weapons is 10/10.

The zipline gun is intentional added I think due to the size of the City and industrial settings , making it easier and smoother  to navigate with the building bit batman like unlike Paris which is very condense and close .

The parkour is also different , I think they want you navigate every movement intentionally if you want a smooth free run instead of just pressing one button and the free run is just automatic, I make less movement error compared to other AC games because of it and i welcome it.

All in all i give it 8/10

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a fantastic addition to the Assassin's Creed franchise. The game takes place in 19th century London during the Industrial Revolution and the setting is brought to life in stunning detail. The gameplay is smooth and the new rope launcher adds a new level of verticality to the series. The story is well-written and the characters are likable and well-developed. The new twin assassins, Jacob and Evie Frye, are a refreshing change of pace and their different skill sets add depth to the gameplay. Overall, Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike. It is a true masterpiece of open-world action-adventure gaming.

This one is going to be hit or miss for even regulars to the AC series. Once again another AC game in the franchise that reinvented things that didn't need reinventing. Combat gets changed up again from its predecessor Unity, which was changed up from its predecessor Black Flag. Combat in Syndicate really tries to imitate the Batman Arkham games, working out all the combatants in the room and valuing chained attacks and perfect freeflow. Combine that with more grinding elements, more leveling needed to stand a chance in certain places, and stockpiling resources to get better stuff make this game a chore at times. That said, its not without its positives. I found most of the missions enjoyable, and the addition of kidnapping people to sneak on into places really seems unique. Gunplay is a bit wilder especially when playing Jacob, which brings me to the other plus; having more than one character to play. Some mission will require you to play one or the other, though there are a number of things you can do as either one which have some variation in their endgame skills. Nothing outstandingly bad in terms of glitches or stability like Unity, which is definitely a plus too...though its a low hanging bar to hop over.

If you appreciated games more like ACII and are not in the market for a grindy change up, pass on this title. If you're ok with grinding, and are willing to try an AC game that changes mechanics up a bit then go right ahead. I personally liked the Jack the Ripper dlc, thought it was short lived.

It's a fun game to play.

The best AC game after black flag. Loved it so much it runs with perfectly good performance as well.
It is a solid game with immersive graphic and fast paced combat in AC series. Buy it on sale if you like steampunk and open world settings.

The first missions try to accomplish what that rest of the game does not achieve - throwing you in an industrial london with a unique experience and environments. Graphics are nice, atmosphere fits, new grapling gun is fun, but also destroys the climbing and exploration of buildings, especially the admiration while climbing. Less of the missions feel unique while in the middle of the game you feel like a whole grindfest and most interiors of buildings can be fully explored, but the rooms feel empty and same in regards of gameplay. Its still buggy and 3 weapon types and 4 enemy types don't feel interesting. Storycharacters don't feel interesting which leads to a stale experience.

Syndicate gets too much flak for what it does, having been treated as the black sheep before Odyssey, Syndicate is good.
London is one of the best worlds in the series in terms of authenticity, standing alongside Egypt and Paris but arguably is better for having lively npcs, playing cricket and other activities. Side activities such as carriage racing, boxing rings and gang wars help you get into the setting well. The Frye twins do entertain but had much more potential, you really only get one mission where the game fleshes out the co-operative aspect which is a shame. 
Story's tone is the opposite from Unity so don't expect it to be serious (Jack the Ripper dlc has a tone more up Unity's street if you fancy that) and movement has been made worse also which will make you rely more on the grappling then free running. 
This game is entertaining despite its flaws, only really getting blasted on release due to fatigue over the AC series. Play this instead of going to London yourself, you'll see the sights while playing AC Peaky Blinders

Despite my recent policy to give a thumbs down to all Ubisoft games due to their decision to discontinue services for older titles, effectively penalizing paying customers, with no refunds issued....this one is an exception. 
It is literally what the entire franchise has been needing for a long time. A lot of the systems have been reworked and all of them have moved in the right direction. I cannot believe I am saying this, but it is so well done that I very much doubted it was made by Ubisoft.

To address a few of the improvements:
- The interface is a lot smoother and more intuitive. Data, missions etc. are categorized in a more streamlined way so there's no excessive clicking on a slowed down menu anymore. 
- The parkour engine has been tweaked, and after the abomination that was "Unity" this one feels so responsive and light that it never ends up being frustrting. Which I don't think I've felt since the days of Ezio.
- The combat system has been completely revamped. No more sluggish drawn out fancy finishing moves while many other enemies circle you, mouths wide agape in bewilderment as to why their coders were stupid enough not to allow them to attack in the meantime...It feels faster. Almost jittery at first but you get used to it very quickly and it is actually as skilled based as an engine like this allows. 
- The world has been balanced very well. It is a bit grindy but nothing that feels like a chore. There are skill and gang upgrades and all have a noticeable effect on the world and your experience in it. The new addition of the "batman hook" is absolutely brilliant, super well coded and I believe a staple of the series going forward. Whomever came up with that needs a raise. 
- The quest objectives are actually enjoyable and almost never recycled. Gone are the days of the tedious "don't get seen or you have to retstart the mission you pleb", these ones are actually good and they make sense in the context of each respective mission, allowing for plenty of approaches depending on the player's preference. 
- The coding - again, it's like the game was outsourced to another, far more capable studio (yes I don't have the highest regard for Ubisoft, given their last I dont know how many miserable attempts to produce games), but this one is both refreshingly stable and light on the system. No lag, no crashes, no glitches, you could actually allow yourself to get immersed in the game for hour without interruption. 
- The story and the characters are....excellent. The dynamic between the Frye twins is quirky, yet endearing. Each have their own personality, which plays a role in the plot. Compared to the absolute travesty that was Liberation for example, these characters feel like they are coherent and complete personas with their own agency in a world of similar personalities. There is a bit of completely misplaced feministy rants such as Evie chastizing the QUEEN OF ENGLAND for her imperialist ways and getting cake in return, but they are few enough not to induce anything other than a mild eye roll. There is plenty of proper british humor involved, for better or worse, but it really helps the setting. 

Honestly, after Liberation, Rogue and Unity, going into this one I was almost dreading to see what they woul mess up this time but...they didn't. In fact this installment restored my faith in Ubisoft's ability to produce a well-made game (to some degree, anyway). I am giving this a surprised thumbs up. It is right up there with Brotherhood and Black Flag, and while it is not on their level in terms of storytelling and atmosphere, I daresay it runs smoother as far as gameplay. Definitely a must play.

Playing for the first time in 2022 as part of catching up on the AC series.  I've gotta' say that although this game is reasonably well-polished and bug-free, as I approach the final acts of the game it's increasingly feeling like a slog.

I usually get involved in a lot of side-quests when I play OW games but in Syndicate I'm just getting bored of them.  That's doubled-up by the fact that the rewards are all kind of pointless anyway, if you build up the economy-related skills early in the game (as I did).  My character is awash with resources and I've already got endgame-quality gear & abilities, so there's nothing left to gain.  I'm finding myself wanting to get the main story done with now so I can mark this game as "Done" and move on to something different.

I'd classify this as a barely-positive review.  I'll see the game through to the end, but for an AC game this one is decidedly average.  Not bad like AC3 was, and a little better than Rogue.  Still not a patch on AC2 or Brotherhood though.  I'm certainly not interested in buying any DLC.
Very underrated. Worth the time. The side missions are worth it

Compared to [i]Unity[/i], [i]Syndicate[/i] has a slightly better story, but it doesn't look as good. One of the most underwhelming aspects of the game is the city of London. In the past, the streets and alleys were full of different buildings to climb and parkour through, but in [i]Syndicate[/i], the streets are wide and the buildings are too tall and sometimes boring to climb, so they introduce a grappling hook instead. The parkour doesn't feel like parkour, but more like using hooks to get to the top of buildings. Additionally, the city is too foggy and muddy to be beautiful, which may be true to life, but it detracts from the overall aesthetic of the game.

7/10
I would say this AC game was one of the best, lot's of gameplay is offered. The story wasn't the best but was up there, and the gameplay mechanics are the best so far. The skills tree with other upgrades was great, but not many outfits to choose from such as Unity had. The Jack the Ripper DLC was unique adding to the story after the main game. If you ever wanted to feel how it is to be a serial killer this DLC is for you. Syndicate was defiantly worth picking up even if you haven't played the previous AC games. This game had a little of the current time events going on, but it still has a little info if you wanted to know.
