Honestly, this game has more bugs than Unity which is impressive to be honest.

I came straight from Unity and they have same problem but worse.
The story is really not strong and the main villain equally underwhelming.
From Sequence 1-8 we only hear the main villain might from mouth to mouth but we never see what he capable of and I don't know why he keep monologue to himself in the office as if it is what make a strong and fierce villain which is not.

The story flow is also another problem. Since we play both twins, we can choose which twins we going to do first but because of that the story end up all over the place.
This what make mid part of the game seems extremely boring.
Also we can do Character Side Quest way over than what we should have and create a weird connection with the main story.

I welcome "Rope Launcher" mechanic, it's fun and easy to go place to place...
BUT
This also a major problem because the parkour centered around "Rope Launcher" and they restricted the Climb Up, Down and Jump. 
- You can't no longer to jump from roof to roof if the range are slightly long even if in the previous game you can just jump but in here, the character will force looking down/parkour down/use Rope Launcher
- You can't drop down from roof like previous game
Basically the parkour become so static and didn't flow well.

BUGS! I experience quest break and stuck in cutscene because a major character died on Horse Carriage.
This happen a lot and mostly because Horse Carriage really buggy and sensitive. There are so many times Horse Carriage just launch to the sky and smash to the wall randomly.
I also experience stuck in Black Loading Screen but I able to move my character during the quest.
I never encounter game breaking bugs or a crash in Unity which is weird to be honest.

Get this on Discount.

A little late for a review but wth. Decent AC game. Not my favorite one. This is the newest one I've played as I'm years behind on AC games. You can skip this AC if you want. I don't feel like I learned any new information from it, as the main story with the Precursors interest me. I feel like I should have skipped this one and went straight to Origins from Black Flag. It was a decent game, just didn't hold my interest and I found myself pushing to complete it.

<<THE BAD>> I found the main story a little bland. I felt this AC was a bit rushed. The game has a real GTA element to it. You run around London stealing carriages and taking over territories. The game play felt bland and very repetitive. But, I'm years behind on these games and I skipped over AC Rogue and Unity. Sorry, French history doesn't interest me. But neither does English history, so it may be why I find the entire game bland. The ending of this game is underwhelming. The game has some bugs. The most annoying one is the music box tune that plays every single time you load into a new area or fast travel. You have to collect all the darn music boxes to make it stop. I did not... X'O

<<THE GOOD>> Jacob and Evie Fry, the main characters, are really interesting. I liked both of them and found myself playing Evie the most due to I like stealth play and Jacob felt more like a wrecking ball. This is honestly the only reason I kept playing this game, as I have my eye set on playing Origins next. The last AC game I played before this one is Black Flag, which I thought was a great game.

(Note: I played a lot more than the 10 hours Steam says I've played; finished the story and DLC's, too.)
This had potential, but I ultimately found it uninspired, and, thus, uninteresting. I've played every AC game to this point except Unity, including Liberation, and I like all of them a lot more than this one. This one looks pretty good, some of the new weapons are cool, the real-world characters held promise, but I felt it was all poorly/lazily executed in the end. Playing as a Templar in Rogue was a hard pill to swallow at first, but at least they had the story, gameplay, open world and execution to win me over in the end. To the main characters in Syndicate, everything is a joke or a duty; neither character made me give shit about them or their mission for even a second. Real world characters were little more than NPC-type quest givers or people you had to follow slowly around while they prattle on about meaningless shit. And, boy-oh-boy, I sure hope you like slow paced detective work that amounts to using superhuman vision to walk around slowly gathering the little bright-light clues, because there's a lot of that. Plus, like so many games from these years, the incessant, stupid fucking rain and all the noise that comes with it... just: fuck you. What pisses me off the most, though, is that after all these years of basically keeping the same on-foot combat controls, they suddenly decided to change them... WTF!? For what? They didn't improve it; they just changed it? For fucking what? Nah; I'm out.

I have played 100% of the game activities and missions as well as those in both DLCs, although I did not collect all of the collectibles (I could not be bothered with the shards and normal material chests; I did get all the normal chests in the base game but not the dlcs). After playing all of that content, I'm happy to say Syndicate is one of my favorite Assassin's Creed titles; it's probably sitting at number 2 or 3. Victorian London is a pretty great setting, and although once again the Assassins are basically just domestic terrorists destabilizing the existing regime, the twins are entertaining characters. I will note that most of the game's notable missions force you to play as Jacob, the male (and more stupid) character. The game does lean into this by having the characters canonically make mistakes but if you prefer a specific character know that you will have to play both.

This game adds a couple new mechanics; we get the zipline feature which makes traversal much simpler, new assassination mission structure which appears to have taken inspiration from Hitman, an investigation mechanic introduced in the Last Maharajah DLC, and fear mechanics in the Jack the Ripper DLC. None of these mechanics are really used to their full potential or significantly developed, although their inclusion is appreciated. Rooftop carriage combat may also be new, but having skipped Unity I'm not confident in making that assertion. The game does see a reduction in scope from previous titles, being limited to two maps; London and World War I London. Jack the Ripper has its own version of 2 London Boroughs and 3 unique mission areas as well. The soundtrack uses a lot of public domain pieces but the performances are excellent and the soundtrack was a real high point in my experience. The game also features a skill and leveling system; the leap from this to Origins was a lot smaller than I expected.

Most of the side missions are pretty bad, although the activities were decent fun and had a good amount of variety. Historical characters are usually portrayed in a disingenuously positive light, and have no real reason to be involved, but this isn't exactly anything new for the series. The exception to this is the Last Maharajah DLC which adds a 10 mission side quest line which is completable either as postgame content or alongside the base game; these missions were varied and interesting. Lots of reviews mention the bugs but I only encountered one bug, which did unfortunately force me to reboot the game. World War I and Jack the Ripper have their own side activities which add some additional variety. For World War I, you control Jacob's granddaughter Lydia and have a fixed level and toolkit. Jack the Ripper presents a similar situation, with all characters having either fixed or limited level ranges and toolkits. Jack the Ripper is actually a completely separate executable with its own progression; selecting it from the main menu just backs you out and loads the other executable.

Overall, I really liked the Last Maharajah and all of the assassination missions in both the base game and the dlcs; the Hitman inspiration did a lot to add replayability to the game and make those missions feel more engaging. Jack the Ripper, despite its high production values and added mechanics, I could take or leave. The plot of the base game isn't anything special but Jack the Ripper's plot is very trite and the mechanics just aren't developed enough to make them interesting. The wonderful soundtrack and multiple traversal options take a lot of the sting out of traversing the open world; I found myself avoiding fast travel and hoofing it instead. I think the game and the Last Maharajah are definitely worth a playthrough (buy the Last Maharajah and play it in tandem with the base game), but only buy Jack the Ripper if you still want more when you're done.

Addendum: I didn't realize when I initially wrote my review that there was another DLC not included in the Season Pass called Dreadful Crimes which is another 10 mission questline. It's entirely investigation missions. The missions themselves are pretty simple but enjoyable, with no combat. It's an interesting diversion and uses the same investigation mechanic from the last maharaja but with an included notes log.

AC Syndicate's biggest strong point is its setting. Victorian London is a wonderful setting for the franchise ranging from the dirty grime covered alleys of Whitechapel to the beautiful gardens of Buckingham Palace. Gameplay is more advanced than the simple "counter-kill" era games, but still enjoyable enough.

The weakest point of the game is by far the Templar antagonists. They are rarely intimidating, have little to no character depth, and most don't get enough screen time to amount to much more than murder fodder.

The dual protagonist approach will either be love or hate. To me it is simply disappointing. The potential was there for it to be so much more, using two characters to coordinate on the same mission and allowing the player to jump to those different perspectives seems like an obvious choice as is the case in GTA V. However the only time this happens is the very first and very last missions of the game. In any other mission you simply pick (or are forced to play) a specific Frye twin and the other will appear in intro and end cutscenes despite being absent in the actual mission.

It should also be noted that the screen time is pushed heavily in favor of Jacob so if you prefer Evie I have bad news. (Until Jack the Ripper, where she stars as the main playable character)

All in all I think an 8/10 is fair. It's a good entry in the series but by no means a masterpiece in gaming at large.

This game has to be the only Assassin's Creed¬Æ that I enjoyed playing to be honest. The best thing about this game is obviously the setting, running around the aesthetic city of London in 1868 for me was an unreal experience. Just walking around the city at night time when all the street lamps litted up is a beautiful sight to see, the game also come with dynamic weather system and transactions between days and nights ‚Äì you can clearly see the changes with the NPC‚Äôs behavior. All the core gameplay mechanics of this game is kind of identical to Assassin's Creed Unity but just smoother, easier and felt really good when controlling your character compare to ACU which was very slow paced. Finding chests actually have meaning now because it now also gave you crafting materials to crafts weapons and upgrades, you get better weapons and upgrades from increasing loyalty levels with your allies by completing quests and activities which sometimes very repetitive hence AC games‚Ä¶ But stealth sequences in this game is pretty much throwing knifes/smoke bombs spam and maybe berserk darts once in a while!? Plan B combat are now free-flow-like Batman Arkham Series but just dumber‚Ä¶ I recommend to avoid fighting enemies face to face because it was so boring‚Ä¶ The story is not really memorable, just some powerful bad dude wanted to take over everything and you just have to messed up his all his plans then take him out of the picture that all no twists and turns. The only thing I hate about this game is the Perks Progression System - it was a horrific experience for me to unlock all of them because some of the requirements is very misleading (The Countershot Perk want you to Countershot 2 ranged attacks in under 10 seconds but you not gonna get counted when fighting MOST of the enemies in the game because its only get counted when you counter shots from the Royal Guards and NOBODY TOLD YOU THAT!). This is an old game so as usual, ONLY BUY IT WHEN IT ON SALE! Buy the Season Pass if you could afford it ‚Äì it‚Äôs very good value.

8/10 - Great Game
Pros (+):
  The game has a really great map and atmosphere.
  They clearly did some research on the victorian era, and on the specific time period/decade, and you can feel it and immerse your self on it.
  The graphics look great. If you want a sunnier and prettier world, search for the graphic's guide on steam, where they tell you how to take out the fog.
  The music, even though pretty simple, is probably one of my favorite OSTs on the franchise.
  Awesome sound effects.
  If you liked Assassin's Creed Odyssey and it's story, this can be your game, since the game is full of jokes and silly moments, mostly done by Jacob.
  Because of the Grappling Hook, stealth and assassinations feel really good, making you feel like some sort of mix between Assassin and Spider Man.
  Even though it's a simplified version of Assassin's Creed Unity, the parkour is still one of the best in the series, being the second best parkour system of the franchise for me.
  Like most Ubisoft Games, the map has lots of points of interest and items to collect, but I never felt too overwhelmed. It's certainly not on the level of Assassin's Creed Odyssey's (god forbid) or Assassin's Creed 2's feathers BY FAR.
  The game's story isn't that long, meaning you can finish it in less than 40/50H, unless you decide to go for the markers, then it can take 80 something hours.. If you are a completionist like me, and you want all the achievements, perks and 100% on everything, it took me 119H for the whole game (DLCs included), but I know it can be done in way less time.
  Compared to Unity, there aren't that many bugs. The only big bugs only happened to me after the 80H mark.
  The Dreadful Crimes DLC is probably one of the best DLCs I've ever played on any videogame in general. It is definitely a must have if you want to play this game.
  The Jack the Ripper DLC is also really good, introducing new game mechanics that are enjoyable while being a fairly short DLC.

Cons (-):
  The story lacks a serious tone and the villains are horribly written (with the exception of Jack the Ripper which is awesome and badass).
  The story can feel a bit random sometimes.
  Not that many memorable moments.
  Even though the Dreadful Crimes DLC is awesome, the game doesn't allow you to replay them. You will have to start a new game from scratch to replay the missions.
  Even though you have historical characters, like all Assassin's Creed games, they never felt too important, sometimes feeling really weird and wacky.
  Most of the cutscenes are a bit meh or straight up bad, specially on the Jack the Ripper DLC, where the cutscenes are literally broken.
  Voice acting could have been better, but the voices of Evie and Jacob are top tier.
  Lots of re-used animations for non-cutscene dialogues. Some feel dumb or exagerated.
  Some missions can feel a bit repetitive, but overall fun.
  Combat is trash, no questions asked. The finishers are really good though, and I suggest switching weapons from time to time.
  The perks and achievements are definitely not worth grinding or collecting, so don't lose you brain over them. If you do, I suggest you want watch/read some guides.
  It was never my thing, but there's no modern day content. There are cutscenes and a "story", but it sucks so much you might as well forget it ever happened.

Bonus stuff:
  You won't do much parkour because of the map layout, but that's part of the era the game is set in, so I can't consider this neither a pro or a con.
  Evie is waifu material.
  Jacob is comical chad.

+ absolutely gorgeous, like its predecessor, and crafted with an extreme eye to detail
+ the grappling hook makes getting around so much easier, although it too starts feeling like a bore very quickly
+ dual protagonists, charismatic this time around, especially Jacob
+ the fighting system is different from Unity, more brawling-oriented; it's just fine, nothing special occasionally even enjoyable
+ you can ride and hijack carriages
+ wear a top hat, pull down hood when necessary
+ your base is a moving train, and your Assassin liaison is Arbaaz Mir's son
+ finally reasonable secondary mission challenges (most of them)
+ meet Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, Queen Victoria, Benjamin Disraeli, Arthur Conan Doyle, Florence Nightingale, Winston Churchill etc.
+ there is a part where you play Jacob's granddaughter in a WWI-torn London which looks amazing
+ the Jack the Ripper and Dreadful Crimes DLCs are truly awesome if you discount the bugs

- collectibles, again, so many collectibles
- the collectible maps are locked behind a paywall (you get some currency but I was only able to get one)
- crafting is stupid, the order in which you get equipment has barely any linearity, and crafting blueprints are hidden around the map
- bugs everywhere: moving bugs, driving bugs, climbing bugs, mission start bugs, mission end bugs, combat bugs, dropping through the floor bugs, crashes as well
- the Jack the Ripper DLC was especially bug-riddled, I could barely finish any side mission because as soon as I initiated the final conversation, I would explode, or the carriage I'm driving would fly to the Moon or some shit like that
- game's mostly brown and grey, but that's London for you
- the final boss fight is beyond stupid, every single part of it

What a brilliant game Syndicate is. The grappling hook breathes a bit of fresh air in the old formula. The weapons (canes, kukri, and brass knuckles) are awesome, as is meeting so many cool people from history and getting a glimpse of Victorian and WWI-era London. However, what is most assuredly not awesome is collecting a bunch of damn collectibles, failing to do a side challenge because the game did not inform you of it, and fighting the control scheme more than actual enemies. That last one might have been my fault as I tried playing this one on mouse and keyboard.
All in all, we were given a fine AC game once again, before Ubisoft Ubisofted all over it.

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate is the most fun I‚Äôve had with an Assassin‚Äôs game since Black Flag. In fact, I liked it more. Apart from its ill-fitting conclusion, it never takes itself too seriously and delights in the rich possibilities of its Victorian setting and great new grapple gun. As you explore its contrasting boroughs, you glean some sense of what powered this great city in the 19th century. The story missions capitalise on this by exploring different spheres of influence, which when combined with elements like mass transit, heavy industry, and law enforcement, make this feel like a different type of city than has been featured in the series to date. Best of all, Syndicate asks you to take London back in a way puts the last few games to shame.

I'll be honest this is far from the worst assassins creed. In fact the layla trilogy is so bad it makes this game feel like a kenway saga title even a ezio trilogy game despite how far from the truth that is. This is the last AC worth your time and money. (Perhaps mirage can change that) That being said it is flawed as shit. There is too much repetitive side content that often you do have to do in order to level your character enough in order to stand a chance against the enemies as it is a leveled based game and not a skill game. 
          On top of that you do want to it because the best gear in the game is locked behind these loyalty levels. At least youll get most of the stuff from city takeover but things like the best gun or the best cane sword is locked behind extremely tedious missions that most people arent going to do enough of in order to max out (Ned and Robert).
       Performance is debatable. While I am able to run the game on 4k ultra 60 fps with no real issues the temperatures do get pretty hot despite this game's age and graphical fidelity. I have also been getting lots of crashing that has no real tell. Some days ill get a few crashes. Other days ill crash every 20 minutes no consistency YMMV.
       The gameplay loop is not bad but becomes extremely stale on replays as it basically uses a similar loop to ghost recon wildlands a terrible ass title. The parkour is a bit weird as it looks like they were trying to keep the unity formula but made it even more sticky (kinda like the kenway games with the magnetism) so its not exactly the best but it is workable and you do have the grappel hook to help you minimize and do some decent assassinations. Combat isn amazing considering how long it takes to drop someone and its always not responsive but once you are maxed out its somewhat fun and bearable. Stealth is interesting like the combat it improves over unity in every single aspect ( not saying much tbh ) but it has some issues. 
         While stealth is now much more viable especially for Evie there are some serious issues. Like a guard triggering an alert despite the meter not being full but at least if you kill them fast enough you can sometimes prevent everyone from detection. You can also now headshot with throwing knifes which is a honest Godsend. 
     The story is far from amazing but its actually decent and much better paced than unity. This game does a lot of callbacks to the original AC that were stripped from unity and it honestly gives some good brownie points to this title. Jacob and Evie are both really fun and interesting protags that are essential foils to each other and have great charisma with the rest of the cast. Evie is easily the best female protag in the series ( Also quite possibly the most attractive character in the franchise) and is actually her own character unlike what they did with odyssey and valhalla.
         Crawford Starrick is like a superior Cesare Borgia they are both very similar in they way they act and operate but he at least is a true templar as he seeks control for the templar ideal unlike Cesare who was just power hungry like his father. He is very intimidating and its honestly fun to see his reaction to whatever the hell Jacob or Evie just did to undermine another piece of his operation. The boss fight was actually pretty cool too unlike the previous title. 
        This game basically took all the new ideas unity produced and refined them enough to be tolerated or enjoyed to some extent. It is certainly worth a run if you are a fan of the series just make sure to buy on a heavy sale and to go to for the gold edition if its cheap enough as the jack the ripper dlc is pretty interesting.
       Also put Evie in Elise's outfit and go for a parkour run you'll thank me later ( Õ°¬∞ Õú ñ Õ°¬∞)

One of the better games in the AC series, before they became over-bloated and repetitive...Well, Origins was good but I never did complete Odyssey or Valhalla because doing the same thing over and over again to complete certain chains just became boring. You might feel inspired enough to actually complete this particular iteration.
This one has a decent but not too convoluted storyline, in the wonderful setting of Victorian London, innit? Smacking people around is simple to get to grips with, maybe too easy for some, but the stealthing is where this game's strength lies.  Oh how I miss planning my stealth activities, using various techniques at my disposal for clearing an area of guards one by one while remaining inconspicuous - something sadly too rare in the latest title Valhalla, where the focus is on going a-Viking, with your little hoard of hairy Norsemen (and women) rather than being, you know, an actual assassin.
It's a very Steampunky vision of Victorian London, where your gang hideout is a moving train...but the setting is amazing and oozing with atmosphere, whether you're scaling the clock tower of Big Ben, playing Frogger on the Thames, or meeting her Majesty for tea and scones.

This AC game is truly one of the greatest i've played and it is clear it is the swan song to the gamestyle they've held onto since the 1st game and it shows just how far it has come in it's years. With just 1 year between it and Unity this game blows all other pre-origins games out of the water it is by far the best, The story is meh and nearly really focuses on who Evie and Jacob are or how they're any part of the Assassin's order or anything like that but the gameplay itself carries the game. 
They remove alot of elements from Unity and it helps improve this game alot I think by not having openly cluttered menu's spreading across your screen for your inventory selection, The combat rinses every AC game to bits before the restyle. The elements of the start of the Rpg era and recognised within this game and it was a strong step forward had I played this game at the time of it's release. 
THE BUROUGHS!!! - Now this made me wanna play the game more than getting 100% Synchronisation of the game, I loved the gang wars and all the Associate activities the game throws at you and it's not too much per borough either but still took a reasonable amount of time which I accept. 
The Combat is the biggest overhaul for me with it's Batman esque style fighting style but more casual and simpler and less overwhelming with certain enemies requiring equipment for follow-ups. 
The Free-running is sort of the same as Unity but you can feel the tweaks from the past and it feels like an improvement and I personally loved the Launcher for climbing buildings because I hate climbing I think it is boring and if there is a faster way I will take it!
The bugs - Now I only came across 2 in all my hours of playing so ill not say anything too critical. So the first was the Launcher when I would use it from Roof to Roof - Jacob would just fall and die almost like he missed the rope XD. Anyway and the second bug was Free-climbing down from a roof onto the ground to go into combat and just being frozen in place still taking damage until dying, however this only happened once so I am okay with it.

Overall - Brilliant game, I missed out picking this one up on release solid 8/10 good overall improvements, Story is lacking but the side-activities make the game.

Jack the Ripper DLC still to do...

While I think the world is beautiful and the villain intriguing, there is one reason above all that makes this game impossible to recommend in my eyes.

Remember in other Assassin Creed games whereby you had to conquer Templar installations to recover areas of a city? Like Templar towers in Brotherhood and Revelations? That makes a return in this game, except, it doesn't at the same time.

I'm at Sequence 8, and the only way to make progress is to conquer 3 boroughs in London. In order to do this, there are red activities that are directly related to Templars and defeating them. After conquering the opening borough of the game, no red activities appeared. I thought it was by design and I would only be able to conquer more boroughs later. Well, it isn't. I'm currently soft locked from making any progress in the game because none of the red activities in every borough is showing up. I have searched for answers and apparently it's quite a common bug, red activities not showing up. Sometimes synchronising with every point in the zone makes them pop up. Not for me, as someone who has synched with every point of the game. I have been all over the map and I cannot unlock these activities. There are no other prerequisites, especially considering how far in the game I've already gotten,

I'm soft locked and so many hours of my time is wasted because of it. They will not fix it because they can't, and the game is too old for them to give a shit.

I cannot recommend this game. Sorry.

It's pretty good. I totally dropped Assassin's Creed: Unity because of how boring it was, even from the beginning, not to mention the terrible UI and multiplayer activities. I was a little worried that I was finally getting over the Assassin's Creed series. I really loved Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag and Assassin's Creed: Rogue. Anyway, the Victorian setting is a really good one and it works well with the parkour gameplay. You get a hookshot, which is a lot of fun and takes away some of the tedium of climbing walls for 40 hours. 

There are some great sidequests as well: I really like the Charles Dickens quests. The main quests are decent, and I like that they made a point to give you multiple ways to finished a "dungeon." What was disappointing, however, is that much of the game is spent clearing out boroughs, much like you did in Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood. That's fun, but it does get old. The other thing that bothered me is that the "final" dungeon, where you finally assassinate the big bad guy, is EXTREMELY basic. Really simple. There aren't any optional things you can do in the "dungeon," and contrasted to the very first one you do, it seems like the developers simply ran out of steam by that point. 

Great setting, improved gameplay over Assassin's Creed: Unity, fun dungeons, and definitely worth playing . . . but be warned that the game does "peter out" as it goes on.

Great game, the game has almost the same design as Unity, although I did like Unity a little more. Really liked the world/ atmosphere that they created, The world was a big open world located in the industrial revolution in London. I found the world to be a bit to stretched out although Ubisoft did find a solution to the big world, The grappling hook. I didn't really like the Idea of being able to just stand next to a building and be to instantly fly to the top. It really destroyed the Element of park-our, that was at its best in Unity. The story was OK, the main characters Jacob and Evie Frye where great characters. I really liked the way that each character had its own exclusive skills which meant that you could quite easily swap between play styles. The game play was fun although I did found it to be quite repetitive towards the end of the game.

Conclusion: The game is basically a downgraded version of Unity(in my opinion), If you liked Unity you will most likely like this game as well. I would give the game a solid 7.5/10, definitely worth it if you could pick it up for less than 10 euros on sale.

I didn't buy this game in 2015 because the writing was already on the wall. Even purchasing it with a heavy discount, I am disappointed. 

Only Ubisoft is capable of taking so many steps forwards and backwards simultaneously. After learning all the wrong lessons from Unity, they doubled down once again on stripping Assassin's Creed of everything that made it fun.

Parkour is much more similar to the simple climbing that will comprise the RPG titles to follow. There is no sense of momentum or finding interesting ways to traverse the map. All of Arno's flourish is gone from the animations. They give you the rope launcher to compensate but even sliding down a zip-line just feels slow and boring in this game.

Combat is easy and repetitive. Social stealth is all but gone completely. "Leveling up" is a concept that should never have made its way into these games.

The only saving grace of this AC installment is the Frye twins, who are actually decent protagonists, but Unity set the bar low with Arno. The overall story, however, is still kinda just nothing that goes nowhere. Another plot-line that gets poorly resolved in a comic book somewhere.

[h1]Assassin's Creed¬Æ Syndicate[/h1]
Assassin's Creed¬Æ Syndicate is the sequel to AC Unity, this time we have the opportunity to wander the streets of London during the Industrial Revolution (1868) as the Frye twins. I will not describe the game segment that allows us to play a few simple missions in London during the First World War. Apart from the appearance of one historical figure, the only thing that differs from the basic gameplay is the slightly different appearance of the city, uniforms, etc. Nothing special.
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
Traditionally, London is the seat of the Templars and we as the twins must liberate the city. The game, although it has a fairly basic concept, gives a lot, showing us many historical characters, and the threads from the previous games are explored (mainly from AC Black Flag, AC 3 and AC Rogue). The main antagonist, although from the first point of view he seems to be a stereotypical villain with a curly mustache (because that's what he looks like), is actually a very well-written character, although I believe that there was not enough time to develop him. Which cannot be said about the rest of the characters. Apart from the main characters and the antagonist (and historical figures), the side characters are just ordinary droids, that are to be avoided or eliminated. But aside from that, the story is really simple, but also very solid, and I liked the character conflicts here as well.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You can immediately see that Ubisoft had experimented a lot here. In addition to the typical activities from the series, we now have access to more modern equipment, such as to grappling hook , which, although slightly destroyed the element of climbing, It was not the end of the world. What is dumb however, is that Ubisoft insisted that the grappling hook has to be the central element of the game, the game often places invisible walls while climbing the roofs of buildings, which forces us to use the hook to move. Returning to the characters, Jacob and Eve have slightly different ways of gameplay, you can improve their basic skills and slightly change their equipment. Our main goal apart from the main plot and various side quests (often in which we use a carriage in chases, or solve puzzles in the Sherlock Holmes style) is to unite London under our own gang by performing sabotages and eventually confronting enemy gangs during big street fights (and our main base of operations is our own train that traverses all of London from station to station, which is really great, not only do we have something new and fun to use here, but it also allows us to appreciate the views of the city). Speaking of London itself, I think it is the best-recreated city in the history of the series, the amount of details, historically interesting places and details of the architecture of the period are amazing, just looking around is a pleasure. The city is full of life, factories are working at full speed, people pour out on the streets, they use carriages, ships and trains to travel around. But before we close this thread, let's talk about hand-to-hand combat, something that's the most different from previous games, and I personally don't like these changes. While in previous games (especially in Unity) hand-to-hand combat was fast and dynamic, and the weapon had a noticeable weight, here our blows feel like wet farts in the autumn wind. Some opponents have to be punched for so long that by doing the same, I could punch my fists faster through a solid wall. It looks too comical and you don't feel any weight.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
Graphically it is beautiful, and the game, fortunately, despite its scale, does not tire the hardware and everything works stably. The music is very good as always and It fits with the historical period. Likewise, the voice actors did a very good job.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
It is a very good game that has unfortunately not been appreciated enough. Without a doubt, the best London in gaming history.

Assassins Creed Syndicate is the 4th installment in the popular "Call of Duty" franchise. In this game, the goal is to take down Emperor Pilaf and recover the last Dragon Apple that is needed in order to grant the main character a wish. Now how can a game as interesting as this fail? Well for starters, this game is made by Activision, the same fools that created the abomination known as "Cyberpunk 2077." The story is absolutely garbage as well. For the first half of the game, you play as James Gordon, a popular journalist in the Spiderman comics. You attempt to hunt down the Batman so that you can gain control over Gotham City. However, near the end of the game, it is revealed that you are the Batman. What?!? And when you finally defeat Emperor Pilaf, and get all the Dragon Apples, all you wish for is to have a suit made of Kryptonite so that Spiderman will never be able to defeat you. This is the worst game I've ever played.
its a pretty good ac game

I picked up this game for ~$15 as the gold edition pack. This game had a slight bug with cloth physics where they rendered at 30 fps or less. Fixed this with a slight change to the AC.ini document, plenty of guides out there to fix this. I honestly enjoyed most of the game. It looks extremely good, a lot like Unity's graphics. Syndicate runs relatively well other than being a CPU hog like Unity. The two main characters were relatively interesting, I liked Jacob a decent bit more than Eevie. Syndicate reminds me a lot of Shadow of Mordor, mainly the combat and skill trees appearance. The return of the gang system was pretty nice, I really enjoyed it, but I wish they had more of a set up than just two of four missions and automatically there's thousands of rooks waiting to die for you. They started restricting freerun movement in this game, which was slightly annoying. Freerunning and getting stuck dead in your tracks is not enjoyable. The specification of bonus objectives during quests were heavily restricted. A double air assassination is not a "double assassination".Air assassinations are not stealthy anymore, "climb on the same cart" does not mean hang off the side, "steal something while undetected" no longer includes looting the corpse. Two of the main Templar members were genuinely sort of interesting characters. The final one was effectively a Disney character, I really liked him but I hated that every cutscene you view, it seems like he's singing. Both the main game and DLC fell for the classic AC blunder of a gimmick boss fight. As for the DLC, I really enjoyed the way it started, there was nice Art and very nice hud elements. The main problem was the crippling of possibilities, what kind of psycho killer gets desynced for killing innocents? The blood of the innocents is a requirement for my rituals. The Jack the Ripper DLC was a rollercoaster, it had such a beautiful start, relatively good cutscenes and missions. Then they just nuked the ending into the ground.

Despite the poor critical reception, this is one of the better ACs.  Fun likeable heroes, refined parkour control, and a great setting.  The only downside is a little bit of grind to increase levels before doing story missions, foreshadowing the grindfest that is Origins and latest trilogy.

Since the beginning of lockdown I've been on a play through from start to finish of the main AC games (2.5 side scrollers are not being included cause they're dull cash ins). Syndicate continues to evolve and solve issues that have either always been there (the ubiquitous camera issues of all games) or massively jumped in for the awful awful AC3 - a game so badly programmed and bug ridden that it was unplayable. "Why do you want to get on that horse and escape, when I can *lock* you into a poorly programmed animation and make you run round and round in circles until you get murdered by the guards finally catching up to you... oh and on the final part of this very long mission without any checkpoints so you'll have to restart from the beginning for the 5th time". 
No AC3 - in the bin you go again. (Note: This was not the remastered version... i've not played it, I'm not wasting more money on what should have been a free upgrade for how poor the original was - but alas no matter the bug fixing it wasn't going to solve that the antagonist was an unlikeable whiney idiot and how bad the story was... both in past and current stories, actually destroying the entirety of the current storyline from 1 and 2s). All in all a catastrophically bad game. 

So, what are the ups and downs of AC:S or Serial Killer Simulator 9 as it probably should be called.
Before we being we should take a minute to honour all those Victims:
All the innocent people on the streets viciously mow down by a high speed carriage/cart.
The guards mercilessly stabbed, beaten, shot, executed. 
The poor fight club victims you cause actual bodily harm to, causing life changing damage 
(Think Arkham series Batman - you know, those life changing injuries where he pile drivers poor thugs onto their neck while opining that he shouldn't kill... the ones where you whince and go "he's never walking again" - we are not convinced this is a good alternative.)

Well, as seems to be tradition with AC games, the antagonists are quite unlikeable, and there's a point you just want to throw them in the river and watch them drown, or just let a line of people line up and shoot them in the skull. It must be an American or something thing that this level of smug arrogance is acceptable and they think it's how people should act. Urgh... in the UK we like tearing strips off bankers like this - or we used to... now we're not allowed to protest, stuck on this island paradise. Is it believable that they'd have a whole gang behind them? No... because they have zero leadership skills. But alas, since Ezio we've not had a antagonist to get behind. 

The continuing interruptions to jump forward so we can watch... er... Not Desmond do something we don't care about continues, Thankfully these are all skippable... skip them, they're rubbish. 
All this nonsense needs to get in the bin. Nobody actually cares. Rubbish. People want to sneak around and stab people. Modern Commando's or Thief with some of the ol ultraviolence, with a good bit of story to tie it together. Sure top and tail it, but really this whole nonsense should be shipped out to a different game. I'd happily play AC: Modern, and run around modern London scaling the Gerkin and running over modern Londoners. I'd feel a lot less guilty about that as well.

The travel controls introduced in Unity are refined here, I felt like I had a hell of a lot more control, and the character did not at the first opportunity leap into a hiding spot from 50 yards away, which often occured when you're running like hell away from things and it's the last thing you wanted to happen. 

The continued micro-reality "fan-servicing" where you get to meet all the famous people of the time continues. This obviously works for a lot of stupid people going "Oooo it's the thing", but it does a massive disservice, so tacky. 

The collecting is back - which here isn't too bad... film on one screen this on another, collect away: it's crap and massively/falsely bloats the game time, but whereas in previous this became an annoyance, Syndicate seems to have got something fairly right here with everything appearing on the map. 

What is not alright is having to pay real money for certain maps which when you've paid a substantial amount for the game is obviously a disgraceful money grabbing exercise - urgh. DO NOT PAY - lots of guides exist online. 

Missions in the main are pretty good - most of them being "Sneak here, murder this person", almost like they've remembered you're meant to be an Assassin and the best way to do that is by being sneaky. There's a few points where it's saying "do this" and doesn't give you a marker until you restart the checkpoint... and oh "checkpoints" how I love you so... no more going all the way back to the beginning when things go wrong.

As with one of the grandest crimes of AC3 apart from being awful, this continues the trend of no tomb puzzles. However, this is much more integrated into general mission play - hence skipping amongst the rafters of Parliament before picking the guards off one by one.

No return of Pirate rubbish boating. Thank god... get in the bin.
No micromanagement of boats. 
No micromanagement of gangs.
Some crafting, but it's pretty basic and doesn't require grinding for crap. 
Keep It Simple rewards this game massively by not bloating on the awful inclusion of many rubbish parts of flash in the pan games. 

So, as long as you can get through the fact the two leads of a pair of unlikeable spanners... the game itself is so far peak AC. 

Will I get through the next three in time to watch Ubisoft fail to grasp that their games don't need to be a Soulslike? I doubt it, some dumb business person is going to look at Elden Ring and go "Moneys!" and not understand that that game is not what Assassin's Creed is about... Oh well... people be stupid.

Its a good game but so boring. Its main strong point is the time and the place the story evolves. 1860+ and London. You don't see often that combination. Overall the Map and its content offer an outstanding atmosphere to the game but at the same time, creepy texture glitches and bugs (random infinite triangles appearing, crazy rotating bodies, everything appearing green! etc.) -crazy stuff- weaken the experience. 

The mechanics are good and typical for assasins creed, so nothing new exept the grapple hook. Which adds more variety to the game and opens new possibilities approaching the objective or even the targets.

The Graphics are very good for a 2015 title but there is no HDR on this one. Also pop up Textures and the glitches mentioned are dissapointing.

The Story is so linear and only certain missions are giving a unique flavour to the game hence the bad recommendation. While the Free roam time is good is very repetitive and brings minor joy to the player, nothing can overtake a good unexpected evolvement in the story with extraordinary missions. 

Buy on sale. Propably you want to skip the DLCs. Since the main game isn't that good, DLCs won't save the title.

I have played through most of the Assassin's Creed games, but I went straight to Origins from Black Flag. I was initially scared off of Syndicate and Unity after their notoriously buggy launches. I was attracted back to Syndicate due to its setting, London, but I don't think revisiting older AC games are worth it after playing the newer releases. 

First of all, the controls feel ultra clunky. It makes you appreciate how streamlined the movement of your character in newer games really has become since the climbing up and down in Syndicate just feels downright frustrating. I found myself on numerous occasions wanting my character to descend from heights, yet the process to do so cumbersome and slow. The zipline addition was nice, but it didn't available every time you wanted to use it (no prompt to fire it would be given). The amount of times your character end up doing the opposite of want you wanted was simply too frequent. 

The setting felt exciting at first, but ultimately the playground of the open world felt empty. Some landmarks of London were fun to see, but it didn't take long for the lustre to wear off before the repetition of menial tasks along with bustle of the environments to set in. The Thames really stood out as a unique area, but a lot of London just felt like more of the same winding streets with the same people doing the same programmed things. There's really no incentive to explore or collect items which is the worst part. Helix collecting felt super pointless and the music boxes hunt offered some riddles as hints, but the incentives to do this were not there. The flowers and artwork collections were more interesting as they offered some interesting historical snapshots in time. The beer bottles were the biggest squandered collectable item. I was excited to read up on various beers on the period as I work in the brewing industry, but instead Ubisoft thought it would be funny to offer cynical tasting notes with no real purpose other than to lambaste beer. Felt like a wasted opportunity and a slap in the face to those who put in the effort to collect the bottles. Without real motivation to explore the map other than the story missions, London just gets boring to traverse. 

Carriages are offered as a major mode of transportation in this game. The carriage chases sound good in theory, but most of the time these chaotic events on the streets just devolved into irritating wild goose chases. Your carriage understandly cannot manoeuvre like a car, but heaven forbid if you need to reverse. One crash basically means your target escapes as it takes forever to recover your carriage. The AI often has rogue carriages randomly run you over if you're on foot, or worse, the NPC you're supposed to protect. Some glitches have carriages flying all over the place. I just wish driving a carriage was more fun than it actually was.

Trains are another major presence in the game, and your home base itself is a roving steam engine. You'd think they would have found a seamless way to disembark the train when you were ready to move on. Jumping from the train can sometimes lead to awkward results (or just plain death) when you're supposedly an agile assassin who can climb Big Ben with your bare hands.

Combat feels good in this game. You're able to combine your dodges, counters, and finishers smoothly most of the time. The finishers involving multiple opponents don't always trigger when you want them to, but the overall combat feels satisfying. Stealth also works reasonably well. You can generally sneak around and pick off enemies one-by-one without disruption, and even if your silent assassin attack is spoiled, at least the combat is enjoyable enough that it probably won't upset you too much. The game is also pretty forgiving when escaping. Unlike past iterations were your enemies would relentlessly pursue you and their numbers multiplying like crazy, this game allows escapes after reasonable distances ran or out of sight for a period of time.

The database of the game was a disappointment for me. Reading about various landmarks and historical events is something I usually enjoy from these games, but this one inserted an inexplicable need to be facetious commentary. Perhaps Ubisoft felt the need to have their writers inject humour into the readings to attract more players to pause and have a look, but things just felt snide and trite to the point that it felt condescending to the reader. It also was marked that the writings were quite opinionated and snarky. Rather than offer an authentic historical perspective, the writers are determined to insert their own brand of humour and viewpoints which detract from any information included.

Finally, the game almost feels a bit like a revisionist history. The game being split between a male and female protagonist is great. What's not great is the game weirdly has almost half of the enemies portrayed as women. A suspension of belief is required when considering that ratio of women as London gang member during that time period. Representation does not make sense when now you can murder almost as many women as men during gameplay. Yay equality? Seems like Ubisoft is catering to the interests of modern day social justice rather than portraying the reality of a historical era in an accurate manner. 

In the end, skip this entry, even on sale, and play some of the newer AC games (Origins and onward) instead. The controls of this game are jarring for players of the newer versions in the series of Assassins Creed. Furthermore, the setting of London really isn't as rewarding as one might expect as Ubisoft fails to provide interesting tasks to do within the world and squanders opportunities to provide immersion. Leave this game in the past.

Game was fun for a while. Do a brainless run and you'll have fun.

To be honest, the game was fun and it grabbed my attention at the start of the game. If I were to describe this, the game is like a hurricane. It begins exciting and slowly becomes a disaster until everything is fine when it all ends. That's how I felt when I was playing this game to completion, I was glad it was over so I can uninstall it.

The idea of playing a AC game set in the Victorian Era of London was exciting, I was interested in learning London's history on child labors, numerous slangs, iconic figures (Karl Marx was definitely the shining highlight), and of course how the story illustrates two Frye twins are able to secure numerous sectors against numerous Templars and Blighters.

My biggest complaint of the game was it felt really boring around Sequence 3 - Sequence 7. And only near at the game was when I did enjoy playing assassination missions, side quests, etc. Sequence 9 was good, but it was a damn shame that i couldn't play more of the WWI era because the missions felt comfortable and required foresight to play the 5 missions. Zeppelin Raid is a fun mode, although I wish it had more planes to shoot down. To end things off, if you're looking for run of the mill AC game. Buy it, the gameplay carries the charm of Syndicate because the hookshot enables so much mobility and freedom on navigating areas. Kind of like Halo: Infinite campaign, the gameplay carries Syndicate a lot. The story? Not so enjoyable, there just isn't enough hype around the key figures to assassinate aside from final boss and the mid game boss. This game has no replayability whatsoever, but an adventure to try out once.

I have enjoyed most of my time with the game, but I also burned-out multiple times trying to finish one playthrough.

If you are familiar with other Ubisoft titles, then it would not come as a surprise that this is also a collectathon with a lot of side activities. That is all well and good, but the way that I have been playing through the game made it so that I collected what I could as soon as I could. That was a slog to get through, and I think I would have enjoyed it more had I collected as I played instead of just collecting. I really enjoy collecting things in games, so I fizzle out when there is this much collecting to do, and the one playthrough that I have done have taken years to complete. I play it, enjoy it and then burn out for a while and repeat until I finally completed the game and all its DLC today.

The gameplay is not that different to other Assassin‚Äôs Creed titles, so if you are familiar with those then it is quite likely that you will find this a familiar experience. I enjoyed it for the most part, but sometimes I had to fight with the controls to get it to do what I want it to.

I really liked Evie and Jacob as protagonists. They were charming and had their differences, but was a good team and I liked their personalities. With Henry as support it made for some good fun. The story is also good, for the most part. I did not care for the present-day stuff, but I imagine that I am not in the minority there and found it a bit annoying whenever it shifted back to it. I wanted to spend time with Evie and Jacob, not someone else.

The optional WW1 section was a nice surprise. There you play as Lydia, [spoiler]Jacob‚Äôs granddaughter[/spoiler], as you help root out spies and help Winston Churchill with the war effort. It was a nice brake from the main story and was short enough to not overstay its welcome. One thing that I would have changed about the story is that [spoiler]Lydia should have been the granddaughter of Evie and Henry instead since they end up together, and Lydia already look very similar to Evie,[/spoiler] but except for that there is little to complain about.
I like the old london vibe that this game gives. And all the interesting characters from history.

After completing Assassin's Creed Unity, I surprised myself by immediately starting a playthrough of Assassin's Creed Syndicate.  I'd just spent 59 hours in Unity, so usually I wouldn't jump into another game with very similar gameplay.  I think the idea was just to see what the game was like, as I had been unimpressed with Unity.

Within just a few hours of playing Syndicate, I knew that I was already having much more fun than at any point in Unity.  And now I've just completed playing Syndicate after another 61 hours of assassin creed-ing this summer.

Syndicate was made by a coalition of Ubisoft's B-team developers lead by Ubisoft Quebec, but I think they created a much better game than Ubisoft's premiere studio Ubisoft Montreal.  I think more work and resources probably went into Unity, much of which was able to be reused for Syndicate, but I believe it's a much better game.

[h1]Changes to the AssCreed formula[/h1]
Syndicate is currently the last main-series game with an action/adventure design.  The next three games are action RPGs.  We learned just this week that the next game will be called Assassin's Creed Mirage and returns to action/adventure.  Syndicate plays mostly the same as previous games, so I understand why the next game, Origins, changed up the formula in a big way.  Syndicate is just an evolution of the formula, but at least it does a lot more than Unity's stripped down gameplay.

Syndicate features a simplified version of the "freeflow" combat system from Batman: Arkham Asylum.  This combat system was incredibly popular for action/adventure games in the early-mid 2000s, so it's impressive that Assassin's Creed held out for six games before using it.  It's very easy, with at least 3 seconds to counter attacks and enemies very, very rarely attack more than one at a time.  There aren't many benefits to high combos and weaving in gadgets is limited.  In my opinion, this version of freeflow combat is too simplified to create the sense of joy from playing it well that I have felt in many other games, like Mad Max and Shadow of Mordor/War.

The other big change in Syndicate is addition of fast and effective traversal options.  Horse-drawn carriages can be driven and raced and there are some combat mechanics.  Ubisoft decided to allow us to freely run over civilians without causing the classic warning: "This ancestor did not kill civilians."  Having to avoiding people would make driving carriages less fun.

The rope launcher is a huge deal.  It's totally unrealistic but so fun.  Once I got it, I never longer manually climbed up the side of buildings like I have in so many Assassin's Creed games.  It also has a large horizontal range for crossing the huge gaps in the city layout from the roads that are much larger than in other AC cities for carriages.  The game's design elements come together well.

[h1]Story & characters[/h1]
As with Unity, the story is that you are an unknown individual experiencing genetic memories to find something for the Assassins.  In Unity it was the identity of a Sage, and now it's the location of a Piece of Eden known to be somewhere in London.  Unity barely had any interaction with the "real world" story, and Syndicate has even less!

Having a video game with two freely-changeable main characters is an idea that I think is genuinely innovative.  They should have both been males, but Ubisoft took the opportunity to have it both ways and also appease the people that think a female character should be portrayed doing the feats of speed, strength, and brutality that are done in these Assassin's Creed games.

Audiences are now so desensitized by impossible portrayals of women's comparative physical capabilities in big budget entertainment that it's got to the point where they can get away with this without alienating most gamers.  But I dare anyone to play the brawls with Evie, where the animations show her in a tank top, throwing around 250 pound muscled men like sacks of straw (her brother Jacob shares some animations), and not pee yourself laughing at how absurd it looks.

Another problem with a female character in an action game is the ideological expectations that comes along with it.  She has to be as good as, or better, than the men.  At no point can she be shown as less capable or unsuited to the task.  As a result, Evie is little miss perfect, who belittles her brother in almost every interaction they have.  I though Jacob was actually a pretty cool character, but Ubisoft's writers never let me enjoy him by constantly having Evie complaining or insulting him.  The only reason Jacob's actions had bad secondary consequences, while Evie's didn't, is because the writers wanted it that way.

In the end, the writers dunked on Evie by putting her into a romance with the completely unimpressive and lame Indian assassin, Henry Green.  Evie is way more manly than he is.  It happens at the literal end of the game, so the writers never have to show how the heck this relationship could possibly work.

If she constantly berated the very competent & masculine Jacob, imagine how bad wimpy Mr. Green is going to get it!

[h1]Let's cut this short[/h1]
This is getting too long, so I'll skip some stuff I made notes about, like the equipment system having the same problem as Unity: most of it goes unused.  I'll end with one more comparison to my experience playing Unity in July.  While Unity is the literal worst-performing game I've ever un on this PC, Syndicate was a freaking joy to play.  It ran mostly at 60fps at 2954x1662 (77% of 4K with Nvidia Image Scaling) with my outdated GTX 1080.  The game looks gorgeous at all times.  The ground textures, with the individual bricks and puddles and reflections, were so impressive.

Okay, I'll say one last thing: screw the Karl Marx missions.  He was not a kind old man walking the streets organizing The Workers¬© and dissuading violent anarchists.  That's total revisionism and I reject the attempt at propaganda.

Its like AC unity but they buffed out the technical problems, but in return made the story awful and removed any parkour.

Its the closest thing we're going to get to an AC in the modern day with driving carriages basically like driving cars, and with automatic firearms at the end of the game. Also they returned to AC2's combat system which was neat, and like all the other games it looks good visually.

However, it retains its leveled enemies structure defeating the point of an open world map. And also there is only one singular map, meaning AC3, 4 and Rouge where bigger in map size than this one. Unlike the other installments there isn't a 'bigger picture' for this game. You're not fighting in a crusade, assassinating a pope, fighting in the american revolution, you're just fighting a generic a-historical industrial revolution capitalist. The plot boils down to a template for all post black flag AC games. Kill the antagonists underlings, and then kill the antagonist while he has an eldar artifact. There is nothing unique about this game's story. Also there are no parkour segments. You are given a grappling hook which allows you to instantly scale buildings defeating one of the key aspects of an AC game. Oh and I hope you like microtranscations because there are more of them.

This game had so much of wasted potential it saddens me. 
It's a good game worth playing, but not a good Assassin's Creed. Gameplay maintained the AC style, but there was no brotherhood bonds, codex, CREED. If it wasn't meant to be an AC game, then I'd say that the story was good. I fell in love with the Frye twins and enjoyed the character of Maxwell Roth. The new combat system felt refreshing and It's a first AC game that I finished on 100% synch. The gang wars were fun and the final missions of the game actually required some stealth and had me feeling like "I am an assassin doing assassin stuff." Lot of people like to compare Syndicate to Unity and I understand them. Unity still feels surperior in some ways, becouse there is so much Syndicate could've been. Coop that unity had,  some gang wars version of the old ac manhunts, multiplayer carriage racing. The choice of keeping Syndicate a singleplayer experience was a big mistake on Ubisoft's behalf. Even if you wouldn't like the story, coop could've brought people in to have fun together, which is exactly what Unity did and why is it still played today, even tho it had a rocky path.

I overall enjoyed playing it, but this game does not offer much for me to return and replay it.

Its incredible to see how things were old fashioned but also rapidly changing into the modern world we see today. THIS GAME IS AMAZING!

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is the last of the OG AC games and probably the weakest one in the series as I had to think about whether to recommend this game or not.

The game feels like a downgrade from Unity. They took out everything great about Unity, the immersive environment, character customization, the murder mysteries, engaging side stories (there are some in Syndicate but they aren't as good), and a somewhat engaging story arc for the heroes of the game.

You don't feel as immersed in the Victorian setting. Both the protagonists and the antagonists feel very bland, and leave you with an overwhelming "meh." The "charm" of the Frye twins wears off fast since the main story feels diluted.

The WW1 side mission line isn't very engaging from my experience, but it was a good addition to the game!

The depiction of gang warfare and the bad guys as "a rival gang" is comical. It's like they were voiced by the same people behind LoTR's orcs and goblins. Some classic lines include:
- "You killed my friends, now I will kill you!"
- "I'll spill your guts!"
- and general grunting.

Now for the DLCs:

Jack The Ripper DLC however was quite enjoyable, it presents a more serious tone, there's a slight sense of mystery about Jack's Identity, the Fear Takedowns are excellent, and being able to play as Jack the Ripper was slightly unsettling cuz I don't want to control a serial killer but it presented some good moments of the narrative. Jacob and Evie are also a lot older and wiser and not clowns anymore which was great. The Sherlock Holmes Series-styled investigation sequences were also well made.

The Last Maharaja DLC is just terrible with the dumbest AI and some of the most terrible mission designs in the game.

The Dreadful Crimes is the 3rd and final DLC for the game and IS NOT included in the season pass. This DLC goes further into the Sherlock-type Investigations and TBH they are really interesting, it's nice overall but the fact that it isn't in the season pass is still quite bad.

The only way I can recommend this game is either you are a hardcore fan of this franchise like me or you want to have a virtual tour of London during the Victorian era.

Not a lot of good things to say about his game. Definitely feels like it as rolled off and assembly line without much thought or care. The story is wholly uninteresting and the missions lack any sort of impact; a lot of running from point A to point B with nothing interesting happening even when you reach your destination. The movement and combat is janky and, while it is a game about stealth, this mechanic was the most boring of the lot. The redeeming, though non-consequential, aspects of the game were the interesting setting and character dynamic between the two protagonists. The graphics were middling and, while I am not  a huge fan of the Assassins Creed franchise, there are definitely better ones out there.

Game crashes constantly

Even with specs that exceds the recomendation that the game auto detects to graphics setting ultra I've gotten random crashes, sometimes constant crashes in certain mission areas.
I tried the trouble shooting sugested by Ubisoft, re-installing the game, turning my graphic settings down to the lowest setting - none of it helped. Assassin's Creed Syndicate may not be the best one of the saga, but it is certainly an entertaining and nostalgic experience for fans who have played the previous installments. 
 Set in 19th century's London, you follow the Frye twins in their quest to end Templar domination. Having the chance to play as both Evie and Jacob was an incredibly innovative choice for the franchise that I welcomed with open arms. Both are different yet capable assassins and the customisation offers a wide variety of improvements, such as different weapons, skill sets and outfits. My favourite was the inclusion of Ezio's legendary robes. 
 The story is charming and fun and as a twin myself I can guarantee that the characterisation and relationships were marvellously achieved. The addition of a story set in World War I and the last couple of interactions with the Queen were also interesting and nice details.
 There are some bugs here and there that can be certainly annoying, but they usually don't interfere with the gameplay. The mechanics, stealth, combat and parkour were just what one can expect from a great Assassin's Creed installment. A gameplay system that is missed by many who have played the newest games.
 All in all, I'd say this was an enjoyable experience, with low difficulty and a fun set of characters and missions. It is not up to level of some of its tremendously grandiose predecessors, but it is quite a nice option for those who have already played them and want to expand their collection and continue to enjoy a game faithful to the saga's beginnings.

This was around the time Ubisoft started the policy of releasing full priced games as beta tests for other games.

One of my favourites AC games in the series and the DLC is just as good. I enjoyed every minute of it. The story line keeps you invested and the missions have a decent balance so it doesn't get boring and you don't feel you're doing the same type of missions over and over again. 

Is the game hard? Like all AC games, it depends on your play style, if you want to be a true assassin and be stealthy all the way through, then yes it can be a bit tricky and maybe test your patience, but if you're like me and not overly fussed if you get caught and fight your way through (unless a mission specifically asks you to be stealthy) then no, I wouldn't say its hard. As all AC games, it doesn't offer a difficulty mode, difficulty is simply based on level of yourself and the mission itself. 

Do I have any issues? Yes, but only one. I did find the controls rather clunky and annoying sometimes, mostly with climbing up and down objects which resulted in Jacob and Evie not either jumping when you wanted them too or not letting go/climbing down smoothly. Did this stop me enjoying the game? Nope.

Decent AC game but nothing special. Doesn't do much to step out of the bubble of the traditional ac format (unlike origins). Story is mediocre but serves its purpose in giving you a reason to beat up some Templars, and speaking of beating up Templars, the combat is serviceable and fun for the first few hours but gets pretty old, pretty quick. However stealth is great, many different ways to approach an encounter and has some decent AI as well. Parkour is good but isn't as relevant because of the grapple hook added to the game, which is fun but ultimately forces parkour to take the backseat. So if combat is decent, parkour is decent, and story is mediocre, what makes this game stand out? Well in my opinion, it's the world. The world has INCREDIBLE atmosphere and I rarely hear people talking about it.  Seeing all the horse carriages and factories emitting large clouds of smoke into the sky is so well done. Patrolling London at night has a sense of unpredictability and can feel quite dangerous. If there is one thing I am a sucker for in games, its the atmosphere, it adds to the immersion greatly and being immersed in a world is the main reason why I play so much single player games (and why I love the witcher 3, rdr2, and the ac series so much). You may not share my passion for the world in this game, but you should defiantly give it a try because I think it's the most underrated world in an AC game. But apart from that, it's just more AC with a few tweaks here and there.

Speaking of which, the game-play... more... of... the same. I don't know what to add, other than it's all running, climbing, counter-combat, map clutter exploration, sync ya view! Which will lead me to one criticism I have over these later titles. Unless the mission demands it, there really seems to be no penalty to breaking stealth and combat is very easy. Amazing journey that fills your shoes with two charismatic protagonists Jacob and Lydia Frye that bound to free industrial London from evil hands. As you raised to be an assassin its up to you to clean the streets from ‚Äúhigher‚Äù class and give freedom for everyone else. 
The gameplay jumps around two amazing characters with their strengths and weaknesses. You can chose how to play the game as both characters are well suited for every job. Dynamic duo keeps gameplay fresh on many perspective.

First time writing a review for a game, but had to for this game. Played it for the first time in maybe 2018, but picked it up again this summer after being on a Assasins Creed bench. I know this is hugely controversal but this is one of my favorite assasins creed games. It feels so assasins creedy, the way you use stealth, parkour and the rope launcher. Absolutely loved the game...

So after playing this game and not getting a refund for this game, I wanna let anyone know that reads this, the game may suddenly bug out even if you restart it and what not, so the way to do it is verify files and reinstall the game, I was on sequence 2 with a quest to chase a kid and it froze before I got into the alley he was going into. So if this helps anyone instead of google results, here you go. Game is one of my favorites and I shall list some pluses for it and minuses that may be more minor!

Pluses:
- Got the game on sale with season pass so definitely worth it, have not seen any bugs "yet", as I said.
- The feel of London is priceless and I love it with the tone.
- Assassins creed story and not rpg for once back then
- Open-world 
- Good for 1060s and up easily for graphics cards, ram I have is 16gb and game is flawless at very high to max graphics

Minuses:
- Having to reinstall the game after verifying which I think is steams fault, but who knows its ubisofts disgusting creation at times.
- A little clonky at times how story goes, but still worth playing one time and everything gained
- Do not buy at full price as game is over 8 years old almost, wait for the sale as inteded!

-Not much to say about minuses, but I will say it is worth playing as an older assassins creed fan, there is some iffy stuff about ubisoft, but trying this out for a playthrough is not a bad as people put it. Good day m8!

This is a tough one to review. Immediately apparent, it's the jankiest game in a series that's known for quite a bit of jank. Unlike AC: Unity, little effort was made to iron things out after release and it shows. It's actually strange to think this game released when it did because somehow the controls feel significantly worse than previous games. Pair that with the lack of optimization and frequent bugs and it starts to feel like you're swimming upstream. If poor performance is not something you're willing to tolerate, you probably won't make it through the main story.

And another thing: not that any of these games are difficult except maybe the later ones, but by God is this game easy. So much so that stealth is optional (e.g. you can single-handedly rob the Bank of England by just fighting all the guards at once). The only element of challenge comes from the poor controls which really just accentuates how poor they are.

With all that in mind, I can't help but appreciate what the game [i] does [/i] have to offer. The cityscape overall is very impressive, and there are some cool new ideas that work well here: I loved hearing trains and steamboats trudging through the city, simultaneously enhancing atmosphere and providing an immersive alternative to fast travel. The ability to switch protagonists GTA V style, and the implementation of drivable carriages (Grand Theft Pony style) are both pretty great. Having multiple ways to go about assassin missions feels almost like a simplified Hitman game and is another welcome change. It's really just a nicely crafted world and among it all, there's plenty to do and see. Activities like: a day in the life of Jack the Ripper, beating people to death with Charles Dickens' cane, and saving children from harsh labor factories then telling them they work for me now. I'm making it seem slightly more awesome than it is, but yeah... that actually about sums it up.

When it's all said and done, an open world game set in Victorian London is a lot to promise, and the potential here far exceeded the final product. If I'm gonna revisit any Assassin's Creed game, this is probably last on the list. Still, I can't help but cut it some slack as the game world is highly detailed. It's gritty, industrial mood is pretty much what I had hoped it would be. I've always valued the franchise as a fun historical sandbox so that alone gives it a passing grade by me.

I've played through most of the AC games to date and I've gotta say this one is the most buggy and frustrating one.
The combat feels clunky and button mashing is here in full-force. Bullet sponge enemies are numerous and they are sometimes unfairly overpowered, hitting you without you even having the time to react. The leveling feels just like a chore and the player customization feels very lackluster when you compare it to the system in Unity.

Even AC Unity wasn't as buggy and unstable at launch (for me) as this one is which baffles me considering it came one year after Unity and it's been almost 7 years since the release.

With that being said, I like it very much and I still can recommend it, IF, you are a AC fan and don't mind the cookie cutter content included in the modern AC Formula. The characters are quirky and funny which feels out of place (in a good way) considering it's a AC game. The main characters are cool and the story (thus far) seems fine.
