assassinscreed fandom com/wiki/Ned_Wynert
1868 London, right, featuring this creature that somehow has not been bullied into being part of half of the t r a n n y reality statistic.

Even besides this s h i t, I cannot, I tried, but I cannot get into this game. It's so shallow and unenjoyable, missing or has dumbed down features from previous games where everything was perfectly right (such as combat, parkour and free movement in general).

Most of the gameplay loop seems to be going through a checklist of objectives on the map that have none or very little depth, world building or anything worthwhile in them. For comparison, in the first Assassin's Creed game, although the missions also repeated in their main goals, but most of them gave more context towards your current greater objective, which is interesting. Here, as far as I have heard so far, some enemy characters in a mission might talk or hint towards why they are in this place and what they are doing, but ultimately nothing of interest and longer lasting and it is likely so for most of the missions. 

The combat is just a button mashing simulator. The fact they have added RPG mechanics to the combat is ruining the combat, because the enemies are damage sponges. It's a night and day difference in the joy of the combat from the first game and this. You can still insta-kill enemies in stealth at least.

I played only as little as I did at the time of writing, but I can hardly imagine this is going to get any better and I don't know if I will return to find out. Some reviews said the characters and story are good. I don't know about the story, having played so little, but so far it's not very engaging and the characters... nah. The only good thing the characters have is that Evie Frye is one of the prettiest female characters in gaming (worth mentioning today merely because it's turning into a trend in modern """triple-A""" game development to make disgusting foul creatures to pass for women), that's about it, but her, her brother's and everyone else's personality are like part of a [i]'mandatory checklist of characters to be included in your """triple-A""" game'[/i] and are just a bunch of people trying to be very cool and [i]"haha I'm a  fungi (fun guy), get it?"[/i] and [i]"haha here's a very witty comeback to your jest! Thou have been engulfed by flames by my recovery!"[/i] and the [i]"haha geeky smart characters, very clumsy!"[/i]. All these tropes are not necessarily bad to do, but when every single character feels like they are made to fill a checklist, all their performances are naturally hardly bearable in most cases. The characters have different names, looks, backgrounds, but yet in the end they are all the same and have been seen a million times over and hardly any of them memorable. Arguably, with so many characters created through all sorts of mediums, it's hard to create compelling characters ‚Äì fair enough, but it feels like no one even tried or they merely did "just enough". I have just never felt in any other game so far to make such a comparison, that the characters feel merely like entries in a list.

I recently got this game on sale and boy this game is buggy as hell. Conceptually it could be the best assassin's creed ever, I like Jacob and Evie Frye as characters and the open world feels so lived in but the numerous bugs that are still present even in 2022 make this game at times unplayable. While I wouldn't recommend this game at full price if you manage to get it on sale then it's not completely bad. Like I said there's so much potential in this game to be the best AC game ever but it's so buggy and badly executed that I cannot in good conscience recommend this game at least at full price.

"What's this, Greenie? Assassin Christmas?"

Haha! I love this game. It's also considered the last "classic style" AC game. Let's talk about the parkour. It's nowhere near as complex as in AC: Unity, even though it uses the same system. A lot of Unity's stylish animations were removed, and freedom of movement was also removed, such as allowing "dangerous jumps" to be performed. As in, jumping from heights that would kill you, but being able to save yourself by performing a manual ledge grab / breakfall. It's understandable that Victorian London's architecture and style doesn't allow for parkour as complex and satisfying as Paris. The buildings and streets are simply too spaced out. Yes, I live in UK, and yes, I used to do parkour as a kid. It was hard to find decent spots that weren't busy, corporate property where you'd likely get kicked out of LOL! xD For that, AC: Syndicate's solution was the Hidden Blade's latest attachment, the grappling hook, acting as a climbing tool or zip-line to get from point A to point B as fast as possible. It feels very satisfying to use, it looks cool, it fits the Steampunk vibe, but at the same time, it kinda removes the need for classic parkour. I enjoy the faster-paced combat and animation diversity. The combos, the multi-kill system, etc... with unique weapons such as deadly canes, kukris and brass-knuckles. Anyone complaining about having to hit an enemy 50 times before they die... do me a favour and buy yourself some higher quality gear, will you? And some perks that focus on bringing enemies down to "Near-Death State" quicker. It literally takes 1 or 2 hits to kill an enemy in hand-to-hand combat if you know the game's mechanics and progression system. And you can even insta-kill enemies with your first strike if the right conditions are met, taking down an entire group of enemies in seconds. Come on, people... first you complained that the classic, older AC games were too simple and repetitive, and the counter-kill system made everything too easy and automatic... 

Now, AC Syndicate's stealth and NPC AI works much better than Unity's. In Unity, the tools (smoke bombs, etc..) were your solution to everything. And I'm not complaining. It felt amazing. But in Syndicate, everything just feels snappier. I like the improvements a lot. I think the gameplay is one of the best things about Syndicate. Manually and silently aiming throwing knives at enemies' heads feels good. Zip-line assassinations bring a whole new dynamic to the gameplay and creativity of tackling a stealth situation. Kidnapping is introduced as both a stealth mechanic and mission objective. The former allows for any enemy not aware of Jacob/Evie, to be kidnapped and used as a form of social blending, allowing access to restricted areas. Whistling is back, and it's very useful. There's different methods of transportation (GTA-style) like horse-drawn carriages with a lot of variety in terms of size, durability, speed and control, which you can ram into other carriages to cause mayhem and destruction or hop onto the roof of your carriage to shoot your enemies, or to jump onto another enemy's carriage and hijack it. There's better side activities which aren't just you going around stealing items / killing dudes. The Murder Mysteries are genius work! They're much more complex and dynamic than AC Unity's, with new mechanics such as tracing the trajectory of a projectile that killed the victim back to its original, potential location, only to find a firearm hidden nearby, etc.. That sort of thing. There's gang allies that you can recruit and call for help, which is reminiscent of the early Ezio AC games, there's a bigger presence of kids than in any other AC game, so the world feels a bit more alive and believable, and whoever thought to make your hideout on a moving train that goes around the city is a genius. It feels so good to return there in between missions, collect income, etc.. and see your twin (which makes comments on your attire and weapons) as well as other side characters chilling about. So cozy.

Let's talk a bit about the narrative. The modern day. What's Abstergo up to this time?

In 2015, Bishop contacts the Helix Initiate to help herself and fellow Assassins Shaun Hastings and Rebecca Crane locate a Piece of Eden, apparently hidden in a vault, somewhere in London. Through camera drones, the Initiate watches the pair of Assassins conduct their field work and download the memories of the twins Jacob and Evie Frye. The artefact is The Shroud, actually teased back in AC2 (The truth puzzles, I believe) the very same piece of cloth that "resurrected" Jesus Christ. Cool lore. Abstergo plans to find it. Instead of cloning a member of the First Civilisation like they planned to in AC Unity, they intend to recreate one from scratch using the Shroud's cellular level healing ability inside their secret laboratories. Very disturbing, but very interesting. The Assassins must stop them before it's too late, because Juno is still out there after Desmond set her free back in 2012. Collect Helix Glitches in game and you will unlock new Present Day Assassin Intel and backstories related to The Shroud, that date back to the Italian Renaissance and the Auditore Villa. Nice throwbacks :) The present-day story, even though there's no gameplay unfortunately, is still pretty great. The action sequences during pre-rendered cutscenes are badass and very high quality, using the full CGI character models, and it's nice to see familiar faces such as Shaun and Rebecca reminiscing about Desmond and how they miss him. Real fan service. Master Assassin Galina Voronina also makes an appearance (she is known from the AC comic books) and helps them take the fight to the Templars, even saving their lives from Otso Berg's elite Sigma Team. Again, very, very badass, especially the end cinematic with that music.

The game has the player take on the role of an Initiate, same as in Unity, as they explore the story of the twin Assassin protagonists, Jacob and Evie Frye, both of whom are playable at any time during the open world exploration and side missions, but they both have their own unique missions too during the main story. Jacob, a brash and charismatic lad searching for glory and the spilling of Templar blood, much like a younger Ezio, and Evie, a smart, beautiful, by-the-book sort of lass who likes to apply knowledge and a more tactical approach to her mission assignments. There is a nice dynamic between the two, typical of twins, with Jacob getting slightly more screen time during main missions as he's the one that gets to cut down Templar after Templar in the best "black-box" style Assassin's Creed mission structures yet! While Evie searches for a Piece of Eden and cleans up after Jacob.. xD The two arrive in London in 1868, as the Industrial Revolution reaches its climax, bringing its lot of inequality and poverty in a city controlled by the Templars and Grandmaster Crawford Starrick, which is a very likeable antagonist, in my opinion. To stop their rule, the Fryes will take over the organised crime in an effort to gather an army, called The Rooks by Jacob, and free London while helping the working folk, such as eliminating forced child labour and liberating London's boroughs. The game can be pretty light-hearted at times, with Jacob making sarcastic comments in every sentence and Evie calling him out for being immature. I love it, and it was much needed, especially after Unity's rather tragic love story / Shakespearean-play kind of ending. I recommend!

Jack the Ripper DLC is excellent. A must play! A disturbing, almost horror-like, cinematic experience set 20 years after the main game. The Last Maharajah DLC is an abomination, though. While interesting in concept, it's extremely buggy and "low-budget"..

I'll probably put this in the bottom 3 of the AC titles, had some pathfinding issues but not as bad as Unity. I think this game is perfectly fine. If you're looking for a 10/10 game, you won't find it, but if you're looking for a nice triple A title that has a lot of love and personality you will find it. If you have played any Assassin's Creed titles before this, you more or less know what to expect. As is to be expected, the historical elements of Syndicate are exceptional; London is a lively and extraordinarily crafted location, and the addition of the zip-line is a necessity and expands on the parkour system. Jacob and Evie are nice leads; I personally like Evie a lot more, but Jacob (despite catching flack from the community) is a really charismatic lead. His naivety is frustrating at times, but that is his character! Evie is the one who is able to hold him accountable. A lot of the collectibles can feel like they are not worth it, and by the end of the game I had maxed out my levels and gotten the best gear possible, so doing the extra missions and leftover content did not feel worthwhile. The Jack the Ripper DLC has been cool so far‚ÄîI am invested in the story and want to see how it ends. 

All in all, if this game is on sale, grab it! It is a fairly inoffensive game and you can kill a good 30-40 hours playing it. Just good, easy, simple fun.

The BS section:

Its BS that you can only have your hood on in "sneak" mode.
Its BS that  your character bumbles around when you attempt to do very precise movements.
Its BS that some of the mission objectives are poorly designed and require overly-precise bull shit, considering the point above.
Its BS that Ubisoft gives you a button to purchace in game currency.
There is a BS leveling system that does nothing but pigeonhole area progression.
The actual combat (not ambushing or assassinating) is repetitive and boring as hell.

TLDR: Its worth a play, but wait for it on sale by a good amount.

another well made game of the franchise, although it did have its draw backs. the protagonists, Evie and Jacob Frye leave a lot to be desired. Jacob is an assassin(somehow?!) who does not think things through and simply kills without thought of any repocutions, whilst Evie although a binary opposite, feels like she does not have much going for her. She is the assassin sister to Jacob Frye and not much more. the story line was mediocre at best; Syndicate brought in the use of gangs as a way to reuse the assassin brotherhood available in previous games, however, the gangs are not used very often apart from the odd gang war. I did,however, enjoy the use of historic figures, such as Charles Darwin and Karl Marx. overall this game was a decent series to add tot the AC franchise, however it is by no means one of the best, but also not the worse.

The last ‚Äúclassic‚Äù Assassin‚Äôs Creed game before the revamp of the formula, the recreation of industrial London is amazing, the characters that you meet are silly and their missions and plot is quite campy but it‚Äôs overall fun, the main missions are also fairly diverse, well-paced, and enjoyable to play through.

As to the problems? The game is buggy, not ridiculously but enough that you‚Äôll notice it, I fell through the ground at one point and another time when skipping a mission cutscene the game wouldn‚Äôt stop resetting the same cutscene, it wasn‚Äôt until I watched it when this stopped.

The game can also be a grind fest, the main missions don‚Äôt get affected by this, but the side content does; the side missions are fairly samey and the game is bloated, completely loaded with content to the point where I think most people would never even contemplate even coming close to finish the game 100% let alone getting the actual thing. There are upgrades, different weapons and skills but they all hinge on you getting different types of currency and materials, some of which can be very annoying to obtain. The big problem with this is also the reason as to why is it there, it‚Äôs not here because Ubisoft bad design choices but instead, because they want to ram other kinds of monetization down the players throat, mitrotranactions and the like.

Beyond that though, I am recommending it because of the story and main missions, the game is fun, just a bit buggy and a bit scummy with its monetization practices, these problems will mainly just affect you if you play through the side content though, so there‚Äôs that.

Out of all the "newer" Assassin's Creed titles and when I say newer I mean every title after Revelations because personally for me that was the best one as it marks the end of an era, this one is probably the best. Quite honestly when I first started playing the game, at the beginning I though damn this AC is gonna be so boring, but luckily I decided to not give up on the game yet and boy was I glad that I did that. I was so happy that my original feeling was wrong and the game just feels better and better as you play it and even the characters who I though I would hate a lot started to impress me and I got attached to them, which is one more good thing in a game in general. The story is not the best there ever was, but it is good with a lot of interesting historic characters that existed in the real world (not gonna spoil it, don't worry). Sure some side-missions feel like pain, but I actually did all of them except the collectibles which I will leave for another time. The world in this game is something that simply amazed me as it is so large, diverse, tall and very enjoyable. London is simply amazing in this game. The one thing that I absolutely HATED in this game is that you could (spoiler alert) use real money in it and buy certain skills in the game, but overall a decent Assassin's Creed game that might not be even close to the original 4 parts but it is worth picking up. In the end try getting it on a sale as it would be a steal then because it usually goes for around 10 euros which is a great price for this game.

This is probably the best experience you might get out of a Game Factory like Ubisoft squeezing every last drop of life out of a series, which still isn't worth the trouble. The highlight of this game is the grappling hook and how hilariously mismatched the game's "Template Situations" can be to the story. Every character and NPC, and even the player character, will activate their generic response no matter the situation. Helping a drunk friend home? Well, that uses the Kidnap mechanic to escort him, so you have to whisper a death threat to him out of nowhere. Just murdered a crowd of Blighters with a gang member? He'll yell at you for robbing the corpses that he just helped you make.
The game also lacks extremely basic, simple, easy-to-implement Quality of Life. You can only place one map marker, and it's extremely finnicky to place on a landmark and feels shoddy overall. If you fast travel after marking a spot, it just completely removes it. Whistling while hanging off a dock will lure an enemy who walks over and immediately falls off and dies of their own accord. An entire boss sequence can be skipped by shooting them repeatedly. Duleep Singh can softlock the game on several occasions. Despite the game only being from 2015, all online services are discontinued. The Gold Edition includes all DLC, except it doesn't, because one DLC is just missing because they feel like it. The reward for finding 32 music boxes scattered around the city with no indicators is an ugly white dress with mediocre effects for Evie. The reward for finding only 20 bottles, which you can buy a map for, gives you the best belt in the game for Jacob.
Evie's voice acting is about as energetic as a dead turtle, and her entire personality is "Do-gooder" with the occasional uncharacteristic sarcasm thrown in out of nowhere.
I spent 31 hours going Completionist on this game and I can't even be bothered to finish the stale, dry breadcrumb of a main storyline anymore. Just play AC 2 and Brotherhood, or Black Flag.

Literally trash. Every mission is exactly the same. EXACTLY. Characters ALL look the same. Bland as fuck story line, almost doesn't exist. Trash cutscenes. Talk about bugs, holy shit is this game a buggy mess.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Probably the last "Assassin's Creed" game in the series. While the story and characters (especially the Frye twins) aren't the strongest we've come to experience so far, the gameplay loop is exceptionally addictive. Blackbox assassination missions in AC Syndicate are also a step-up from Unity, and stealth is actually pretty good too.

If you're experiencing performance issues, make sure the game is installed on SSD and set the [b]"ACSyndicate.exe"[/b] priority to [b]"Normal"[/b] from [b]Task Manager > Details[/b] menu. The graphics have held up quite well except the terrible LOD popping and lack of in-game anisotropic filtering. Fortunately, you can find plenty workarounds on the web for that.

This is a fun split on the AC series.   Different weapons (no swords), vast city that feels alive, great action set pieces.  You'll be in high speed chases enough times to get good at them, as well as fights on boats and trains.  

Changing between siblings is fun and easy, each having a different specialty.  

There's also... the zipline.  Game breaking? A bit yeah.  Absolutely amazing?  Yes.   

If you've enjoyed AC games so far, this won't dissapoint.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate was my first ac and i really enjoyed it there were some things i didn't like but a lot of things i did like. When i play a new AC i usually set this game as an expectation which could be a off since this game isn't really like any other AC i mean it has the parkour it has the stealth but it also has Area capturing like Just Cause 3 which i really liked because it means you can do other stuff besides main story and side missions. i'm going to list a couple of things i did and didn't like about Syndicate

Donts:

-Side Content, I didn't really get a chance to do side content but thats because i didnt see myself doing it, i saw it more a way to level up your loyalty with certain people there were interesting side mission like the World War I mission where you shoot down incoming planes or missions for the queen after you beat the game but i really wasn't interested in the side content of Syndicate

-Bounty Hunt, Bounty hunt was a real lowpoint for me, if you failed to it stealthy you get chased by 3 to 6 carriages even if the guy you're transporting is dead you get tons of enemies after you which i kinda get because they want there boss back but sometimes i got carriages after me even if i did it stealthy but i forgot to kill everyone 

-Ending, SPOILER ALERT i will be talking about the ending in this section and how i didnt really get it or like it. So it ends pretty poorly the whole time you're busy finding this "shroud" and in the end you dont even get it at least in unity you get the sword of eden but here someone gets fucking shot and thats it. The boss fight with starrick is a meh for me it just involves dodging some walls of idk electricity and fighting starrick with the pretty simple combat.

-Combat, So the combat isn't something i really dislike but it could've been better it has this combo meter but you only use left click so whats the combo? It comes down to enemy angry you attack enemy, enemy dead, There are some brutal finishers which are pretty cool and overall it can be satisfying if you use the kukuri (Knife, Just a big Crooked Knife) but there are other weapons like a stick with an hidden scythe and sword but i didn't feel as satisfying as the knife there are also brass knuckles but it just feels like hitting someone with your bare fists 

Likes:

-London, Victorian London has been presented really well showing poverty, child labor and that anyone would do something just to earn a penny. You can see really well where areas are poor and which areas are rich. Monuments and iconic buildings look beautifull such as westminster castle, Big ben just westminster itself looks really pretty.

-Main Story Missions, Unlike unity AC syndicate had pretty good story mission of course you had the "go kill this fellow" missions but they weren't as frequent as in unity which i really enjoyed they also seemed to fit really well with the story itself, if you're playing mission with evie it most likely had to do with the piece of eden whilst mission with jacob were more chaotic and less stealthy so you could really pick a side.

-Characters, Jacob and Evie Frye are in my opinion really likeable characters one is trying to rile up a gang to save london from the blighters and templars whilst the other is focusing on the mission to find the piece of eden, it feels like the actions jacob and evie frye do really impact the story for example jacob assassinates one of londons very important bankers almost crashing the economy, its pretty simple to see what kind of people jacob and evie, overal there is nice character development like evie falling in love and jacob becoming les chaotic. There also side characters like Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens and The Queen which are really nice to see even though they dont stick that long and after 2-3 Missions dissapear

-Stealth, this game has really good stealth, The Whistling is a nice feature to lure enemies instead of waiting for them to see you like in unity.

Overall i really like Assassin's Creed Syndicate it has a good story, good characters and a good enviroment

This must sound crazy, but I got into Syndicate after playing a fair bit of Odyssey and Origins.  I've had my fun with huge open-world maps brimming with quests, but Assassin's Creed was never meant to be that game. 

LONDON is just glorious and comes alive in a lot of ways. I'm still marveled by the trains that never stop running. And that you can plop yourself on top of one and get a jolly ride with a view. Fortunately, I experienced zero bugs. The graphics were a hoot with some really beautiful lighting at dawn and dusk. And I keep thinking, why do I need an entire map of Greece when I can have ONE well laid-out city with a lot of hidden surprises and monuments to explore. 

AC:Syndicate really harkens back to what I call the controlled independence. You still can go everywhere and start certain quests at random, but there's no way to "fail" a quest. The Animus kicks you out and puts you back to the last checkpoint. There are no choices to make, only a illusion of them. Well you can choose how you want to approach an assassination, but that's about it. 

At this point, the present-day story is pretty much a dud and is just there because I think Ubisoft doesn't think it can throw it away entirely. What started out as a nice framing device with Desmond is now in a rubble. I was hoping something interesting might happen at the end but to no avail. All in all, get it if you really miss the Assassin's Creed of yore. 

P.S. I can't be the only one to hate naval combat, so I didn't miss that at all here!!

Ok, so it's controversial.
On one hand, industrial London, brilliantly designed, so atmospheric and enjoyable. 
On the other hand, industrial London, grey or brown-ish.  Slightly depressing.
On one hand, 2 playable characters, Jacob and Evie Frye. Brother and sister, with different views, behavior, fighting styles, weapons.
On the other hand, they aren't much different, except for appearence and few perks that make Jacob a little bit tankier, and  Evie invisible while sheaking (balance? nah, never heard of it). Both can use any weapons and brawl in fight clubs (I sincerely doubt a woman would be allowed to fight in a boxing match back in the 19th century, but hey, screw real history, right?).
On one hand, immersive weapons: brass knuckles, walking canes, kukri (exotic, but still bih knives), pistols. I mean, someone would look awkward walking around 19th century London with claymore, broad axe, or a crossbow, right?
On the other hand,  brass knuckles, walking canes, kukri and pistols are all you get. They could have added police clubs, various knives or daggers, sabres, etc. Give more variety.
On one hand, I like RPGs, so I was excited when I saw character levelling.
On the other hand, it looks so dumb when an enemy easily tanks several headshots, because he's couple of levels above you.
On one hand, fights are fast and dynamic.
On the other hand, they're fast because each attack animation loosk like if it had 3 or 5 frames. They look terrible. Especially hand to hand combat in fight clubs. Ubisoft devinately saved money on animators.
On one hand, optional tasks aren't too annoying and I completed them to get 100% sync.
On the other hand, I completed optional tasks to entertain myself and make missions more challenging and interesting.
On one hand, I liked that Evie and Jacob's outfits are immersive and they put hoods on only when sneaking. Altair and Ezio stood out too much. They had no chance to blend with the crowd in their robes.
On the other hand, there isn't much variety in customizing their outfits. Shame.
On one hand, they added grappling hook!
On the other hand, it's so hard to properly aim this thing. If you thing it works as good as in Batman games, forget it. It's not totally unusable, but aiming is terrible.
Story...well, Evie is all serious "I mean business and do things right papa's daugher", Jacob is an idiot. Jacob breaks things, Evie fixes them. The antagonist Crawford Starrick is boring "I'm evil becuase I'm evil" cliche. He killed his goon, because he interrupted Crawford playing the piano. So evil, I shake in fear.
All in all, I liked the game and completed it several times. And it's the only AC that I completed 100%, but only because it's very easy.

If you're someone like me who for some godsforsaken reason still likes the Assassin's Creed games despite how formulaic and bad they can be, I'd definitely recommend this game. I got immediately drawn in by the victorian setting, ended up liking the characters, and the soundtrack by Austin Wintory blew me away; I still listen to it once in a blue moon on it's own because I like it that much.

My favorite addition that was added in the past game is how the assassination's work, which unfortunately was dropped after this game until IIRC the DLC stories of Valhalla. In this game and Unity, you are told to kill a target. You aren't given explicit instructions unless you want to get a unique cinematic kill, or give yourself more opportunities to use in the pursuit of how you want to take out the target.

Unfortunately I can't really divulge any more about the game because I only beat the main story and a lot of the base game's content over a year ago, and I only now started playing again to finish the Jack the Ripper DLC, which I ended up dropping before because of burnout from the main game. I had a LOT of fun during the moments of the game where you actually control Jack as he's off in pursuit of his goals; it made me feel half like Scarecrow and half like Michael Myers. The final story mission was a nice take on a boss, too, and that's as much as I'm going to say on it.

Overall, I really liked it. But at the same time, this is VERY MUCH an Ubisoft Assassin's Creed game. The last one using the original formula until Origins changed things to the current formula, with a parkour system I really liked, and (at least in my opinion,) a slightly interesting rpg/perk system that could have been ironed out more. Honestly wished there was more to the game after beating the one DLC.

8/10, would shoot, stab, and zipline my way through Victorian London again.

[quote]
I'm a True Assassin's Creed fan, Assassin's Creed 1 was my first game I played. I started playing this series from the very beginning of it. finished games one by one from AC 1 all the way to AC Odyssey, enjoyed every single one of them, the stories were great and i was obsessed with this game series, but when it came to AC Syndicate, I missed this title so i skipped it, not that I never gave it a try, I played it back then when it was freshly released, played for an hour or so, it just didn't feel right.

AC Syndicate was kinda strange, i had this feeling from the start, I really loved AC Unity which came before it and AC Origins which came after, but this odd ball, nah. with that said, now that i'm actually writing this review, I've finished the main story and conquered all the cities. even now, I still don't like it.

Why i don't like it? it's not the graphics, to be honest graphics and visual effects got a huge upgrade since the Unity. i think it's the location and possibilities in it. London or England as a whole is a boring place for Assassin's Creed games. the city conquering missions were so trivial and repetitive, at the last missions i was pretty much sick of them, just wanted to finish them, get the Uplay points and just be done with them.

the character were alright, I liked Evie more she was lowkey cute, but again they didn't feel like any thing we ever seen before, they were like disconnected from the whole series.

the ending was ridiculous though, very low effort part. specially when Evie and her brother were in turn thrown out of the fight just to counter those funny lethal rays from piece of eden and make their ways back to the fight, again and again this happened. and finally he was killed, just like any other person. 

even funnier than that was the part after this, when the cut scenes began and it came to the current time, there was a girl with Assassin's outfit and using hidden blades and smokes against guns! so funny. and again the game kept us in limbo, no information about current time activities, like who is that invisible woman (Goddess?) that talked to that officer! it wasn't something new. I remember such voice and Goddess back in AC brotherhood and later in AC 3 as well.

So yeah, I don't know about this one, can't recommend this to any Assassin's Creed fans, but you try it, maybe you like it.
	[/quote]

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ One of my favorite settings in the series

+ The city feels lively and all the moving pieces (carts, boats, etc.) create  fun obstacles and different ways to travel

+ I like the moving home base idea

+ Not an overwhelming amount of collectibles like some other games in  the series

+ Side activities were enjoyable and didn't feel like a grind

+ The twins made for interesting protagonists and I liked being able to play as both of them

+ Gang upgrade system was a nice bonus that makes you feel like your gang is really gaining territory


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Some graphical bugs and glitches

- Combat is too spammy and quick without a lot of impact

- Not enough weapon variety, each of the three weapon types feel very similar with the main differences being the finishing moves

- Combat is already easy because of the guard breaks and parry system; guns and throwing knives make it a joke

- Not a lot of enemy variation, and every enemy is dealt with in the same way

- Stealthing a mission is harder than killing everyone in the area

- Can't change between characters at will, it is story-driven

- Main plot felt weak and a bit disjointed

- Final boss was way too easy

- Gang upgrade system, again, makes the already easy combat system even easier by nerfing your enemies in disastrous ways (like making all of them spawn with less health???)


[h1]Summary[/h1]
Base game completed:  YES
DLC completed:  NO
Rating:  7.5 / 10 - Good

This was a tough one to review for me. Evie and Jacob are both amazing, and their interplay is very well written. The gameplay is solid, the mission design does what it needs to, on the face of it this is the best AC game by far. The problem is the bugs. Even setting aside the animation and control bugs that Assassin's Creed seems to think aren't something we should be bothered about, there are missions that can't be finished if you're in the wrong type of cart, horses will teleport into the air, things spawn in places they shouldn't, sound drops out of headphones, It's a shitshow of bad QA and it strains my conscience to recommend you buy it.

That said, Evie and Jacob are just such great characters that missing this would be a shame. If only there were a way to play the game without rewarding Ubisoft for their insulting bug (non)fixing practices...

This was not my first time playing Assassin's Creed Syndicate but this time I played the game a tiny bit slower and tried to get more it to the story. Character in the game were great I really liked the twin assassin's the two main protagonists and I really liked they both were the same and very different at the same time. The story itself though wasn't that good it was average at best. The free running was a tiny bit "janky" sometimes I had trouble starting free running but it wasn't a big deal. When it comes to graphics I was not able to play the game at max settings but this game looked worse than AC Unity. Human faces and building interior as well as lighting did not look as good as the previous game did. Another thing that I didn't really like and what I missed because it is an AC game is that you can't get out of the animus I always enjoyed in the previous games exploring the "real world" which you can't do here.
So this is how I'm going to rate the game.
Story -  6/10
Graphics - 7/10
Gameplay - 7/10
Characters - 8/10
Overall - 28/40
It was a decent game that I would recommend to get but still it doesn't come anywhere near Assassin's Creed 4 : Black Flag. If you are going to buy the game I would highly recommend getting - Jack the Ripper DLC.

I am playing this in 2022 , first time - just catching up with the games since I never owned a gaming PC. I heard a lot about this game , mostly negative stuff but I am personally a huge fan of Assassin's Creed series and did not want to miss this entry. Thankful that I did not. 
*SPOILERS* for late-comers like me 
I see it may not stand near the brotherhood and black flag entry but even if I do not want to I will still praise Ubisoft for Syndicate. 
I do not know how geographically/politically/historically correct they were in portraying london but whatever they did they did a good job.

There are a few sequences (6/7/8) where the story does not seem to connect very well. 

I did not like the little disputes between the fryes , Henry Greene just appears to be a very weak character and did not do justice for an Assassin. 

Jacob and Evie are fantastic protagonists and the other NPC like "Freddy", "Pearl","Maddox" are very well designed.

Villains are meh and some of them just feel like fillers to expand the overall story. 

Gameplay wise it is like any other Assassin's creed entry , good to see the grapple hook for easy traverse/escape between the buildings. 

I liked the Gang wars and Child liberation , although templar hunts and bounty hunts were repetitive. 

The game has a good balance between the 2 characters and you do not have to choose whom to level up , both have separate missions to allow them to fully unlock all the skills .

The ending was fantastic, although unlike previous games (except Unity I think)  you do not get to play the Abstergo events.

I also personally liked the World War 1 side mission but the Queen missions were absolutely unnecessary.

Overall happy with the story with little offtrack moments , some funny bugs here and there  ,and meh villains I would rate it a solid 7/10. 
Only Sad thing is I wont be able to see the Frye twins coming back again.

Loved this game. For a warning, I'm not a good gamer, or a gamer who will stick with a game and play it all the way through unless it pulls me in with its weird magic. Though this one was a thrill. I love the mechanic of the twins, how one is the aggressor and the other the typical sneaky assassin and how some mechanics were unlockable for one yet not the other. I like how there were skill (level) tiered places on the map, and how it affected how you played-though I am one for wandering around aimlessly sometimes and getting beat up for it. Still enjoyed every second of it. I love how the story makes you do those little things that are VERY important, yet also seem quite small. I like how there are gangs that you can beat or get beat up, it makes it more fun then just having the police that you have to watch out for. And I like how when you progress, you can have your gang buddies accompany you in beating up the other gang or other things, though unfortunately I didn't use the mechanic much with my first play-through, I'm planning on using it more in the future. I love the little bugs that it has, which makes it better and funny, at least in my opinion. Feeling like Spider-Man with the grapple-thing was a blast, going from building to building and climbing up quickly. 
Good game. Fun game. Interesting game. Different, for sure. I love the time, historically. Kind of feels like I understand it better. Thumbs-up from me.

Has to be the worst assassins creed game I have ever played. It has the most bugs I have ever seen in an AC game. The movement is scuffed, its glitchy, its not fluent. The combat is always the same and is ridiculously unbalanced in certain scenarios. The game is very inconsistent in actions. Ie. The mission where you need to knock out guards instead of killing them. I get caught, I run in a circle for 5 minutes to get around him, I do, I can't knock him out so I kill him. Restarts the game, I go back and hide in a hay bail. I come out and hold E to knock him out. It doesnt say E until the guard turns around and alerts everyone else.

The travel system is actually asinine. The train, the carts, the way points. The way points are buggy some of them dont work, the carts just ram into everything making everyone fight you. You always spawn on the train for a mission and then have to go 2000 meters waiting in the train or in a cart to get to the destination in a district which is 4 + levels than you.

The leveling system is actual garbage, you have to level up two people at a time which creates inconsistencies within the game. There is no efficient form of travel so you are going through high level boroughs while there level 8 people fighting you at level 3 simply for existing.

The amount of enemy gang members is complete asinine, you can't do anything without unrelated gang members in the streets rushing over into a restricted area. So then are stuck in a 1v10 situation.

I HIGHLY DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME. The only reason im going to continue playing it is because I bought it.

A good ac game, with nice scenes and story.  

The good aspects:
- The city of London is BEAUTIFUL. very well made, and pretty historically accurate. 
- the dual protagonist thing is great; you can play 2 very different assassins (they are twins) which gives many options to how you wanna finish a quest. Jacob is a brute and Evie is sneaky. 
- the gang thing is very clever. How you make yours bigger and the enemy weaker (both from fighting and from sabotage through traits). 
-The story is rich with many side quests and missions and public actions to keep you occupied for hours. 
-the level system is easy, and it's not purely about equipment as it was in Unity, but about missions and killings etc. 
-WW 1 travel was very clever, and well made aspect to the game (even though too small).
-stealth is MAJESTIC. public stealth, hiding assassinations, and generally the movement of the assassins are fantastic and smooth. 

the bad aspects:
-the combat is average. The moves are too hasty they seem mechanical. The executions are brutal BUT that highlighted shit around your target, even when you re finishing him off is PATHETIC. And i coudlnt find how to disable it (possibly you cant).
-the combo finisher is broken. Or it's random. Many times i had 2 3 enemies ready for a chain execution, but Jacob was fininishing them one by one...
-side missions, even though plenty, are BORING... all the same things again and again. Nothing special and nothing unique. But you meet many historical figures that "help" the assassins... Queen Victoria, Karl Marx,Graham Bell etc
-the district gang fights/side missions to control it are BORING... literally 4 types all over again and again. 1)Kill the target.2)kill group of enemies.3)save the kids. 4) kidnap enemy, and then kill the Boss of district to name it yours. Thats it. 
-you cant quite keep up with the story. How you met this lady/man? why im helping him? why hes helping me? How i found out about this enemy base? It is supposed london assassins to be LITERALLY helpless, as the story began with, but you end up having friends almost anywhere for no reason and unlimited resources FROM START...

All in all, it is a decent ac. it can become boring if you try to achieve 100%, but for sure it can keep you occupied for more that 25 hours and have great fun with it. Roaming London and killing enemies and saving people is great. 
7,5/10.

I thought this was supposed to be the great farewell to the "classic formula", but instead this is more of a parody of the series.

I've played every Ac before this one, I wanted to get back to the series because from what I've played from odyssey I really liked it, but didnt want to skip titles so picked back from Unity and now this one, and boy what a mistake that was...

Unity had an interesting story and character development almost as AC2, didn't encounter many bugs when I played that one, But it had a lot of issues gameplaywise...

However this one is a new low...

- Whats the story really? 
- If I play one character is because I wanted to play the whole game with that one.
- Horrible controls and gameplay, I mean this really came out the same year the witcher 3 and arkham knight did? wtf they didn't improve (or should I say fix?) almost anything from unity.
- You never feel that you are making something that matters, since there are very few mission templates and they repeat a lot.
- Every area feels very copy paste and even reusing a lot of assets from Unity, which makes little sense to me.

The only things it has almost going for, are:

= The setting, I guess, but is so much wasted potential the way is presented here, as if it were a saturday morning cartoon.
= Good visuals for screenshots (because in motion it breaks apart)
= A not so bad grapling hook that makes every other mechanic from AC, meaningless.

I know what comes after gets better so this is not a hard pass on the series.

My advice? Even if you are a fan, skip it. And even if you don't like the current formula (origins, odyssey and valhala) dont't submit yourself to this one on the basis that it has the "classic feel" whatever that is, or because of the overarching story on present day that usally ties the games up, there are 4 cutscenes that don't lead up to anything and you might better watch em on YT.

With the recent Ubisoft sales, I was able to pick this game up and finally play it for the first time (remember when they released Unity and it got so much bad PR that almost no one played Syndicate and Rogue?)

Maybe that's why I never played this game in the first place, but seeing how cheap the game is now, I decided to aaaaaaaaaaand it's good but not great!

Admittedly, it's not as good as Unity or Origins but it sure as hell isn't a bad game. It's also not a perfect AC game because it got really boring by the time I was near the ending. There were A LOT of repetitive missions and overtaking sections of the map can get really tedious.

The gang system is cool and all but the AI can get really dumb at times and can break immersion - especially when you're doing stealth missions and your gang just randomly attacks EVERY SINGLE ENEMY ON THE MAP.

What makes this game great is the fight sequences, although once you reach the max level, there's probably no enemy who could stop you, and you get overpowered REALLY FAST.

Character wise, there were a lot of lazy writing on Ubisoft's part when it came to making Jacob and Evie. I don't know if it's because I played so much of the side missions that the main storyline became a bit disconnected - but what is an open world game if going sideways breaks the main line. There were a lot of moments that I just went "Uhm, what?" especially with Evie which I will not spoil, but to those who have played this game know exactly what I'm talking about.

I guess the bottom line is that this is a good game but not the best. It's great for the price but it's just that kind of game where you go "meh" after 10 hours.

Assassins Creed Syndicate is an absolute masterpiece and that's my review in short. In dept this game simply took everything that Unity tried to broaden and perfected it in my opinion. The combat is in depth and the weapons and character customization is on par with Unity in many ways. I found that I needed to level Jacob and Evie in sync to deal with the growing enemy strength. If you do not provide them with the best gear and skills, fighting enemies and completing missions becomes somewhat of a challenge. This game has the replay-ability of Assassins Creed Black Flag since the game play is crisp and the story is gripping. Between meeting famous people in history or the humor generated by the sibling relationship of our protagonists this game has it all. It did not disappoint me in the slightest.

[b]The Pros:[/b] 
-The London setting looks and sounds great. Sometimes it's nice to just sit in a train and take in the scenery
-Solid parkour/stealth gameplay
-There is a nice territory progression system in place that you can work through at your own pace (the gang wars)
-Very convenient auto save system

[b]The Cons:[/b] 
-The characters are bland. Different characters show up, make a few quips, then disappear. Rinse and repeat. I don't care about any of these characters after 20 hrs of playtime, and couldn't provide a memorable quote from this game if my life depended on it
-The story is fragmented and there really isn't a sense of progression. You could mix up all the story beats and show them in a different order, and it's pretty much the same experience
-A host of new features make the gameplay way too easy. This game still has the parkour/stealth mechanics from the previous AC titles, but the addition of the things like the grappling hook sidesteps all of that and dumbs down the approach to stealth situations. The grappling hook itself feels fine, but is way too convenient of a tool for a game that still bases it's design around traditional AC mechanics
-Since the combat is so easy, there's no real risk, no reason for stealth beyond personal challenge. This breaks a few missions that are designed around using clever ways to reach the target (You can just walk in, kill a few enemies, then walk out with no consequence)
-Gameplay progression feels irrelevant. There's a whole system with skill trees, inventory upgrades, and gang upgrades, but honestly most of it is unnecessary since the gameplay never changes. It stays the same, it never evolves. You play one templar hunt, you've played them all. Easy to get open world fatigue
-The missions/sequences feel uninspired. Too many ways to cheese them, and conversely sometimes you can fail missions for obtuse reasons beyond your control. Also plenty of game-breaking bugs that require you to quit the game and come back to fix
-The previous AC games I've played are usually immersive in their historical setting, but I didn't get much of that with this one. Previous AC games would shed light on little nuggets of history and through playing you'd get to know more about historical figures, buildings, and moments etc, but you'll have to go out of your way to find that here
-The city is beautiful, but the game doesn't make an effort to make the locations unique so it's ultimately not very memorable

[b]Overall[/b], this game is a solid time waster if you want to shut your brain off and play something mindless without worrying about the game throwing a mental wrench at you. There isn't really much more beyond that though, and if you ask me for a recommendation for a game of this type, there are plenty of other similar games I'd recommend over this one. This is the weakest Assassin's Creed game I've played so far; I think the franchise made the right move to switch up their formula going forward.

Just try it. It's not for everyone, I know, but I am and have always been a fan of Victorian style games and art design. From Bloodborne to this, I just love it all. It's still a great game despite the slightly disappointing story but the characters are written fairly well, especially Crawford. Also, the completion process is just a smooth fun ride. For those who get 1000 helix credits just by completing the map, buy the helix glitch revealer, not the secrets of london. It'll save you lots of time. Last thing, the Arkham style combat is fucking great.

Taking place closest in history to us, the game takes place in Victorian England following the Frye twins and their goal of taking back control of London from Templar hands, following the assassination of Edward Kenway years earlier. Having a unique opportunity to play as two different people, switching from one to another in a matter of a second, the game gives us two different perspectives from the same side, one that abides by the Creed and follows in her father's footsteps focusing on the Piece of Eden, and the other swaying away from his sister's goal to take matters into his brawling hands by forming a gang to take down Templar lieutenants, crippling their control. Gang members act in the similar way as Assassin recruits did in some previous games, helping protagonists in a more direct way rather than from the shadows.
The twins give a fresh approach to the otherwise single main charater, each with their own views of the world and how to approach and solve certain problems. Evie is charming, eager to help, while Jacob just as charming is more playful in his approach, not taking himself or the problems around him too seriously, but fully aware they are.

Traversing London's 4 to 5-story buildings is made easier by the new gadget, the rope launcher, making reaching the tops of buildings a breeze, as well as quickly "hopping" from one rooftop to the next. Another new gadget is the introduction of the voltaic bomb which, similar to the smoke bomb, incapacitates enemies but also damages them as well.
A welcome return to the franchise are the whistle and for PC players a mouse wheel as a method for cycling through weapons, both having been removed in Unity, with takedown opportunities continuing in Syndicate. The looting of bodies also gets a boost, having been severely nerfed in Unity, giving more consumables and reducing the need to shop after or during missions.
There are 3 different weapon types to use, kukri, cane-swords & knuckles, offering 3 different styles of combat to pick from, as well as firearms and Assassin gauntlets. There are plenty of styles to acquire, some requiring crafting, each offering different stats, most notably belts for Jacob and capes for Evie offering defense and stealth points, and their various outfits stat boosts. The cost of weapons and outfits is in the realm of affordability, yet another welcome change from Unity, and making money to purchase them comes in the form of pubs' income that needs to be unlocked under gang upgrades, which is then easily picked up from the train's vault, as well as various side missions generously providing another income.

The hideout this time around is a moving train that circles the entire playable London area that can be easily boarded and disembarked at any moment, climbed on top for a more adventurous travelling experience and even sight see from within the train with an option to change camera angles and view London from unique perspectives.

Similar to Unity's helix glitches that take place in different time periods, one of Syndicate's optional memories takes place during World World I, taking place years after the events of the main game, the short story following Jacob's granddaughter Lydia helping Winston Churchill with the enemy threat on home soil.

Syndicate DLCs offer more in term of extra missions, weapons and outfits, one of which brings back murder mysteries from Unity while playfully introducing the creator of one of the most famous detectives in The Dreadful Crimes DLC.
Jack the Ripper DLCs however, gives us an Assassin's Creed's take on the famous serial killer that terrorized Victorian London, by offering a connection between the Assassins and the Ripper. Taking place 20 years after the main story we once again get to play as Evie as she returns to London looking for her brother after his disappearance, but getting to play a few short missions as the Ripper himself as well. His perspective is so unusually different, fitting perfectly with his maniacal persona, and playing as him satisfies that dark parts of ourselves we sometimes like to peer into. The DLC also introduces the fear element into the story and combat, and although fun to use and play around with, it somewhat defeats the purpose of being an Assassin if taking down enemies is not by assassinating them. It's a fun, innovative way of subduing enemies and an ideal tactic that should've only be used by the Ripper himself.

As the last true Assassin's Creed game in the franchise it's nostalgic looking back at how far the franchise has come, accomplishing so much by each new title, expanding on the gameplay mechanics and the connecting story from the very first to this last game. Syndicate is a strong addition to the rest of the titles that by the ending of the Ripper DLC creates a sense of sadness as we say goodbye to a long journey where we followed so many Assassins throughout the game's history that helped shape the world and its future, unsure if we'll ever get to take similar journeys again. Even the modern day part ends in the same vein, leaving us on a cliffhanger not knowing what the future will bring. Regardless of the changes waiting down the line we'll always be able to go back to 9 games that made us all Assassins by the end.

As someone who got into the AC universe with the new games such as Origins and Odyssey, I kept hearing people saying the older games were better and this game made me understand it. The old games feels more simulation-like, showing more of the AC universe and history without going into too much detail. It's just a simple game with full of nice enviroments, making me feel like I'm in London for real. The details on everything -even the stumble when you jump off a train- are just beyond great. The new fight and gameplay mechanics are a must have in every AC game yet there are none. I feel like a steampunk spiderman.

The setting did the hard carrying on this one for me, and the fact I got it at 75% off. Say what you like about Ubisoft's templated open-world design (and there's a lot to be said), but no one else can capture the "Hollywood-historical" aesthetic vibes the settings and particularly cities of its games exude, and they knock it out of the park with Victorian London. The fact this game was released almost 7 years ago and still looks as good as it does, is impressive.

As for the gameplay, you know the score. I'm not OCD enough to ever want to 100% one of these but its not to bad if you stick to the critical path. I play these games as side games when I want to kill some time, and in that respect, they're decent. That said, while the DLC are mainly alright, the Jack the Ripper DLC is the most janky, bug ridden, and content-thin release for an AC game I've experienced, next to King Washington for AC3. It's also a gigantic missed opportunity due to how they handle the eponumous murderer (i.e. it's comedically lame)

Fellas... I think I have a new favourite Assassin's Creed game...

Everything about this game hits right, they removed the tedious parts of Unity's combat (the tracking bullets), the parkour is the same but this time with a grappling hook WHICH IS SUCH A FUN GIMMICK, there isn't as much customisation as Unity but the outfits they have look SO COOL!

The main protagonists are my favourite so far (especially Jacob), almost every cutscene Jacob is such a mood with his sarcasm being one of the best things in the game, Evie being the more cunning twin still has her moments of witty humour throughout the story too.

Now let's get to the story, the story is one of the best yet. Throughout the entire game I was getting a mix of AC1, Brotherhood and Unity all mashed into one. Instead of liberating a single base which liberates the whole area like in Brotherhood, instead you only liberate small parts of each area with each base you destroy. This makes you feel like the main villain is as powerful and influential as they say. The assassin missions are like Unity mixed with AC1, you plan your own route to the target and kill them however you please, then once the deed is done you get that AC1 style memory corridor where the dying target talks to you before you swipe a feather on their blood to show the deed is done (this time it's a handkerchief). The main villain is great, he's actually really threatening unlike previous villains (like let's be real here, as good a Templar as Haytham was, he wasn't all that threatening). Some quests are absolutely great too, there's a lot of them that have the same vibe as the comedic Yakuza substories (such as Freddy's old lady disguises or that one mission where you escort the Prime Minister's wife to the most dangerous pub in London), despite how goofy these scenes are, it doesn't ruin the tone of the game at all as I'd rather this than serious characters void of any personality (ahem, Connor).

I see a lot of people say this game is one of the worst AC games and I mean it's kind of clear to me that those people are the same who thinks the series died after Revelations (which is what I thought thanks to the awful mess that was AC3 until I actually played Black Flag onwards).

I loved the grappling hook!  Aside from that, I loved being able to switch between the twin characters, and traveling all through London during an era that has captured my attention frequently in movies, books and history.  It was so much fun!
its the last true assassin's Creed

Well. The best so far, not all buggy like Unity does but surely the best so far. I think this will be my last AC Game unless they want to bring back the game mechanics of an "original" AC. Not copying the mechanics of Witcher.

This is just another, generic AC experience. I was thinking about how to rate this game and it was close to a thumb up, but eventually I realized there are plenty of better games, more worth spending your time on.
This title is worth playing only If you are a real fan of the franchise or you have no good games left to play.

The story line is meh, characters are not really memorable, but not terrible as well. In the beginning I prefered Evie, but after several hours I realized that she is the one arrogant, egocentric and looks down on her brother, it's just all packed in a soft skin and false smile. To me, Jacob is the one with a truly kind heart and interesting personality. 
Syndicate is easy to get into it, there is almost nothing new to learn If you are used to playing Assassin's games. Main quest line along with the side activities struggle to keep the player involved or at least not bored from time to time.
Possibility to fast travel during the missions was removed again. It's important to mention, because sometimes you need to travel a fucking kilometer to your destination. Ubisoft shows again how annoying it can be for no fucking reason at all.
Be aware of bugs that can occur during the gameplay - less than in Unity but more serious eg. disappearing target or a mission that can't be pushed further, forcing you to load the game.
Also more enemies spawning out of nowhere and a bit more scripted events than in Unity, which makes this title the the most annoying AC game after AC III.

About the good things. Dreadfull Crimes are a bit harder than Murder Mysteries from AC Unity and even more entertaining but hidden behind a paywall, because it's a separate DLC (not included in season pass).
Rope launcher is great in my opinion. Folks say that it killed climbing mechanics, but for me it's a very nice tool to make the gameplay faster and smoother and also adds some new possibilities to your approach.
London is a beautiful environment. It's a living, believable, dense city and it's a pleasure to spend time there. It's not so overwhelmingly packed with hundreds of icons, which was pretty disturbing in AC Unity.

I finished the game and all the DLC's as well and I was really tired and had enough of it for the last several hours. I definitely didn't feel that way in the previous AC games (except AC III). It usually was the further the better, but in this title the peak of my enjoyment was somewhere in the middle.
Generally AC Syndicate is a waste of time unless you enjoy generic AC missions, story lines and seek for some more of well known game design.

There was a time when Ubisoft was a good storyteller (excluding Assassin's Creed 3 for they crammed too much stuff into it) and I was a fan of the franchise. But after Black Flag, it became a disappointment as the storytelling getting more and more sloppy due to frequent releases: the plots range from boring to unbelievable; characterizing is minimal and tasteless; moral standard just goes wherever is convenient to the plot like a child play, as they just made the antagonists do bad stuff for no reason and didn‚Äôt even bother to justify all the killings and damage the protagonists did. 

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is the same in these regards. The story is boring and predictable, following an uninteresting structure of ‚Äúpicking out every minion and then the boss‚Äù. This time they tried to make two protagonists likeable with cocky personalities, but that didn‚Äôt pan out because of the bad writing and the negligible effort in actual characterizing. And I don‚Äôt even want to go into the moral discussion since it is so convenient like it is for pupils. In short, the story department is expectedly bad.

As for gameplay, it really is a good example of what is called ‚Äúfast food video game‚Äù: Ubisoft found some formulas that work, then just copied and pasted them to the entire game and even to other franchises. These gameplay are heavily repeated throughout the game and there is no meaningful story to keep them refreshed and interesting. As a result, it is fun at the beginning, but after some hours in you become very sick of it. 

Worse still, it is designed to be a long game deliberately and only some of the gameplay are interesting to begin with, among which are stealth and investigation. For investigation, it is mainly featured in Dreadful Crime DLC where you play detective to solve murders. It is fun and somewhat creative but eventually caused fatigue because this game has the problem of not knowing when is a good point to stop. For stealth, the game has some decent stealth levels I enjoyed, but these level designs were reused a lot. Additionally, stealth levels are generally quite short and straight-up combat tends to be the fastest and most efficient way to complete missions, making stealth kind of pointless and redundant.

Speaking of stealth, it is probably the most decent part of the game, and since Assassin's Creed games are categorized as stealth action games, stealth should be the core gameplay. However, you spend the majority of your time in this game doing all sorts of tedious and repetitive chores, not stealth. Therefore, I really think even the developer themselves didn‚Äôt figure out what sort of experience should the game provide, let alone know how to make it good. 

As for other aspects, this is a very glitchy game, some of which are straight-up game-breaking. The combat lacks lots of depth to be remotely interesting (basically just QTE). The control has the same kind of unresponsiveness that can trace back to the first Assassin's Creed in 2008, causing all sorts of unwanted action ‚Äì in my experience, 90% of mistakes I made is because the control decided to do funny things instead of following my input correctly. The environmental building is probably the only thing I am satisfied with and has never disappointed me since the first Assassin's Creed - Victoria London is beautiful and detailed. It is unfortunate that the only good it did is aesthetic and to show off to your non-gamer friends, and it comes with poor optimization.

This game may have a bit of charm to new gamers and those who didn‚Äôt play any Assassin's Creed games, but for more experienced players, it is very boring with all the stunts you have already seen, and I don‚Äôt think it is worth your time and money because from what I have seen, it is full of lazy and sloppy designs, like the developer didn‚Äôt even care about the final product and just wanted to push it out to the market to make some quick bucks. Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a lifeless game.

A game unfortunately prejudiced by its techinical problems on release represents, for me, one of the high points of the whole franchise. 

The story can get a bit holier than thou and some sequences can seem incongruously concluded to the characters benefit but it is still pretty slick and maintains urgency without becoming overwhelming. The plot, overall, is good but is not the game's main strength. 

The combat is excellent with plenty of sneaking and stabbing relieved by some moments of direct combat where you are still effective enough not to be embarrassed. Care and planning is rewarded without precluding players being able to just go in guns blazing. This makes the side activities a pleasure rather than the hassle they sometimes can be.

The setting is also a highpoint with an interesting and detailed environment that is both well inhabited and sparse enough not to be overwhelming. The game exploits the richness of the time and place without drowning itself in historical inanities.

I have also played the game twice before on PS4 and the PC version stands very well against it.

Overall Rating: 4/5
Good:
Conquering territories is a nice way to level up your character. It's a grind but fun and has a purpose. It also relates to the plot which is nice.
The grappling gun works well and let's you traverse the city quickly.
Stealth is a bit better than previous games and can be used as a tactic.
They story is light on but enjoyable, it doesn't take itself too seriously. If you are looking for realism you're gonna have a bad time as you'll be on jaunty side missions protecting Karl Marx and Charles Darwin.
What I did like about this one is the story progresses at a good pace and doesn't feel like it drags. You don't get stuck grinding just to complete a mission.

The Bad:
Still doesn't have a fully realised stealth system, enemies are eagle eyed and there's not much cover you can utilise. Seems like a no brainer for assassin's Creed to have better stealth because you are assassinating people more often than not.
Lacks non lethal weapons or easy ways to knock out enemies. Often you're just killing everyone and everything.
Combat is more arcade like with combos and multipliers. It's smoother but a bit too simplistic and button mashy. I would have preferred something more like in unity where you engage with the combat by dodging, parrying and striking instead of mashing attack and dodging occasionally.
Too many high powered guns later in the game which you can exploit with the data reload skill. After a while you just start shooting everything.
The main characters are ok but could have been fleshed out a bit more, not much depth here.

So here we have an AC game set in 19th Century London, the Victorian time period. The general gist of the game follows the usual formula of the AC games, huge map and you free various areas by killing bosses and uniting a rebellious group to take over.

As someone who's spent the last 10 years photographing London, written a photo guidebook  "Photographing London" and won awards for my London photography this is a dream come true! What makes this extra special for me as a born and bred Londoner is that my great great grandfather was a photographer around the time period this game is set! Being able to wander the same streets and several landmarks as I do now is an incredible treat, the changing light and the wonderful atmospheric conditions especially at night, the rain soaked streets are a treat for me these days in the game they are dream come true. I have commend the game designers on making this incredibly accurate, sure some liberties have been taken in certain places but for the most part it's a pretty damned accurate representation in terms of scale, of the streets of London. What I love most is able to see how the 19th Century London has changed compared today. 

Enough gushing! What about the game? We'll no real surprises, you basically pick fights, climb around the city, beat the bad guys, collect goodies and save the day! No real surprises, fairly standard AC gameplay formula. It's good fun making stealth kills undetected but the missions are mostly quite similar with a few mini missions here and there like stopping a runaway train or solving crimes. 

There are some bits that do grate. They've taken some liberties like mixing some well known historical people like Alexander Graham Bell and Charles Darwin. One thing I have to commend the makers is on the accents on the key characters, so much voiced dialogue from the main characters and some of it is witty and that extra effort really pays off. 

However there's the general population's dialogue....hmmm. There's this idea that everyone in London, especially from the 19th Century, all sound like extras from Mary Poppins! Some of the voice acting is OK but other things like the some of the women's voices from the Blighter's ( what's that name about?! ) are way too "Cor Blimey Guvnor!" and as a Londoner it's quite cringy at times to hear those Dick Van Dyke, Mary Poppins accents *shudder*!

I'm not normally much of a fan of the AC games, I liked Black Flag but this one really has grabbed me probably because I can relate more to the location as the city of my birth. Overall I have to say I love this game and I can forgive the repetitive nature of the boss missions for each area as the graphics and slick gameplay, amazing locations are just a joy to behold. 

Being able to sit atop Nelson's statue right at the top of the column in Trafalgar Sq, just amazing experience I never knew I'd ever get a chance to do in a video game when i first started gaming back in 1982!
