While this is undeniably an improvement over Assassin‚Äôs Creed Unity, it also suffers from being its direct successor. If Unity with all of its rather innovative approaches to gameplay and story alike, as well as its attempts to go back to the roots of the franchise in embracing the qualities that made Assassin‚Äôs Creed II such a good game, is seen as a general failure in the gaming world, then Syndicate can be seen as damage-reduction in response to that failure.

What this means is that I effectively feel like this game was streamlined to appeal to absolutely everyone. This is not necessarily a bad business practice and of course not unheard of amongst AAA titles, but Syndicate seems to have been sandblasted so thoroughly that the game‚Äôs potential character is effectively gone.


Stealth is optional for the vast majority of the game and the few times it is necessary barely poses any challenge. The same goes for parkour: Remember when you‚Äôd have to search for a way to climb some tower in the first Assassin‚Äôs Creeds for like five minutes? You get a grappling hook about two hours into the game now, which enables you to get to the top of Big Ben in like 5 seconds. Well, there goes your sense of achievement for those two disciplines.

The combat system doesn‚Äôt make up for that either. In a direct counteract to Unity‚Äôs challenging, yet flawed and slightly buggy combat system, Syndicate‚Äôs combat system went back to the easier combat systems of Unity‚Äôs predecessors but didn‚Äôt quite manage to replicate their appeal. Part of the reason why is the fact that they kept Unity‚Äôs level system, but replaced the rest of Unity‚Äôs combat system. The direct result of this is that you have to heavily rely on combo chains to beat stronger enemies if your equipment isn‚Äôt quite up to the task yet. That essentially results in having to stab an enemy like 30 times in the gut in rapid succession ‚Äì and no, that isn‚Äôt overkill, this is merely what‚Äôs necessary to take down some street mugger that just happened to have a ridiculous HP pool because he spawned in a high-level territory. Otherwise, these high-level enemies don‚Äôt stand out compared to their low-level counterparts ‚Äì they‚Äôre the same character model and use the same moves. The former scenario will be the case quite often as the equipment ends up being a bottleneck more often than your own skill, due to the generally low difficulty of the combat system.

Also, as this game plays in Victorian England you no longer get weapons like swords, spears, and axes. Instead, you get brass knuckles, kukris, and some weird dagger that‚Äôs hidden in a cane ‚Äìnone of which I enjoyed using, so I just ended up shooting everyone instead. That‚Äôs right, you also get guns, but they‚Äôre not nearly as fun as you might think at first ‚Äì for instance, they scale with the level system as well, just like the melee weapons, so headshots only count as a damage multiplier. This means you‚Äôll end up pumping several revolver rounds in some high-level enemies‚Äô bare head and he‚Äôll still walk away with merely a headache.


Now that‚Äôs the most important stuff concerning the gameplay, let‚Äôs get to the story. The story of Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate runs on a very simple rule: The quality of a character is inversely proportional to their importance in the story.

The two protagonists of the story are both awful characters, each in their own way. On the positive side, they deserve each other. Jacob is impulsive and easy to provoke, so he likes solving every problem with brute force. Due to this he‚Äôs also quite easy to manipulate, listens to barely anybody at all, and doesn‚Äôt even think about possible consequences before doing something. Evie on the other hand is unbearably arrogant and likes to berate anyone and everyone on what they should do and what they shouldn‚Äôt, including her brother Jacob. Besides that, she‚Äôs is confident in her abilities, to the point where she can‚Äôt imagine herself failing a task, but heavily judges others for doing so. Needless to say that the twins don‚Äôt get along during the entire game at all, and when they do it appears to be rather forced. Both of them also have a rather childish view of what they‚Äôre doing which only deteriorates their characters further ‚Äì the clich√© one-liners they utter throughout the game only reinforce this impression. Though the worst thing about all of these character flaws is that they barely ever face repercussions for them and even if so, then these repercussions are quickly forgotten and they learn nothing from it. This is especially true for Evie, as Jacob becomes a little calmer and more thoughtful over time. Evie remains mostly the same, as she only ever sees herself proven right in her demeanor throughout the story. This is also partly thanks to the fact that your sidekick and Evie‚Äôs primary love interest is an absolute doormat and virtually useless without her help. Compare both of these aspects to the story of Ezio and Edward overcoming their flaws and finding wisdom and a new meaning in live or former sidekicks like Yusuf and Adewale, who could easily hold their own against hordes of enemies and you‚Äôll find this game‚Äôs main cast to be rather lacking.

The Templar‚Äôs side doesn‚Äôt look any better, the grandmaster himself is more bland and generic than most of his subordinates, he doesn‚Äôt have any direct impact on the story until late in the game and you barely learn anything about him at all. He‚Äôs neither an overarching antagonist like the Borgia for example nor a cunning strategist controlling everything from the shadows like Torres. He doesn‚Äôt get a mysterious reveal like Germain either, he‚Äôs just kinda there and everybody knows it. Then you see him in person for the first time and he‚Äôs dead like five minutes later after the most boring boss-fight imaginable. Most of his subordinates are just doing their own thing as well, only a few of them are actually following a concrete scheme, and half of them are not even convinced Templars, but each of them still manages to be at least as interesting as their grandmaster.

So, due to the Frye twins doing everything their way and the Templars doing virtually the same the story also suffers. I often didn‚Äôt even remember what I did in the last chapter, as it had so little connection to the current one and no impact on the story or the characters whatsoever. Though, on the positive side of the character quality‚Äìimportance law that I stated; the side characters are quite good, and their quests also add to the atmosphere of the game.


Despite all of my criticism, this still isn‚Äôt a bad game, you can have quite a lot of fun with it ‚Äì just don‚Äôt expect too much. It‚Äôs good for killing some time, but don‚Äôt expect to remember much of the time you spend with it later.

just finished this game weeks ago.

Game environment, character model & design is superb. London is beautifully rendered in this game.
However there are several major flaws to this game that is worrying. 

1. The stronghold mission where u have to free and protect captured rooks...? This bugs me (and noticeably a lot of other people also). The rooks themselves screws you up by suddenly freeing themselves & joining the fight without being asked to. And guess what, they'll be dead afterwards.
2. Replaying memory error, in looping cycles. When you're replaying memories, too often you will get the looping death screen while loading. Cross your fingers and hopes it would load properly.
3. Some other randoms bugs/glitches (explosives suddenly going off while being PLACED on the ground)

I'd still put this game as a 'recommended' one, but needs to be cautious while playing it.

An often (unfairly) forgotten AC title. 

Awesome setting, smooth free-running, and the protagonists are great! 

Fighting can get a little tedious (having to hit people 20 or so times to kill) and once the story is done there's not a horrible amount to do, however what [i]is[/i] there is fun.

I think what killed this game at the time was it came at the same time as numerous complaints that AC was becoming too modern and gadget-y, however I think with the massive overcorrection of the recent three titles this game is a lovely throwback.
the light is terrible, I can not see anything

The main review was written at 50hrs / 45% progress, edited after I completed main game in a little under 100 hrs (I did some idling though to generate money, still not enough to buy / upgrade all gear) and standalone DLC Jack the Ripper that took me another 10-15 hours.

I am a huge AC brand fan and didn't miss a single game apart from Valhalla and Odyssey (which is next on my list). I grew up on rather depressing Altair story and lived through revered Ezio d'Auditore's life and yes, like many, this set a bar this brand is yet to reach again. AC3 was a shocking meh, Black Flag was probably 3rd best (although quite different), Unity was aight and Rogue was okay but a bit outdated by the time it got released. I also played Origins and that was - simply put - different. Obviously, this trend remained and AC is no longer the brand it used to be - whether it's influence of Witcher 3 or change in leadership at Ubisoft, I cannot say.. but it's fair to say that Syndicate is an epitaph (or epilogue if you like) to Assassin's Creed as we knew it.

And now finally to the game - how is it you may ask? Well, it's not as bad as I thought it would be. See, after terribly optimised Unity this game came up with a new feature - two heroes between whom you can freely choose (something I prefer over having to choose one permanently -> Odyssey). When I go back to dated reviews, claims were protagonists were boring / annoying and that game itself was pretty dull.

But no, these two new protagonists are not another Ratonhkake:ton (sorry for my spelling, lazy to google it and don't remember it that well). Yes, Jacob is a bit annoying with his rebelling nature at first, but Evie is sympathetic to me and I prefer to play for her during my free world wandering (this interestingly changed in the second half of the game where I switched and preferred Jacob). They both have their differences and they bicker a lot, something I wish I could change (just like when your parents are about to divorce and you cannot do anything but watch) but eventually all ends well to my satisfaction. Both of characters have slightly different skill trees you can fully unlock by the time you reach 50% of game (provided you collect treasures, do side activities and so on) and it makes you pretty bad ass early in the game.

Second new feature, which I personally enjoy since GTA: San Andreas times, are gangs of [strike]New York[/strike] London! Just like when you are liberating camps in Far Cry series and get random friendlies spawn around those territories, same was implemented here and I kinda like it. I don't like it to the point where I would have a gang follow me while I am ziplining through the city but they have their situational use and controlling 'rooks' is easy. 

These were big game changers for the brand but going forward in time, it was nothing in comparison to Origins. Now for the quick summary for those who don't like to read long sentences:

Pros: 
+ Industrial London
+ Two switchable protagonists
+ Gangs feature
+ Riding shotgun / stagecoaches!
+ Wide variety of historic figures (it's nothing new yet still entertaining)
+ Train base with memorabilias
+ Last 'true' Assassin's Creed
+ Less of Shaun and other "present" assassins (although you cannot escape them completely)
+ Boats and trains for you to travel on
+ Hook for slightly faster traversing through the city

Cons:
- Main story is slightly 'meh' and uninteresting
- additionally, the newest artifact from First Civ is BOOORING
- achievement for hitting 5k destructibles
- Jacob is occasionally really ignorant, their arguing is especially irritating mid-late game
- number of bugs and glitches including game breaking issues that were never fixed
- DLCs are atrocious, scenes do not trigger, bugs after bugs just terrible optimisation in comparison to main game
- Indian assassin Henry (sorry pal, you're lame)
- the fate of 'modern timeline' was never explained in following games, all the buildup since AC2 about Juno and sages was squashed in some comics - super FAIL
- WW1 timezone was too big and felt out of the place

Overall I can say that I have enjoyed playing this game (apart from seldom bugs) slightly more than I did Unity and I weep with a thought that from this point onwards, we'll just play poorly presented variation of Witcher 3 clones with typical Ubisoft features.


Ad: Jack the Ripper standalone DLC (will contain spoilers!)

This came up with a familiar territory in different colours (fall 1888) and a story about gruesome killer - Jack the Ripper. I have expected the return of investigative missions I so much enjoyed in Unity but nope, not at all. You get a lame-ass story about Jack being a former assassin who went nuts (I still don't understand what triggered his hatred for assassins when it was templars who killed his mother) and corrupted Rooks. You also get to play for him in a number of missions, something I have suffered through due to him being so annoying character. I'd rather play for Rodrigo Borgia or some other villain who had a bit of charisma!

Pros:
+ just about right in size and content
+ wide variety of side missions, including a number of new missions
+ limited option of gear, you are not flooded like you were in main game
+ economy is nonexistent, making gear upgrades super easy
+ investigative sections of main plot missions
+ Jacob survives

Cons: 
- You don't get to play for Jacob (which I intended to)
- Evie gets older and indian-ish but does not look the same!!
- Jack the Ripper character and his missions
- recycled dialogs,you often listen same lines / voice across - different missions
- recycled models (Arthur Weaversbrook is Benjamin Disraeli in a hat etc)
- what happened to Henry?? After marrying Evie, I'd expect him to come with his wife...
- still a large number of glitches (exploding stagecoaches, random resetting / insta-failing missions)
- absolutely atrocious fighting effects (Evie no longer kills, she stuns enemies with indian wristbands but no one bother to change animation for hidden blade fighting style)
- returning Rosetta Stone to rightful owners in Egypt in one side mission - what? Without English scientists we would know nothing what hieroglyphs are so bitch pls


As standalone DLCs go, Dead Kings was so much better!

Just finished this game, it was amazing!

I want to recommend playing all the main games in order of release date. I'll write more about the previous episodes below.

AC Syndicate was awesome. A great surprise, like AC Black Flag was a great surprise. I usually mostly focus on the main story, and not much on the side quests and stuff, but in Syndicate I completed a lot more optional content than usual. I put 51 hours into the game. I have not yet touch the post ending content. And I do not have the Jack the Ripper DLC. These would probably add another 10-20 hours.

Over 6 months ago I started with AC Unity because I wanted to learn more about the French revolution. I don't really care for the basic gameplay of stealth and killing, but I like the story and the historical context of all the AC games. Then I decided to start the AC series from the very beginning, so here are a few words about each game. Of course it's your choice whether you pick only a few of the AC games, but again I recommend playing them all, and in order.

For each game I'll list the main PROS and CONS, and mention the level of frustration I had. Some games are a bit glitchy, and the controls can be frustrating sometimes, where you're trying to run through the city chasing someone, and your character decide to hump a wall instead of running.

AC1: takes place around 1190 in Israel Palestine and Syria
PROS: A great way to start, the story is simple enough, and it's like an AC tutorial. Makes the later AC games a lot less confusing.
CONS: the game is a repetitive in the structure of its levels. It looks good for such an old game, but it's starting to show its age.
Frustration: low.

AC2: takes place in Italy in the late 1400's
PROS: Great story, charismatic characters. First of 3 games telling the story of Ezio. More content, richer game than AC1 by quite a lot, yet they did not add so much that the game became overwhelming. Really nice progression. Really cool to meet Da Vinci. Kinda cool to beat up the Pope...
CONS: also an old game.

AC Brotherhood: takes place mostly in Rome, Italy in the late 1400's
PROS: Great story, sequel to AC2, 2nd of 3 games telling the story of Ezio. Adds more content. Assassin recruits add a nice layer of gameplay.
CONS: also an old game. I think I found the ending a little weak and confusing.

AC Revelations: takes place in Turkey in the early 1500's
PROS: I loved the development of Ezio as he is older/more mature. I loved the connections to Altair (the hero of AC1).
CONS: it was a bit weird, not as attractive, to leave Italy for Turkey. The game felt darker, a little less exciting, in some way hard to describe.

Frustration: I remember the level of frustration going from low to medium in the AC2 trilogy, but I can't remember which game was better or worse.

AC3: takes place in the United States in the late 1700's
PROS: Still an old game, but the graphics are a step ahead of AC2. Great historical story. Interesting historical context.
CONS: Very glitchy. I think I had a game breaking glitch for the homestead content, which is optional but sounded interesting, and I didn't feel like going back or restarting the game to try and fix it. Some of the story/gameplay in the present time is plain stupid (ie. the level in Brazil, I found super lame).
Frustration: high.
I highly recommend buying AC Odyssey Gold Edition when it's on sale. It includes AC3 and AC Liberation, AC Odyssey and its DLC. Awesome deal.

AC3 DLC: Tyranny of King Washington: takes place in the United States in the late 1700's, in an alternate universe. It was ok, but feel free to skip, it doesn't add anything to the general AC story.

AC Liberation: takes place mostly in New Orleans, in the late 1700's, usually included with AC3, so don't buy it separately
PROS: different (female hero), short and simple but well made
CONS: I didn't care for the levels in the bayou
Frustration: medium

AC4 Black Flag: takes place in the Caribbeans in the early 1700's
PROS: awesome game, great surprise, being a pirate is actually very fun which I did not expect. Great graphics (even in 2021), makes you want to swim in the ocean.
CONS: can't think of any
Frustration: low

AC4 DLC: Freedom Cry: takes place in Haiti, in the early 1700's
PROS: story of a secondary character from Black Flag, taking place immediately after Black Flag. You liberate a lot of slaves (it felt weird that it's only when you play a black hero that you work hard to liberate slaves. In other AC games, you just express some sympathy and then you move on. I found it a bit uncomfortable, not in a bad way)
CONS: some dull moments, the story and the game were good, yet I did not feel grabbed like I was with Black Flag.

AC4 DLC: Aveline
PROS: none, sorry
CONS: super short story, they wanted to make people want to buy Liberation. Bad advertisement imho, because Aveline is a very empty DLC, while Liberation is actually a nice game. Feel free to skip this DLC. Does not add anything to the story.

AC Rogue: takes place in the United States and Quebec, in the late 1700's
PROS: good story in the sense that it connects a lot of dots between other games in the AC3 and AC4 series, and is a good lead into AC Unity. The ocean looks nice again, but very cold so it did not make me want to swim :)
CONS: Maybe it was the character(s), or maybe it's because this game had less new/original game mechanics compared to some other ACs, but I didn't feel as enthused by it.
Frustration: low/medium

AC Unity: takes place in Paris in the late 1700's
PROS: I loved visiting Paris during that time. A step up in the graphics from previous games.
CONS: a bit glitchy, sometimes felt too difficult for no good reason.
Frustration: medium

AC Unity DLC: Dead King (I think that's the name?), takes place right after Unity
PROS: satisfying weapon at the end. Nice to explore Saint Denis.
CONS: Same as Unity.
Frustration: medium

AC Syndicate: takes place in London in the late 1800's
PROS: polished, innovative, all around awesome game
CONS: none?
Frustration: very low

I‚Äôm pretty mixed on this one, on one hand, the story and combat are pretty weak and leave the game with a weak foundation that is plastered upon this gorgeous and super dense 1860s London with fun traversal, polished stealth, and a good amount of variety. The open world of London is one of the best in the series and is only slightly worse than Unity‚Äôs Paris simply because of the lack of interiors and it feels a bit smaller because of the new movement additions of the grappling hook and horse-drawn carriages. The combat, however, feels like a poor man‚Äôs Arkham combat and almost all of the improvements seen in Unity‚Äôs combat have been simplified to the point of insanity. I don‚Äôt know if I really like this game a lot but I think it is still a pretty solid entry in the series and a decent conclusion to the OG series I guess even though it could‚Äôve been a lot better.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Explore Victorian London 1868, during the industrial revolution; new mechanics such as carriage driving & rope launcher make exploration a lot more innovative & effective
    [*]Associate activities such as carriage races & fight clubs are short, enjoyable, & decently rewarding for side indulges outside story memories
    [*]"Rooks" are allies that can be recruited across London, once upgraded they become an fearsome force that can overpower almost any enemy group; they add new ways to approach both combat & stealth opportunities
    [*]Dreadful Crimes are the equivalent to AC Unity's Murder Mysteries, dreadful crimes are shorter & require less clue gathering however, they demand more intuition; also have very stylish visuals when in eagle vision
    [*]Explore a short sequence of events in World War 1 from 1914-1918 (Fun Fact: this sequence marks the final piece of main series Assassin's Creed content until Desmond's time period)
    [*][b]Frederick Abberline {Best Man}[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Every loading screen is approximately 30 seconds, fast-travelers beware!
    [*]The train hideout map icon should be more locatable on the map
    [*]No incentive to switch protagonists in the overworld, skill differences are almost negligible
    [*]Base game has many bugs, from de-sync loops when replaying memories to NPC's not progressing properly
    [*]Jack The Ripper has many bugs, massive FPS drops & activity objectives literally self-destructing on arrival; albeit extremely hilarious at times
    [*]Social glitches should not exist, if 9/10 appearances they make result in the ubisoft service not functioning correctly; they are a waste of space (literally)
[/list]

So I gave Syndicate a thumbs up, because I do really like this game for reasons that I will get into later. But, I have a big problem with this game, summarized in one word. GLITCHES.

1. When I first started the game, there was this blinding light. It was like walking into the sun. And then there were strange instances where I would enter a shadow, and it would be pitch black. This was completely unplayable, so I exited to desktop, and went back in. It was fixed, and it never happened again, but still.
2. Whenever I was on a fast vehicle, or there was just a lot of action, the game would stutter. Sort of like lagging.
3. Would sometimes freeze for about 5 seconds before resuming.
4. Sometimes just completely crashed to desktop.
5. Loading screens were absolute murder. I don't know if that can be considered as a glitch, but let's just say that you might want to pull up tic toc or something while you wait eons for it to load.
6. Textures wouldn't load quick enough.
7. A character model disappeared once, so there was just a floating book. (Kind of funny, but still.)
8. A character's dialogue would sometimes get cut off.
9. I sometimes couldn't fast travel.
10. Sometimes I couldn't attack.
11. I was escorting someone once, but they just randomly stopped moving. Had to reload objective.
12. I was tailing a carriage, and it got stuck. Had to reload objective.
13. There was this other time that's hard to explain. But still, I had to reload objective.
14. This one time, the game saved right before an essential character was shot. So when it kept reloading, that character would immediately get shot, and it was an endless loop. I don't even know how I fixed that one.
15. And on top of all that, the carriages drove on the wrong side of the road. ;)

This is just insane! I don't know how this can be the final product of something. And I'm sure there were other glitches waiting to happen that I just didn't discover. I have never seen this many bugs in any game ever.

But that being said, I finished the game. And if you pretend that those bugs don't exist, this is a really awesome game.

The setting is fantastic. It's set in old London, and it's a mix between steampunk and gothic culture. To be honest, I think I've discovered that steampunk and gothic are the best combination ever. The characters are great. You meet historical figures. The DLCs add some interesting stuff. It just a really interesting environment.

The gameplay was great. It has the Assassin's Creed touch, but it also has new mechanics. I think that this is the only game with the grappling hook, and let me tell you, that is fun. Building your gang can be strange at first, but you learn to like it. And I'll probably say this with every AC review, but YOU CAN CLIMB ANYTHING. That's just so cool.

So if there weren't the glitches, this might be in my top ten games of all time. But those glitches... [angry noises]. But, you can make it through the game. And maybe these won't happen to you, but I don't know. Just, keep what I've said into consideration.

The Victorian London setting for an Assassins creed game was a great idea, truly beautiful and it stays true to its historical roots. The two main characters are good in my opinion, Jacob Frye can seem pretty shallow however i feel he fits into the badass Assassin Dream really really well. This game is one of the best Assassin creed games in recent history, Its disappointing it was mostly overlooked. The Characters can often seem to overlook and set an off tone to the dark dark time of the Victorian Era; However i feel it fits fairly well, it is a nice contrast to it. Plus the dark moments of the game arent exactly too dark, Things most definitely couldve been done better but still, very good. The general combat of the game can feel button mashy but thats how its meant to be, the main point of the combat is to attack an enemy till another attacks and you must counter them and then you need to repeat until one either dies or blocks and then you just guard break. Fairly simple but it gets enjoyable when there are many enemies because of the amount of timing and precise reaction times you must have, it allows for an engaging combat style. However if you are looking for a more complex combat system it isnt here. The side content is generally good all around and leaves you wanting to do alot other than just the main story. Progressions feels good however maybe a bit too fast. 

TLDR Check out the game if you are into industrial revolution/victorian era london aesthetic and time period. Also for a good fair amount of side content thats interesting and a main story that will leave you plenty engaged. Get it on sale for under $15

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is the last of the *OG* AC games. In my opinion it is the weakest one in the series but it's still quite enjoyable which is something almost all Ubisoft games got going for them

TLDR: This game is a 6/10 for me and I'd recommend it only to a die hard AC fans and to anyone who want to experience London as a setting.

Now for the Pros: Victorian London looks great, it's gorgeous and well detailed overall. The rope launcher was a nice addition too. The game was decent enough customization (although less than unity) and most of the outfits look great on the characters. I did not experience any major bugs either. Recruiting gang members to infiltrate regions was also quite enjoyable. There are many tools in the game and the stealth aspect is quite strong.

Now for the Cons: The story is quite boring tbh, i never felt the need to know what would happen next. The protagonist Evie and Jacob Frye are just quite bad, Victorian London is a dark setting with child labour and poverty and people getting opressed but the Frye twins present this upbeat tone and act like clowns and the problem is.. their jokes don't really land. Its a weird choice overall. Also Evie and Jacob are pretty much the same, the only difference is at the end of the skill tree which you won't really unlock until the game is almost done which takes away from the point of having two different protagonist in the first place. The villain is a generic bad guy who wants to take over London and also wants the Shroud of Eden. The game looks graphically worse than Unity, the draw distance is super low due to an omnipresent fog, which also reduces performance, because if you remove the fog, you will get a performance boost and realize how bad the city looks at the far end. The combat is the worst I've ever seen, it's literally just button mashing and looks super cartoonish. The weapon types are pretty much none, there are some daggers, cane swords and knuckles. There's also a lack of proper animations and the whole game can start to feel a little repetitive. There are also 40 different side quests, which actually mean that there are 4, copy and pasted 10 times in different regions (cough *dunkey reviews* cough). The parkour is a huge step back from unity, in Unity where you could freely jump about and create cool paths, well now even with similar animation, Jacob lacks the agility, the game also just won't let you freely jump and will constantly try to hold our hands thus reducing player agency. The city although designed very well isn't one for parkour, the streets are super wide and you'd have to use the rope launcher which again being a cool gadget, just throws the parkour out of the windows and becomes a Batman game. The rope launcher also is just terribly under used, it would have been super cool to use it in combat and the kills could've been brutal, maybe even in stealth, even earlier games like Rogue have used rope darts to do similar stuff, why couldn't Syndicate do it too. The horse carriage are also just super weird to handle. The game also has super weird cutscenes in a few moments, and this is greatly magnified in the Last Maharaja DLC. Even GTA San Andreas, a game from 2004 had better cutscenes. The Season Pass of the game doesn't include all the DLCs. The game also has microtransactions.

Now for the DLCs: 
Do not buy the Last Maharaja DLC, its just terrible with the dumbest AI and some of the most terrible mission designs in the game. I'm an Indian and I still had no interest with this DLC. 
Jack The Ripper DLC however was quite enjoyable, its presents a more serious tone, there's a slight sense on mystery about Jack's Identity, the Fear Takedowns are really good, being able to play as Jack the Ripper was slightly unsettling cuz I don't really want to control a serial killer but it presented some good moments of the narrative. Jacob and Evie are also a lot older and wiser and not clowns anymore which was great. The Sherlock Holmes Series styled investigation sequences were also well made.
The Dreadful Crimes is the 3rd and final DLC for the game and *IS NOT* included in the season pass. This DLC goes further into the Sherlock type Investigations and tbh they are really interesting, its quite nice overall but the fact that it isn't in the season pass is still quite bad
The cosmetic items such as the outfits and stuff look nice, it depends on person to person if you like them, although almost all the outfits in the game look great

My contender for most underrated Assassin's Creed game. People were getting tired with the AC formula, which is why they ended up soft-rebooting the series in the next game, Origins. But anyone who skipped this game totally missed out. In many ways it's the pinnacle of the original formula.

The game starts with a bang, with IMO the most exciting intro sequence in the series (although Black Flag is also pretty awesome). Keeping pace with the industrial revolution, your assassin's kit is more powerful than ever‚Äîthe rope launcher lets you scale buildings even faster than you can descend‚Äîwhich gives a nice sense of ability progression to the overall series. The new abilities don't break the formula though, it's pretty much the same old gameplay you know and love.

Your hideout is on a moving train that travels the entire map. A freaking train! How cool is that? They didn't have to do that for the story or anything, it's really just for the cool factor. I can only imagine the poor programmers and how many bugs were discovered in the engine when you have a moving hideout.

The attention to detail is really good in this game. Case in point: horse-drawn wagons. Wagons in this series goes way back to ACII. Where they sucked. OK, maybe they weren't that bad, but they definitely felt clunky and the missions that had them were bottom tier. Wagons are in the next game after Syndicate too, Origins, where they also suck. You turn your control stick and the entire horse+wagon entity pivots on a dime. No sense of physics. But in this game, Syndicate, they actually took time to get it right. I mean, no one thinks GTA has realistic car handling, but it's close enough that you don't think about it in the moment, and I'd say the same is true for Syndicate.

In terms of historical roster, this game does not disappoint. Dickens, Darwn, Marx, Queen Victoria.

The gang system is a nice addition. It doesn't change all that much, but my favorite part is how it adds a more immediate sense of progression to taking over the map, since you now have buddies you can call in after you've taken over that part of town.

If there is one weakness of the game it's that the missions don't stand out when compared to the previous 8 game of the series. The hot air balloon chase of Unity. The Treasure Fleet of Black Flag. Castello Crasher of Brotherhood, etc.. It's not that the missions are bad‚Äîthe assassination of [spoiler]Dr. Elliotson[/spoiler] is quite memorable‚Äîjust that it's hard to stand out when the series has already done so much.


[h1]Personal Series Ranking[/h1]

Assassin's Creed II
Assassin's Creed Brotherhood
Assassin's Creed Syndicate
Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag
Assassin's Creed III
Assassin's Creed Revelations
Assassin's Creed Unity
Assassin's Creed Rogue
Assassin's Creed Liberation

That being said, I'll give a short review. 
The game is fun, I personally love the grappling hook although others would consider it cheating and a shortcut, theres still plenty of parkour to do and explore. Stealth feels same as Unity but polished without the multiplayer aspect, and it feels really rewarding when you put the extra time into collecting resources to upgrade and activities as well as practicing combat. The soundtrack, while I love classical, does not seem to fit most times in chase sequences or cutscenes or even the main part, the fighting. The writing is pretty bad, Evie is okay a bit bland at times but Jacob feels really forced to be the funny guy and attempts to make witty one liners we've all heard before. The characters and villians in this game are really forgettable and stereotyped hard core except for obviously the main 3 characters Henry, Evie and Jacob. I actually like Starrick since he was at least shown more than one sequence. Graphics are GORGEOUS. I love the lighting and everything is beautiful in London. Story is alright. Sometimes really great and interesting and sometimes bland and just feels forced with filler like your typical anime. So all in all, gameplay, graphics are really fun and eye candy. I love it. The writing, story, and soundtrack really hold this game back. I can't recommend this game at its retail price but ONLY when you find it on sale.

With Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate Ubisoft once again took a step back, this time also due to the badly rated (but still underrated) Unity. But was that really necessary?

Well, no. Performance issues aside, Unity was a great game with some real innovative elements (as far as Assassin‚Äôs Creed is concerned anyway) and gorgeous graphics. With Syndicate Ubisoft seemed to undo all of that, while also trying out some new things that would be used in the later sequels.
So gone were the beautiful graphics. Now they merely got the job done. Nothing groundbreaking, but at least it ran fine on most of the systems it released on.
Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate is by no means a terrible or uninspired game, unlike Rogue, but just a decent one that seems to things mostly by the numbers.

Gone is the extremely detailed city of Paris, instead making room for the more plain, but bigger and higher city of London. I‚Äôm indifferent to this one, but I prefer a more detailed and smaller city for sure.
Gone are the more open ways to assassinate a target with it now focusing on a more linear approach instead. Terrible choice.
What has been added are the two playable characters Jacob and Evie, each with their own set of skills. Jacob is more focused on direct combat while Evie is more focused on stealth. A very good addition to the series!
A rope launcher has been added to the arsenal for quick traveling upwards and/or getting in and out (but mostly out) of conflict quickly. Also a good addition as it takes away some unnecessary or unwanted climbing; sometimes you just don‚Äôt feel like climbing up, especially with the higher buildings in London.
There are now gang territories that can be conquered. A fun addition that also fits the city of London, but not a very novel one.
Combat has been a little sped up and there are some other small, new features and changes. I think I‚Äôve discussed the most noteworthy ones, but feel free to let me know if I missed out on important stuff.

Multiplayer hasn‚Äôt returned, but we didn‚Äôt expect it to. Co-op has also been removed instead focusing solely on the single player portion. A weird choice since a 2 player campaign co-op would be ideal. And especially now that you have two entirely different characters to play with.

Ubisoft has never managed to match the graphics of Unity ever again. Instead they opted for a style that would run on most of the systems, thereby steadily increasing the userbase I assume. The graphics absolutely suffice. London is a nice place to play in, but it was a little too dark for my own taste. I can‚Äôt really remember seeing any or a lot of sunshine. However, the animations and details of the buildings and environments were as beautiful as all of the other entries in the franchise.
Voice acting, music and effects were also strong as ever.

Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate would be the last Assassin‚Äôs Creed game to do it by the numbers. This was a decent game, with a good story and a few innovations, but nothing that would blow your mind. I personally experienced it as a step back when compared to Unity.
Anyway, following this game would be a new take on the series and it would return two years later instead of the usual annual releases. Its name: Assassin‚Äôs Creed Origins. See you next time!

Side note, I say this is the best because Black Flag, while a fantastic game, and probably better in some aspects, it didn't feel like an "Assassin's Creed" Game, the same goes for Origins.

I also recommend getting the season pass, as some of the gear you get not only looks amazing, can you give you a nice boost so you can more easily slay Blighter and Templar scum. The Jack the Ripper expansion is also incredible, and the Last Maharaja expansion, while not terrible, isn't great either, I think it's main selling point is the O.P Knife you get for finishing it. Finally, the Dreadful crimes pack is also fun, combine that with Jacob's Sherlock-like outfit, and you'll be having hours worth of fun.

This game improves upon everything Unity failed to do. Some might argue that the combat is too easy, I don‚Äôt see it that way, the combat is very quick and you have to time your movements very precisely. I don‚Äôt like that the story is divided between two protagonists and you have to upgrade them individually, with the same exact perks, makes you feel like you‚Äôre repeating the story. As for the story, I don‚Äôt find it that engaging so it is weak in that regard. As for the assassinations I feel this game perfects them, allowing multiple different ways to carry out story driven assassinations. The game is fun however the story is lacking, I recommend this game to those that enjoy the gameplay of AC but not so much the story. The music and environment are both stellar and cruising around Victorian London is very fun. All in all a good game, I give it a solid 8.5/ 10 (There is a weird glitch where Evie and Jacob‚Äôs clothing are locked to 30fps but luckily there are tutorials online of how to set it to 60, once fixed it looks great but something to keep in mind)
gwapo

STORY

Relatively short for an Assassin's Creed game of such scales - London has to be one of the biggest locations in the entire series (before Origins, Odyssey and Valhalla), yet the story is too short for it. Starrick isn't as charismatic as other main antagonists of the series (compared to Germain and Haytham), and in this one we're playing as already trained assassins. Nonetheless, both Jacob and Evie have interesting personalities, and even if they have barely any character development, they're still interesting to play as and I didn't skip a single cutscene with them. The most boring character, unfortunately, has to be Henry. He's just... there.

WORLD

As I said, London is one of the biggest maps that Assassins ever Creeded. And it's interesting to traverse around it, I found myself just looking at the character walking around at a slow pace, or some dafties playing cricket in the backyard. London feels alive thanks to all the carriages and trains. And surprisingly, every region has its own taste to it. 

GAMEPLAY

Yes, ranking system exists. And yes, it works as a really good way of implementing difficulty. It's up to you if you want to make the game easier or keep it purposefully harder. Nonetheless, you still insta-kill if you use the hidden blade.
I've got no beef with Ubisoft Towers and I honestly wish they kept this gimmick, it really shows what you can do in the world and where you can go. 

COMBAT

Different weapons! Bet we won't see that again. 
For real, it's nice to see an assassin wield something other than a sword for once, and each weapon has its use. Throwing knives are still nice, but the lack of sleep darts makes the game a bit more difficult. Pistols are great for open combat. The combo system is also a nice touch, especially combined with some of the skills from the tree.

SOUND

The sound design is great. My only issue is the soundtrack itself - it's easily the weakest one on the series. Too much quick strings, mostly without any other instruments on the background. An interesting touch, but not fitting for Assassin's Creed game.

TECHNICAL

Surprisingly well-polished, compared to the previous game in the series. Granted, it still has some signature Ubisoft bugs related to NPC generation, but other than that - it's as smooth as an Ubisoft game can get.

CONCLUSION

Buy it when it's on discount. If you want to spend some free time walking around Victorian London - the game's for you.

[b]Overall- 7.5/10
Story-7/10
Gameplay-8.5/10
Graphics-8/10[/b]


[h1]Highlights-[/h1]

[b]A lived in world-[/b] I never got tired of observing NPCs, anywhere you stop you can listen in to random conversations. Got to see people playing cricket, bullying each other, conspiring, making sculptures and all kind of things. It's funny to see them react.

[b]Skill Tree-[/b] There is enough hints of upcoming AC games in the syndicate- Levelling up was fun as the skill tree implemented is good. Also, I really enjoyed clearing clearing map. 
Combat is easy since just spamming Parry key is enough, it was enjoyable.

[b]Jacob/Evie switch-[/b] Loved it. With the well implemented skill tree you get to make two characters side by side- Evie for stealth and Jacob for when you want to act first and think later. Aside from gameplay I liked how the duo was used in story as well.

[b]Grappling/Modes of travel-[/b] I liked London more than Paris, roads are often wide hence the need of grappling hook. Grappling also makes climbing a whole lot faster which I enjoyed. There are other modes of travel as well- carriages, trains and boats. Crossing Thames by hopping across boats is just so much fun.

[b]True Assassin's creed-[/b] It continues on with Unity's concept of various ways to do assassination- opportunities/assists. It's quite fun.

Assassin's Creed has been a series that has had it's up's and downs especially with it's storytelling. Syndicate is definitely an example of weird storytelling because half the time I don't even know whats going on. All I know is you play as a pair of twins in Victorian London fighting off Templar's disguised as a street gang. I will say I get a lot of Gangs of New York vibes from the overall presentation and even though the twins are designed in a way that makes them stand out they both play almost the exact same. I will say Evie Frye definitely feels like she is the main protagonist and her brother Jacob is along for the ride and I say that since spoilers Evie holds the assassin ideals in high regard and Jacob really could care less. But overall combat is really good and where they "innovate" definitely stands out as unique even if some of those ideas water down what could be either challenging combat or the now trademarked free running.

Syndicate is a very unique, and fun game, that varies a bit differently from what other AC Games follow. The fact that they used two different characters and blended them together was something that was uncommon for AC, and it turned out to be just what the game needed. The way they blended Evie and Jacob is great, it shows the contrast in personality and gives them different play styles, but also allows them to work together perfectly, suiting what ever play style you want, for EX: Jacob is more of a aggressive get into the fight and blow things up, Evie is more of a stealthy Assassin. To this day I still play the game for side quest activities and to ride carriages around and zip line across roofs. It was truly brilliant how they made the game. If they hadn't of added Evie and Jacob and all the new gadgets the game would of been too much like Unity. But, they didn't and that made the game truly unique and one of my favorite AC games.

[h1] Things I liked [/h1]
-Stunning graphics
-Beautiful rendition of victorian London to traverse - the environments are very visually detailed and they picked a great setting for this game.
-Satisfying and engaging parkour
-Badass-looking outfits and combat animations
-A pretty fun combat system that lets you pull off cool things like multi-finishers.

[h1] Things I disliked [/h1]
-A boring story and protagonists with almost no personality. There characters consist of the "rule follower" sibling and the "rule breaker" sibling, and all of their conflict stems from that. The villain also has no personality other than being really evil and doing a lot of messed up things to show you how evil he is.
-If unity was AC 5, then this game is AC 5.5. Very little was done to improve upon the gameplay of the previous titles besides adding a few gimmicks like a grappling hook and character switching. Virtually every mechanic in this game besides the combat is identical to Unity.
-Arbitrary level gating that serves [b]no[/b] purpose other than to artificially stretch out your playtime. The higher level zones aren't meaningfully different than the lower level zones. They have the same kinds of environments, the same kinds of enemies, and the same side content. The only difference is enemy level. Oh and big surprise, you can buy level boosts with real money, because everybody loves buying a game and then paying even more money to skip of the redundant parts that were put there on purpose. 
-Side content is extremely repetitive and copy-pasted. There's like 5 different types of missions, which are mostly the same thing (kill a guy) but with different steps. All of the enemies use the exact same 3 character models. If it weren't for the quality and beauty of environment, playing this game would feel like a chore after a few hours of playtime.

[h1] Final Score: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ [/h1]
This game is not all bad, but it really feels like it doesn't need to exist. It's not a meaningful step forward for the franchise and feels more like a proof of concept than an actual game. If you're looking for a similar but more complete experience, I recommend Unity. I give it 2 out of 5 stars.

Well, Assassin's Creed Syndicate is an Assassin's Creed game, with everything it implies in great settings and totally assisted but still frustratingly imprecise gameplay.
So I won't do a review of every Assassin's Creed game here and will just focus on the particularities of Syndicate.

As I had played Unity less than one year before, I feared I'd be too fed up with the formula to really enjoy Syndicate. Curiously, I did.

At first, it seemed far too similar to Unity, but in industrial London, which was dark and poor, and globaly less appealing. And the streets being broader and the buildings taller, the free-running took even more time than in Unity.
Then I unlocked the grappling hook.
It's incredible how a very simple gameplay device that lets you skip the more bothering aspects can change a game.

Basically, it's still AC, but faster. And here, faster rhymes with better.
We're back to a Brotherhood-style city with similar activities all around that lets you free the different boroughs. Yes, the activities lack diveristy, but they're really quick to play and so far less bothersome.
And actually, I found the gameplay more varied than usual. You still have the fights and the free-running and the stealth, but you now also have carriage pursuits, carriage fights, and kidnapping (which feels a lot like stealth, but still different).
For once since a very long time, I didn't feel like there were too many things to do (ok, maybe a bit, but not so much).

Story-wise, there's not much, but the characters are fun. Having two heroes to play doesn't add anything to the gameplay, but it creates a cool and original dynamics with funny dialogues. It feels far better that the usual super-human main character that does everything all by himself.
And for once, we see that assassinations actually have consequences, and though it's always easily fixed, it felt like a nice change.

Suddenly, Ubisoft tries to make themselves pass for feminists. Which is a big fail since victorian London was one of the most sexist time and having women in pants walk the street without raising eyebrows from the passerbys feel like a missed opportunity. Plus it's absolutely obvious that Evie was added as a playable character as an afterthought. At least, they didn't screw up her character.

Like the gameplay, but it's too repetitive like the older Assassin Creed games.

My hours played reflect time spent while online only. Not the amount of time spent playing this game through 2 deployments and on two separate devices. This game is perfect. It was the first to bring in a female assassin, and the premise behind the utilization of character approach. You can actively swap between the Frye twins depending on what approach you prefer. A token to ts elements, the game plays like the older premise of leveled zones with an open world and linear story.  It added a unique method of upgrades, additions, and abilities that are a first for an AC game and was the first game to really trim the fat on the modern day lore (which I personally have always found rather boring).

Regarding ACS, I would recommend it fully. It's narrative is fun, it's gameplay unique, and the London street gang is such a surprising dynamic for AC but makes so much sense and they tied it in so well. I love the era, the feel of the game, the story... it's incredible. I wont mention the Jack the Ripper DLC... no one should.. Leave that one out for its bugs, audio issues, and whatnot but everything else... perfect. Truly. I strongly recommend this game.

Great Game, set in industrial revolution era Britain. Eve and Jacob have wonderful character development, the brother and sister rivalry really adds to the immersion and really sucks you in. The side characters of Mr Green, Mr Signh, etc are well built. The environment is a lovely and well built art piece. The side quests have interesting historical figures to spearhead them and keep you thirsty for more. Weapon and equipment progression is well paced those who grind hard early will reap the rewards of a very easy play through no matter the difficulty. As a history geek myself absolutely love the Assassins Creed Series I have since AC 1 this review is a touch biased and I realise that Ubisoft as a company is not perfect but by viewing them as two separate enitities I am able to enjoy the series and strive to help the company become as good as their work is.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is quite simply the most disappointing Assassins Creed game in the series, and for quite a few reasons. While the visuals are good and the setting within a huge industrious city is impressive, this game falls short in every other way of any previous game. Graphics and controls are better in unity. Story is better in literally any previous game. Weapons and combat are better in all the other games. Vehicles are terrible. Skills and levels are pointless and the gang system is incredibly expensive. This game feels more like a 'Beat 'em up' than an Assassins Creed game, and it is by far the biggest let down.
The Story is terrible - if there even was a story. You play as Jacob and Evie Frye, as they embark on a mission to track down a Precursor Artifact and free London from the Templars. That's it. For 18 hours. You accomplish this by playing many side missions and going on as many wild goose chases as possible, making gameplay incredibly boring. The area takeover missions are dull and repetitive, and in the end pointless. In the end the two characters run off into the distance and it feels like you haven't actually experienced a story at all... was  the whole story just a prologue? Sure felt like it. And the Characters have no development at all. Jacob stays a brash, thoughtless kid who runs around doing whatever he wants, and just feels empty, while Evie is always the caring one but never learns to take action sometimes.
Graphics are nice, but honestly feel like a downgrade from Unity. While London is much larger and far more dense, the cost of losing these visuals just don't seem worth it.
Gameplay has been massively simplified to the point where the game baby-feeds you all sorts of new gadgets and skills that you'll never end up using. The points-based skill system is interesting as it actually lets you develop as a player, but can be annoying if you just want to level up but placed the wrong points in another area. Combat is the worst it has ever been. Sure it changed in Unity, but this is ridiculous. The game has become more of a 'Punching Sim', where I can stab someone 6 times and they still somehow have enough willpower and blood to counter and and defend themselves? Yeah sure, thanks Ubisoft.
Overall, Assassins Creed Syndicate feels like its supposed to be a different game, with completely new combat and a bizarre story that feels like it was mangled just to fit the Assassins Creed overall story. The one good part of this game is the grapple. My god, it made the whole game at least enjoyable for climbing. To bad they downgraded the parcour system they perfected in Unity to make climbing buildings without the grapple pure pain.
Assassin's Creed Syndicate gets a 2/10.

[h1] Assassin's Creed Syndicate [/h1]
Assassin's Creed Syndicate is the last installment of the Assassin's Creed franchise were the franchise follows it's classic Assassin's game feel. The game is very similar to Unity in many ways but unfortunately for me it is somewhat like a reskin of Unity with some slightly downgrades. 

Syndicate has basically the same parkour as Unity but it is somewhat slower and less fluid. I especially don't like that they changed the leap of faith control. The combat has become more simple and therefore less engaging. The gear system is also somewhat downgraded. On the plus side I do think that being able to switch between two characters were one is specialised in stealth and the other is specialised in combat is quite interesting. I enjoy that in Syndicate you get a skill tree that enhances your assassin's skill progression and that you get different approach methods in some missions. The murder mysteries are a bit more interactive.The main story is not the best one out there but its okay. The map, London is well constructed but it does not feel as alive as Unity's Paris. Neither does the graphics look as good. But honestly it makes this game a sort of AC game were for me it's neither a wonderful or horrible experience to play. 

My only complains that really bothers me is the absurd task that are needed to get all the perks Also the good old hidden treasure chest where some chest will not appear on the map unless you are near them made 100% completion somewhat harder. 

7/10

[h1] DLC: Jack The Ripper [/h1]
The story in Jack The Ripper DLC is somewhat interesting but playing as the Ripper is what shocked me the most. I really liked when I played as the Ripper because it felt somewhat different to the base game. I wouldn't say that the DLC is amazing but it was a nice change.

6.9/10

As someone who has played almost all of the mainline AC titles (except Unity), this was the most polarizing entry I have played so far. On the one hand, there are times where I get sucked into the world and get that classic assassin experience: stealthily taking out targets, exploring the secrets of the world, and bringing justice in the way only an assassin can. On the other hand, there are plenty of times when something would go wrong: usually either the free run mechanics would not work properly, or the graphics would glitch out and obscure my line of sight. 

Speaking of which, it was hard to tell which graphical problems were caused by the game itself (having come off the heels of Unity, I don't know how much was fixed for this game) and how much of it was the fact that I could only run the game on the lowest possible settings. Either way, there have been a lot of cases where the errors have blocked my view and I have to either navigate by the mini map or stumble forward blindly and hope I don't get spotted. Some missions were fine, while others had glitches galore; it felt like a matter of luck. The frame rate would also slow down significantly, causing most cutscenes to stagger the voice lines with their lip movement.

With those issues out of the way, I have still enjoyed the game. The setting is excellent, the missions are the right amount of challenge, and the characters work off of each other fairly well. The line launcher is an invaluable tool for navigating London rooftops, though I have not found a way to do a Leap of Faith off of one (needed for a side quest). I also really liked the weapon choices in this game; a cane sword is just the sort of tool that an assassin would use, particularly in this era of dapper dressers on the streets.

If you are not already a fan of Assassin's Creed, I do not recommend this as your first title; with the extra content to find, it can be overwhelming to newcomers.

If you are a fan of the series, and you have a gaming PC that can handle this beyond the minimum settings, give this a go. I can certainly agree that it feels like the last AC game that takes stealth seriously.

If you are a fan, but do not have a high quality gaming PC, I would recommend finding a console version. This is a good entry for fans of the series, but running it on minimum settings creates too many hassles.

I say, AC Syndicate is just a minor upgrade of AC Unity. Compared to AC Unity, you can upgrade more in AC Syndicate (you'll know it during the game through). Skills system slightly improved, investigations are much fun to play with since, most if not all, of the crime scene is 'based' on true or documented stories. And this has much more interesting DLC compared to the boring one in AC Unity. But then again, this isn't comparable to AC Origins and later franchises. But I would say this is the last 'Assassin' game in franchise history.  

But overall, you'll still enjoy this one if you're a fan of history and stealth and puzzle game. You'll definitely also love the Frye twins!

Being able to incorporate some relatively modern technology, manage a gang to take back London, and the two protagonist approach to the main story made Assassin's Creed Syndicate one of the better games in the franchise for me. 

There are definitely some issues with stealth mechanics (like every AC game) and some question marks around the decision making for the ending but outside of those two (somewhat bigger) issues Syndicate manages to be one of my favorites in the series.

The Last Asssassin's Creed game that feels like an Assassin's Creed game.

It seems really nicely optimized! Looks great even on non-powerhouse PC. 
This is basically Assassin's Creed Unity + 
Same sprightly and fun parkour, same emphasis on action as much as stealth but stealth is NOT forgotten like in later games. You've got some customization for two different characters you can swap any time you want and they both have a shared treasury but their own skill sets and inventory. 
Intentionally Unity had an emphasis on grace in combat and Syndicate focuses on more of a brawl style with much more involved fights sometimes encompassing multiple gangs. The fun is the focus: more sneaking around and less SLOWLY walking through unskippable cutscenes. 

This game went all in on goofiness with mad scientists mustache twirling baddies, but that works for a series that started out pretty far-fetched and only looks worse when it tries to focus on the 'story' which doesn't make much moral or logical sense (Templars and Assassins are basically just two cadres of murderous cultists at this point). Instead Syndicate focuses more on the adventuresome characters, historical encounters, and outlandish scenarios and this works much better. 

I had a couple visual hiccups (T-poses and clipping errors) but no crashes. I greatly appreciate to option to 'free run down' which Unity did not have so that the Frye twins can vault down from rootops much faster and more efficiently with very few hang ups on architecture. 

The over all tone is simplified. When you get the grapnel any traversal is a breeze. Seems like less an emphasis on finding sync points as much as treasure which gives you less money that before but it does make for a slower and steadier sense of progression than being tossed a thousand gold right off the bat. 

Overall, a nice atmospheric romp!

As a fan up to Unity and ultimately turned off the series from that title, I hesitated on this game for a long time. That was in error. This is a much better game than the previous title and feels more like a traditional Assassin's Creed game even if it does feel smaller and shorter than the mainline numbered titles.

Things I like - 
Parkour has been improved but not fixed compared to the previous game where Arno felt like controlling a drunk the character controls in this game feel tighter. Perhaps a bit too tight as I found the 
 player character constantly stopping at the edge of a jump when I would want them to continue by jumping across the traversable gaps. Still, it's not bad.
Carriages - The carriages added a much needed break from running along the ground or parkour and they feel pretty good to drive but the area of London in the game is a bit too small.
The wire - Like Batman, the game adds a wire launcher for quick climbs and quick traversal across rooftops. There were parts when I felt that it would do things that I didn't want to like shoot me up a place instead of across a street, mostly when I was in a hurry, but it works well enough.
Removal of multiplayer - Thank you, that was a failed experiment that most of the time added nothing but frustration with missions designed for multiple people and AI that honestly didn't know how to handle it.
Unique assassinations - More unique assassinations are a great addition and something that I felt was under used in the previous game.
Music - The music and the way it's integrated into the game is amazing. I know it's very subjective but I loved that the music changed whenever you got high up. Combat music was also not grating.
The Thames - Playing Frogger with the ships and barges crossing the river was really cool. That's it.

Things I'm indifferent about - 
Combat - While I find it marginally better than the previous game it went too far in the wrong direction. Combat in the last game was slow, and I swear the game ignored button inputs to make sure you got hit if you were surrounded but here... In a word, it's too easy. In another word, it's too indulgent. Finishers are too long winded, especially the multi kills but you still can't instant counter kill like you could in the previous games.
Multiple Protagonists - Seems like a waste of the concept. The characters play too similarly to really differentiate them and while playing one the other is not even around except in cutscenes. They could have had the second character be back up or something and they could have made the characters play more differently. As it stands there are minor things like 3 skills each that the characters get that are unique but they don't do enough. Even then the game doesn't seem to know how to use them, the female character will get combat missions and the male character will get sneaking missions even if they're "specialized" for the opposite.
Experience gain - Not needed. Doesn't add anything to the game that just having better gear adds to the game. A level 1 character can also stealthily assassinate a max level character and if you're openly fighting then you're doing it wrong.
Story (modern and SIM) - The modern Initiates stuff is still cringey as Hell. Don't talk directly to the player like you're talking to a player character. Just don't do it. Add in a lackluster ending and it's just pointless. The SIM story is also fairly dull and outside of a few interesting missions it feels like a pointless side story. Add in another lackluster ending and it's just meh. The Penny Dreadful ones were great though. The Jack the Ripper DLC was also kind of meh with a crap ending.

Things I hated - 
Nothing really. Just minor annoyances that are too small or too petty to really bother with and a few politically biased eyerolls.

Overall, I say try it on sale.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is what Assassin's Creed Unity should have been.

Controller I used to review this game: ASTRO C40

----

Assassin's Creed Unity pushed what Assassin's Creed can do with AI and that led to horrible performance issues. While this game cuts down on the AI a tad bit and gives you an amazing game.

Assassin‚Äôs Creed is a series that ‚ÄúI like,‚Äù I don‚Äôt love it (like a fanboy that buys each game on day one) or hate it (for how long the series is). But I like Assassin‚Äôs Creed for how in-depth the story is for both the Assassin and the character inside the Animus. One thing that I love the most about the Assassin‚Äôs Creed games is the places/city‚Äôs the game puts you in. Syndicate has a very 'Peaky Blinders' feel to the game and oh man, I loved every second of it.

First off lets state the obvious, the performance. It's fantastic on the 3900X with 16 GB of RAM and a 1070... it runs flawlessly. Thought it did an "Ok" job on my old i5-6600. The game is very CPU heavy so you've been warned. So with that being said I have nothing bad to say about it, the game rarely dips under 58 FPS, constant 59 - 60 FPS.

Gameplay, missions, cutscenes and in-game money. Gameplay, I love it honestly once you get introduced to the 'Grappling Hook,' the whole dynamic and mechanics of the game open up. For cut-scenes when you take over Gang Leaders territories, they're mostly the same with the same animations and dialogue, but in different locations of where the event(s) took place. Missions are widespread throughout the city, they give take advantage of using the whole map. In-game money is somewhat easy to come by, but at the same time it's hard to get if that makes any-sense. Unlike Unity, money can be earned when completing missions. If you are having a trouble time with money, you can spend real-life money (microtransactions) to get more in-game money (don't do this). You just have to experience the game in order to get the full understanding on how everything works, from upgrading your gang to upgrading your outfits/gear.

Where is the Animus by Abstergo? By Sequence 4, the Animus is 5% of this game whole game. No lore outside of the game, I'm kinda disappointed. The Animus is just cut-scenes, you can't wander around. Was I the only one that liked the whole in-real life thing they did where you can wander around the Abstergo company like in Assassin‚Äôs Creed 2 and Black Flag?

(I will update this review to include if the Animus is to be found anywhere else in the story.)

-----

Edit: After you complete the last sequence of the story mode a Abstergo scene plays, other than that. Nothing Animus related.

So I've played every Assassin's Creed game from 1-Syndicate. 1 was on console and Unity was on a different platform, but I feel a little weird about how back and forth I am with this series.
Maybe it's burnout more than anything else but I just feel so bored and done with this series this time around.
The game is technically very functional in it's modern PC version. It looks amazing and it carries with it all the technical updates from Unity. However, with that said, I just felt so initimidated and simultaneously disappointed when the game opened up to me and I saw how large the world was and all the tasks it was populated with.
Assassin's Creed is the pinnacle of modern open world RPGs that have huge worlds that are beautifully crafted but with either nothing to do or only tedious copy/paste tasks to populate it. There is a really cool story here and I love the dynamic between Evie and Jacob, but I don't like how much the map is filled with stupid tasks, and I don't like how I need to do that in order to 'level up' which is a thing in the Assassin's Creed series now.

I've played AC Syndicate after playing AC Odyssey for solid 80 hours, and I have to say that Odyssey really lacks a lot of core materials such as cinematic quality, convenient dialogue and character development within the narrative. Putting olive trees and pantheons everywhere may look good from far away but cities felt the same and empty overall. However, this is not the case with Syndicate. I LOVED how the Victorian Era London felt alive with its NPCs and beautiful city design. It resembled the Dishonored universe a lot, which is a huge plus for me.

Combat system was not my favorite but oh boy, double assasination is so satisfying that I probably assasinated hundreds of Blighters while just walking in the street. One of my disappointments is actually the lack of variety in enemies. I have to say combat feels really repetitive after a few missions but the game compensates it with assasination missions. 

Overall, I would say Syndicate is a good game. It has its flaws but I can say that it holds up pretty well even in 2021. 

PS: I LOVED Evie Frye. Too bad Evie had such fewer missions compared to Jacob.

I purchased AC: Syndicate and found out that my ultrawide monitor is no longer supported. That is right: this game had ultrawide (21:9 for example) support on launch and later took it away with a patch. Furthemore, none of the usual "hex edit tricks" work on this game since the game does not seem to expose this setting anywhere.
Truly amazed by the incompetence of Ubisoft, I thought I will not be surprised in such a way when pretty much every other game in the series can be fixed via a Hex Edit. Syndicate cannot be fixed, and the fact that it used to fully support ultrawide cutscenes (lots of footage on YouTube from around the launch) before a patch removed this functionality makes this a terrible purchase.
If you have seen a fix for this let me know but as it stands I cannot recommend this game to any ultrawide user.

[h1]tl;dr 6.333.../10 [b]OVERALL[/b][/h1]
[u][b]8.5/10[/b][/u] ‚Üí AS a TITLE in the [u]A.C. SERIES[/u]
(IF you like the series, you're gonna like grinding this one as well.)


[b]the BAD first :[/b]
[list]
    [*]If your level doesn't match minimum requirements, you're in for one hell of a losing battle even with decent reflexes, which shows either laziness or lack of funds (by [u]corporate[/u] over-charge)... and THAT is DEFINITELY not cool in my book. (more explained at [u][b]***[/b][/u] by the end)
    [*]No more jumping at will (except with a combo of keys), so forget jumping -quickly- to save your life or diving in water to avoid being seen... nope. I guess people feared getting wet in London in the 1800's... morphine, nicotine and alcohol were apparently not enough to cure the common cold, eh ?
    [*]No more picking up weapons from dead bodies.... I loved doing that in "Black Flag" :'(
    [*]Boring as fuck : do 4 or 5 kinds of missions, fight a gang, repeat...
    [*]Bland environment despite good textures and obvious work on era fidelity
    [*]Gang wars are annoying... where you [b]cannot[/b] aim at your enemy for a nice shot, but THEY can. And, why in THE HELL are your allies watching you fight multiple enemies on your own ???
    [*]You can't harm neutral civilians anymore... even "by accident". Boooooo!!! Do I really have to go back to GTA5 ??? Please don't make me :'(
[/list]

[b]the DISCONCERTING stuff :[/b]
[list]
[*]"Stealth" is quite different... you don't have to hide bodies anymore. In fact, they will be more like a distraction to the enemy. As if every one of them either became poets or detectives... (comments on regrets or trying to do an autopsy)
[*]I know Ezio was a badass of a character, but with twins... so much MORE could have been done
[*]When revolvers had already been invented by then (era in which Syndicate plays), shouldn't the main character be able to AT LEAST wield a musket ?? ;)
[*]Also, someone PLEASE explain to me why you cannot kill a simple guy in f2f combat with a  one-strike using a blade... I don't understand that (and never will in most video games).
[*]What good is a "GPS" when it can't tell that you need to drive ON THE LEFT SIDE OF THE ROAD in England ???
[*] Also, I've had my share of supernatural stuff happening on the streets : dancing carriages, rocket-shot horses, Super-people (shooting straight to outer space)... lol
[/list]

[b]the GOOD then :[/b]
[list]
    [*]No more sticky hands, finally !!! (not talking about Ë©†Êò• here, but magnetic walls‚Üîgloves)
    [*]You can dodge bullets again... yeah !! ^^
    [*]There is a good blend of former game mechanics with new ones, like "driving" horse carriages...
    [*]... which brings us to this new way of going around "fast". They are a really nice addition to the game. Travelling can be more fun depending on if you like to drive... like me ;)
    [*]It is graphically decent, with good textures and not too demanding in resources
    [*]The twin characters are somewhat likable, though Jacob can be annoying
    [*]Controller/KB&M support is flawless... but you probably should go with a controller on that one ;)

This is, what i‚Äôve heard, a VERY unpopular opinion. But i think this game is one of the strongest installments in this franchise and i honestly don‚Äôt understand where all the hate is coming from.
Assassin‚Äôs creed Syndicate brings 1800s Victorian London back to life in the eyes of the twin pair Jacob and Evie Frye. Both very likeble characters in my opinion. I think Ubisoft catched the ‚Äùsibling attitude‚Äù between them very well and Evie is honestly one of my favourite assassins up until this point (2021). She‚Äôs especially important to me, as a female gamer, since this was the introduction to a female leadcharacter to the assassin‚Äôs creed game series.

In terms of actual gameplay, I prefer this combatsystem over the new ‚Äùhitbox‚Äù system they introduced in the later games of the franchise. Yes, i know the gameplay can be a little bit repetetive at times but the main quests, that drives the story forward, is where the game truly shines (especially Evies missions).

So my final conclusion is that, if you haven‚Äôt been an assassin‚Äôs creed fan before, then this game won‚Äôt win you over. But if you are a fan of the franchise and wants to try out syndicate, then i don‚Äôt think you will be disappointed.

I really had to think about whether or not to recommend this game.

The game feels like a downgrade from Unity. They took out everything great about Unity, the immersive environment, the murder mysteries, engaging side stories (there are some in Syndicate but they aren't as good) and a somewhat engaging story arc for the heroes of the game.

You don't feel as immersed in the Victorian setting. Both the protagonists and the antagonists feel very bland, and leave you with an overwhelming "meh." The "charm" of the Frye twins wears off fast since the main story feels very diluted. 

The WW1 side mission line isn't very engaging from my experience, but was a nice addition to the game!

The depiction of gang warfare and the bad guys "a rival gang" is comical. It's like they were voiced by the same people behind LoTR's orcs and goblins. Some classic lines include:
- "You killed my friend's, now I will kill you!"
- "I'll spill your guts!"
- and general grunting.

I haven't played the DLC, just couldn't find myself having the energy to play anymore of this game. But, form what I saw, the Last Maharajah is a broken, badly written mess. While the Ripper seems to be fine, albeit awful writing. You never actually figure out what motivates Jack or get any insight worth the $ they are charging. 

The only way I can recommend this game is if you want to have a virtual tour of London during the Victorian era, or if you pick it up on sale.
