I love the setting of AC Syndicate. 1800s London is a fun place to visit in the game. There are lots of great details about the game that are enjoyable. But every time you clip some architectural detail, or you get stuck on a ledge (seriously just let me step down without hitting an extra damn button or making me change buttons for up and freerun), or can't easily run up something, or the camera does it's weird sudden movement/perspective changes... it not only breaks my immersion but it just frustrates me. The camera ones sometimes make me queasy. This game is so much like Unity, aside from being the obvious re-skinned elements it has largely the same UI issues.

Some fun items London architecture. This is always the high point of any AC series and this doesn't disappoint. While there is some conformity across London, there is a bit of a different feel to each borough. Another is the WWI subplot, no spoilers, it had a lot of fun elements and I loved the character's unique costume from it.

If you're playing out of order, I will admit to having skipped this one originally, I much preferred Odyssey's interface and mechanics. This felt like a major step backwards both in UI and in button controls and layout.

The Short:

Great graphics here & there, √∫tterly boring & frustratring gameplay. Grind, grind, grind to get level-ups needed to get at the heart of the game. It took me 13 hours of frustration and grinding to get at level 6 and get the story (simple as it is) rolling for a bit.

The Longer:

Point is, while the City is rendered in exquisite beauty in all its victorian splendor&squalor, it is √°lso crawling with clone baddies that are ESP-gifted, and are psionically linked to every other baddy in the vicinity. Meaning, when You attack one in a neighbourhood that isn't Yours, or one of them sees You, the game immediately spawns oodles of baddies, and cops with "super-batons" that kill in just a couple of blows. Which -in turn- leads to the standard tactics of : killing..get up to the roof, press "c" to go stealth, wait a bit, rinse & repeat ad infinitum. Gang strongholds can be cleared-out in the same manner. A fair bit of that carried-over into AC: digital world...ehh.. "Watch Dogs 2" grind, grind, grind. Stealth-kills fix that for a bit, but then the crazy of the ai comes bubbling-up: I tried to stash all bodies from stealth-kills out of sight. Well, I shouldn't have bothered. Stealth kill a baddie. Let the body laying around, and in most cases no-one sounds the alarm despite citizens making a ruckus.. weird.

All in all, the "open world" is a frustrating affair that can only be enjoyed from samey-samey-roofs. Get to street level to take-in "The Sights" the programmers have so lovingly crafted, and you're in for endless, boring assaults of cookie-cutter baddies.

What's √°lso seriously annoying is the utterly sl√≥w levelling. It feels like a purposely stunted levelling-system to make players spend √°ctual money on XP-Points. Sneaky, stinky CEO-Beancounter stuff.

On the rest of the game: 

When a neighbourhood is (FINALLY) Yours, only th√©n do You get to admire the work the programmers & builders put into the game. But, by then, a lot of players will have put-down the conroller for good.

Is the game "hard"? No, not really. It's rather more like"artificially stunted" to make it seem "hard" but the base-mechanics are all standard AC-fare -apart from the Grapple-Hook, which is a nice addition to shorten trips around The City- with a somewhat wonky stealth-system.

On a more positive note: The clothes of Evie and Jacob, are a Steampunk dream. The rich brocades, something inocuous, like the movement of Evie's cape (loathed by many, oddly enough), the lace, the buttons even, it all defines "attention to detail" from people that love to design stuf.

Shame that it has to live in such a mediocre, grindy game. I cannot really recommend it, unless it's in a weekend-sale for $10.- or something.

Edit: You know when it f√≠nally starts to get fun? With a trainer. While only using "infinite health", the game became far more enjoyable (for me, at least)

Despite everything, I d√≥ like just aimlessly walking around victorian London. The architecture is spot-on, the atmosphere too.  It also has a tiny bit of steam-punk here and there. Not realistic, and history-purists wil balk at it, but it's fun for me.   Shame that the actual 'gameplay' is mediocre, and grindy.

I've played all of the main series (not counting the 2.5D spinoffs). After playing Origins, I decided to come back and play some I'd missed, like Unity (bought from Ubisoft directly) and Syndicate. Unity was not a good game, even setting aside performance issues. Boring story, bland characters, and really boring and repetitive gameplay. Syndicate, on the other hand, is a really quality entry into the series and I think the strongest one since AC2 or maybe Black Flag. It is obviously the last one of the series to retain the old formula of staying within a single city and lots and lots of parkour. I love the newest three games, but they are so wildly different in gameplay, that I won't consider them to be in the same family.

The good - 

Well-written protagonists and their varying abilities let you cater to whatever gameplay style you want. I generally preferred playing Evie due to stealth, but Jack definitely rocks fights.

"Attack the outpost" missions are varied and enjoyable, more than other typical Ubisoft offerings that came before this one. While each type generally has a formula, they are still fun and provide some challenges at times.

The flavor and atmosphere of Victorian England is well-done. Smoky, rainy, crowded, dirty. The river traffic is fun to interact with, too, hopping from one boat to the next like Frogger.

Fights are well-done and visceral, particularly as your skills develop. NPCs do employ different fighting styles and fights can quickly go the wrong way if you're sloppy.

More environmental options for kills or stealth.

The zipline is a little immersion-breaking as well, but it makes getting around London a ton easier and is a great QOL improvment -  no more wasting time climbing up the side of something.

Using your gang as backup is fun, effective, and they can be upgraded in multiple ways.

The bad - 

The "bosses" are not that memorable, outside of the endgame boss and one of his lieutenants.

Carriage chases are annoying, because the streets are so crowded.

Fast travel always takes you to the top of a building and you wind up have to jump off, blah blah. Why not just take the player to the front door?

The camera locks to the player during certain sequences and it's annoying because you want to look down the street or your next objective, etc.

NPC levels feel a little odd in how they relate to player abilities. I never had a good sense of what they actually meant.

The ugly -

No "choices matter" in the game. This is jarring, because the characters often comment on the outcome of certain actions, but the player has no agency to choose a different path. The AC series has never really been known for that, but it's always been a glaring issue that really stands out in this game.

It doesn't really effect gameplay much, but the trains just seem odd in the game. They go around a loop like a model railroad. Some weird immersion-breaking moments there.

NPCs just react oddly to a dead body in their midst - "Ah, you were a good soldier. Now back to pacing aimlessly." You'd think they'd be a little more alarmed, call in help, something. Kind of immersion-breaking as well.

Overall, though, if you like the AC series, it's well worth getting, especially on a discount. I got my enjoyment out of it and am now moving on to Odyssey again, but don't have any regrets about playing this one unlike some others (looking at you, Rogue and Unity). If you've never played the AC series before, but like action games, it is maybe a good starting point as it is not as dated as the older entries from a technical perspective.

Syndicate is pretty much in the dead center in terms of the AC games. It has a decent story and its gameplay mechanics are enjoyable, but at times annoying. For every pro, there's going to be a con, and with this installment in the franchise, its a game that I would rule as a "meh".
awesome

I played AC Odyssey as my first AC series. But AC Syndicate also provide another exciting points: to travel Victorian era of London.
Interface & other story telling also attractive points in my opinion.

I'm gonna be honest with you. Even though the mechanics and mission design are way refined and less clunky than Unity, overall I found Syndicate to be a worse, more boring and uninteresting experience compared with the previous game. The story is so boring and generic I speeded and had a hard time going through it, to a point I gave up and saw the ending missions on Youtube. I mainly used the game to do some virtual tourism around London, and that was great as it is typical in the Assassins Creed cities, even though it pales in comparison with revolutionary Paris. That city was one of the best I have ever visited in a game.

Overall I'll still give Syndicate a thumbs up mainly because the mechanics are well improved and most of the issues I had, were mainly caused by my disinterest with the series main story and bloated content. Assassin's Creed fans should like it, I think.

Epic, i especially liked murdering everybody with Jack

The city itself is beautiful, but the script is oversimplified with no climax. The villain is lame, the main characters lack any depth. Ivy is a bit more interesting, but everyone else are just shallow characters with dull and childish dialogues. 

Unity was a lot more interesting compared to this part of the series, too bad it was buggy at launch.

The zip-line changed the whole dynamic and eliminated parkour as an element of the game. Now you can climb wherever you want or jump from one building to another without any effort, and the extraordinary distances it can get you erodes any realism from the game.

Regarding the inventory, Unity had a much large variety of weapons, now each character has to choose from 3 weapons, which makes fights boring and look all the same, not speaking about the animations which are shown real fast and lack realism. On the other hand, we have two nice skill trees, one for the characters, another for the Rooks, but by the end of the game I didn't need to make many improvements to the Rooks, as they don't seem to add a lot to the game anyway.

The whistle mechanism is back and is also oversimplifying the assassinations, I was so glad they got rid of it in Unity, good thing they didn't add all the stealth in bushes mechanism, which made stealth so easy.

They even tried to use the "server bridges" to jump in a different time period, which was played out really cool in Unity, it was a very dynamic and intense transition, a good way to shake things up a bit, here it was a meaningless series of side-quests with the same old story we know. Nothing new, nothing challenging. 

There are some bugs around, but not enough to bother the game play. 

I completed the game to make a full impression about it, but it's not worth it, nothing interesting happening from the story point of view. So there's nothing to see here, I would rather recommend Unity as it adheres to closer to traditional AC's principles.
good story at all
The best game of the whole AC franchise.

For an AC game, one of the better ones. Like any Ubisoft open world game, the map is festooned with collectibles. Frustrating that there's no in game map for helix glitches or secrets of London and requires purchasing through the Ubisoft store with helix credits - there's enough rewards from finishing up other collectibles to get ONE of the two maps. Suggest the helix glitches map. 

Zipline tool is very cool, and surprisingly, the carts weren‚Äôt bad either. Gang upgrades were pretty funny, and calling up carts with allies on command is great for the transportation and also some of the challenges on missions can be cheesed with the allies. Cart racing, though, was pretty frustrating. It's luck dependent since it's impossible to outrace the other racers; the AI will just speed the other racers' carts up. 

Story wise, the brother-sister pair of deuteragonists are great. It‚Äôs cool they both have some different master perks, different preferences for equipment, and different interests leading to different missions undertaken. Makes them a bit more distinct and less bland. 

Jack the Ripper DLC is quite good too. Doesn't overstay its welcome.

While it boasts one of my favorite protagonists in the Assassin's Creed series the gameplay and story felt pretty flat. There's not really much to make you root for the characters other than their small story about their father but Evie and Jacob's charismatic and contrasting personalities sorta made up for that shortcoming. Now onto gameplay... well it gets hella repetitive especially later in the game which kinda makes the game a bore tbh. There was a point, more than halfway into the game, wherein i just kinda wanted it to end because the story didn't click for me and the gameplay was just the same thing after the same thing. (Also ngl the last boss fight and ending was pretty disappointing)

That said, the game was still fun especially whenever Evie and Jacob are interacting. The setting was good and the music was personally one of my faves of the whole series. Not the best AC game but definitely underrated. 

Pick it up on sale if u can.

oi fuckin britain bruv

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a great example of quality vs quantity.

It doesnt lack content, it doesnt lack missions or story, it lacks soul.

[b]Unless youre a die-hard fan of the victorian era, London or AC games in general you will feel bored.[/b]

The story spends the majority of its time on boring parts and lacks the Cinematic feel of AC4 or Unity
The world feels repetitive and lacks major Landmarks that keep you interested, London sure is pretty but quickly feels boring.
The gameplay is annoying to the highest extent and the grappling hook feels like a shortcut through it.

And despite all of that it still has some interesting content, attention to detail, and enough reference to keep you interested through the main campaign.

For a AAA game it feels average and empty, play it for the campaign, for the Secret Stories but for the love of god get it on sale.

[h1]"Destruction‚Äôs Our Delight"[/h1]

[b]Technical analysis summary[/b]

Graphics: 8.5
Sound: 7.5
Playability: 8.0
Longevity: 7.5
Impact: 8.0

[b]Pro[/b]

+ A splendid digital London with a beautiful atmosphere and an amazing OST.
+ The first AC with two protagonists. Both unique in a very immersive story.
+ Captivating and frenetic,yet less technical, combat system
+ Lots of things to do in a more classic AC experience...

[b]Cons[/b]

- ...but the last one of the Desmond Arc
- Bugs and glitches here and there.
- It can be repetitive to certain players
- Despite trying for something new, it goes back to well know dynamics of the series.

[b]Overall Verdict[/b]

[b]7.9[/b]: The last true classic AC game of the series. Full of fanservice but in an overall well-designed game with an interesting story, for most of the fans of the saga this will not be a burden but rather a value. It deserves to be tried even just for the historical period in which it is set. The music and atmosphere manage to make the player live a unique experience. Absolutely recommended if on sale.

Good

Bad

TL;DR this is the game that forced a year off. It shows. Badly. This is the only AC game I do not recommend. It's just bad.
Ultrawide works in Windowed mode, but is just 16:9 stretched to 21:9 in Fullscreen. This is frankly inexcusable. The game is also horribly unstable, with bursts of crashing every few minutes and occasional hours of stability. I never figured out why.

Quick note that the WW1 section is, imo, the best part of the game. It's vastly less irritating than most of the main game, feels like you're doing something truly essential, and holy shit that costume is stunning.

London is successfully London. It looks great and is suitably huge-feeling, though noticably less dense than previous games. You get around 50 hours of action not including DLC. Missions are split between the twins, and exp is shared so they always feel more or less equal. Skills are identical for most of the game. Evie eventually getting a few unique stealth skills, Jacob gets combat. The grappling hook is really nice. Yay!

Unfortunately the quest design is aimed very specifically at making everything as annoying as possible. There were very few that I rated above 2/5, which is painfully disappointing since all the characters are very well done. None of the region-unlocking minigames are remotely fun and most of the optional quests are just irritating busy-work. The story is pretty good, just mired in mediocre gameplay. There are a few utterly rage-inducing moments that almost made me give up completely.

The economy, so very nearly perfected in Unity, is here deeply unbalanced. Investment is stupidly expensive for very little return, to the extent I only felt the benefits in after maybe 40 hours - by which point I'd made vastly more money just opening chests and completing the wide variety of cash quests.

I've played all AC games from 3 up over the last couple of months. They've all had slightly iffy starts and consistent annoyances. This is by far the worst, and really does feel like it was made by a crew who were exhausted and out of ideas. The world and the characters in it deserve a much better game.
Fun game.

FEBRUARY 9 / MAY 26 2016
It's really rare I write a review about a game, but after playing this game all the way through I was compelled to act. Not only is this game an insult to the senses in every way imaginable, the gameplay, the story, the recycled characters most notably Jacob Fry who is just a mix of Edward Kenway and that guy from Watchdogs no one remembers. The creators with Ubisoft at the helm have seemingly grown tired of anything that resembles quality or joy in their products and rather is scarily close to turning into Stalin of the game world, a position currently inhabited by their self-proclaimed enemy and biggest competitor - EA. They shit all over their users with the most notable example with Unity in which they released an unfinished product at full price, and only offering compensation several months later after a massive backlash extremely rarely seen among consumers, but forcing customers wishing to accept the peace offering that they could not anytime in the future sue Ubisoft over Unity. 

And with this stinking pile of garbage they have not only put together a cliche-filled, gameplay-broken, lazy approach to gaming by taking the standard template they seem to just be recycling for every annual game, but they have more importantly completely "forgot" to optimise it after release since it after all was a much better release than Unity in that it was actually playable upon release. UBISOFT - this has been said way too many times already that it borders on customer service clich√©, but I have a sincere hope that there is still some good people left at your companies who believe the magic and beauty in beautifully crafted games. That games are not only a way to pass the time and shoot some bad guys, but that can enlighten and broaden ones minds and transport oneself to a different world, a different time. I must believe that is what the creators of AC 2 were embodying when they created what is, in my opinion not only the finest AC game to be released, but one of the best sci-fi games of this generation. You got everything right: the location, the story, the gameplay, the sidemissions, the graphics, the music - and most importantly, you respected your audience in delivering something to be proud of, and something you felt your audience deserved. For those responsible for that piece of art - I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart. 

And to those who have become mindless robots churning out what has - UNFORTUNATELY - become a yearly tradition of shitting all over audiences, I will never forget, but I still have hope you will redeem yourself before this franchise finally runs out of steam. Finally, I just want direct my attention to the head of Ubisoft - Yvet Guillemot (or how its spelled). You sir are responsible for what have befallen this beloved and excellent franchise, and you will ultimately have to answer to all those fans you have dissapointed time and again, and who miracelously come back for more every single year, myself being one of them, because they still have hope that the franchise might one day be great again. Chances that you'll ever see this I release is close to none. But hopefully, when enough people complain and force your eyes open, you will see what you have become. 

I hope for that day.

This game...
Ok, first of, this game is beautiful. The settings, the character models, the lighting. And also, the combat mechanics are well made and the feeling that you get while travelling with the grappling hook is great. That was everything great and well done in this game. Now I¬¥ll cover everything else.

1. The performance
While playing this piece of art (in terms of graphics), the game often started lagging and freezing, making me have to wait a large amount of time until I could move again. At some point, I found out that Whitechapel did¬¥nt want me to uncover the rest of the map via viewpoint, freezing and closing the game every time I¬¥m too close (less than 200 meters was the limit) and I had to set the game to the lowest graphics possible, making it a pain to look at and still lagging the game out as much as possible. There also was this mission called ¬¥¬¥Hullo Mr Gatling¬¥¬¥ where you had to use a gatling gun against loads of enemies (obviously). This mission made me stop playing this game as it made the game freeze. When I tried restarting/leaving the mission, I got sent into the room of infinite Blackscreen as punishment for me trying to get rid of a problem. But don¬¥t get me wrong; the game lagged everywhere, that wasn¬¥t the only place to freeze the game forever.

2. The parcour
The parcour in this game is one big mess. It¬¥s in no way optimized for pc. It¬¥s a pain watching Jacob and Evie struggle getting over a wall lower then their body height. The only thing well done in terms of parcours is the grappling hook. Which also doesn¬¥t work every time. The parcour still works, it¬¥s just not too good.

3. The combat system
The other thing well done in this game. While the weapon arsenal isn¬¥t big, it¬¥s unique and cool. The cane sword looks cool, the combat while using the brass knuckles looks amazing and the kukri knife somehow just fits in the game world. Throwing knifes are cool, the revolvers are a cooler looking and a  louder alternative, there are smoke bombs (well, they are there) And there are poison darts ( I didn¬¥t use them). Sadly, you couldn¬¥t use the grappling hook as a weapon, but that¬¥s okay. 

4. Storyline
I played this game for 17 hours and I really wasn¬¥t interrested in the story, but that¬¥s just me. 

5. Summary

As said, the game looks amazing and the combat system is great, but the parcour is just not good, the glitches make it uncompletable and (for me) the storyline is not interresting.

Ah, Syndicate. What an unexpected breath of fresh air.

After Unity (which I hated), I finally got to play Syndicate and visit a time period that interested me a lot more than the (first) French Revolution. And we have never been closer to the Modern Era in an AC game than in Syndicate which is set in Victorian London.

The game manages to improve almost all aspects of Unity, mostly by simplifying mechanics. This applies mostly to the combat, stealth, and parcouring. The addition of the grapple hook is totally nicked from Batman but it works and it's fun to use. With it and the carriages getting around London is not as much of a slog as navigating Paris could be. There is a lot less clunkiness and bugs overall.

The only aspect that is noticably weaker are the graphics. Coming from Unity, Syndicate will just look bad even on Ultra settings. It has its moments and it's certainly not an ugly game but Unity was leagues ahead. Of course it came with steep hardware requirements and a host of performance issues.

In London you will encounter a ton of historical figures such as Charles Dickens, Karl Marx, a young Fred Abberline (only a sergeant at the time) and someone very surprising after the final mission. There are also nods to Sherlock Holmes and you can find Lewis Carroll reading the Jabberwocky poem in a park.

Naturally the game suffers from the Ubisoft affliction of way too many map markers. The amount of *stuff* you can do is overwhelming. Collectibles and generic missions are around every corner. At some point, I just started watching Lindsay Ellis video essays on the side while exploring the city and it was surprisingly relaxing. There is also a completely split-off area of the map set in World War I London where you play as a descendant of the Fryes, doing basically the same missions as in the main game but with a slightly different touch. It's alright.

The main story is better than Unity which, to be fair, isn't saying much. There are some minor plot twists but on the whole you will probably not be surprised very often. The villains - Templar Grandmaster Starrick and his goons, the gangs controlling the boroughs of London - are cartoonishly evil with zero redeeming qualities. The grunts look like someone really liked the thugs from Dishonored but thought they'd be pretty in red and green, too. Seriously, even the physical proportions are reminiscent of Dishonored (which is weird because the overall realistic art style doesn't match that at all).

The protagonists - Frye twins Evie and Jacob - are genuinely funny at times. They are perhaps not brilliant, complex characters but they are alright and I enjoyed playing Evie. Yes, she is a bit of a Mary Sue but I was personally not that bothered by it. I liked her sass and being female myself, it was nice to finally play a woman in an AC game (no, I'm not counting Liberation). Her romance [spoiler]with Henry[/spoiler] is sweet and casual, and it's worlds better than Arno/Elise. Not that that's difficult.

The ending [spoiler]was basically the Unity ending, only this time the good guys all survived, yay.[/spoiler]

As far as the modern day plot goes, there is really nothing at all beyond some cut scenes featuring Shaun and Rebecca. I loved it because I love those two dorks to pieces, and don't you dare kill them off, Ubisoft. There were plenty of throwbacks in Victorian London as well (visiting Edward Kenway's manor is part of the main quest).

What I found hilarious is how badly the game tries to imitate AC II / Brotherhood. Retaking the city by claiming strongholds feels very much like those old games but it's also the interface (red / white again) and even the UI sound effects that are so very Brotherhood. The soundtrack is very different though, it fits the setting perfectly.

Overall, I can recommend Syndicate *but* primarily for fans of the AC series. If you strip out the nostalgia, it's probably not very engaging. I liked it mostly based on the fact that it's a huge improvement over Unity and because of my fascination for the time period. I don't think I'll replay it down the line but it was nice. A solid 5/7 I would say.

I really wanted to like this game, but couldn't. 
The art design of industrial London makes for a nice setting, however, that is where the good stuff ends. 
The story is very generic and boring. The villain is supposed to be this well collected and cunning Templar leader that also has bat-shit, psycho fits when something does not goes his way. He is lame.
The generic enemies are 90% just people wearing red coats. Early game they can very quickly kill you, but will a little bit of investment into skills or gear they are trivialized.
You get the most interesting gadget very early which is the Batman style grappling hook/zip line. It is nice because it allows you to skip over one of the worst parts of the game which is the movement. I've played a lot of other Assassin's Creed games and never have I had so much difficulty trying to get my character to do something as simply as walk up or down a 1 foot tall fence. The climbing/parkour is really bad and I am not sure why.
You get guns which can be fun to just aim and head shot enemies to quickly eliminate them but there are only three types of melee weapons; kukri, cane sword, and brass knuckles. They all feel virtually the same, disappointing. 
I struggled to finish this game and probably skipped most of the side quest memories and couldn't bring myself to play the Jack the Ripper DLC.
I would skip this entry in the series unless you really want to play a game in the industrial revolution of London and love collectathons.

This is my first REAL experience with Assassin's Creed and I love it! Most reviews will say that the game has a bad story or not very fun combat and I disagree completely. 
WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD. The story is about the two protagonists: Evie and Jacob Frye. Two assassins who kill the henchman of Crawford Starrick. One day they want to do better and ultimately defeat Starrick from getting the piece of eden. 
The combat is amazing to me, the combat is easy to get used to, but this doesn't mean that you will not die. The combat is actually more hard than easy, because some of the enemies have LITERAL ONE SHOT WEAPONS. 
The characters are extremely likable, the jokes mixed with the seriousness makes some amazing characters. You can even meet Charles Dickens to Queen Victoria!
The death scenes are absolutely amazing. I won't go into great detail but they have perfect lines, music that goes so well with the pure craziness in each villain, and so much more that just makes the death scenes perfect!
The assassination missions are the best things about the game though, the one that stands out the most is the assassination of Maxwell Roth. He will be a brief ally until he blows up a house with children in it (don't worry you save them). This leads on to you going to a show he is holding where, surprise surprise! You have to assassinate him! In the show  Everyone will have to wear theater masks which leads into a little trick Maxwell pulls on you. He will put out his henchmen in the exact same clothes that HE wears as a decoy. Once you kill all of them, he will show himself and burn the whole place down. This leads into the best assassination mission in the game, and the best death scene in the whole game.
There is one last thing I have to say about the game and that is the fact that London is absolutely gorgeous.
I would absolutely buy the game if you had the money.

Syndicate takes the gameplay of Unity and smooths some rough edges. It should've been better than Unity, but for me personally it wasn't.
The reasons are actually very simple:
1) While Syndicate adds a couple of new activities and a couple of new mechanics, it still felt to me more like a clone of Unity set in London rather than an original game.
2) Some of the secondary activities I enjoyed the most in Unity were either removed (the Nostradamus verses and Helix glitches) or transformed into a minor game mechanic (crime investigations).
The music is pretty lacklustre, although there are some rather nice pieces. But I really liked the work Austin Wintory did on the Banner Saga and that's why his work on this game is pretty disappointing.
The voice actors are pretty good, but not brilliant. I can't blame them, though, because sometimes the lines they were given are...
That's when we get to the Achilles Heel of the Assassin's Creed franchise: the story. Syndicate is not an exception to the rule as its story is bland and boring and the characters' personalities are left undeveloped. Even meeting some important historical figures, such as Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, Karl Marx or even Queen Victoria herself, doesn't save the mediocre script.
The only reason I recommend this game was given in the first paragraph: I believe that the fans of the franchise won't mind the drawbacks I mentioned. If you are new to Assassin's Creed, though, there are better choices to start from (practically any other game in the franchise).
Assassin's Creed Syndicate is the proof that Assassin's Creed went into stagnation and needed some important changes. Luckily, the Ubisoft bosses recognized that fact and the newer games in the franchise go in a fresh direction.
Where it will lead them and how long until Ubisoft start to repeat themselves once again? Only time will tell.

This is a very underrated Assassin's creed game. The story is fairly decent, it ties in to history quite well and, although not being that interesting, it feels fun. The graphics are great and Victorian London is a great open-world. It has a great atmosphere depending on where you in the map from rat-infested slums to tall; clean buildings in Westminster. There's Big Ben, Buckingham Palace, Trafalgar Square, 10 Downing Street, Piccadilly Circus, St Paul's cathedral, and many more. The parkour is great and the grapple hook is fun to use. Combat is also great. It's honestly one of my favourite assassin's creed games, and I've tried them almost all of them par Rogue.

I am an old fan of AC. I first played it when i was 5 years old, AC 2. To play this game, I can feel all the nostalgia I had, be on me. This game is revolutionary, The semi RPG/Crafting and upgrading system can be a little bit of a   headache, but it was something new that the Guys at Ubi tried. And they nailed it perfectly in this game, unlike Odyssey, This game is an almost perfect balance of RPG (the crafting, stats with items you either buy or craft, multiple weapons and cloth choice which you can buy and need to have an level to even use it) with the plain old AC formula, added a little bit with the mechanics from AC Unity but a little bit Tweaked.


The parkour, was dissapointing, to say the least. The Parkour was tweaked and was in end killed, you cannot jump or fall to your death, because your own mistake, you can't also jump from somewhere low to land on the ground faster. You now have to use a Rope Launcher to move faster.


The new system with points could've been better, BUT it's great, if you are looking for a good ac which is balanced, you could try unity but this is Syndicate we are talking about. If you want to level up you need to spend your points on abilities which you only get only some skills. 


The game could've done better, but it's good as the last Balanced AC game. You should buy the game :))

The game over all is as fun as other Assassin's Creed games I've played.  The only draw back is when your on roof's or wall its hard to get down when you want; when using keyboard and mouse instead of a controller.

Rife with Ubisoft's famous errors, bugs, and poor optimization. Took me ages to finally get it to display correctly at 1920 x 1080 without cutting off part of the screen or only displaying in a corner, and I had to come up with a workaround even for that. The controls / movement / combat are insanely clunky compared to other titles in the franchise, and the whole mandatory switching characters throughout the campaign is incredibly frustrating and immersion breaking, it's one thing to have different characters for different campaigns, but it's odd to go back and forth so much. I've always enjoyed the franchise, the main campaigns and the dlc campaigns, but, this is one I had to return, as due to the poor functionality and lackluster gameplay, it was simply unplayable.

If you're starting with this assassins creed for your first assassins game then stop reading because the rest of this review isn't for you. At the time of this review I have just beaten the main story of Syndicate. It took me about 19-20 hours and in short I would reccomend this gamebut wait for sale since it goes on sale a lot for a great price. The story was good but it started off very slow and it doesnt feel complete until the very end which made the ending very engaging but some points of the story felt disconnected from others. However all of the sequence assissanations were great since there were multiple ways and infinite possibilities of paths to take when going for the kill. By far the best part of the game is the end where, in my opinion, it has the best assassination and has good pacing to lead you into the final sequence with starrick. This is one of my favourite games in the Assassin's Creed Games. The graphics look quite nice. The city design is excellent and while the grappling device caused a bit of trouble I liked it as it saved a lot of time when scaling large buildings, and while my opinion may not be shared with many people. The story is quite entertaining and the dynamic between the two main siblings (Evie and Jacob Frye) is quite entertaining, it can also be somewhat boring although this is rare. I would highly recommend this game to anyone, new players looking to begin or just to see what they think of Assassin's Creed games or old players who want to experience it on PC. Highly Recommended.

The third AC game that I've played. I have been playing Warframe recently, where the controls are fluid and extremely quick with a lot of fast paced action. Transitioning to this game, whew the controls feel heavy and awkward, especially those surrounding the use of carriages.

Besides that, game is good, and playing it in 2021 it feels a little aged, but the graphics, look and atmosphere of the game is still pretty good. You invade people's home they will appropriately respond by coming to shove you, you kill someone in the streets, and they will gather in a circle to admire your work. If they witness you killing, they will run shrieking from you, albeit not very fast. You can play this game stealth, or just come out and brawl, shoot and ram every enemy you meet.

The main problem I have with this game though, yes it is an assassin stealth game, but you have 2 characters 1 built for stealth and 1 built for brawling, but the story and side missions require you to use them for the other purpose and I feel the it makes the specific character trees useless if they are just going to ask you to use the brawler to stealth and the stealth to brawl, especially in the mid game where you need to be careful where you put your points into since you cant upgrade everything yet.

Fun game, excellent designs behind the NPCs, the outfits and levels, excellently written villains like Pearl and Maxwell, but the story is rather bland. With all the fancy shmancy games coming out these days like Cyberpunk 2077 and Genshin Impact, this game is still able to stand up for itself, though it can see it fading into history soon with highly anticipated games like Suicide Squad

Any joy I get out of this game gets quickly squashed by an errant GLARING bug that would've taken a QA team 2 seconds to find, or by the quite frankly abhorrent controls.
I have never felt less in control of my character.
I have accidentally catapulted myself completely the wrong way far too many times, gotten glued to a random railing because my character refuses to jump down, failed missions because I was literally prevented from doing anything or gotten stuck between two parkour spots.
I have accidentally scaled the tallest building in the area when trying to zipline in completely the opposite direction.
I can never activate anything unless I come to a complete stop and stare at the thing for about 5 seconds until the prompt deigns to show itself.

I like the characters and the environment is amazing, but the 80% of the gameplay drives me insane.
And this is a Ubisoft game.  They expect you to run around a colossal map and grind map markers.
And they didn't bother polishing the gameplay so it doesn't feel like piloting a drunken rhino using interpretative dance.

Don't get me wrong, I love the victorian/steampunk genre, I was so excited to play this game because of that one reason.
I pretty much like every genres (the location, the time, the story, etc)s Assassin's Creed has been using so far.

So, what's the problem with this game? Many things unfortunately.

I'll start off with the positive:
-Really great music if you love classical/victorian era music, it makes the atmosphere way much more better, really, it is probably the best point of this game.
-A map that has the right size for an Assassin's Creed game.
-Nice graphics and textures but... See negative.
-Principal assassins (Jacob and Evie) looks pretty cool and promising enough, so does the other characters, such as Henry Green, perhaps not as much as Ezio and Altair but he looks pretty decent, not as much as Jacob and Evie though.
-Throwing knives

Here's the neutral points, depending on the whom, it could be a negative point, for me, it is but it's not that bad anyway:
-There are no swords in this game.
-Not every costumes from previous games are available, unfortunately, not a disaster, but would have been good to have them.

Now, the negative:
-Ugly textures not only from far but from close too, graphics are okay, they're not that great actually, textures are pretty good but depends of what and the lod (distance view) is kinda horrible considering the age of the game, plus it is nothing like in the E3 but that is to be excepted from Ubi isn't?

Now the even more negative that makes me hate this game more than liking it:
-Microtransactions, you've heard that right, optional? Hey kid, I don't care that it is optional or not, it's already an overpriced game, why should there be any cancerous crap like this in a game like this?
-Gameplay has been dumb down, there are some good things about it but it's too easy that it is too hard, get what I mean? Probably not, the gameplay is too basic, I don't know if it is me, but there are things you cannot do anymore.
Double air assassination? I don't know what's wrong with it but it seems like you have to be really close to the two persons otherwise it won't work like in the previous Assassin's Creed games, it's really bad.
Jumping and running, what the heck is this? Can't you just keep the formula of Assassin's Creed II: Brotherhood? That one was way better than the ones we are getting recently. I mean, you could jump anywhere and dies from it while in this game, it won't let you jump, like some kind of anti-noob measure? Yeah no, but thanks, no, I don't want that crap.
Running and jumping feels so simplified, if you want to drop off you have to repeatly click "E" (default keyboard key) instead of holding it once and dropping (and die if you're too high) like you could in the previous games.
I could be making a big paragraph about the gameplay that would take me 1 hour to write but I'll end it here, you get the idea of what I'm trying to say about the gameplay of this game.


In the end, I would suggest this game, but the gameplay is so simplified, I don't like it, I can't stand it, otherwise, it looks like a good game with flaws here and there.
Don't buy it for more than 15$.

If you are new to the series and or are a casual, you'll probably love this game if you love the steampunk/victorian era but if you are a previous Assassin's Creed players who likes the gameplay of the first games then this will be a downside to you.

Honestly, I would except the up-coming games to get more complexe and harder, but I was wrong, they really went mainstream, Assassin's Creed should not be an easy game, it should be an challenging game with a complexe gameplay, or at least, that's my opinion.

Despite my initial grievances with the grappling hook to parkour across streets, the environment encourages its use through wide streets and large gaps between boat masts and building towers. I would consider the game a slight step down from Unity, but the characters are engaging and overall the game still captures the blend of history and fiction. The music in this game is amazing, which surprised me as I never found music to be a notable strength of the AC series. Advanced parkour mechanics from Unity are refined which is the best parkour mechanics in the series imo. Overall, I'd give it an 8/10, but I absolutely love the series until Odyssey so my review might be a little biased in favor of the game.

EDIT:
Having now completely 100% sync the main game I will say that this game sucks for completionists. Side characters such as Darwin and Dickens are great characters that should be more involved in the main campaign. But almost all associate activities are forgettable. The Duleep-signh activities are riddled with multiple breaking bugs i.e. quests completing before characters finish talking, getting GER'd into an infinite death loop until a reddit forum from 5 years ago told me how to exit this game breaking bug.

TLDR:
For a casual assassin's creed fan who enjoys the stories and characters this will be a great game. For a completionist that fights for every achievement and quest, this game will make you suffer more than any of the previous titles, it is just too oversaturated with mediocrity and grind.

Good game!

[u]PROS[/u] 

+ Ginormous game map (1868 London) with mind-blowing levels of detail

+ You get to play as Evie Frye (a bad-ass combo of Black Widow & Hermione Granger)

+ You get to wear and color customize incredibly stylish outfits

+ You get to rescue children from evil sweat shops

+ Fight Club (though I'm not supposed to talk about it) 

+ A bajillion things to do and collect!

[u] CONS [/u] 

- A majority of the story quests require playing as Jacob Frye

- The HUD is intrusive and overwhelming (but it is entirely customizable) 

- Cart riding is wonky and awkward (and cart racing is rigged)
 
- A bajillion things to do and collect!

[h1]Superior to Unity in every way and the best traditional Assassin's Creed game to date.[/h1]
I was biased to believe that it was bad, but it ended up improving on everything that Unity stood for.

This is the truest Assassin's Creed to date. Both side content and main story missions are filled with assassin sandbox objectives and it's a delight to be able to be a proper assassin, scoping the area, picking guards 1 by 1 and outgunned and outnumbered, but prevailing over the opposition. Child Labor, Templar Huts, Gang Strongholds, Cargo Steal - encourage you to be the best, to recon, to utilize tools, to be a bad–∞ss. You can kill gang leader before actual gang war. Ziplines are a welcome addition, the cover system is better.

The assassinations are better than Unity. All of the Assassination story missions present unique settings and opportunities, "Unique Kill" is great, there are barely any fail states. Lambeth Asylym, Buckingham Palace, Bank of England, Alhambra Music Hall - so many well designed missions.

The new combat system is tough to start getting used to, but once you level up and start using Multi Kills, it becomes very satisfying. I even completed fight clubs deliberately, to farm Quadra Kills.

The music is very good. Free exploration and stealth infiltration music - masterfully crafts the atmosphere, impressively interesting timbres and arrangements. The soundscape of industrial London, with all sorts of alarms, horns, whistles, metal and machines feels very inspired and a must to experience.

The story has it's bad moments and I was planning to rant about it a lot, but no, I ended up being completely satisfied, the framework in which it operated was very good. (kill 7 henchmen and the main bad guy after)

[h1]I really liked this game - but unfortunately it's not a good game. The game is bloated. This game is a slog and chore to grind up to 100% with zero payoff. MOST of the side content is amazing, plainly good - this game's problem is that there is just too much of it! By the 10th hour of going through only side content, there won't be anything new for you to see. The collectibles are as terrible as in every Assassin's Creed game.[/h1]

After I completed the final mission, the game has yet unlocked more side content for me to do - Queen Victoria missions. You really can't help, but need to all the hard work not to go to waste, can you Ubisoft?

Bell, Dickens, Darwin, Victoria, Nightingale - none of them are of any value to the actual plot, most of them are present for like 1 mission in the entire storyline. They couldn't shoe horn Karl Marx into the story missions, and so his side content is unlocked abruptly and without introduction. 

[h1]The game is designed around the idea of "take famous person -> make protagonists run errands for them"[/h1]

The races are bad, probably the lowest point of the game. Need for Speed Underground levels of rubber-banding on opponents part.

One of the weakest games in the series. Mechanically it's identical to AC Unity (which wasn't particularly stellar either, but it was ok), but everything is a notch lower class than Unity: mission scripts are on the boring side, the city lacks the charm of Paris, and the industrial revolution is by no mean as exciting as a real revolution. Overall feels empty and pointless and I struggle making myself complete the game. Most gameplay embellishments introduced in this part don't have a meaningful difference, except gang members which throw the mission complexity and the plot out of the window - you almost always can get away with just sending the mob doing the dirty work for you and wipe the area before entering.

Sucks compared to several assassins creed games before it.

The combat feels like im fighting cartoon characters (To be fair, that was probably the idea) and is incredibly slow. The parkour is the exact same as with unity, but buggy and clunky. The grappling hook ruins the point of parkour though, so it doesn't really matter. Oh and the grappling hook ruins the point of parkour, which completely tosses any motivation to climb anywhere right out the window.

Progressions sucks with both characters having different levels, because you have to constantly switch to keep them somewhat in sync. Otherwise you'll have a level 13 Jacob and a level 7 Evie. And at that point it's just awkward.

The graphics and setting are the only thing that save this game, but it's still an awful game for an Assassins Creed title.

Just finished the game (never bother with all collectibles unless really worth collecting).
This is one of the best games in the entire Assassin's Creed Franchise. Lots of great new ideas like the grappling hook, horse carts (with ram ability to take out enemies in pursuit), and various in-game activities (like boat raids, cargo escorts/hijacks, templar hunts & gang strongholds etc.) keep the game "fresh" and give you tons of things to do to besides the excellent main missions. Especially liberating districts from enemy gangs is lots of fun, as you get to take out their operations by force (be it by liberating children from sweatshops, kidnapping leaders, taking out templars or rampaging through their strongholds). 
A true highlight of the series - I actually liked this one more than Unity & Origins, i.e. the predecessor/successor titles. If you love the AC franchise, this game is a must. If you don't like AC, you probably will change your mind once you've given this game a try. 
The only thing I dislike about the game is that it gives you a choice between two characters, but then goes on to disregard your choice for some specific missions (which can only be played as one of the two protagonists exclusively). But given the overall quality of the game, that minor flaw can be forgiven.
While the main game is set in 1868, you also get to see a small part of London (around Tower Bridge) in 1915 in a side mission storyline. The Jack the Ripper expansion is set shortly before the turn of the century, and is the best part of the game.
While the game itself is good, the Jack the Ripper expansion/DLC is close to a masterpiece. The lighting, the athmosphere, the special moves, the new activities - absolutely amazing. I just wish they hadn't ruined the story with a predictable ending that reversed daring choices earlier in the storyline (I would've preferred more open & unclear outcome, and thought the main game protagonist was made to look ineffective and weak in the storyline of the expansion), but that doesn't change the magnificent gameplay.

Although both protagonists are engaging and funny, the gameplay falls a bit short of other assassin's creed games. Combat is somewhat held back from it's predecessors, moving (especially on ledges) is clunky at best and mission endangering at worst. 

The gang mechanic was interesting, although on multiple occasions gang members showed up (during missions even) when I did not call them and started randomly killing Templars or Blighters. This caused multiple mission failures and the impossibility of getting some mission challenges/side quests because of their antics.

I was not afraid of the antagonist. He seemed like a robber baron who just lost his chain of command.

The good: the setting is incredible. I love how they did Victoria-era London and was delightfully disgusted when I did the asylum quest. Carriages were also incredible. The city felt alive, it felt moody, it felt bustling and dirty and smelly - just I have read London was in the 19th Century. 

I think this game is worth your time, despite the shortcomings.

Guy Ritchie's Assassin's Creed: Syndicate. I didn't give this game a fair shot when it first came out, I didn't have the patience then that  I now have for tackling certain lengthy stealth missions. The game is gorgeous, I mean they captured the dirty industrial age so It's not like mountains and fields of flowers gorgeous but it is so damn well designed. Evie and Jacob easily jumped up to being some of my favorite assassin's in the series. I know that's considered blasphemous in many fans eyes when Altair and Ezio exist but I was enthralled in my 30 hours of play. Having to level the two up separately forces you to spend time with the both of them and if you wanna be a powerhouse by the endgame then you'll most likely tackle all of the missions available. I wont spoil any interactions with certain figureheads, I know Syndicate sits at being around four games ago but this could still be a fresh experience for some. 

Taking place after Unity, I did feel a little bit restricted in terms of customization. Where's Unity allowed you to choose from single swords to heavy swords, axes to spears and even rifles as well as a wide variety of costuming options. Syndicate will let you choose from three weapon categories: Kukri Knives, Sword Canes, and Knuckle Dusters. Fortunately for me, I loved each of them and spent a lot of time playing with each of the weapon classes. You even get to choose from a variety of pistols which are surprisingly fun to use and you will use them often. Something that was interesting about Syndicate was that some of the rarer items could only be crafted by rare materials, rare materials that could only be received through doing certain missions thus incentivizing you to play through them all.

Another fun addition was forming your gang "The Rooks". I didn't use them nearly as much as I should have, once fully upgraded, you can even summon a carriage full of them to your aid and at max level they are just as powerful as the enemy AI late game. There are a variety of activities to do with them form carriage thefts to train robberies (damn, kind of want a Western Assassin's Creed now. Anyone else? Remember the "secret project" in Black Flag lol.) to turf wars and cargo escorts. As with plenty of the other Assassin's Creed titles, there is still some buggy AI and this will lead to some frustrations. Tailing missions are a plenty and in terms of the parkour mechanic, it felt like a slight step back from Unity. This lead to either Jacob or Evie going in directions that aren't exactly where you were pointed even if the path looked clear, quick fixes though. Just change your path.

Overall Assassin's Creed Syndicate was an awesome game and I'm glad I gave it a second chance. Now on my way to Origins, I start to get into what some have referred to as the Mythology series. I can only take this to mean that there is some Egyptian Mythology in Origins, and Greek for Odyssey. I have also heard that the next few are rather large installments in the franchise, I personally can't wait. If you're a fan of Assassin's Creed or just a fan of stealth action games, I highly recommend Syndicate, I think there is something here for everyone to enjoy.

The last old school Assassin's Creed game, and it is a good one.

Game play wise, this is very good and it plays much better than older Creed games. The combat has been reworked, so you are not just waiting for the enemies to strike so you can counter them. The parkour elements are much more fluid, with separate buttons for going up and going down. Also, you have a grappling hook this time, so you can get to the top of any structure in seconds. 

However, the real star here is the city of London itself. It just looks great and feels authentic to what the city would've looked and felt like in the 19th century. The amount of detail crammed in is impressive, and I was still noticing new things towards the end of my play through.

I don't know... this game feels like all form and no function. Despite it looking pretty and feeling very Londonish, it just doesn't feel like there's much holding this game together. It also doesn't help that there are bugs, glitches and optimisation issues all over the place.

But 3 hours in and I don't feel gripped by the narrative, or the combat, or the exploration or the gang management... or basically anything about this game. It all just feels very muted and disconnected, not enough to keep me actually entertained rather than just present. It's like they said to themselves "I know all the stock parts of an Assassin's Creed game, let's do it again" and that was it.

The integration of the narrative with the gameplay seems very half-arsed too. I started playing, I got to London after playing a couple of disjointed missions, then one character expresses an interest in being a gangleader and sooo... now they're a gang leader, with no particular preamble. I defeat a random gang boss by kicking him off a train and sooo... now I have a train with a load of management options and a bunch of other characterless characters thrown in, okay... how... entertaining... what relentless progress I am making by doing these otherwise boring tasks.

This just feels joyless and the whole game feels like a foreshadowing of the single player MMO direction that the games ultimately took.

New combat dynamics added since earlier games add a few more ways for this game to misbehave and disappoint.  A singular emphasis on pointless parkour marred deeply by poor interface will keep you flopping about like a fish on a dock.  What the game lacks in execution, it doubles down on in childish and puerile dialogue between the comic bookish characters which render any hope of plot and setting immersion moot.  As always, though, if the stupidity of the main storyline's plot and dialogue aren't enough to dismantle the experience, there's an unavoidable, underlying "modern comic book conflict pasted together by a vignette of historical settings" linear storyline to remind you that you're here to be subjected to the gamemaker's whimsy, rather than to actually play a game, leaving one to wonder why Ubisoft even bothers with pseudo-"open world" games at all.  The one area that the game shows clear execution is in making sure that it takes up enough time to negate your refund period in order for you to get a bare glimpse at the open game world proper, thanks to their barrage of linear introductory missions through which they pretend to entice you with their immensely forgettable characters.

Don't waste your money.

If the game were to crash again while playing in offline mode, as it did in my case multiple hours in, you might have to restart from the beginning. Alright, this is going to be a big one, but I'll try to be as complete as possible. I've just hit 100% on both the main game and the Jack the Ripper DLC, so while it's still fresh on the memory. Some of it is in spoiler text. Look at these bits at your own peril.

[h1]What I really liked:[/h1]
- The world opened quickly and is, from that point on, fully accessible. There are conquest activities that are usually interesting and well made, and plenty of collectibles.
- Dreadful Crimes (DLC) was very well thought out and definitely recommended if you liked the murder mysteries in AC:U. They've improved by miles, I figured them all out from the clues and none of the solutions felt incredible farfetched.

[h1]What I liked:[/h1]
- I've played through the game as Evie, except when forced to play another character. This is because the game has implemented a smart system where either of the twins has a unique playstyle. Jacob favours combat and Evie favours stealth. I like being stealthy, so I picked Evie. Also, during the game, Jacob's only redeeming quality is his top hat and that's never a good thing.
- The main story is entertaining, but the end is super predictable if you've played any AC game before. It ends just like [b]all[/b] the other ones. No specific spoilers, but none are needed. I don't care very much for the 'witty' arguments Evie and Jacob seem to be continuously having, but I can see how others might enjoy that type of dialogue as well.
- Freerunning has definitely improved, but the characters still stick to the Arno school of never giving up on ledges. When you're trying to move fast and precise, the system seems to be fully intent on making the wrong calls when it comes to freerunning, but I suppose this is to be expected from the AC series by now.
- Jack the Ripper (DLC) introduces a mildly interesting new concept of using fear as a weapon. You play through brief sections of the game as the bad guy, which might be seen as enjoyable to some players (but not me, I just powered through to get back to enjoyable bits). The DLC also adds a serious amount of content, which will make it worth your money.

[h1]What I disliked:[/h1]
- Jack the Ripper (DLC) has an unsurprising story that harps on the concept that "even assassins can be evil", as if we didn't know. This is meant to further an arbitrary "we're all the bad guy" narrative that this series didn't need. The unfortunate bit is that the big plot twist is presented literal seconds after the DLC starts, nothing else is surprising.
- The Last Maharaja (DLC) is a poorly thought out section of the game with minigames that are unnecessary and an entire drunk section that is neither clever nor funny. Besides this, the whole side story will at the end feel like a complete waste of time. Would not recommend.
- Races are n o n e s e n s e - aren't required for 100%, so I skipped them all but one (to try it).
- Jack the Ripper (DLC): [spoiler]It's a little bit bull that the police officers turn against you midway through the DLC. Now - all of a sudden - the assassin's activities are a problem. Honestly? 20 years ago they openly ran a crime syndicate and that was all fine and dandy, but one murder now suddenly makes it that you 'should be arrested'. Ultimately, Abberline is still on your side, but feels like rather forced plot development.[/spoiler]

[h1]What I hated:[/h1]
- The Dickens and Darwin conspiracy DLC was immensely disappointing and frankly a waste of time and effort. Strongly do not recommend.
- I had several crashes and soft locks for no reason. I would have carriages drive off even though it had no driver. Dead guys would block mission progression by claiming they were alive (but are on the ground, quite dead, but alive, but unkillable). I had a random guy panic drive off with a carriage that had a mission vital corpse in it (as part of the mission). More crashes. I had audio glitches where suddenly no voice lines were spoken. All in all, I think during the time I played, I encounted 10 to 20 serious bugs and it's not a good look for a game with this type of budget.
- Huge downside for what I personally hate [b]the most[/b] in video games. Getting beaten in a cutscene. [spoiler]Lucy (an enemy) steals a necklace from Evie, despite having just lost a fight without putting a scratch on Evie. Hate it. Just have Evie be too late instead and Lucy already has the necklace and escapes the fight. Same result. Similarly, the plot ultimately didn't need Lucy to even have the necklace, so this was very pointless.[/spoiler]

[h1]Would recommend![/h1]
All in all, I'd say this game is a solid game to play in the AC series. It's enjoyable and certainly lives up to the AC formula.

This game is far more light-hearted and playful than the rest of the entries. I love the dynamic and playful banter between the twins. The open world sandbox is also pretty nice, with the rope launcher making it easy and fun to jump from rooftop-to-rooftop. The combat is completely revamped, especially compared to the slow-paced Unity. The fights here are quick and brutal, making it a whole lot more fun to look at and to engage in. The story is pretty bland, but the fun personality of the two, especially Jacob Frye, makes it worthwhile.

My only gripe will be how EASY every mission is and how ridiculously OVERPOWERED you will become as the game progresses. You will unlock upgrades that will make you and you allies stronger, and some will cripple your enemies' health and deadliness. By the time you finish the game, it becomes too easy wherein every enemy can die even if you don't try hard to actually survive. And also, the more places you conquer, the lesser the enemy presence is.

So yeah, it gets boring at the end where there's no more danger...at all.
Eh. Gets boring really fast, and doesn't really feel like an AC game. What's the point in sneaking around when you can duel wield revolvers through 90% of the game?

This is another standard AC game with the same old mechanics we are used to, such as: "climb, please climb, NO, I SAID CLIMB UP DON'T JUMP TO THE RIGHT WTF" and "I just wanted to climb down but instead I did a leap of faith without knowing there was one here and now my target got away"

Despite these charming frustrations, Syndicate brings a fun, new, and interesting mechanic to rooftop travel: the grappling hook. And we will probably never see it again because that's how Ubisoft works but to me it made prawling the city so much more fun and efficient. The ledge above you? Zip. That building across the street? Just spiderman that crap. 

Other than mechanics, Syndicate takes place in London which, of course, is beautiful and ugly in all of the most human ways. The thing about AC is that even if you don't care for the gameplay you can enjoy the scenery and worlds they build which are surprisingly accurate in design if not scale.

tl;dr I have many gripes about the AC series but I still play them.

I immensely enjoyed Black Flag before this, but I just wasn't feeling it with Syndicate. It doesn't have anything unique to its name except for the Victorian setting, but I found the world to be lacking in detail, and sort of lifeless. The only new things this adds to the series are vehicles and a gimmick to skip all of the climbing, both of which are anathema to Assassin's Creed as a whole. And yet for some reason I keep thinking that enjoyment is to be had somewhere in here, and I simply haven't found it yet. If you have any advice on how to have fun with this game, please share your wisdom, because I'm going to need it going forward.

Here's the short: If you're a fan of the traditional AC formula, you'll likely like this one. If not or you came into Origins and beyond and like those, this one likely won't change your mind. I would recommend getting it on sale + [u] Jack the Ripper DLC [/u]. 

I happen to fall into the first camp. To be clear, I think Origins/Odyssey/Valhalla, what I call Nu-AC, are just barely okay as games but really awful Assassin's Creed games because they veer so far away from the formula and stealth and assassinations are a complete after thought it feels, so much so that they really should stop calling it Assassin's Creed and brand it as a spin off series of its own. 

That aside I think it's unfortunate that Syndicate was the last of the traditional formula because it introduces some neat ideas like the grapple launcher, although some people feel it takes away climbing puzzles which yeah I can see where they're coming from there, the gang system which did affect the world in a noticeable but largely inconsequential way, and with its setting being the one that takes us the closest to modern day without going into the bland Abstergo vs. Modern Assassins stuff, although there is still some of that sprinkled in. 

The main game is nothing special in the series. Towers, tons of collectibles which amount to not much, side activities, very bare bones RPG mechanics, a story that just drags along over a about 20 hours, and some crashes and bugs here and there that required a restart from time to time. You might think I'm weird for recommending the game after listing off those last points which would indicate a tepid or mediocre experience. That's because as of writing this I just finished the Jack the Ripper DLC 100% sync (99% for main game, can't be bothered with WW1 collectibles), and honestly that experience alone was worth it and what I consider the pinnacle of this game and the best Assassin's Creed content since Black Flag/Rogue. I'm dead serious. I would gladly trade Nu-AC for more content like Jack the Ripper DLC or full games modeled off of it. 

Here's why: When it comes to telling a story in a game, what you tell and how you tell it are pretty important pieces. The story itself isn't really special, pretty short compared to the main game as expected, and deals with how the Assassins are connected to an important historical figure. What really struck me was the dread and atmosphere, especially when playing as Jack the Ripper, it touches on the Assassin's relationship with greater society and how it's getting more and more difficult to be secret while maintaining a relationship with important figures or public institutions like the police, and the fear mechanic was the cherry on top. Like most/all Ubisoft titles, it has some great ideas but never quite reaches its potential and I feel like this DLC was the closest they've ever gotten to it since the very first game back in 2007, and leaves me wishing that they kept going in this direction to do so.

Bought this game shortly after receiving a copy of Assassin's Creed: Unity, and can safely attest that both Unity and Syndicate are amazing games with a wide array of content, they offer an improved AAA Assassin (not pirate‚Äî not warrior‚Äî ASSASSIN) experience akin to those of the first AC games in the series, with improved stealth in practically every aspect. If you're looking to play an Assassin's Creed that feels like Assassin's Creed but not in a dated fashion‚Äî Syndicate and Unity are what you should go for.

While Syndicate offers the player the Assassin flair the latest or even some of the previous games in the series have failed to deliver, one of the only flaws I feel like worth mentioning is it's parkour system who's blander and whose sometimes feels inconsistent (moreso than even Unity under certain cases), and the depth and intricate skills you'd have from parkouring in Unity are barely transferrable to Syndicate's own parkour, even though they're the same system, while the map is Unity was built for intricate and skillful parkour, Syndicate's world has been stripped of parkour elements. Still, either way, it is a much more enjoyable freerunning experience than any of the games that came after, and I don't really feel like there are any other objective problems that don't stem from subjective point of views or biases.

I'd visit Revelations' Istanbul and Ezio's Italy once or twice if I had time, but I'd go back to Syndicate's London a thousand times.

Excellent world, beautiful art. Horrible controls, bunches of bugs and movement glitches. Terrible game design choices in terms of control schemes, difficulty, mission design, and so on. The only thing that keeps me coming back to finish the story is the world design. I do feel quite immersed into late 19th century London, so they nailed that. I just cannot stand failing a mission because my character jumped in the complete wrong direction, or dropped someone in front of a carriage instead of putting them inside one, or many of the other errors that could have easily been avoided in a better designed game.

AI behavior is extremely inconsistent. You can murder someone right in front of them and they won't ever see you. Other times you can fling a knife from a rooftop 20 meters away and they'll immediately initiate combat and bring the whole gang with them. Your own gang ally members can sometimes run into an area while you're sneaking around doing your assassin things, and initiate combat with enemies, sometimes causing you to fail optional objectives, or causing kidnap targets to run away. There is no way to tell your allies to stay away. You only get to watch as your targets are meddled with by a stupid AI.

Combat is extremely frustrating. You can attack lightning fast about 4 times in a row, and then suddenly your character refuses to move for a good 2 seconds to leave an opening for the enemy to hit back. If you're fighting a group of enemies, it will throw 3 different button queues at you at a time. You can not do anything in this situation because if you press 1, you miss the other 2 and take damage and most likely stagger as well, where another couple enemies might attack you again. Enemies have the ability to block, which requires a heavy attack to break their defense. If you hit them with a light attack, they will stagger you and hit you back. That's fine and fair, however it takes a million years to pull off a heavy attack, during which you can be attacked by other enemies. Also, enemies can start to block while you're in the middle of attacking them, so they get a cheap deflect since there's no way to cancel your attacks. There really should have been a dodge/roll button that can be used at any time in combat. During combat, your camera is locked down below a certain angle. If there is a sniper above the fight, you are simply NOT ALLOWED to look up at them to do something about it. Despite, you know, the main gimmick of this game being a GRAPPLE HOOK, and the fact that you have a gun for just such a thing. Speaking of which, you are completely unable to manually aim your gun during combat. The aim button isn't even used for anything else in combat!!! Why the hell can't you still aim if you want to???

Also, speaking of the grapple, it does make traversal much nicer than having to climb up and down repetitively. It's a little clunky, but it can be forgiven because you're not supposed to be Spiderman, you're supposed to be a 19th century assassin. The major problem with it is you cannot aim where you want to fire the grapple. You have to completely rely on the contextual auto-aim by looking around. I cannot tell you how many times I've looked straight forward at a roof in front of me, but Jacob or Evie TURN AROUND and grapple up onto the building behind me. That wouldn't have happened if I was allowed to manually aim to which ledge I wanted to go to.

I really wanted to like this game. Somewhere within, there is a really good game. It's just buried under the layers of terrible, contextual controls and shoddy AI. I am really hoping Origins improves upon these things.

This game is fantastic! It's pretty different from the other AC games, and is more combat heavy in some instances. The combat itself is a mix between the traditional AC combat and the Batman: Arkham series. The stealth mechanics are pretty alright, too. You actually have a crouch button in this one, compared to the earlier games. Not as good as 2, Brotherhood, or Black Flag, but still, I love it. As of writing this review, I have not beaten it, but I will say there are some things in the game I do not enjoy:

1. The game focuses more on Jacob than Evie, which sucks, because I think Evie's character is more fun to play as, especially during stealth missions
2. The game is more balanced for Jacob, due to Ubisoft's opinions on female protagonists at the time the game was made
3. Robert Topping's races are bullshit. The driving in the game isn't great
4. Getting off of the train hideout can be a pain

Regardless, this is a fun game, and a nice addition to the AC series. 8/10 in my book

This is definitely one of the best Assassin's Creed games I have so far played.
The controls are almost perfect, and you actually feel like you are having full control of your movements, without jumping into your death. Although, I never got it to work well with a controller. So, this was with mouse and keyboard.

The atmosphere in this game is beyond stunning with really nice soundtrack. You really feel like walking around in the old London and if you have ever watched the Sharlock Holms movie with Robert Downey Jr., you will quickly see the same atmospheric feeling to this game. The idea of having two main characters to control with different main missions works quit well. My only complaint is that there are no "outside" world of the Animus and the storyline could have a little more depth. But besides all that, I really enjoyed this game!
