Personally, this is one of my favorite Assassins Creed games, after Black Flag. The game mechanics and the story is very intriguing and will keep you hooked for a while. There's a lot of creativity with this game, you're able to create a gang and eventually rule all of London, and have your goals of being the best gang possible. The perks are the best, both characters have their own set of personal perks, but most of them they have commonly between each other.
Yes.

For an "Assassin's Creed", not at all a bad game but also not one of the Best Ones either. The Story is boring but gameplay is fine.
But as an open world game, it's really good.. Play it and enjoy it.

This game is also the last Assassin's Creed before they changed the gameplay, so the game is as simple as those Assassin's Creed use to be.

The environment is this game looks clean. Victorian London and it's streets are big. The Architecture in this game in beautiful, spot on from historical standpoint, the world design itself is very good. Streets are filled with people & so many buildings have fully explorable interiors that makes this open world a must see. The scaling of everything in the massive.

The basic missions you embark on are pretty normal as far as "Assassin's Creed" games go with the usual objectives of tailing, killing and kidnapping. Parkour is as good as any assassin's creed game, driving carriages and rampaging on the streets of London with it is a lot of fun, hell, you can even drift with horse drawn carriages. Fighting enemies on train tops & carriage tops and kicking them off the running train & carriages gives a feeling of much satisfying finishing blow. Combat, Stealth and Ecosystem is also very good. Combat system a little different from other AC.

But many things in this game has upsides and downsides.
For example.. The scaling of everything in the massive, the roads. the buildings, the trains etc.. the sense of scale really adds a feeling to the game.. jumping from rooftops to assassinate your target etc feels great.. but then again, the buildings are so far apart that it creates issue with the free-running when you have to move from rooftops of one side of the road to the other side of the road or if you're chasing someone or avoiding someone who's chasing you, it takes so much time to often climb the building or get down from building bcoz the roads are way too wide which makes those buildings far from each other creating issue of not being able to jump directly to the rooftops of other side of the road.. that problem only gets solved when you get the grappling hook to easily glide from one side to the other side of the road. So everything has both it's upsides and downsides.

Overall a good open world game.

Ironically, my controls didn't seem to work smoothly until AFTER the very last story mission. 
The story's interesting but a lot of the missions weren't. Conquering London quickly gets repetitive and often the only thing that kept me playing was the fact that I just loved moving through this city. It's gorgeous and feels very real, and ziplining along rooftops makes it very easy to travel long distances. I wish they'd added single horses as well as the carriages, it would often make it easier to navigate the streets. 
I played most of this game after finishing Origins and Odyssey, and following those two this is a letdown. It's far less sprawling and just overall more forgettable. Play it if you love London and the Victorian era, otherwise skip it.

Highjacking carriages and taking down locations and building up your gang was great and something i usually didn't care for. There is no story, just an array of loosley strung together side missions ranging from simpler than the turorial to ragequittingly frustrating, mostly since the controls fight you while you are on a timer.
Progression is pretty quick, skill points are plenty.
Sadly there is no mission replay. Once I got the end game gear I already was stuck with having only hunting down collectibles or doing cargo missions. 

Controls are again a sore point for me as pc user. I was constantly fighting automatic actions like climbing walls or railings when bumping into them while sprinting.
Just a dedicated sprint and climb button would make movement a lot simpler.
World and character Interaction though.... E does it all: speak, pickpocket, knock out, takcle, pick up, loot, open chests and doors. I'm a bit surprised how I didn't knock out a pickpocket target more often.

The map while just a small part of London, seemed quite accurate as far as I could tell. However generic city blocks in Whitechapel and City felt a bit too much like copy-paste to me. 

Overall didn't feel like a waste of money since I got it on sale, but unlike other entries of the series Syndicates London didn't strike my sightseeing itch.

EDIT :This review still remains Negative but wanted to make sure people know Roofisoft/Rapeysoft made this game. They don't deserve your money.


TL;DR - Hurr durr previously free and accessible collectible maps are now micro transaction bait hurr hurr.

TL;BRIA - You know the drill guys...its a Ubisoft sandbox third-person-action game. It looks pretty, well made albeit with the usual Ubisoft brand of bugs, you know, the small ones that annoy you persistently but not enough to raise a huge cry over?
We have all been here before. Many many times. Watch Dogs, Far Cry, Assassin's Creed..so many times...

But this time is different. Because this time, Ubisoft has finally done it. Locked the collectibles maps (thats right! MAPS! Plural! there are two sets of collectibles map!) behind a micro-transaction .And the cost has risen since Unity as well, the Helix Points needed this time is 1000 which doesn't come by often in this game.

In sum, Ubisoft has made sure that an active part of its already available content is made that much harder to find unless you cough up 10 euros for EACH map. Look, DLC's always been part of the Ubisoft package, but its always have been adding something extra or giving you access to some high level gear early in the game. In this case however, a DLC actively takes away your 100% unless you're willing to comb thru the huge open world for them or stream a video guide on the side. All of which actively takes away all the fun in a game.

Maybe this is an unfair gripe and some people might say "yeah, you think all collectibles should appear as blazing neon icons on the map everytime? How privileged are you???". All fair points. But this is a Ubisoft game. With their usual brand of collectibles which always have been accesible to those of us who think paying a fair price for a game is enough to enjoy its content. Not this time.
The best old-school / pre-RPG AC out there. If you missed this due to how bugged Unity was, I seriously suggest giving it a go!

i was going to wait until i was done to review but im honestly not sure that'll happen. 

the main characters haven't been developed past their initial stereotypes for like the last 5 sequences. the most im getting out of the story is "mean templar owns everything in london, his faceless gang of repeated character models are all evil, jacob wants to make a better gang, and evie wants to find pieces of eden." everything outside of that has either been jacob and evie rehashing their same argument about what to do over and over (someone explain to me how jacob can think pieces of eden are all nonsense stories after everything that's happened in this series), or shoehorned historical references and political intrigue that flies by at such a pace or at times when your attention is divided that absolutely none of it sticks. I couldn't tell you everything that happened in most ac games but at least i have some solid memories of characters and circumstances, while this game is just all over the place.

on top of that, it just isn't nearly as fun. london is huge, which seems like a good thing, but it kind of makes freerunning much less useful than it should be in an ac game. driving is boring and often terrible, especially when the game decides to spawn four carriages around you during a chase and physics are absolutely thrown out the window. the grappling hook is cool in theory but due to london's size it kind of replaces frerunning, and you end up on slow ziplines around london for the majority of your travel time. 

the two character system also seems cool but honestly evie's overpowered stealth skills are so much more useful than jacob's combat skills, which is especially annoying because they make so many of the jacob missions stealth based after making it clear he's the combat specialist. i can't remember a single memorable mission even from the story, and the district missions are all the same five missions copied and pasted about a dozen times with different amounts of guards, most of which are trivialized by evie's stealth and knife headshots. the game does like to make things difficult by spawning in enemies like in carriage chases, as well as shitty ai decisions that can completely ruin a mission through no fault of your own, especially if you're trying to get 100% synch, which i absolutely would not recommend.

the way people talk about unity is generally how i feel about this game. i didn't expect to love unity but it sucked me in with its simple love and revenge story, good satisfying combat, and beautiful sights. syndicate gave me shallow, unlikeable characters, weirdly fast but boring combat with a focus on excessively long and flashy executions, and a city, as detailed as it is, ends up feeling unvaried and boring, probably due to the repetitive missions. im looking forward to finally getting to origins more than ever now.

Here's an opinion (sort of) on this little, probably a bit underrated Assassin's Creed: GTA London 1868 game. 
The point is here in this ‚Üì
Why even make London here larger than a whole planet Earth if you couldn't handle other aspects? Like, book novel of this game is tremendous, it is gorgeous, it is better than sex to read it. Why couldn't I play what was and how was written in a book as I definitely would? Imagine, story in game would have that level of quality, while we all got typical British humour wank story. No offence for those who liked it, they just really, really overpushed in writing a bunch of interesting characters rather than develop them. That sucks but I know it could be better.
And a gameplay. The gameplay. Would call it an Assassin's Creed: Unity 0.5 and would be even right. Still, called it Assassin's Creed: GTA London 1868. With all that bloody similarities. With all that simplicity. Some missions are barely passable but not because they got Minesweeper Windows 98 Edition difficulty but because of bugs. Games's so easy it's BRAINLESS.
Still I would recommend it. With all that sins, bugs. underperformed story, "GTA got a heecup" vibes, with all that Johnny Sins, it's still have a gorgeous London, tremendous cast of historical personalities, probably the best DLC out of all franchise (Sorry, The Da Vinci Dissapearence, Dreadful Crimes took my Sherlock Holmes' inner fanboy's heart and ate it and I like it) and you definitely would get an unforgettable experience.
Just a fun game for anyone with tactical/stealthy likeings.

I‚Äôll start off by saying that I really like the AC, Far Cry, Tomb Raider type games. They blend adventure, interesting characters, good storylines, and a bit of a grind into all of their games. With that being said, Syndicate is no exception. 

In reading other reviews, they mentioned bugs and glitches in the game. I had almost no bugs or crashes until towards the end of the game. I think the DLC was somewhat poorly made or optimized and did introduce some bugs and straight up crashing to where I‚Äôd have to restart my game.

With that being said, I did really enjoy this game. The atmosphere of London was fantastic, the graphics were very good, the combat was simple yet fun, and the characters/story was pretty cool. 

I did get this game at a heavy discount on a Steam Sale so that definitely affects my review. I would not get this game at it‚Äôs full price but would definitely recommend it at a discount. 

7.5/10

Basically Unity if it's mechanics and overall gameplay was better. Doesn't do much for the franchise but it's still immersive. Story is really poor especially Evie and Jacob are not interesting at all, although Jacob starts out as being quite childish but slowly learns his faults, and we only see this more improved Jacob in the Jack the Ripper DLC so that's a shame. I came from a Georgian, England city so it felt great for me. I wouldn't really recommend it as it does nothing to further expand the series and becomes extremely dull and repetitive. But! You do get to beat chavs up until they defecate. So what's that; a 10/10 of course!!!

Virtual Tour Bus

As far as time sink experiences go, this is a pleasant one.

Victorian London's digital reconstruction is a marvel to behold and the true reason to buy this game - it is just breathtaking. Although somewhat anachronistic and revisionist for obvious reasons - e.g. no prostitutes in the streets of London for Jack to kill.

Speaking of anachronisms, the inclusion of historical celebrities like Marx & Darwin as quest givers is a joke that this franchise needs to let go. The writing of such characters makes my eyes and ears bleed. Just stop it.

Gameplay-wise, you know what you are getting, it is the usual Assassin's Creed bloated content. But this time it feels better curated and paced.

The story is just a formality but the characters are very likable with superb voice-acting.

One of the good AC games.

I've played quite a few of the AC games and this one is my all around favorite. The visuals are stunning the and combat is enjoyable, having played AC Origins this i believe was the last game before the combat mechanics update so it's a nice representation of that final "ode to traditional style combat" found in the original AC but with some tasteful updates and changes. 

The characters make for a memorable duo and quite honestly it was their personalities that brought me back to this game, in addition to the enjoyable story missions. The unique kills make for some pretty awesome cutscenes and there's quite enough extra content (even before expansions) to keep you satisfied. 

I'm at 22 hours currently and just approaching the tail end of the story now if that's any indicator. For the$19.99 you spend to get it at its current price, I'd say its well worth it.

I only really had one complaint.. 
*****heads up this is a spoiler if you haven't finished the first three games****

With the end of Desmonds journey I guess I would've liked to see more of a linear continuation of that story and plot pretense - however unfortunately it seems that the "real world" story has stepped into a more difficult-to-follow narrative (but for anyone who played AC4) this has been going on for a while.. 

All in all, I'd give it a solid 4.5/5 though - Great gameplay, beautiful graphics, rich story and memorable characters. It would've been sweet to have some PvP/Multiplayer like in brotherhood/unity - that would be an absolute blast. Maybe there will be something in Valhalla? 

For what it's worth, I do consider myself a tough judge.

Ever since the release of Assassins Creed back in 2007, I have been a fan of the Assassins Creed series, and when when Syndicate was released I heard great things about it, but when I picked it up, I can't say I was that impressed.

Now that's not to say the game isn't good, I was just underwhelmed by how small the map was compared to previous titles and the new gameplay mechanics weren't for me - I was after all used to the original mechanics.

Skip a few years ahead and we see the release of Origins and Odyssey, both two games that use an altered version of Syndicates mechanics and I find myself really enjoying both games, though both weren't very "Assassins Creed" like. So I think I will revisit this game when I have time.

At this point in the series, Assassin's Creed Syndicate is the 2nd best Creed game (behind AC2). I was not expecting it to be as good as it is, but Ubisoft learned from their mistakes in previous games. Syndicate is the classic Assassin's Creed formula refined and perfected.

Evie and Jacob make a strong duo. Either one of them alone ranks higher than most of the other protagonists in the series for me. They're further held up by a strong cast of characters and many worthy foes. The story is intriguing, well-paced, with an ending as good as I've seen from this series. 

While the graphics quality feels like a downgrade from Unity, the aesthetic does Victorian-era London justice. 

The side missions were fun, although the bounty hunt missions were weak. The assassination missions were as strong as ever. I loved that they kept the "Opportunities" system from Unity. I also felt that the WWI side content was tremendous. It was shocking to me how much content was in this game that Ubisoft could have put behind a pay gate, but didn't.

The parkour and combat continue to evolve, even beyond the strong showing from Unity. The upgrade, gang, and gear systems were all well thought out too. As I played the game, my two characters were getting stronger. I felt that I could tailor them to my play style.

Syndicate serves to be a lovely "farewell" letter to the aging Assassin's Creed formula. I'm looking forward to seeing how Ubisoft shakes things up with Origins and Odyssey.

I played it when it came out and didn't like it that much. Everything felt like a side mission without much clarity as to what I was actually supposed to be doing or which character I was supposed to be doing it with and SO MANY COLLECTIBLES. Honestly, it's ridiculous. Now that it's been a few years, I know what to expect and I can enjoy the game more. Having gone through it a second time now, the story line makes a bit more sense.

Probably THE best Assassin's Creed game in the series, IF you don't count the following two. Humor is on point without being cheesy or dumb, historical figures are relevant and mostly accurate to real life counterparts, and gameplay is easy and smooth for new players. 20/10

2020 Honest Review

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Aspect[/th]
        [th]Reviews[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics[/td]
        [td]Quite impressive for 2015 games. I love the beauty of London.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay[/td]
        [td]It's still stealth and parkour (and now you can drive a wagon/carriage/cart but I hate tapping spacebar just to increase speed). But from this series you"ll see that Assassin's Creed becomes more RPG than the predecessors (just like Far Cry franchise, seriously Ubisoft?). They implement SKILL TREE and EXPERIENCE POINT. For every 1000 Exp you will get 1 skill tree point and you will be leveled up based on how many skill tree points you've spent. You also need to collect various materials to craft weapons or armors. You can conquer boroughs and do some side missions. Not only skill tree, you also can upgrade your gang. Do you need grinding? Yes. Will it take you much time? I think no, just a little bit. If you conquer London before completing the main mission, I bet you will unlock all skills, gang upgrades and most of the weapons, armors, & outfits. Yes, they give you many choices of weapons, armors, and outfits that you can upgrade once too. Uniquely, you can play as 2 character with different specialties : The Frye Twins, Evie and Jacob. Evie favored for stealth and Jacob for straight fighting. But after you unlock all the skills, I feel that both of them can do both stealth and straight fighting (h2h combat). But for some of main missions require you to play with the selected character (they have different logos on map). Another part that I like is Rope Launcher (or Grappling Hook) which will make traversing and killing much more efficient. IMO, the downside is there is no sleeping dart. But overall, fresh gameplay, not very RPG, you still can use hidden blade, going stealth, and kill templars. After playing AC Black Flag, AC Rogue, and AC Unity, I ranked AC Syndicate as 2nd after Black Flag. Rogue imitates Black Flag and Unity a little bland but still enjoyable.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Story[/td]
        [td]Set in the Victorian Era in London. So you"ll see coal mining, child labor, driving machinery, steam trains, steam ships. The main story is good, not very "Assassination" thing like in the AC : Unity but also included some political agendas. But I think the best villain here is Maxwell Roth, not Crawford Starrick. I love the main characters especially Evie because she is woman and mature. Jacob is funny. Both have different personalities, and having siblings can sometimes make you fight. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Price[/td]
        [td]Average, get the BUNDLE. 4 titles in order.[/td]
    [/tr]
     [tr]
        [td]System requirements[/td]
        [td]Run Highest setting with RX 580 averaging 51FPS, sometimes I hit 30ish FPS. Yeah, time for me to buy a new card.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Bugs[/td]
        [td]Stucked once and desynchronized automatically. But I didn't find any bugs that affect gameplay.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Patch updates[/td]
        [td]No more updates.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Others[/td]
        [td]I played 80% with Evie, not because I love stealth, but this is the first time I could play as woman in this franchise. She is the best character so far. LOVE IT[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

OVERALL : 9/10. Enjoyed this game so much, been dating with Evie around 51 hours with 95% completion. Too tired to get 100% completion.

Edit : I got 99% completion after finishing World War I missions.

Let's go through my list of ''Likes'' and ''Dislikes'' about this game. Shall we?

[Likes]
* Interesting time period
* Ability to switch between the two protagonists via the menu
* The liberating of the boroughs reminds me of when I liberated the areas in Assassin's Creed 3. Ah, the memories! This one is slightly better, though.
* The Stealth, Assistance, and Infiltration opportunities first introduced in Assassin's Creed: Unity. A real treat to see those opportunities in this, shall we say, interesting game!
*Beautiful historic landmarks!

[Dislikes]
* The combat system is, well, bullocks. I prefer the Ezio trilogy's take on the combat system.
* Lack of historical figures as Templars. I know, beggars can't be choosers, but, hey, AC3 had the closest one had to a list of ACTUAL historical people as Templars. The heck, Ubisoft Quebec!
* The player is forced to spectate during the modern day portion. What the actual f--k, Ubisoft Quebec! AC: Black Flag's may have been faceless, but, at least we DID something during the modern day portion!

I'd rate this game no more than a 7/10. Despite its major flaws that I listed, it is a pretty damn good game!

Also the Modern Day story is much better than the previous few, but still not back to the levels of the first 4 games.

After a rather serious tone in Unity, I'm glad that Syndicate's taking a more relaxing approach. The story is very good and well-paced, filling with many colorful characters. It can be repetitive if you're completionist type but you don't have to be doing everything if you don't want to. Highly recommended.

I kinda fell out of Assassins Creed for a bit, then Origins brought me back to the series. I happened to play Syndicate after completing Origins and Odyssey so I was missing the new mechanics which I felt were much better. However Syndicate is a good AC game, and I had missed the good old Assassins Vs Templars rivalry. 

While this game is a bit old, its still a great game to explore. I initially avoided it as I am not a big fan of the time period that was the focal point of this game, but was pleasantly surprised when I played it. As usual its was relatively easy to master the game and along with it classic AC mechanics were fun to exploit. The world is pretty immersive and while I do wish the map was larger , there is still a lot of cool areas to explore and discover. The Victorian/industrial era vision has been beautifully captured by the developers and you really get into the environment as time passes. 

But best of all, its got a good story and some memorable and lovable characters which makes it worth your while. There are aspects of the game that are repetitive and monotonous though. Certain activities are just rinse and repeat ones and gets boring over time.

Great Game :D

So there are so many bad things to say about this game that I will start with the positives.

The open world is pretty good and feels alive. It is a lot of fun to just look at the while riding the train or to walk trough the streets.
This game also had one of the most creative hideouts - a train.
It also looks pretty good in terms of graphics but has the same render distance issues that Unity had.
The parkour looks almost as good as in Unity but not quite as good.
Having two main characters was also a interesting but the way the playtime was split between them is bad.
Assassination missions were the best type of mission in this game since you had multiple ways to approach the mission, it was similar to Unity but felt a lot more refined and finished.
The Kenway mansion was the most interesting place to explore in the game and it was just really cool going there.

But well, now to the bad points.

First of there is Jacob. He ruined most serious moments with his bad jokes. They tried making him a goddamn comedian but man his jokes are really bad most of the time, I mean Evies Ezio reference was funnier than most of his jokes. Evie would have actually been an alright character but she just didn't have enough "screen time". The story was alright when Jacob wouldn't ruin it with his first grader humor.
The modern day was better than in Unity, which isn't hard to pull off, but it was still bad. I mean they kept talking about a modern day story that would have actually been interesting but no we get like 10 minutes over the whole game and we don't even get to play it.....
While the open world did look good that was all it did. The open world was terrible when it came to parkour opportunities, it was so bad in fact that they had too add a rope launcher which felt ridiculous and unbelievable as hell, I mean it felt like someone went: " hey how about we make it spider-man" and then someone reminded them that they can't do that so they did this. And to top that the parkour was just buggy as hell at times. I mean I tried free running on a tree and suddenly the char I was playing as would just stop and when I tried to continue they would either just walk on the spot or fucking fly away.
The combat was also not much better. It looked "cartoonish" and just ridiculous. All you had to do was spam X and occasionally press either B or A so yeah and in terms of weapon variety the game offered you three weapon types or rather one weapon type but three types of skin either the knife the stick or the fist and they all played the exact same. The combat was also inconsistent at times cause sometimes enemies can't damage you when you are in a finisher animation but other times they can......
Even more inconsistent was the stealth. It was alright except for the times where enemies detect you through walls or instantly see you even though you were 10m away from them and they saw you for a second. It just got annoying pretty quickly.
The game also isn't the most stable. I had a lot of crashes but luckily not to the point where I could become unplayable like with Unity.

Overall this is one of the worst Assassin's Creed games. The gameplay was alright but the story was just not that good and didn't even take itself serious at times. I would say that this game isn't worth it at all.

This game is a massive improvement over unity

+ Having started playing this game the day after I finished Unity, this game craps all over Unity from the very first few minutes of play and shows up Unity for the massive turd that it is.
+ The parkour is better, much smoother. Small movements are possible again to edge into position. Your character will not jump up even on low crates unless you press the parkour up button.
+ The main characters have much more personality. The Frye twins play off each other brilliantly. In general, the writing is much better.
+ Proper side characters are back. Say hello to people like Charles Darwin and Charles Dickens.
+ As someone who lives close to London, it feels like a very believable rendition of London in the 19th century.
+ This is the closest Assassin's Creed ever gets to the brilliant AC2 trilogy. Not that I don't like the subsequent games (in fact I love Origins), but they take a different path. Syndicate is the closest feeling of fun you get from the AC2 trilogy.

= I'm not a big fan of the weapon and armour system in Syndicate (which is an extension of Unity's). It feels in between the more or less straight "worst to best" systems in the older games and the more full-on RPG system in later games, but the worst of both worlds. It feels limiting. However, it's a relatively minor gripe in the context of some of the worst element of the last few games in the series (like the awful parkour in the previous few games.

- Can't really think of any outright negatives to be honest, Syndicate is one of the best games in the AC series.

[b]tl;dr[/b] 
This is the first Assassin‚Äôs Creed game I have properly enjoyed since Black Flag. They‚Äôve fixed all the problems from Unity so no parts of this game felt like a chore, it‚Äôs all fun. 

[b]Full Review[/b] 
Most of the good things I have to say about this game are really just a list of all the things wrong with Unity that have been fixed for this game.

For a start this is the first Assassin‚Äôs Creed game to run properly in widescreen. The graphics look better and run smoother than Unity. The Victorian setting is great, having familiar UK historical figures makes it so much more engaging than previous games. For example when I tripped over Florence Nightingale and dropped Darwin down the stairs it was so much more entertaining than if had just been some random characters that I knew nothing about.

The biggest problem with Unity was there was too many tedious things to do and thankfully they‚Äôve stripped all of those things out. The annoying multiplayer is gone, the terrible enigma missions are gone. The annoying lockpick mini game is gone, you now just hold down E to pick locks. There are also significantly fewer locked chests and you can get the lock pick skills very early on in the game so they are not a source of frustration. The treasure maps are back (the good ones from II not the rubbish ones from Black Flag) so finding all the collectibles is no longer so tedious. The incongruous and boring investigations have been relegated to a DLC that you can just ignore.

The confusing different currencies have been improved, you now just buy equipment and upgrades with money and get experience to unlock new skills.

The clunky free running and combat mechanics have been refined and are much smoother and satisfying.

It is not just fixing things from Unity, there are other good things worthy of mentioning. The new kidnap ability add a bit of variety rather than just always killing people.  The grappling hook is a nice new mechanic, it means there is no need for all those random cables between buildings in previous games which were only there for assassins to run across. The carriages too are a nice way to get about quickly. I like how the map was split up into segments similar to how Black Flag was split up into islands which made it much more satisfying to systematically collect everything and complete the side missions. I like the music, it fitted the atmosphere of the game well. The series has flipped between medicine and regenerating health but this is the first game to combine the two which I think works well. You can use medicine if you get overwhelmed by enemies but you don‚Äôt have to go off and find a doctor between every mission to heal yourself back up. Another nice little touch is some of the enemies have has which can get knocked off during combat.

Having 2 different assassins, the stealthy one and the confrontational one, is a nice idea. Each character has a few unique skills but you can still use whichever approach you like with each character.

After the atrocities committed against the Irish accent in Rogue I was worried that this game was going to have everyone talking in the way American‚Äôs think British people talk like Dick Van Dyke in Mary Poppins. However in actual fact the voice acting is very good.

The game is by no means perfect though. There are still the annoying Helix credits for in app purchases and some of the treasure maps are only available through this. The grappling hook aiming is very pernickety about what you can actually fire it at, you can‚Äôt directly aim at where you want to go it just picks somewhere near the middle of the screen where it thinks you want to go. Once you get used to it movement can be very fluid but it takes a while. The carriages are very unrealistic your horse can smash through cast iron street furniture with little impediment and you can throw your whole carriage from side to side to ram people. The aggravated me at the start but then I remembered all the other wildly unrealistic things in the game and just started to enjoy the mechanics of driving even if they didn‚Äôt make sense. The writing and characters are a bit formulaic, the plot is once again relive the memories of an assassin to find the dohicky of the week. The historical cameos feel a bit forced in places. There were these items that appear on the map which when you collect them just give a message saying that the social glitch service is unavailable. I‚Äôm not sure what they were supposed to do but I‚Äôm guessing it was on some server that Ubisoft no longer maintains. There is still only one save game so you need to mess around with save files for different people to play. The game features perks which unlock after you have done something an arbitrary number of times. Some are fine like assassinate X number of people but some of them are ridiculously grindy like the one for drifting a carriage round 5 corners in a row. I never managed this once let alone 75 times.

None of the above really bothered me as the game as a whole is solid enjoyable experience, all of the things to do in the game are fun and working your way through them all is very satisfying.

Recommended settings are unable to actually play the game. Heavy lag, stuttering, freezes, constantly with EXTREMELY high CPU usage for seemingly no reason. Even Unity ran better. It's a shame, it looks so good, but the lack of finishing work prevents this game from being actually enjoyable. Probably half of my playtime was spent looking at a frozen screen with 100% CPU usage.

The last Assassin's Creed before they changed the gameplay. No eagle in the this one, game is pretty simple and most of it set in London, while it's a bit better than Unity it sits at the bottom alongside it.

London looks good, but most of it looks the same, so you'll get a bit bored repeating the same things over and over again, while the game isn't very long, it'll take close to 50 hours to 100% it.

Story wise it's a boring and shallow, doesn't add much to the AC lore, while both main characters are good, Evie is by far better & more charismatic.

What i enjoyed the most is the fighting, 3 different weapons, with brutal and nice finishes.

I recommend it for fans of the series, who want to play all the AC games, but for people not familiar with the franchise and don't care very much about the story, i advise you to play Origin & Odyssey.

Before the actual review there's 1 thing which is very important to say:
This game is only playable if you download the nvidia game ready driver 446.14.
When I installed the driver the game became playable (there were frequent game freezes + crashes every 2 minutes).

Now for the actual game...
I give it a 7/10. The main reason is because of the driver issue which should've been adressed to the players when starting the game or simply on the page!
 Gameplay wise I think it's not as good as other AC games. I enjoyed the combat but it takes so long to actually kill anyone until you reach the higher skill levels.
The stealth was however executed perfectly, no flaws whatsoever!
The story was good, I liked how they let you play as the brother/sister assassins which worked really well.
I'm very glad I got to play this game even though it's been out for so long.

Plus :
- Good graphics
- 2 playable characters
- Character customization (outfits, gears and weapons)
- Excellent parkour just like AC Unity
- Many side activities and missions
- Large map to explore
- New fast paced combat with multiple kills ability

Minus :
- less entertaining story 
- Performing certain multiple kills in combat sometimes confusing
- There are still some issues like freezing or crashing at random situations
- Revealing some collectibles on the map requires Helix Credits that can be purchased through IAP but the game might still give you a small amount of free Helix Credits at some situations
I enjoyed this game, toward the end the combat got a bit repetitive but still good overall.

I would like to point out that the game does crash, but there are a number of fixes out there (just google it and run through them, one will eventually fix it). I haven't done any fixes, just to test these crashes, and they happen about once every 3-4 hours or so (if they happen more often, its clearly something wrong with your system, or maybe just a faulty download). Its actually a nice reminder to get off the PC for a bit and move my legs.

There are also a lot of random freezing in the game. [b][u]THIS IS NO FAULT WITH THE GAME AT ALL[/u][/b]. This is caused by the new Nvidia drivers (there have been other games reporting this issue too). Just roll back or reinstall the 446 update one and it will be fixed.

Now that is out of the way...

This game is arguably the last "assassin" game. After this, they do feel more like an RPG than the unique style of games that Ubisoft produced (not that its a bad thing). If you're a fan of Assassin's Creed, there is no reason to not get this game. If you are looking to get into the Assassin's Creed franchise, go get Assassin's Creed 1 and work your way from there.

That being said, I wouldn't say that the game is worth the money out of sale. Just wait for a sale to get this game. You should be able to get the gold one for around ¬£20 (which includes the DLC).

This is really the most underrated Assassin's Creed game ever and the one least heard about and somewhat *forgotten (*together with AC1). I'm having so much fun that I can't put enough word on it. The setting is really awesome since it throws you into the heart of the age of industrialization, London! And it's mid 19th century and everything feels steampunkish, just like you would expect of this environment. The gameplay itself feels like a combination of GTA and Batman games mixed into Assassin's Creed.

Let's get to pros and cons, 
Pros:
Graphics are great.
Realistic Stealth
Not so much of an insane grind like Odyssey. You can go straight through the story without stopping for side quests.
Combat that doesn't let you go up against 100's of enemies and still win... (I'm looking at you black flag)
Cons:
The only bugs that do appear are quite annoying, like having to reset the game due to glitches. OR getting stuck in a barrel.
Guns don't really make a lot of sense. Like somehow a level 2 blighter can shoot you perfectly while driving a carriage and you're driving a carriage and there is a tiny portion of your head visible. 
Crafting is repetitive and annoying. "Why do I need hide to invest in a shop???"
This is a great iteration of the game.  Loved it.

No other games/programs give me BSODs, just AC Unity and AC Syndicate.

Drivers/OS are up to date, reduced graphics quality to lowest, etc. and it still decides to BSOD whenever it wants. Sometimes, it's immediately on load. Other times, it's when I enter/exit a mission.

This isn't an assassination simulation, it's a BSOD gacha game.

This review is for people who played Unity. [b]TL;DR: huge improvements on almost everything Unity sucked at, but gameplay a lot easier.[/b]

[b]Tip:[/b] There's a big amount of content that is kinda hidden but you definitely wanna play. Look for a new icon around the east end of the Thames midway through the story.

[b]Stuff Syndicate did great:[/b]

+ Stealth is much better. We can whistle again!
+ I enjoyed the story much more. There's a lot more character development and cutscenes are more prominent. Note that this story is much lighter than past AC games, but I welcomed that change of pace. Note that some [i]major[/i] revelations are hidden away as assassin intel in the database.
+ Villains are much better. Given more personality and I never had any moments of "why am I killing this guy again?"
+ Assassination missions are even better than before since every one has an optional unique assassination. They're extremely fun.
+ The game has you play as twins, which makes the story and gameplay more diverse and lets us play as a woman for only the second time ever (and Liberation was kinda a side game, anyway).
+ Eagle vision isn't so annoying anymore. Though we can't use it while running.
+ Horse drawn carriages are a thing now and are a fun means to get around.
+ Modern day story is much more substantiative now. It's still all cutscenes and you are an anonymous, voiceless protagonist, but Unity set the bar reaaaally low.
+ Entering windows actually works consistently now.

[b]Stuff with trade-offs:[/b]

* London is quite nice, but it's not as lively as Paris.
* Combat is less frustrating. Unity was so heavily pushing me to smoke bomb every encounter. Syndicate's combat is more fast paced and has fewer enemies who block every normal attack. The downside is that it gets too easy very fast.
* The game adds a grappling hook, which is really great for getting around London's tall buildings and wide streets. Unfortunately, aiming it is a pain (it's not really manually aimed).
* The game has a district liberation mechanic and it's quite fun (lots of different activities to do), but it gets tiresome eventually. Arguably too many activities.
* Seems to be the least historically accurate AC game to date. Most villains are fictional. Buuut, it's not actually too bad because it let them write stronger villains.

[b]Stuff Syndicate did badly:[/b]

- Seriously, the game gets really easy. XP gain is too fast, I'd say. You can hit level 10 about halfway through the content.
- While most collectibles aren't too bad, helix glitches are terrible. Super hard to see, often difficult to reach, and just too many. But they at least offer story now instead of nothing.
- The game has terrible races added in. They're all optional and just for money, XP, and loyalty (which leads to a few unique items). They're fiendishly difficult and not fun.
- Very few buildings can be entered now. That was one of my favourite new features in Unity. I'm told it's for performance reasons, but I sure wish they could have made it optional for non-quest related buildings, then.
- Parkour is more restrictive. Characters stubbornly refuse to jump when I tell them to.

[b]DLC notes:[/b]

* Dreadful Crimes is amazing and the best of the DLC by far. Annoyingly it's not in the season pass.
* Last Maharaja is a buggy, poorly produced mess with merely an okay story (and very predictable).
* Jack the Ripper is fun, but the side content in it is meh.

TL;DR: I really loved playing this!

It's been a while since I've been unable to put down a game, usually I'll get distracted and end up forgetting to finish it. But with Syndicate, I played it full to the ending and I'm working on the collectible and optional missions now. 
Story: All the conflict felt genuine, Evie and Jacob's clashing personalities but love for each other felt authentic. The overall story of taking down each of the Templar's was well executed, it had a nice pacing. Evie and Jacob's stories were weaved together neatly and it felt like you were spending a balanced amount of time between them. 
Gameplay: Dear god I wish the rope launcher was standard fare for all AC games. I'm playing Unity now and I keep running off ledges while hitting R. The rope launcher was incredibly helpful for navigating the map, especially before you get the gang upgrade for the blighters to stop bothering you in the street. 
As for combat, it was well balanced, it wasn't too hard and it left you at a good pace where you could focus on leveling up in certain boroughs or you could jump into the next main mission a little early. 

I'd definitely recommend giving this a good go!

Game freezes every 2 or 5 mins for 4 -7 secs randomly. I tried almost every fix.

*********************
// Edit:

Specs:

Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-7700HQ CPU @ 2.80GHz

NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060

RAM:  16339 Mb

___________________________________________________

I got it to work. All I have to do is open the Nvidia Control Panel, add this in the program settings tab, set power management to Adaptive, limit the max frame rate to 30 FPS, open task manager, set ACS.exe's priority to Normal, set the affinity and uncheck CPU 0. Go to the in-game options, turn Vsync off, set the refresh rate to 60hz, set the environment to Very High, set textures to Medium,, set shadow quality to High, ambient occlusion to SSAO, and anti aliasing to FXAA.

Game looks passable and the frame rate takes a little getting used to but at least its playable. 

I didn't know any of that bollocks settings 3 days ago. I'm just a filthy casual. Glad I learned something new. Thanks Ubisoft. 
 
I still wouldn't recommend this game though. My solution might not work for you.

Nice game with acceptable graphics. If u have a decent graphics card (gtx 1060 and above) i suggest u play unity.

The good:

* Good graphics, great Victorian-era environments.
* OK Music and sound, but not great.
* Supports 21:9 ultrawidescreen.
* No bugs encountered.
* No FPS issues on tested high-end hardware.

The bad:

* No first-person camera switch option.
* Controls via Mouse and keyboard are somewhat clunky.
* Climbing/jumping onto things is often frustrating. Sometimes you trigger wall climbs/jumps at corners accidentally, sometimes you have to move around to be in the right position to do a jump, etc.
* Story and plot feel somehow naive and sometimes childish. Lots of ass-pull plot devices.
* Lot's of cut-scenes and no-interaction sequences. If I want to watch a movie I go to a theater.

The ugly:

* You have to install the Uplay Cancer on your system.
* Ubisoft thinks it's necessary to rub their virtue signaling under everyone's nose at every start to pander to the easily-offended minorities.

Conclusion:

I only recommend it if you're a fan of the series or interested in playing a game in the Victorian era (like me).

I'm still catching up on all the AC games in order, and I'd say Syndicate doesn't really stand out -- in either a good way or a bad.  It has all the standard stuff I want to see in an AC game with some of the more annoying aspects of games past removed or simplified, but on the other hand it doesn't really add anything new and special.  I did enjoy visiting Victorian London and meeting various historical characters, but I miss the 'home improvement' feature of previous games.  Also, I've noticed a trend in the most recent AC games I've played where doing the missions provides you with such good gear so quickly that most of the purchaseable items are outclassed by the time they are affordable.  Finally, although I know some people weren't too keen on it, I miss having an interactive modern setting to further the meta-plot.  Overall I'd give Syndicate a solid B-.

To begin with this review I must say that I've never been attracted to XIX century nor London. I really liked AC Unity (I played it in 2019, so almost no bugs) and I didn't have many expectations about this game because of what I said above. But from the start, I've been really really hooked on this game and I [b][u]DEFINITELY RECOMMEND THIS GAME[/u]!!![/b].

I think the presentation of the story is marvelous, a few sequences to get how to control the characters and then boom, London! You can do whatever you want there. Personally, I liberated most of the city on sequence 4, and then Westminster on sequence 5 because of a necessary upgrade to achieve 100% on that mission. The story focus on one or two targets every sequence, which every one has its own perks to assassinate. I loved getting the unique kill opportunities. Also, the secondary objectives are really achievable. To me, that's positive, because it means I wouldn't get frustrated at every mission lol.

You also control 2 characters [spoiler](3 if you count WW1)[/spoiler], and they have their own missions. I love them both, I feel they are very charismatic in their own way, and I like their story though the game. Jacob is more carefree and decides to liberate London while Evie is more thoughtful and decides to look for the piece of Eden there in London. I know some people have complained about the leveling system, but I think it's pretty good, I was at level 10 really early on the story and if you do every mission, you'll most likely get to level 10 very fast.

The only negative thing I've encountered is that I can't get into the cooperative missions, or whatever they are called, it always displayed an error message.

Overall, this game is sooo good in my opinion. I had low expectations because "meh, London", but I'm so in love with the city and the story that now I'm really curious and willing to travel there one day!

This game is not terrible. That's how you should decide. Do you want to pay 20+ Euro on a game that is "not terrible"? 

Here's the thing. Nothing in the game is truly memorable. There are only two missions I really remember, the Intro tutorial mission because everything was new and I was excited to be playing Assassins Creed again (I used to be a fan in the good old Ezio times), and the first real assassination mission because I learned some new game mechanics. It's unfortunate really because the story has potential and the main characters are interesting. But the game doesn't capitalise on it and instead you find yourself with an underwhelming feeling of meaninglessness every time you finish a mission. There were a couple of great plot twists that kept me going but even then, as soon as the cut scene finishes you're back in town, earned another few experience points and unlocked a new weapon without any significant impact on gameplay. No real sense of reward. No 60 seconds to get out of the place before it explodes, or being trapped until you find the secret exit, or anything like that, which makes you feel disconnected from the mission as soon as it's done. 
The cut scenes are short and repetitive and they fail to build up tension. I think maybe this is the biggest problem here. If you don't care much for the story and just enjoy climbing walls and killing targets from above, then this game is great! the free running flows (thanks to the infamous grappling hook) and the fighting mechanics are not bad. You can do combo hits and if you time your strikes you do more damage which is always satisfying.
But the assassinations don't give you that sense of achievement or reward, they are not challenging, they lack a sense of progress. The story is clumsy and the missions feel disconnected. There are too many characters and you don't really feel drawn to them. 

Some side missions however are quite fun, where the only way to do them is by not getting detected, which to me has always been the heart of the game. Stealth mechanics are decent and stealth kills do feel rewarding.

Only play it if you're a fan of the saga and if it's on sale for less than a fiver

Honestly...I really wanted to like this game. I have a real love-hate relationship with the AC games (well all the ones blag flag and after anyway). I tend to love the setting of them. But man the story themselves are downright boring, uninspiring, with some of the most aggravating pc controls I've ever had to deal with. And Syndicate is no different. 

1860's London is a great setting. You meet historical figures cause AC loves shoving that in your face. You get to see these absolute beautiful environments, and explore the large city of London, the voice acting is great...But that's about the only good thing from this game. 

One of the protagonist Evie was really interesting. I liked just how passionate she was for the Assassin order and was excited to see where it goes...Too bad it feels like the game makes her take the back seat to Jacob, her brother and other protagonist. Essentially the stereotype over-confident, thinks he's smug character.

The Controls in this game on K+M are some of the worst controls ever. Which is shocking cause AC on PC has always had awful controls so the fact there even worse here is a achievement alright. Too many actions are binded to the same keys which make for some frustrating moments (i.e E is tied to counter and also carrying bodies and looting them, making for some aggravating moments in the middle of combat). Add in AC's notorious parkour where your character refuses to do the simplest fucking things like letting go of a building edge, or refusing to hop over this tiny little fence. 

The game does introduce a grappling rope that you can use to get from rooftop to rooftop. This is cool at first until you start to realize the controls for that as well are also awful. Trying to swing to a specific spot? That's ok. The grappling hook will lock onto a different location at the last second so that it takes you longer to get to your definition.

The Carriage gameplay here literally makes me want to punch a wall. Any mission where I was required to drive a carriage I ended my game session upon completion. Streets are crowded with way too many carriages making it a nightmare to get around. Enemies chasing you in carriage pursuits are not fun in the slightest. You'll get fucking sandwiched in the middle of a dozen carriages from both enemies and passerby npc's. Trying to do attacks with your pistol on carriage is broken as hell as sometimes your character won't register that you're spamming the F key a thousand times to get them to shoot. Then when they do, they outright refuse to reload their guns so you're stuck getting shot up the ass by enemies while you're unable to defend yourself. There's a mechanic that allows you to ram your carriage into other carriage's but that's as useful as tapping someone on the hand telling them to stop. 

Story like I said at the beginning is very boring. No interesting characters aside from Evie, missions feel like added on chores with no real purpose. (Although there is one mission that has to do with Edward Kenway which was brief but cool). The villains are generic. 
But Holy Hell am I glad there were no Present Day abstergo bullshit. Ok there are cutscenes that you can't skip, but almost 20 hours in and I haven't been ripped out from the London setting to go hack some computer so that's good atleast. 

Overall probably play with a controller, and if you can deal with the same ole same ole formula of the AC franchise then you might enjoy this.

One of the more underappreciated Assassin's Creed games out there.  You get to play as 1 of 2 characters and can switch out as you please (most of the time).  Great gameplay, inspiring and lovable characters.  You get to interact and help out Charles Dickens, Charles Darwin, and Karl Marx (I could hear Fox News in the back of my head condemning the game).  Overall great game, fun setting (Victorian England).  If you like steam punk stuff, you'll love this game.  Also would highly recommend  the Jack the Ripper DLC.

I don't know if I should say it's my favourite AC game because I haven't played all of them and it's not like it's a masterpiece... but it's my favourite AC game YET.

It's so much fun. For the first time, I understand why it's a sandbox game - finally I want to spent time just playing IN it rather than playing the main plot and any side quests to level up. I don't really understand why some people hate it - it has great free running, fun combat, the story isn't anything life-changing but it's solid. Characters are REALLY fun (god I love Jacob Frye).

This is a personal preference, but the setting? OMG. I love London with all my heart, and being able to run around Victorian London, especially during the quarantine, makes me insanely happy. Just got this game here in 2020. I like the Assassin's Creed franchise but I am not a loyalist that plays every version. I initially didn't even give this game a second look because it just looked like another European version of Assassin's Creed which seemed to have been done before. What sold me in the video is that this was the closest to modern day that the franchise has ever gotten. That is what I have been waiting for and thought the series was originally headed for story-wise with a modern day game with Desmond as the protagonist. The ‚Äòtoo long didn't read‚Äô version is essentially: This entry in the franchise fails to capture the wonder and fun of Assassin's Creed: Blag Flag.

The mechanics are roughly the same as previous entries in the series with a few notable exceptions, for example the new grappling hook allows you to instantly climb tall buildings, escape combat, and traverse between roof-tops - however it kinda removes the "parkour across the rooftops" which depending on your point of view was either an enjoyable hallmark of the franchise or really tedious - don't get me wrong you can still climb things the old way but it's slower so why would you. This doesn‚Äôt contribute to whether this view is negative or positive just that veterans of the series so far might be interested in knowing this beforehand.

The main story missions are the decent however the main characters a bit too stereotypical to believe. It was interesting getting to interact with famous characters [spoiler] like Alexander Graham Bell or Florence Nightingale, Charles Darwin, etc. And I really enjoyed the WW2 blitz sequence.[/spoiler]

As someone who lived in London for years, I was impressed how accurately parts of London were recreated and there were lots of ‚Äòtake a screen-shot‚Äô moments!

Sadly, the game play loop of clearing areas gets tedious once you‚Äôve done one of the same 3 types of side-missions about 9 times each, and the main story is not interesting enough to keep slogging through. I stopped playing at about 25hrs.
There were no technical problems or crashes.

On balance, I don‚Äôt recommend this game, but it‚Äôs not totally terrible ‚Äì more like a 5/10.

When it comes to the standard Assassin's Creed formula, Syndicate stands out as the best in my experience. While the top AC game is unequivocally Assassin's Creed IV, Syndicate nails the base game play incredibly well. The combat is fluid, weighty, and fair. The different combative play styles add a nice touch, albeit for the most part cosmetic. Syndicate's story isn't anything revolutionary, but is still engaging enough with its characters to keep you invested in the events (I have only two hours on here, but have played the game in its entirety on console). The customization is less than that of Unity, but what we're given is serviceable. Exploring London is fun and a lot of work went into constructing the scenery, something Assassin's Creed has consistently nailed. Overall, if you're looking for a solid Assassin's Creed experience I would definitely recommend Syndicate.

Edit: Additional pro's and cons

This is my first foray in the to Assassin's Creed series, mainly drawn by the Victorian London setting. I was born and lived in London for over 40 years, so I am intimately familiar with the streets and landmarks, particularly in the Westminster area. The developers have done a fantastic job on the detail, and you can compare buildings like Westminster Abbey, the Houses of Parliament, St Paul's Cathedral etc. with the real thing, and see what a stunning recreation this game is. A few liberties have been taken with layout, but what is there is correctly reproduced, and it makes a huge difference to me to be exploring a real city that I love and know well.

Regarding gameplay and overall plot, I don't really like the 'game within a game' idea, I don't see why I can't just be playing the actual characters, instead of playing modern people playing a video game of the characters. It just seems overly complex and unnecessary when I get ripped out of the Victorian setting for some modern cutscene that in no way affects gameplay. However it doesn't happen often, and I can mostly ignore and forget this aspect. 

I play using an XBox 360 controller for almost everything, as this is much more comfortable for me than keyboard. This works well for sneaking, fighting and driving carriages, and I enjoy the gameplay. It reminds me of Tenchu, an old Playstation game of Ninja in Feudal era Japan. 

The game develops nicely offering both freeplay activities around London and set missions. I found the first boss battle (in Whitechapel) to be the hardest of all the boss battles, probably because I took the wrong character (use Jacob for the bosses), and because I didn't know what to expect. Like Tenchu, these bosses require straight up fights, when you've been sneaking around trying to avoid straight up fights most of the time. 

Overall I am enjoying the game and will be getting others in the series, even though they won't have the London setting that makes this one particularly special for me. I have bought the pirate-themed one (Black Flag) and played a little, and several others look interesting. Hopefully they'll add a WW2 theme and a Feudal Japan theme eventually.

I had some issues with the screen sizing (NVIDIA RTX 2060) as it seemed nothing fit the screen as it should. 
And some missions made the game to stop working so I had to close it and give admin permissions to certain files to solve it, but the game was very nicely created. And I've enjoyed playing it.

I hated this game. The PC keyboard/mouse controls are insanely overly complicated, not intuitive, not user-friendly. You use the same letter keys for multiple things, and if you hold them slightly too long, or hit them too quickly, you end up doing something completely different than you want to. 

Although there are fast-travel points, you can't actually use them any time you're in the middle of a mission/quest. Which is ridiculous. Your hideout is a train, which moves very slowly and if you've got a mission across the city, it takes forever to get there, no matter which travel method you use.

The carriage driving is also terrible. The controls are too sensitive and there's no way to modulate speed in a reasonable way, so you end up smashing into things and taking corners far too fast, without being able to easily navigate around obstacles or NPCs. 

And speaking of NPCs... Many, many missions have an insanely high amount of NPC characters, all of whom you have to overcome to achieve your goal or goals. And many of those NPCs are able to (and do) kill you in seconds, even when you stay within zones that are appropriate for your character skill limits. Redoing quests/missions over and over, simply because the leveling system is very badly done, is extremely frustrating. 

The sneak option is really poorly implemented too. In other AC games, things like high shrubs and grass, or even a stack of crates, are usually decent places to hide. Not in this game. There's basically nowhere except roof-tops to hide, and even when you do, NPC characters climb up right after you in excessively large numbers. Which breaks the immersion of the game, because if you're crouched and hiding on a roof, how the hell can characters hundreds of feet below you, spot you and climb up to you instantaneously? 

As well, I found the game to be very, very glitchy. Lots of stuttering, freezing, crashing. My hardware is more than capable of running it, but I had constant problems just getting the game to keep running. 

I really like quite a few games in the AC franchise, but this one is awful. Repetitive game-play, unimaginative storylines, terrible keymapping, terrible in-game navigation, terrible NPC leveling. Huge waste of money, I wish hadn't purchased it. I'll tell you what I wish someone had told me... Even on sale, it's not worth it unless you enjoy being constantly annoyed and frustrated.

7/10, long story short. The gameplay and mechanics introduced here are great, however, it's not as much as an "assassin's creed" game, there is much more focus on fighting and brawling, almost to the point you hardly need to be an assassin and you become a juggernaut fairly early. Story was practically the same as Unity, all your decisions lead to pretty much nothing and make no implication on the overarching story of assassins creed games. Its too bad the characters didn't have much more development because they were actually interesting, too many plot holes.

I have to say, I very much enjoyed this game. The aesthetics are great and the world feels very lived in. It truly feels like a glimpse into industrial era London, and the music goes well with it (at least most of the time, had one weird glitch once...). The gameplay is what I've come to expect from the past AC titles, along with a decent story and characters. Evie and Jacob are very archetypal, but it never seemed to bother me, and I enjoyed both of them (although I played as Evie primarily). There are some neat additions like the hookshot that make for some fun as well. The game isn't without flaws, and suffers from some of the same problems as Unity (although far, far, FAR less). I didn't feel like the flaws took away from my experience though, and were only ever minor things. 

The DLC were all decent additions to the game, however I don't think any of them would be worth anywhere near the standard price. Absolutely buy on a deep discount. The game, overall, is a solid entry in the series and caps off the original AC style well. Now I'm on to Origins.

I liked this game, its a bit buggy in places but very enjoyable to play. I loved being able to pick and choose between Evie and Jacob Frye in the open world quests. I also greatly enjoyed the romance between Evie and Henry. (Swoon!) So sweet!

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is my favourite so far in the series. 

Pros: 
- Characters: I love Jacob and Evie Frye. Their charisma, sarcasm and wit always made me smile.
- Location: Beautiful location. My dad used to live in London so it was amazing to feel such familiar environments. 
- Good Story: The story is really well done. I didn't find any missions tedious or pointless at all (apart from maybe one of Evie's where you taxi politicians from A to B) I enjoyed all the options you were given during assassination missions. The idea of following 3 routes to a kill really livens up the game for me. 
-Freerunning: Usually, in my reviews of AC you'll find this in the Cons. But I believe they redid it all in Unity but I've yet to play that. But the Freerunning compared to past games is so so so sexy. No more climbing buildings randomly when trying to chase or run from someone. 
- Very few tail missions!!!: compared to previous games where you tail someone every 6 seconds. 
- the cosmetics are also v sexy.
- WW1 Missions!: FUCK YES. Having read the emails in AC:Black Flag where Abstergo literally say 'they are not going to do WW1 etc because it's too recent.' the fact that they slipped a few small missions in the London themed game really pleased me. 

Cons: 
- Liberating the areas is far too time consuming and dull (thankfully it's optional for the most part)
- Towards the end of my game, around 70%/80% through the campaign my game randomly began freezing frequently. Oftentimes even crashing to desktop and being unable to play without launching it 3 times. But for the first 70% it worked beautifully.

This is an enjoyable addition to AC

ASSASSIN'S CREED: NO CONSEQUENCES 

Well, that was disappointing. This entry to Assassins Creed felt like the developers were feeling pressured to make a new game to keep eager, edgy little 12 year olds interesting in their franchise. 
Remember how in the first game, even up to the third one, there was hefty storytelling and cutscenes before the real game actually started? Like you‚Äôd play some levels as your guy in the real world before you started reliving memories and doing all the cool Assassin Creed-y stuff? Yeah well, that doesn't happen here. You get about 50 seconds of a super minimized movie-like trailer that supposedly explains the ENTIRE plot in one go, that tells you who all the bad guys are, what all the key points of the story are  that honestly looks more like an E3 tech demo than it does an actual story mechanism. To top things off, the trailer doesn't even cover anything that‚Äôs happening in the real world - it's all about the memories you'd be reliving and the world that contains them. Remember in Red Faction Guerrilla when you get past the Town of Parker and the world opens up to you and there this short sequence that plays? It tells you about OOOHH COOL SIDE QUESTS and OOOHH BAD GUYS and OOOHHH UNLOCKABLE THIGNS THAT YOU SHOULD FIND and its super overdramatized? Well that‚Äôs EXACTLY, and I mean EXACTLY what happens here in this game, but the difference is that the one in Assassins Creed is meant to substitute any and all interactive introductory story telling. 
You know what we call that in the real world?

L A Z Y 

and 

B O R I N G


When I saw that, it made the first level and, honestly, the entirety of what I played feel rushed and not thought out. Probably because it was rushed and not thought out. 

When you finally get into the game, surprise, surprise - nothing has changed at all. BUT HEY GAMERS YOU GET TO PLAY AS TWO CHARACTERS AND ONE OF THEM IS A GRYLL!! 
Yeah, that'd be great if you gave me any motivation to actually play the game at all. It felt like Assassins Creed 3, just in watered-down Steam Punk London. You "meet" Charles Dickens in this game and other notable people of the time the same way - same exact way, in some case - as you did Benjamin Franklin and other notable persons from American history in AC 3. It felt like all they did was replace the skin and the voice actor but leave the sequence, the animations, and the circumstances basically the same. 

Again, what is that kids?

L A Z Y

and 

B O R I N G

Oh, and let‚Äôs not forget the ultimate and sanguine experience of consequence free gaming. I guess that shit was cool when you were 12 and still said "Frigg" instead of more colorful words, but I'm a big boi now. I want big boi things. Big boi things are usually associated to high risk/high reward. 
In this game, Assassins Creed: Lazy Tech Demo, you can literally stab someone in their fucking neck in front of a huge crowd of people and NOT ONE OF THEM WILL EVEN FLINCH. 
You can simply get up and walk away without being followed. Enemies were about to be an exception except for the fact that combat is joke and gives you a 3 second window to parry attacks, all while instagibbing all enemies with your super cool, London-Victorian fighting style that make zero sense. 
If you haven't pieced it together yet, all of that is not high risk/high reward. 
It's negative risk/high reward. You'd have to be a drooling retard to enjoy a game this stupidly simple and unfinished. 
Some of the less relevant but equally annoying gripes are: 

The mantling system is painfully inaccurate. Want to climb that wall? Too bad! Looks like youll be jumping into the out-of-bounds body of water next to it and drowning! Thanks for playing!

The voice acting is too good. I know, I know, I'm complementing this shitty game. Let me ask you this: what‚Äôs worse than a game that could be cool falling flat on it's face? Doing the same thing but falling even harder because of how cool some parts of the game could have made the rest of them. The voice acting was top notch, especially between the main characters. The facial expressions were great and they had believable and human banter back and forth and I really liked it. 

And then the rest of the game happened. 

Imagine this. You're told that you're getting handgun as a birthday present. Oh how exciting! Oh joy! You go out and buy the most expensive, clean and efficient ammo you can find for, lets just say, 9mm in this case. .43 cents a round? PFFT. More like $1.35 per round! All 200 of them! That's right baby, you got the good stuff. Gonna make this gun a polished and streamlined workhorse with these badboys. All the salty boomers at the range are gonna be jealous of you!

Your birthday rolls around. You run downstairs, almost tripping and falling over the feeties on your puppy-dog onesie pajamas. You plop your fatass down in the chair in front of the birthday cake, it's numerical candles, one in the shape of "4" and the other, "0". They flicker, casting bright orange slivers across your greasy face. Your mom or dad come out from the kitchen but you can't tell who cause youre so focused on the table in front of you, desperately awaiting your present. 

It's here. The moment you've been waiting for. You dragged your case of ammo with you and now its resting on the table, heavy and expensive. The parental unit slides the small, sleek, plastic box in front of you and immediately attack it with your disgusting fingers. You break the tape, almost crying with excitement and open the latches. The clam-shell opens, slowly. There it is!
THERE IT IS!

ITS-

ITS A-

IT'S A.......it's a.....Hipoint?


..............

........................


.......................................................


What??
What the fuck??



Being half retarded and knowing nothing about guns, you think, "Well that's oddly disappointing but how bad could it be?". You take it to the range and get summarily laughed off the firing line after a disastrous series of misfires, misfeeds and just not being able to maintain a sight picture because the disgusting abomination is so fucking heavy. Afterwards, boogery and crying, you decided to just use it as a door stop because not even the gun exchange will take returns for that model and GunBroker banned your IP after you put it up for sale.

If you followed all of that, that is basically what playing this game felt like. It was like they rushed through it, marketing it as "OH HEY DONT WORRY GUYS ITS STILL AN ASSASSINS CREED! sAVe ThE pEIcEs Of EdeN AMIRITE?!!?!?! ;;;;;))))))" just to keep people satiated until they took their fists out of their assholes and make an actual game. 

Obviously, I don't recommend this. Save your money, literally do not even buy this on sale. It was such a disappointment after playing the better titles in the franchise. 

Overall, be smart and Buy CZ or Glock/10

There are still bugs here but I suppose they have become a default for AC games now. The game does have a good story to dwell into and the brother-sister combo is pretty good. The combat is more versatile than previous games, when it plays out well it plays out well but sometimes it can get frustratingly weird, if you got bonked on your head by the cops you'll know what I mean.

Graphics are impressive but do keep in mind of the quite common stutter bug this game has, to fix that add the code to turn of nvidia hariworks framerate thingy(just google how to do it) and that smoothens the game out, also you can turn off the fog for more clarity.

I would rate the game 3.5/5, it is still a decent game for the fans but not as good as Black Flag or the initial games in the sense of story. As far as mechanics go it is more fun to play out than the older games but at the cost of some annoying glitches and cheesy story points.

Loved:
-The gorgeous London recreated with sights to see, probably one of my top favorite settings in an open world game.
-The train hideout system.
-The multiple ways you can assassinate your final targets.
-Costume design.
-Free run is more fun with the grapple mechanic.
-Cart driving was also fun, I still don't understand how you make a horse ram :p but fun none the less.
-Good story for the most part, especially the DLC for Jack.
-The precursor object they are in the game seems to be an interesting one.

Hated:
-The additional objectives of missions don't grant you half the bonus if you complete half of them, you need to complete all of them which sometimes is annoyingly hard due to bugs with freerunning or weird detection glitches. Like in the strong hold conquests sometimes a rook would die for no apparent reason and I won't ge the extra bonus.
-The love story between eevie and henry just seems shite, like hes the damsel in distress and his intrusion in the game feels forced and unnecessary. Kinda annoying character to be an assassin. For how much I loved Jacob and Eevies as the protagonists, I hated Henry as a whiney b****.
-Nothing unlocks if you conquest all of London, it would be amazing if you got a side mission or atleast a cutscene for conquering the whole city, I got none. This grind brought me back to another game I hated, Mafia 3, for doing useless conquering stuff with no end result or gift to the player. Atleast a cutscene would be good.

I would rate the game 3.5/5, it is still a decent game for the fans but not as good as Black Flag or the initial games in the sense of story. As far as mechanics go it is more fun to play out than the older games but at the cost of some annoying glitches and cheesy story points.

An excellent entry in the series. While the story of Jacob and Evie Frye is quite interesting, the bigger highlights are the delightful setting, the charismatic lead characters and the fluid gameplay. Even many of the side missions are interesting to play and the DLC content delves into memorable story lines such as Jack The Ripper and brings us in contact with characters like Charles Dickens and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. 
If you are an AC fan, do not miss this one. If you are an action game fan, the gameplay and speed of the playthrough will attract you even if you don't understand the story.
