That's it, that's the review

Overall score: 6/10
Technically recommended, although it‚Äôs defenitely not the best Assassin‚Äôs Creed game.

First, the good...

Gameplay - 9/10
A lot of fun and makes the game actually worth playing. It has enough variety for a truly assassin oriented game, in order to not feel excessively repetitive. I honestly didn‚Äôt feel that the controls during combat and free-running/parkour were any clunkier than they usually are in an Assassin‚Äôs Creed game - although this has always annoyed me. The combat system is not the best in the franchise, but also not the worst, and it‚Äôs very easy to master. It is, at times, pretty frustrating because it can be unresponsive - more so than in previous installments. For some reason triggering finishers, especially group finishers, is hard to achieve. The movements are very fast, which I like, but the combat animations themselves as well as the ragdoll physics aren‚Äôt the best, and there is almost no blood. The stealth system is fun and easy. The parkour system is also excellent, even better with the ability to zipline between the enormous buildings, making exploration both fun and immersive. The rope launcher also adds a really cool stealth mechanic with the ability to return to rooftops extremely quickly after swooping down for stealthy air assassinations.

Graphics - 8/10
Although not as high quality as Unity, I still found the graphics of this game to be really nice for a 2015 game (excluding Witcher 3).

Performance - 8/10
Decent performance given the quality of the graphics, with occasional frame drops and very short, temporary freezes only in demanding combat situations. However, my graphics card being six years old, this was actually surprisingly better than expected. I think the game has been decently optimized but it could be better.

Setting/Time Period - 7/10
Victorian England, from the surroundings to the people all around, felt extremely immersive. London is an absolute pleasure to explore, with realistically sized buildings that really make you feel you are there. However, the time period itself is not exactly the most exciting one in the franchise and also the somber looking city, accurately portrayed for its time period, is not the most beautiful to look at.

Soundtrack - 9/10
Beautiful and appropriate for the setting. Unlike other assassin‚Äôs creed games, the songs are actually new instead of being recycled versions of the same Assassin‚Äôs Creed II melody.

And now the really, really bad...

Plot - 0/10
Probably the worst plot in the entire assassin‚Äôs creed franchise. Contrived, predictable, illogical and boring. Throughout the story, the male protagonist is demeaned as much as possible in order to exalt the female protagonist as much as possible in exchange, with very forced, obvious tropes all over. The entire story felt more like a parody or a mockery of the franchise, especially of its own main character featured in the game‚Äôs cinematic trailer. There were numerous missed opportunities to improve his character development. Having dual protagonists was terribly executed. Greatly disappointing.

Characters - 4/10
The male protagonist, Jacob Frye, is a deeply flawed, relatable, fun assassin, with an amazing sense of humor, sharp wit, upbeat attitude and really badass, lore friendly skills. Overall, he is a breath of fresh air among too many uptight, serious, boring characters. He is also young, reckless, immature, brash, cocky, rebellious and appears to be the black sheep of his family. He has serious father issues. Like all trained assassins, Jacob is adept at stealth, but he doesn‚Äôt actually excel at it - he does, however, excel greatly in combat. He is thrilled at being an assassin and is very enthusiastic about it, unlike many other assassin‚Äôs creed protagonists. Jacob‚Äôs voice actor is amazing. As a character, Jacob Frye is on par with Edward Kenway of Assasin‚Äôs Creed IV Black Flag due to having very similar personality traits and character flaws. However, in this story he is portrayed horribly, unfortunately, and because the plot and the writing in general were so bad, his character development was seriously hampered. He is portrayed as the cliched ‚Äúdumb little brother‚Äù of the female protagonist, Evie Frye, who in turn is portrayed as the cliched know-it-all ‚Äúwise older sister‚Äù - and they‚Äôre twins. In contrast to Jacob, Evie has absolutely NO character flaws whatsoever and is the ‚Äúbest‚Äù at everything. She has the wisdom of an assassin Mentor when she‚Äôs just as young as Jacob, who she treats like garbage constantly. She has a ridiculously overpowered invisibility skill that is totally anti-lore and unexplained. She has no personality and is constantly getting highly praised by tons of characters and is liked by everyone that isn‚Äôt an antagonist - in other words, she‚Äôs a Mary Sue. All the flaws went to the male and none to the female. As a woman who strongly believes in gender equality, I was very disappointed. The assassin‚Äôs creed franchise needs realistic and believable female protagonists with flaws, complexity, and a personality. Lastly, in this game there is also a complete absence of interesting and memorable side characters and villains. The main villain, Crawford Starrick, was very generic. Only Jacob Frye contrasted all the boring, contrived, one-dimensional characters.

So, in conclusion...

If you play Assassin‚Äôs Creed games for the gameplay and immersion and NOT for the story or characters, by all means, play this game - it‚Äôs a lot of fun! But if you need a well written story that actually makes sense, doesn‚Äôt put you to sleep, and has memorable characters, play Black Flag or the Ezio trilogy instead.

Best and last true assassins creed game. With the exception of some controls issues being frustrating (running up walls accidentally, unable to jump off a ledge, etc) this game is the best in the series. Fascinating scenery, attractive main cast, lighthearted story, pleasant music.

Uplay killed this game for me.
I will be brief.

- Uplay deleted my save file: 18 hours into the game. Determined it to be one of the better AC games. Then had an internet issue so started Uplay in offline mode. Overall amazing game. While it's not as memorable as AC 4,3 or the Ezio chronic's, it's definitely amazing. The Evie and Jacob duo was absolutely beautiful. Both interesting and developing characters, without any character persona plot holes, they do as they are meant to, they do as they seem. Very nice screenplay on them. The game conquering system is a bit boring, but I found it quite relaxing while watching smnth at the same time. Leveling and combat system both mediocre. The grappling hook really did it for me, saved me from being tortured by climbing everything, it was really fun to use as well, a really nice solution to the horrible mechanics of Unity. Animation and graphics were both really good, the weather and mood of London was definitely easy to feel and understand. Animation of individuals, while a bit stiff, they were nice to look at, fluent and such. Incomparable to Unity, which had so little time put into that. The side quests were while amusing due to the story of old London, like Jack the Ripper and stuff, it was mundane af. Basically "catch, take, kidnap, tackle, kill". The stories were good, but did not feel very, or any really, interactive scenes or anything. Even with me catching Jack the ripper sooner than the game planed, so I have to wait for him to run to a different point while I just wait from him to run away, as I was faster than him. Didn't feel very planned out on the side missions. Weapons and armory in general were really boring. While it made sense considering it was at that time in a big city, it was really boring with the same weapons, just +1 +1 damage or whatnot, while I did not feel any difference in combat by having any of the weapons. The recruit gang stuff was in a way interesting, but kind of useless to me as they were generally weak and not really needed since the game itself was quite easy. The main story, Jacob and Evie, graphics, voice acting, interesting personas and history of London was really, really amusing and definitely worth the price of the game. Cheers.

A little over an hour and a half in. It's certainly a different experience from other AC games, combat is much more of a brawl/beat'em up style rather than quickly dispatching several enemies immediately after combat starts, and the dual-protagonist mechanic is a very different breed from any other AC game. That said, it's a great game so far, characters are fun and all seem pretty genuine, if a bit on the nose, but the dialogue between siblings is genuine, and the little pokes and competitions they have together are pretty spot on for actual siblings, the combat flow is smooth and much faster paced than other games, it actually requires proper timing to parry and counter enemies, not at all like the heavily broadcasted attacks from enemies that you can instantly parry and kill them with. Movement is wonderful, holding space while freerunning automatically climbs up, holding E automatically runs down, makes for a much less frustrating parkour element than past installments. All in all, its a different experience having 2 characters with separate skill trees and playstyles (Evie is smart and cunning, much better at stealth, while Jacob is better at direct combat and loud approaches). Characters are well put together, combat and movement is smooth, and the story seems really fun so far, but thats 100 minutes of gameplay so who knows. Definitely recommend though.

Excellent entry into the AC series.
Much more improved game play and features which made the game feel alive and fun in many new ways.
The main characters are also quite likable and their interactions with each other make the overall narrative of the game less of a bore than other AC interactions in the past.

Visuals are incredible, and the feeling of being in England is just a great change of scenery from many other games.

Pros
-Jacob and Evie Frye are endearing / likeable main characters and are portrayed very well
-Excellent level design. London looks simply gorgeous and portrayed realistically
-Fun combat mechanics. Its a lot faster paced than previous AC games
-Character animations for climbing, locomotion and combat are great
-Good set of character upgrades and customization
-Traversing the game world is much easier. You can use Rope Launcher to zipline across big gaps from building to building both horizontally and vertically
-You get to hire gangs around the streets who'll aid and fight for you
-Audio and music is authentic to the 1800 era
-You'll get to meet and interact with lots of historical characters
-Some fun side activities like fist fighting, racing, robberies

Cons
-Story is meh. Nothing to write home about. Just your generic assassin vs templar plot set in yet another country. Only the main characters held the story together
-Gameplay loop while fun does get very repetitive with the same basic busywork of killing, tailing, capturing, infiltrating, conquering etc on different districts

You'll mainly be playing Assassin's Creed Syndicate for the strong main characters and exploring the visually appealing, beautifully crafted city of London. Its a fun game while it lasts but not a game you'd go back and play all over again. Buy it on discount. You'll get your money's worth then.

Overall, I rate this game a solid 8/10

I have been a huge Assassin‚Äôs Creed fan since 2009 after playing the masterpiece that is Assassin‚Äôs Creed II. However, due to the bad reputation of this game, it was not until 2020 that I finally played it for the first time. Now I understand why it has such mixed reactions... because mine is one of them.

First, the good... 

Gameplay - 9/10
A lot of fun and makes the game actually worth playing. It has enough variety for a truly assassin oriented game, in order to not feel excessively repetitive. I honestly didn‚Äôt feel that the controls during combat and free-running/parkour were any clunkier than they usually are in an Assassin‚Äôs Creed game - although this has always annoyed me. The combat system is not the best in the franchise, but also not the worst, and it‚Äôs very easy to master. It is, at times, pretty frustrating because it can be unresponsive - more so than in previous installments. For some reason triggering finishers, especially group finishers, is hard to achieve. The movements are very fast, which I like, but the combat animations themselves as well as the ragdoll physics aren‚Äôt the best, and there is almost no blood. The stealth system is fun and easy. The parkour system is also excellent, even better with the ability to zipline between the enormous buildings, making exploration both fun and immersive. The rope launcher also adds a really cool stealth mechanic with the ability to return to rooftops extremely quickly after swooping down for stealthy air assassinations.

Graphics - 8/10
Although not as high quality as Unity, I still found the graphics of this game to be really nice for a 2015 game (excluding Witcher 3).

Performance - 8/10
Decent performance given the quality of the graphics, with occasional frame drops and very short, temporary freezes only in demanding combat situations. However, my graphics card being six years old, this was actually surprisingly better than expected. I think the game has been decently optimized but it could be better.

Setting/Time Period - 7/10
Victorian England, from the surroundings to the people all around, felt extremely immersive. London is an absolute pleasure to explore, with realistically sized buildings that really make you feel you are there. However, the time period itself is not exactly the most exciting one in the franchise and also the somber looking city, accurately portrayed for its time period, is not the most beautiful to look at.

Soundtrack - 9/10
Beautiful and appropriate for the setting. Unlike other assassin‚Äôs creed games, the songs are actually new instead of being recycled versions of the same Assassin‚Äôs Creed II melody.

And now the really, really bad...

Plot - 0/10
Probably the worst plot in the entire assassin‚Äôs creed franchise. Contrived, predictable, illogical and boring. Throughout the story, the male protagonist is demeaned as much as possible in order to exalt the female protagonist as much as possible in exchange, with very forced, obvious tropes all over. The entire story felt more like a parody or a mockery of the franchise, especially of its own main character featured in the game‚Äôs cinematic trailer. There were numerous missed opportunities to improve his character development. Having dual protagonists was terribly executed. Greatly disappointing.

Characters - 4/10
The male protagonist, Jacob Frye, is a deeply flawed, relatable, fun assassin, with an amazing sense of humor, sharp wit, upbeat attitude and really badass, lore friendly skills. Overall, he is a breath of fresh air among too many uptight, serious, boring characters. He is also young, reckless, immature, brash, cocky, rebellious and appears to be the black sheep of his family. He has serious father issues. Like all trained assassins, Jacob is adept at stealth, but he doesn‚Äôt actually excel at it - he does, however, excel greatly in combat. He is thrilled at being an assassin and is very enthusiastic about it, unlike many other assassin‚Äôs creed protagonists. Jacob‚Äôs voice actor is amazing. As a character, Jacob Frye is on par with Edward Kenway of Assasin‚Äôs Creed IV Black Flag due to having very similar personality traits and character flaws. However, in this story he is portrayed horribly, unfortunately, and because the plot and the writing in general were so bad, his character development was seriously hampered. He is portrayed as the cliched ‚Äúdumb little brother‚Äù of the female protagonist, Evie Frye, who in turn is portrayed as the cliched know-it-all ‚Äúwise older sister‚Äù - and they‚Äôre twins. In contrast to Jacob, Evie has absolutely NO character flaws whatsoever and is the ‚Äúbest‚Äù at everything. She has the wisdom of an assassin Mentor when she‚Äôs just as young as Jacob, who she treats like garbage constantly. She has a ridiculously overpowered invisibility skill that is totally anti-lore and unexplained. She has no personality and is constantly getting highly praised by tons of characters and is liked by everyone that isn‚Äôt an antagonist - in other words, she‚Äôs a Mary Sue. All the flaws went to the male and none to the female. As a woman who strongly believes in gender equality, I was very disappointed. The assassin‚Äôs creed franchise needs realistic and believable female protagonists with flaws, complexity, and a personality. Lastly, in this game there is also a complete absence of interesting and memorable side characters and villains. The main villain, Crawford Starrick, was very generic. Only Jacob Frye contrasted all the boring, contrived, one-dimensional characters.

So, in conclusion...

If you play Assassin‚Äôs Creed games for the gameplay and immersion and NOT for the story or characters, by all means, play this game - it‚Äôs a lot of fun! But if you need a well written story that actually makes sense, doesn‚Äôt put you to sleep, and has memorable characters, play Black Flag or the Ezio trilogy instead.

Alexander Graham Bell, one of several historical celebrities I've met within mere moments of setting foot in Victorian London, has given me a rope launcher. Cool. With it I can quickly grapple my way to rooftops and create ziplines between buildings to slide across. It's fairly clunky and somewhat limited‚ÄîI often find myself staring at a nearby roof and wondering why the hell I'm not allowed to sling over to it when I've reached smokestacks twice as far away‚Äîbut it's still fun and gives me a way to escape, Batman-like, from a brawl I'm badly losing. It also provides an alternative to freerunning across rooftops, which feels the same as it does in other Assassin's Creed games: fun and dynamic at first, but ultimately a bit routine, and sometimes even exasperating. That's not a bad way to describe Assassin's Creed: Syndicate itself. There's a good first half where almost everything is fun and exciting, and slowly but surely it begins to drag. 

As in past Assassin‚Äôs Creed games, you're once again inhabiting the bodies and memories of heroic assassins via a futuristic (magic, really) virtual reality machine. There's a sprawling open-world you can explore by free-running and climbing. The streets are cluttered with innocent bystanders, angry policemen, and vicious members of an enemy faction. The map is covered with icons signifying collectibles, side and story missions, and vantage points: tall buildings you can scale to reveal even more locations of interest. Stealth is your primary tool, and missions typically involve careful infiltration, lurking above enemies, and taking them out before they know you're there. There are also a few tailing missions, where you must follow a target without being spotted, though I found them considerably more forgiving than I have in the past. 

Syndicate offers up some other new toys and features, mostly cribbed from other open-world games but still enjoyable enough to freshen up the proceedings, at least for a while. There are horse-drawn carriages all over London, allowing for GTA-esque hijacking, high-speed driving, and the comical bowling over of bowler-hatted Londoners. As you battle the Blighters, the gang that's taken control of London, you can employ thugs from your own gang, a la Saint's Row, to do some of your fighting for you. Combat is Arkham-style as you take on huge crowds with counter-attacks, combos, and finishing moves. These things are initially fun‚ÄîI really did enjoy my first handful of hours with the game‚Äîbut by mid-Creed they mostly begin to feel like a chore. A late-game carriage-based story mission might have been bracing if you hadn't already taken dozens of carriage rides. Battling a half-dozen enemies is initially exciting, but hours in it becomes just another exercise in patient (or impatient) clicking. 

I felt at odds with myself, when I started my journey with Jacob and Evie I loved every bit of the world, but the longer I played the more of a chore everything became. The ripper DLC along with Dreadful crimes was a saving grace. But after finishing Syndicate I think an extended break is needed from the franchise. Let me be clear, I didn't hate the game, in fact I quite enjoyed it, but the game falls short with too much of the "same" events filling the world and an extremely anticlimactic end. Overall I'd give it a 6 out of 10.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is known for being probably the worst or one of the worst Assassin's creed games throughout the history of the franchise, and yes I guess Ubisoft did ruin the deep lore of Assassin's Creed that every single hardcore fan loves and praises and especially after Unity turning out to be a great failure, no one was even slightly optimistic about Syndicate. However... for me this is the best instalment in the franchise. I know that almost every AC fan will disagree with me but as a person who played almost every AC game, this is the only one where you actually have a little bit fun. Here's why:

First of all, the story doesn't take itself serious. This made AC fans angry as the story in Syndicate is just not taking itself serious at all. You have so many ridiculous moments throughout the game that you stop taking the game serious anymore. But I am not a fan of the franchise, even though I played a lot of them. For me this was the only game where you can actually have somewhat fun. The interactions between Jacob, Evie, Henry and other historical figures are very ridiculous and make it seem like the whole story is just a joke, but that's all I want personally from a game and this game delivers it. I do hate the assassins lore and all the fight for pieces of Eden, and in this game, that lore was absent 99% of the time, except for the final boss fight, which was just horrible. That was undoubtedly the worst part in the entire game. The game also fails to show any character development throughout the whole story, but to be honest, it's not even needed. The characters are just having fun and the small conflicts between the twins during the story are enough for the serious part.

The graphics are great, the environment is more colourful and a little bit more cartoonish, but it has its charm. The 19th century London is beautiful and I love just casually walking around the map ad just enjoying the atmosphere of the industrial era. It being my favourite era in history makes this game even more pleasurable for me to play and explore. The music fits the story and the environment perfectly. The animations are great, they are done better than Origins, at least the people here have emotions on their face.

Gameplay is... well AC, nothing really changed. They added the grappling hook and the carriages which makes it easier to travel. The fighting animations are not very interesting and are buggy, but well, every single AC game has buggy controls so nothing surprising. But in general it is has the most boring fighting animations and this is the weakest link in the whole game. They also added the levels system which wasn't really that annoying. You still need to grind xp to progress in story, but personally that is not a big issue in the game.

The dlc's are good. Well the dreadful crimes missions were great, I loved those missions as it actually felt great being a detective. The issue is that you don't really face any consequences from accusing a wrong person except for a little bit of money loss, but I think it would've been better if the game made the player try to get deeper into the case and actually try and solve it. The last Maharaja story was just bad. It was boring and not fun at all. I don't know what was the point of it at all and honestly I haven't even payed attention to it but I don't think I missed anything serious. And finally the Jack the Ripper storyline which was pretty good. You get to play as the Ripper a little but even though it's not a lot, you still can enjoy Ubisofts take on the Ripper. You also get to see older Jacob and Evie which eventually shows some character development, as they seem more mature.

Concerning the bugs, it has a lot of course, it's an AC game it can't be without bugs. The climbing bugs that made Unity such an annoying game to play were mostly gone, so you could finally enjoy parkour without getting stuck every five minute.

In conclusion, for an AC game I rate it as 4/10. It is a bad AC game just because it is somewhat disconnected from most of the lore. You can skip Syndicate after Unity and play Origins and it still wouldn't change anything. But as a game that is just fun to play, I rate it 7/10. It has a flaws and ignoring them is impossible, however I played the game for over 100 hours, I finished every mission perfectly and got every single achievement on this game, and I honestly don't regret a single minute spent in this game, no matter how repetitive it was sometimes. So i recommend this to those who just want to play a game with a light story and no deep lore from previous games.

Was pleasantly surprised about this game. After completing Unity I was expecting another rushed dumpster fire but found this game had refined on what was bad of the previous game and build on it. The gameplay felt slightly different from all of the games before Syndicate and enjoyed it very much. The setting of London was done very well and felt like a city come to life, something I've always enjoyed in AC games. However after about hour 20 of cleaning up boroughs and picking up collectibles the games repetition started to sink which is the series' greatest flaw. You can see the start of what Origins become in this game and I welcome the changes that Ubisoft is bringing to the series. I hope they continue to change the game in ways that keep the players wanting to come back for more, not leave because it's the same game reskinned over and over.

I have a complicated relationship with this game....

TL:DR; The story is a bit lame, especially the ending, but the gameplay and overall feel more than makes up for it.

I guess I should begin by saying I think this is probably all-round the best Assassin's Creed game Ubisoft have made, but it does have some flaws too.

As alluded to in the TLDR the story leaves quite a bit to be desired. I know by now we've established the general principle "Templars are bad, Assassin's are good. You're an Assassin so go poke the bad guys with pointy things" but in this case that seems to be literally the only motivation you have. They don't even seem to be doing anything *that* morally wrong in this case, other than wanting to control stuff (but I mean who doesn't??).

**SPOILER ALERT**
There are also a couple of continuity issues in the missions that have frustrated me... there's a particular mission where Evie gets hypnotized and as the player you have to steal from some civilians for him. For me that broke my flow a bit in terms of connection with the character... but more perhaps more significantly as soon as I got control back I naturally pulled out my gun and shot him in his stupid face with his annoying fake a** accent. Imagine my elation when he went down like a sack of the proverbial. Alas I still had to complete the mission and he was miraculously alive again at the next step of the sequence. There are a couple of instances like that and it's just a bit frustrating.

The ending is also kinda rubbish. The final boss fight is pretty weak and Evie ends up in some half-assed romance with a hapless Assassin. For the record Ubisoft, the world has never and will never need hapless Assassins. All Assassins should be bad-asses, that's how this works. This is at the end of a conflict between Jacob and Evie that seems randomly forced and unnecessary, every 'mistake' of Jacobs that Evie clears up seems to have been completely unforeseeable/outside of his control and happens purely because 'reasons'.

** END OF SPOILERS **

Really though I'm just quibbling. The story could be better and the armour you get for Evie as a result of unlocking Reuge's Vault looks really lame, but these are just trivial things. Call me a loser but even just going through and finding the 'Secrets of London' music boxes from the picture clues was quite fun.

Overall the gameplay is really well done and smooth. The world-building and feel of London is awesome, especially speaking as a Brit. I especially love the grappling hook and carriage mechanics, they make moving through the city a lot of fun as opposed to just getting from A to B. 

The borough control system is awesome too, wresting control of London from the 'Blighters' (ok, ok that is a dumb name) piece by piece all the while levelling up your characters was great. Investing in your gang and watching them grow over time is very satisfying.

I know people have complained over the twin system and the addition of Evie because it's seen as bowing to PC brigade but honestly I feel like it adds quite a lot. Having two playable characters, one with a combat specialty and one with a stealth specialty kept the gameplay feeling fresh from beginning to end. I'll admit I took it a little far and some 'assassinations' with Jacob became a case of summoning a carriage of Rooks alongside my normal complement of 5 bodyguards and storming the location with fire and fury... but IMHO the ability to do that broke things up nicely in a game series which has historically been a bit 'samey'.

This has been quite the ramble but hopefully this helps someone :). Bought this on sale for ¬£15 and it's honestly the best value for money I've had in a while.

Wow....going into this game, I assumed this was one of the worst games in the series because of how people talked about it. However, after 14 hours of gameplay and completing the main storyline, I can safely say this is one of my favorite games in the series. I didn't realize how much fun it would be to play as an Assassin during the industrial revolution. I loved every bit of it. There were a couple of things that annoyed me of course.

1st Con:

Since Unity, Ubisoft has the removed the counter kill feature.. I dont know what the exact name for it is, but it's extremely polished in AC 1 and the Kenway series. Basically allowing you to destroy groups of enemies by correctly reacting to each type of unit, kill,throw,disarm,stun, etc etc. It's in the Ezio Trilogy, but it's so weird and complex. The kenway series perfected it and it makes being the assassin so much fun. Even though were suppose to be sneaky SnEaKy, assassins are living breathing weapons, and the Kenway series shows how cool this system is. I hope one day they bring this back. Imagine how much cooler combat would have been with this system in Syndicate.

2nd con:
We are on PC, so were not usually using joysticks. when kidnapping somebody, to keep yourself from looking suspicious, you have to walk very slowly. If you don't have a controller, you have to gently tap the wasd buttons so that you don't attract too much attention, which I found annoying. PLEASE FIX THIS UBISOFT...or don't this game old anyways whatever. 

3rd Con: 
The Modern storyline from what I've seen after playing Origins and Odyssey 100% completion as well, is absolutely pointless. I mean, wtf happens to the shroud???? Who knows, and I guess who cares. The modern storyline has seemed to be pointless since Black Flag until recently in Odyssey which seems to be taking a new route with this Layla chick. But yea....pointless

Yes the story was cheezy, but all Ubisoft's stories are cheezy. And I really enjoyed playing as Jacob and Evie back and forth, which was way better than in Odyssey where they just flipped the two motherfuckers around which is so stupid but ok....

Get this game..You won't regret it. It is freaking awesome. BTW, as of today at 11:58pm, I have played and beaten every single Assassins Creed game. Hooray!!!!

7 out of 10 

Sadly, another rather forgettable saga in the Assassins Creed series. 
In many ways, Syndicate is the best version in the series up to this point.  Unfortunately it falls flat in one of the most important parts of an Assassins Creed game - the main story.  The game feels like a huge missed opportunity. 

The good: 
 - Best controls of any Assassins Creed game up to this point.  The run-up and run-down commands work very well.  Carts and the rope launcher are amazing.  And combat is smooth without any difficulty focusing on an enemy. 
 - The mini missions are quite enjoyable.  Unfortunately there are to many of them. 
 - Evy and and Jacob are quite likable characters. And for a change the main characters actually look like they could be assassins, not pretty boys. 
 - New ways to navigate (carts and rope launcher) cuts down considerably on time wastage. This made a huge difference to the game experience.  
 
The bad:  
 - The game is still far to long.  There is way too many mini missions and pointless generic crap to collect.  It is better than most games in the series.  But the game really starts to drag towards the end. 
 - Unfortunately, the main missions are a real letdown.  Most Assassins Creed games get this part right, but Syndicate doesn't.  The main missions are too short, too easy and show little of London's splendor.  
 - London feels really bland - most of it could have been any generic location.  You see too little of the grand historic sites in London - towards the end when the game starts to drag.  Assassins Creed Unity may have been a mess; but at least Paris looked and felt amazing. 
 - The game is too easy.  You can use the brute force approach 90%+ of the time. There is little need for stealth.  That is sad, because the stealth is the most fun in my opinion.  
 - The script writing is bad.  You start with two very likable characters, who fall out in the middle and make up in the end. It is so cheesy it hurts. 

The ugly: 
 - Horrible bug mess.  Crashess galore. 
 - The multi-kill action selection is hopeless.

So about 5 or 6 years ago I realized I was just about the only person alive that had never played an Assassin's Creed game. I set out to play them in chronological order and it wasn't going well at first. I liked the concept but had to force my way through the earlier games. Brotherhood and Black Flag were about the only ones I enjoyed for the most part with others either being more annoying than entertaining or just flat out bad.

This one is INCREDIBLY impressive.

Positives:
While it still retains the (mostly) awful parkour mechanics where the character does all the work and you just point in the direction you wanna go, they refined it quite a bit. In the previous game actually, they added a separate free run down key. I struggled to get used to it after so many years of playing the other games but the previous title just wasn't good enough to really hook me so I never got a chance to really come to grips with it.
Well now with this one I think they polished everything rather nice and once you get used to it, it is SO MUCH easier to safely get down, in fact I haven't fallen and taken damage once.
As usual for an AC game, the animations, voice acting and sound effects are all very well done. The characters are quite likable so far and the introduction of the grappling hook, which I thought would put a sour taste in my mouth, is actually super useful. Not only does it speed up climbing huge buildings but it makes for much faster escapes. And of course...you don't HAVE to use it if you don't want to.
The fighting is much improved! It is the most well done 'melee' combat of a "fighting" game like this I have played. (Comparing to stuff like Mad Max and Batman etc). I say melee loosely because there are various weapon strikes here and there but I won't compare it to the might of the legendary Witcher 3.
Most importantly, the annoying bits like constantly de-synchronizing because you didn't do something exactly right is mostly gone. There is very little repetition with this one. Most missions, though not all, will have a fail-safe so to speak in that you can attempt to do it the 'right' way but then when things go haywire, you can fight through it and proceed with plan B.
I almost forgot to mention the leveling system whereby you can upgrade your characters. This makes things so much smoother as you start fighting harder enemies. It is fairly balanced and nicely laid out.
Lastly, the map is astounding and this is big coming from me because as much as I love European history, I have never found interest in 19th century Europe. This London map is incredibly alive and performs so smoothly on my computer which is far from the top of notches.

Cons:
For once, I have very little negative to say about an AC game. It isn't perfect, I have still gotten killed because my character wouldn't climb exactly as I wanted or wouldn't drop down to where I wanted. It can get frustrating at times and I occasionally wish they would just make it 1st person and give it Mirror's Edge controls but whatever.

Some of the characters are a little forgettable, but the Frye twins and a couple supporting NPCs are all I've needed to make it a generally enjoyable experience. Locomotion and separate character optimization between the two protagonists have elevated the game and allowed multiple play types depending on mission type (minus a few PC-specific missions).

Absolutely disappointed. The control mechanics and game spawning system in this game is horrible. After playing AC4 I was really looking forward to playing this one next. 

Firstly, The controls are complete crap. Why they had to change them opposed to previous games is beyond me. There was nothing wrong with them. As a matter of fact, they are now worse. To incorporate stealth in this game (as with all previous AC games are meant to include) it's nearly impossible to with the poor control mechanics. I cant tell you how many instances I tried to avoid being detected and the game controls ended up making me randomly jumping rather than escaping detection in time.

Secondly, the spawning system. I cannot even count how many times this game has respawned me after a death directly in the sight of enemy npcs. I mean come on... At least give the player a fighting chance to recoup after they spawned and not have to initiate a fight right off the bat.

Thirdly, in addition to the spawning system, Why is it every time I kill a certain enemy during the side missions they ended up immediately respawning? This happens with at least 1 enemy npc during every side mission I play. I will be playing stealth and crouched behind an object, whistle for an enemy to come near, perform an assassination, and then as soon as I assassinate them that same enemy respawns a couple meters back where they initially were patrolling causing me to be spotted.

I'm highly disappointed in this game. The open world is great, the missions would be fun if it weren't for these issues & the livelihood environment makes it more immersing. But these gameplay flaws cause this game to be complete trash. 

I highly doubt there is going to be any updates to fix this for as long as the game has already been out. This would have been a decent game in the AC franchise if they would have hired somebody that knew what they were doing when it came to avoiding these issues.

With a lot of spare time because of COVID-19, I've been catching up on missed AC games. I stopped playing after Black Flag, and now I've made it to Syndicate. This one definitley seems like a turning point in the series with a fairly drastic change in gameplay from previous titles. It's fast, it's fun, and it's a breath of fresh air from the normal AC formula that honestly got stale back in AC 3. This was a weird one for me.. I kept playing it while I kept getting annoyed at it. It had enough Assassin's Creed to keep me going but at the same time it was the most disjointed and odd package I've ever played out of any of the series.

There are so many bugs that pull you out of the experience just as it starts getting going and you can't look past it, and yet there's still that compulsive need to keep going, if not to see where the story is going but to unlock some more things so that you can unlock more things. 

I must be a masochist because I spent at least three hours combing the WW1 map looking for all the crates and helix glitches. Speaking of glitches, the 'Social Glitch Service' or whatever they call it has never worked for me, it always says it's down.. it is my understanind that you can get (very) minimal amounts of Helix Credits(TM) from this, but who knows.

This is the first Assassin's Creed game that I really felt they were taking the piss with real money transactions to 'speed up' single player gameplay by selling xp boosters, weapon and gear pack unlocks etc. It is quite disgusting. Unity had some of these as well, but they weren't really pushed so hard and there weren't whole maps (to show where the collectibles are) locked behind real money transactions like this. 

The story in this game was so disjointed - at times I wished they just had a set narrative mission structure they forced you through, Jacob's missions, then Evie's missions in each memory sequence one after the other but the whole game feels like they just cut it up and threw bits here and there - possibly to distract which bits were cut out for sale as dlc etc. It was so bizarre (probably because I had the season pass and all the DLC and stuff was unlocking based on player level rather than story progression etc. and it was just all a big ol' mess. 

Hands down the most disjointed narrative I've ever played (which I don't think was the intention).. explains the need for the fresh start that came after with Origins and Odyssey since this one because damn, a veritable pile of random crap scooped up together and then thrown about the room  only to be scooped up together again and each piece handed out to multiple people at different times with the expectation that somehow everyone will know which piece of crap was shat out first.

Good times. I still had fun playing it - it hits me in my OCD needs to feel like I'm achieving something even though ultimately it's all just a waste of time. Thank you gaming! But yeah - be prepared for what you're getting into.

Oooh.. P.S - the best piece of DLC that I enjoyed the most was the Dreadful Crimes, the only piece of DLC that is positively rated on Steam and the only piece of DLC that isn't a part of the Season Pass/Gold editions etc.

The last Assassin's Creed to stay true to the original formula, Syndicate is one hell of a way for the series to go out with a blast.

A couple of years before AC Origins hit the shelves and buried the classical AC formula forever, Syndicate showed that Unity's failure was nothing inherent to the decade-old formula: it was a journey that took us to unexpected depths of fun, challenge, depth and allure like those that made the franchise great in its heyday.

You play as Jacob and Evie Fry, a couple of twins who are members of the Assasin's Brotherhood. Tasked with the by now all-too familiar mission of bringing down a templar conspiracy in the midst of society, they set forth on an against all odds mission to prevail upon tyranny and oppression.  This time instead of Renaissance Italy or colonial North America, you take the fight to mid 19th Century London.

What is remarkable about this game is that no matter how repetitive this storyline may seem to veteran AC players, it delivers, and delivers soundly: enemies are memorable, gameplay is bombastic, the game is a thrill to play from start to finish and no menial task feels ever like a chore. It helps immensely to have the likes of Charles Dickens, Alexander Graham Bell, Charles Darwin and even Karl Marx provide you with some of the side quests... whereas you encounter Disraeli and HRH Queen Victoria herself during the course of the main story.

As befits an Asasssin's Creed game, it will have you ruthlessly assassinate foes (stealth has been perfectly implemented in this iteration), battle it out for control of London various suburbs, steal carriages, hijack trains, etc. Asassinations are probably the best the series have to offer, offering a blend of AC Unity's "opportunities" system with the traditional stealth formula of AC games (in other words, what Unity so painstakingly tried but failed dismally to implement). Then, there are the gang wars, which pits what begins as ragtag band of ne'er-do-wells against an entrenched, corrupt criminal organisation that runs the London underworld. Finally, hijack missions provide a nice distraction from the constant fighting, offering a nice blend of parkour and hit-and-run that is so properly implemented in the game.

Should you feel that there is so much one can do in 19th-Century London, you need not fear, for there is a nice caveat to it all: about halfway into the game you will be able to access a rift of sorts that will let you switch between the aforementioned reality... and a London during the darkest days of WWI. Then, there are the DLC to spice things up all the more: the first one has you aid an exiled indian prince in his quest for redemption. The other one is more like an autonomous expansion, if you will, and has you track down the infamous Jack the Ripper as he wreaks havoc in late 19th-Century London. While the setting is roughly the same as in the base game, the tone has radically changed and its markedly depressing. It sometimes feels more as an horror game rather than an AC game and it ended up getting on my nerves. I enjoyed it thoroughly, but I found it somewhat unsettling and disturbing, so no qualms getting it over with.

Next, the graphics department is to be commended: for a game that came out in 2015, it is quite the looker. Optimisation is also worthy of praise, as I ran the game on an AMD Phenom IIx6 1100t Black Edition and a GTX 660 on medium, never getting less than 40 FPS. Sound is also remarkably good, the voice acting deserving a special mention on this regard, as the Fry twins come to life before our eyes with seamless ease; same goes for the main villain, Starrick, whose evil baritone voice will stick with you long after you finish the game.

My only qualms with this game is that it ended. While I enjoyed Origins, this was Assassin's Creed done right. I do hope someday they will take up this path yet again and give the classic formula a chance.

While it has some bugs and graphical glitches. The story is interesting and London is a great setting for the assassins creed series. I recommend to pick it up on sale and play it. Those who are stubborn enough (like myself) might try to complete it 100% and my word is it a task.

The game has to be played, I honesty grew attached to Jacob and Evie after playing the entire Campaign and the DLC's. The game itself stands out from the previous Assassin's Creed games because it introduces close combat and eliminates any swords.

A lot of people complained that Syndicate does not feel like previous Assassin's Creed because they introduced the Grappling Hook which made climbing so much more easier and rooftops are so much efficiently climbed. I honestly didn't think I will like it, but taking into consideration the setting and the period the game happened I honestly loved it.

The attention to details in buildings is just amazing. I got to visit London once more in a video game and that was amazing. I honestly thought I will be having the entire map, but it only contained the centralized areas and it was rich and amazing in history. I loved it.

Now the story was different from previous ones, the focus was not as much as before from both characters on the Items of Eden, only Evie that focused on them, but it had some really fun and interesting missions with Jacob. Not many like him because he was so careless, but that's what really made me love him a lot. He was silly and full of himself but was damn good at it.

The DLC, Jack The Ripper was just as amazing and I wish I was able to play with Jacob more on it or at least have a separate DLC where you play as him. Was a nice story and left me a bit confused and I honestly recommend playing that one too, to close the game.

Overall I'd score this game at: 8/10

This game is garbage. Bad voice acting, bad script, bad graphics for its time. The gameplay would be fun if you weren't at odds with the controls. Want to scale down a building slowly? NOT AN OPTION. I honestly want to slap those idiots who said the old system of parkour felt too 'easy' or 'basic' It was functional. When you don't aim your jumps and you leave every climbing decision to the computer instead of the player; You get an imprecise mess of a movement system. 

Parkour up and forward seem to be the same thing 90% of the time and then 10% they will be completely different from eachother. Parkour down is just dogshit. IT IS DOGSHIT. It doesn't work.  you want to scale down to a window and take someone out but you'll just jump off the building completely or freeze in place like a brick with limbs. Not to mention sometimes the autoclimb crap is so bad it will ignore both your inputs AND the camera angle and keep moving you along a wall in the complete wrong direction. For a game with all this vertical space to use, you will have a better time forgetting about it altogether. The old assassins creed engine wanted you to be precise where you pointed your camera before moving or jumping and occasionally there would be an object in the way you jumped to instead by accident. This game says 'Don't worry about aiming where you are going, we will just decide a random spot for you and stick you there like a magnet.' I have never had to think so hard about moving in a direction before jumping in my 22 years of gaming. It is a chore. It may look kinda cool when it works but I play the game terrified of WHEN (not if) my character will soon leap off in some nonesense direction getting detected immediately.

 The combat also suffers the issue of spamming towards an enemy for 20 hours with the same 1-2 punch until they fall over, the animations for fighting are missing frames or are just too fast. THEY LOOK RIDICULOUS. It looks like those mid air punch flurries from dragon ball Z. The stun feature is a must and they only have 1 animation for it. So every fight ends up with you pulling on both ears of every single enemy npc in the game. The old games had better controls and the fights looked cool. You didn't have to worry about the number above goon's head meaning they could knock you ever despite being the same as every goon you had killed at level 1. Level gating the areas of the map is limiting the freedom expected in an open world game. Just have enemy TYPES and have the combat difficulty consistent to those TYPES of enemy. WHAT the actual hell is so hard about that ubisoft!?

The stealth is also broken. I never had a clue how far away I could be seen by guards. Sometimes 20 meters, sometimes I cannot be seen 1 ft away from an enemy. BECAUSE EVERY ASPECT OF THIS MONSTROSITY IS BROKEN. 

Who likes this? Who could like such an objectively terrible creation. Who does this entertain?

The sum of this games parts should on paper make it just as good if not better than Black Flag. Recognizable people to do missions for like Charles Dickens and Carl Marx, two separate characters to control, an entire gang to control and upgrade, satisfying combat, vehicles, a gear and crafting system like the newer assassin creed games. Unfortunately the game feels like it was rushed and everything that should be good in this game comes off as barely average.

Okay, after that much Time playing this Game deserves a review. 

Frankly I was quite disappointed, when I played AC3 back then, after playing Revelations, so I skipped Ubisoft and AC games altogether for a looong time until there was a special sale, so here we are. First off I played Origins (was curious about the story), but finishing the game I came to the conclusion: it sucked. So I thought how worse can it get and jumped to Syndicate and, lo and behold, I was impressed. All the Elements I got used to and missed so much over the years were all again united in this game, so to shorten it:

+ Story (amazing, if you haven't played it yet, you're going to love it, at the latest, when you come to Seq 3-4)

+ Music (not the masterpieces of 2 and Brotherhood, but still beats the hell out of everything else)

+ Skill-Features (simple, yet efficient)

+ Gear (Finally something crafty to tinker with)

+ Upgrades (Boy, weapons, tools and Gang Upgrades really pushed the bar)

But of course you have to lower your sights, when it comes to

- Controls

- Game stability

no offense, but we're still talking about Ubisoft here. All in all thats all for now on the quick, forgive me, if I forgot something.

[h1][b]WARNING! This review may perspectively contain indirect spoilers![/b][/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
The story is set in Victorian era in London (1868, to be specific) during the great industrial revolution. This time, you play as two twin assassins, the calculating and stealthy Evie, and the hot-blooded and straight-to-battle Jacob Frye. The mission is simple, stop the ruling hand of Templars in London and defeat the crew pulling the strings.

[h1]Personal view[/h1]
The story itself was pretty mediocre, not great, but not necessarily bad, it was the typical - climb the villain ladder and kill off the atagonist. There was really no character development, although the characters themselves were interesting, nothing too generic and common. The origin of characters are also missing, I do not know anything about Evie or Jacob, only that their father was an assassin and he liked to give wise quotes.

Apart from story, what really caught my attention is, of course, the enviroment and "atmosphere". In-game London was immersive and I really felt like I was roaming the 19th century. It is my first expirience to actually see children in a video game (especially PG-18‚Ñ¢ rated one), which adds to the immersion, because sadly, child labor was very common in this era - working in factories under unacceptable conditions for long hours. But except for this depressing fact, the population is very lively and active, they react to what you do. The map is very huge (I believe about 30% bigger than Unity‚Äôs Paris), so thankfully, they added horses and carriages to drive you around faster.

As for equipments. you have various revolvers to choose from as firearms, and as for melee - Kukri, Cane-Sword and Knuckles. Other than that you have throwing knifes, voltaic bombs, smoke bombs and med-kits. You are also equiped with a grappling hook (made by the great A. G. Bell), which has made traveling from roof-to-roof much easier! 

As Evie and Jacob arrive to London, Jacob gets the great idea of creating a gang called "The Rooks". There are enemy gangs all around the London, the more boroughs you conquer, the safer the streets to travel. Your gang members always greet you, and offer you help, by getting recruited. You can recruit up to 5 gang members.

In conclusion, if you are looking for an Assassins Creed game set in 19th century, which has an amazing map and enviroment to interact with, and don‚Äôt mind a more or less clich√© story - it is a game just for you.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
+ Characters, not developed, but interesting (Evie, Jacob, Starrick, love ‚Äôem).
+ Enviroment, the city is beautiful!
+ Graphics
+ Optimization - Medium settings; 30-50 fps (avg. 48, 1% of time bellow 30); on a Intel Core i5 
   4460; NVIDIA GeForce GTX 960 (2GB VRAM); 8GB RAM. 
   So if you have a newer budget rig, you should not worry.
+ Awesome combat combos.
+ Traveling methods (horses and the grappling hook).

- Story, it was not bad, but there was alot of unused potentional for such rich historic era.
- Climbing, not entirely, but there were moments when the game decided doing the opposite of what I was doing, and it was frustrating.

[h1]Additional info[/h1]
Finishing the story, with minimal side-questing = ~ 21 hours

[b]This is not really a spoiler, but it is a nice addition to the game. I will still mark it as spoiler just in case, because I sure was surprised to discover this feature.[/b] [spoiler]A World War I sequence - You play as Lydia Frye, the granddaughter of Jacob Frye. Shes an assassin operating in London. You have an area around the London Bridge available, and you are basically doing missions for Winston Churchill. You finish the missions by killing Sage, who is the leader of German spies.[/spoiler]

Just so you are not confused - With every 1,000 epx, you get a skill point, and to level up your character, you have to spend those points. The higher the level you are, the more skill points you have to spend.

Conquer 3 boroughs (basically neighborhoods) to unlock senquence 9.

Talked about this game with my friends recently after playing it some more to pad out time and it's time to add to the bitching.
Alexander Graham Bell was the inventor of the telephone, photophone (first machine that moved data using light, kinda like an optical cable), a man who helped build one of the first hydroplanes and spent his life improving sign language. This game depicts him like a child overdosed on sugar.
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was a medical professional, the diagnosis itself - observing symptoms and using them to figure out the cause - was a concept he found interesting and used the concept to write detective stories about Sherlock Holmes. In this game you meet him as a child and he watches you solve crimes which are about slowly following big arrows to the end. So in this game Sherlock Holmes is all about good assassins saving the world.
Before the game was even out I saw someone complain about some company logo on the trains not actually existing until the 1960s, but honestly why care about one small texture everybody's going to miss anyway when people like Bell and Doyle are being butchered before your very eyes?

Assassins Creed Syndicate is definitely a great game. Graphics are awesome and the story line is, as usual in any AC game, better than watching a movie. The new thing here is that you get to play with two assassins instead of just one, as we were used to. Also fighting mode improved compared to previous AC games.

Assassins Creed Syndicate is one of the many major installments of the AC franchise. Set during the peak of the industrial revolution in London, you play as twin assassins Jacob and Evie Frye. The two are out for the templar, Crawford Starrick. Starrick runs most of the Factories is London, and circulates child labor. His gang of Templars run wild throughout London, and the primary feature of the game is to take London back from them. The gameplay is simply brilliant. It features improved shooting mechanics, the brand new rope launcher, fast paced combat destined to keep you on edge, and beautiful graphics and scenery. The story itself is very good. Dialogue is well written, and characters really feel alive. There's also an abundant amount of real life, historical associates. Such as Charles Dickens, Karl Marx, etc. The game also features some fun mini games and side activities, and the most incredible ww1 segment. Honestly, this might be my favorite Assassins Creed game. Just Great overall.

Veteran AC player here, played through almost every AC game since the first one came out (save for Unity because I'm not certain all the bugs have been worked out, Odyssey because I haven't gotten it, and the Chronicles series because. What even are those?) and I've loved the story from the beginning, but honestly speaking it took me a while to get to this one after playing Black Flag since [spoiler]I was honestly hoping for some sort of continuation to Desmond's story after III, and then I realized they were probably more than likely gonna leave him dead and focus on the other assassins and templars.[/spoiler] Nothing against it, since I feel like they did do Rogue pretty decently. But. Well. 

[b]Pros[/b]
- Decent setting and characters, [i]lovely[/i] soundtrack and unique atmospheres, but that's par for the course at this point. It's always interesting to see which historical figures they're going to drag into the game and how they're going to tie into the plot (though I feel they were a [i]highly[/i] underused). 

- Pretty much your standard AC game of running around an area collecting glitches and treasure while unraveling plots. 

[b]Cons[/b]
- A little wonky and buggy at some points. Crashed a few times, which is irritating because it takes almost forever to start up sometimes. Hit some branches while on the rope launcher and it either flings me into the air or sends me plummeting into the middle of enemies that shouldn't be alerted. Trying to make my controlled character move to peek into a corner kill was like trying to thread a needle using a pair of pliers. 

- The mechanics of the controls for the free running were... not as intuitive as they could've been, and the animations made the movements lag as all hell. 

- The Social Glitches are really, really annoying. Please, just let me get all the collectibles in my playthrough without the need for some [i]omg super cool social activity[/i], Ubisoft, it's driving me insane. I'm a completionist and I don't have friends. 

- The skill tree felt. Slightly out of place? It worked fine, no glitches here, but I'm slightly irritated by the fact that it felt like general skills an assassin character would h a v e was just used to bulk it up. Spending skill points to learn how to loot automatically after a kill? Hm. 

- I hesitate to truly call any AC game [i]boring[/i] because that's just patently untrue, but there was a certain charm to their earlier games that made it easier to care about what happens to the main characters that was just sort of missing in Syndicate. While the twins are witty and sassy, [spoiler]Jacob spends most of the main game bring a brat and Evie was just constantly exasperated and there was no real resolution other than oh well, we love each other because we're family and daddy dearest was wrong because trauma (: also haha love I guess.[/spoiler] Evie says [i]requiescat in pace[/i] to a [i]dress[/i], which you know, haha throwback but also sighs (though in hindsight it was probably long enough that any real meaning to those words when Ezio used them would have been lost to younger generations of recklessly youthful Assassins). Plot feels a little offbeat, and also very skin deep. Sometimes it goes from plot point A to plot point B while leaving me reeling because what on EARTH happened between them and thinking I missed some sort of mission that explained it. There's no real beefiness to it to make up for the general m e h of the handling. They went right back to the whole Assassins are Good, Templars are Bad, black and white bs after this was made clear it wasn't the case in III and Rogue. Was half expecting something to happen in the end because the twin weren't supposed to be in London at all. Henry didn't even know they were going against orders to be there. Nothing happened, wholly disappointed. Could've had a much more engaging plot if the third act conflict hadn't just been another rehash of [i]oh no we had the thing but now the enemy has the thing and now we need to get it back from them/get to where the plot needs us before the enemy does[/i]. 

- Definitely feels like they could've made Crawfard Starrick a more interesting antagonist, like they did with Haytham Kenway. We don't get to fight him until the very end, literally just assassinating Templars off a checklist. The entire game felt like going through a big checklist of murder and treasure hunting. 

- While combat was fine in the main game, the combat + fear thing for the DLC while also trying to juggle counter/breaking defense/the game's automated targeting was just [i]attrocious[/i]. 

- The carriages. Don't even get me started on how the [i]carriages[/i] handled. 

- Minor nitpick but the voice acting for civillians and minor characters [i]grated[/i] at my nerves, especially when they're put on repeat and they wouldn't just [i]shut up[/i]. Can't even abandon them sometimes for certain side quests like the slow carriage ones, and it's the same set of dialogue by the same voice actor. 

- Even if you get the game just. Don't even bother with the Jack the Ripper DLC. I'm begging you. Don't do that to yourself. 


[b]TL;DR[/b]
Completed the main game at 98% and the Jack the Ripper DLC at 99%. Negative review because there isn't much new going on here compared to older AC games without feeling like the collectibles were a bit of a slog, though I will honestly say buy it if you'd like to complete the collection. But if you're looking for an AC game to get, might as well get your money's worth with Origins.
its good but kinda boring

I wish there was more than just a Yes or No for a review, but before I start this game is fantastic and I would recommend playing it.

So why the negative review? 

I hate that Ubisoft continues to push their launcher even though I bought the game through Steam. It's a whole extra added layer that is really not needed. And then, on top of that, there's all kinds of microtransactions being pushed your way to pay money for boosts and gear or what have you. 

I just want a single player Assassin's Creed experience. 

Now lets talk about Syndicate specifically. This was Ubisoft's version of Saint's Row in my opinion minus all the ridiculousness. And it worked great. 

No story spoilers, but this section has info about different things you get to do in the game. Skip this section if you don't want to know. Basically, you're fighting for territory in London and the main character Jacob is a gang boss. It's fantastic, and the game play for this is a ton of fun. Also, the side missions are actually meaningful in this game unlike Unity. Lastly, it was really cool having two playable characters one for traditional stealth game play and another to Rambo in like a savage. I've always wanted to play an Assassin's Creed game in this manor and it was executed perfectly here.

Combat in this game is fluid and rewarding. It just works. And thank freakin Jesus there is a counter to guns. In Unity you'd just get wrecked by guns, but here, you have a counter to dodge or shoot back. It's so nice to be able to do that. 

The RPG elements in this are only a small part, but it's really cool to have the skill trees and be able to customize your character. 

London, the city is fantastic. It's so alive and bustling. In Unity I loved the running through houses and all that. Unforunately, that is gone. However, you get a batman grappling hook which helps you get around and eases the burden of getting to objectives.

On that note, the Parkour here is not as good as Unity. The animations and moves just aren't. What did get better though is the controls. Much much better. More often than not I was able to make the character do the thing that I wanted them to do when I wanted them to do it. Climb, jump, slide whatever. But it still was not perfect. For example, climb through window and grappling hook are the same freakin key. So you run up to a window and try to hop through and you end up flying up onto the roof. I still don't get why we have to be limited on mouse and keyboard. I have 61 keys on my keyboard, just give me a separate entry in keybinds for every action. That way I can just map that thing out. And if people are too lazy then they can use a controller and be limited to having buttons do multiple things.

So, my final thoughts. This game was fantastic. Loved it thoroughly. Just wish the Ubisoft club would leave me alone.

I'm blasting through the AC franchise and each and every game I play, it gets better and better. AC Syndicate, based in London during the mid to late 1800's about two twins raised by a father who was an assassin that was unfortunately killed and not able to finish his mission take his place and to end what he had started. You play as Jacob and Evie Frye who aim to take down Crawford Starrick, the Templar Grand Master who aims to take over London in his complete control. 

The story is much better than it's previous titles but then again the AC franchise tend to have the same concept for every one of their games. The feature of being able to play as either twin (Jacob & Evie) is a very cool and different feature added but some missions force you to play one of the twins even though you want to change them. Graphics are gorgeous, you can form gangs by taking over boroughs around London which is also new. 

Overall, Syndicate was a great success!

[h1] Assassin's Creed: Syndicate [/h1]
[i]Really good, although repetitive[/i]

I Really like this game. Most of it is acctually preety good. Okay, I confess that the last AC i played was Black Flag, back when it came out, and I had a blast, although I didn't finish it. This one, however, amde me go all the way to the end: I loved the activities, I liked the story and I really liked our main protagonists, Jacob and Evie. However, by the end of it, after I had already conquered everything, I just wanted the story to move along and be done with it already

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Standard assassin's creed. In missions, you have set objectives and can approach them however you like, although you are pointed a certain direction through the bonus objectives. Parkour feels a little... Weird, at least initially. The whole "Free run up" and "down" took a thile to get used in my head, but given the landscape and the obstacles you're required to traverse, it get a lot easier when jacob doesn't jump a gap he was supposed to drop from like Ezio and Altair did. Combat feels allright, even though it's oh so easy.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Meh. Don't expect much. just let it take you along for the ride and you'll be fine. Also, they kept the "Present part" of the story to a minimum this time (HALLELUJAH)

[h1]Atmosphere[/h1]
Well, ubisoft did it again, surprising a total of zero people. Everything is recreated with the most details taken in consideration. Flawless. Only flaw is I couldn't buy ice cream from the poor lady selling it on a square. She was trying so hard, and everyone was ignoring her. Poor thing. Then, I went to a pub and people were dancing and having a great time! But I couldn't get a beer. It's a shame! These meaningless activities, like buying a newspaper, having some ice cream or being able to buy a ticket to acctually go in a passenger train could have enriched the experience a lot, but what is there is really cool

[h1]Final score[/h1]
7.5/10. Pretty good, had a fun time, but by the end of it I already really wanted to move on to something else.

------------------------------------------------------------

THE DLC:

[h1]Last Maharajah:[/h1]
Didn't touch it. The "king" is a prick and I want him to die in a fire. [strike]Long live Britannia![/strike]

[h1]Jack the Ripper:[/h1]
I tried to get into it RIGHT after I finished the main story. At first, it felt AWESOME. You're Jack the effin Reaper, man! You're seeing scribbles on your screen like the voices in your head, and you're chasing none other than JACOB! "Oh man, this is going to be SO COOL", I thought to myself, right as I was introduced to the fear system. And then, in the middle of the chase, I decide to kill a civilian because, well, i'm jack the ripper going on a rampage, duh, and I get the message: "Jack the ripper didn't compromise his plans by killing random civilians". Uh... WHAT? 

Okay, I can power through this. Allright, cutscene with jacob, but i'll still go around instilling fear in London. Let's see the next memory and... It's Evie. In a boring invstigative mission. When I wanted to be bashing skulls. I put it down after that and don't intend on touching it anytime soon. Maybe when I reinstall this

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a welcome addition to the Assassin's Creed Series.  I would place this one just about Assassin's Creed: Revelations.  Purchased at the discounted price of $10.85 it was a steal.

Pros:
There is a LOT of content (~55 hours).
This is a very good looking game and full of texture.
Most of the offered activities are fun to do and succeed at.
Pretty good villains and general story.
The city exudes personality and although I have never been to London, assume that it captures the city relatively well.
The "Secrets of London" was really enjoyable for me and once I realized I could rotate the map to view buildings better it became even more enjoyable.

Cons:
Various performance issues.  Specifically when driving the carriage.
No map can be purchased to find all of the collectible glitches.  I am not a through and through 100%er for games but would have fetched all of them if it were easier to find them.  There are too many to go through a walkthrough and call it "having fun".
Traveling from point A to point B can be extremely tedious.
I expected more collaborative gameplay considering there are two main characters.  This only happens rarely.

Nitpicky criticism:
There was some injected conflict between the two main characters that occurred.  There was no build up to the conflict and the resolution of the conflict was meaningless.

Advice:
If a waypoint is over 200 meters away take a carriage.  Running or going across rooftops will add hours to gameplay if you don't heed my advice.
Do not let NVIDIA Experience set any graphical settings if you are using a TV as a monitor.  It seems to prioritize resolution over textures.

Whoo boy, almost done with all of them, and Syndicate . . . while it's obviously the best between itself, Rogue, and Unity (not that being better than Rogue is exactly high praise), it's not a 10 out of 10.

The problems with it are petty, but add to the general feel of a Ubisoft game.  I'm not sure whether to applaud them for trying new things and failing, or to tell them to stick to what they do well.  I lean towards the former, though.  I suppose if I have an option between "more of the same" and "something new, but it might not work" then new is better than not.  Still not as good as just not screwing up at all.

So, for the downsides - in this game they're actually relatively few.  Though I'm tough on Ubisoft games, understand, I think at their core, they're (usually) good games.  There's a reason I keep playing them.  Lemme list some of the issues that range from slightly irritating up to rage-inducing.

If you try and steal a cart with two on the bench, the second will ALWAYS throw you off.  Not tip you backwards - you'll roll off, no matter what.  And knowing this, you have no option (at least that I found, short of shooting one of them before kicking the other off) to prevent it.

Speaking of carts, the area on them is small.  With "E" being your contextual action button, you will vary between hijacking the cart, getting IN the cart, and jumping off the cart, no matter which of the three you actually intend.  Usually it'll just do whatever's the least helpful at any given time.

Some of the buggier quests that end in conversation will result in things like your character never actually exiting the conversation.  The pause menu, when in conversation, only has two options:  resume, or disable subtitles.  Or, presumably, enable them if they're already disabled.  None of those options help.  At that point you've got no choice but to shut it down.  This generally happens after it saves the fact that you DID complete the quest, so that's not a huge hardship.  Except it means I have to sit through 2 minutes of unskippable introductory horsecrap again when I start it up.

Also, a recurring issue, sometimes you'll just be detected by someone with no line of sight, faaar away, who realistically has no way of knowing you're there.  Again, that's recurring, and to be entirely fair, it seemed to happen a LOT less here.

The challenges for each level were actually usually pretty easy to spot, and they didn't disappear if you failed them, so if you noticed you just failed something but don't know what, you can check.  That was a great improvement, honestly.

Also, you can tailor your abilities through choosing your own equipment, with some shared between Jacob and Evie, and some specific to each.  That was fun to do, and I liked the different options you had with each.

Don't think, though, that it escaped my notice that crafting materials were distributed randomly and in tiny quantities, forcing you to farm them to craft useful accessories, or (the obvious intent) to buy them.  Look devs, if you're acknowleging that people would rather spend money to NOT play your game, maybe make a better game.

Scratch that, I think I just found the modern AAA game dev's business model.

Snark aside, the assassination missions were the best they've been in a long time.  They really gave you a lot of options to get it done and then let you do what you want.  They started that in Unity, but they've definitely honed it here.

And Dreadful Crimes was great.  The gameplay was fine, it was a nice change of pace, but the actual story of it.  I actually noticed the thread running through them and just idly thought, "Oh, that's just world-building, they're just mentioning this in a lot of these stories because they're painting a picture of a real, living world."  But NOPE it actually all comes together with a puzzle that's not TOO hard if you've been following, but it's just hard enough to feel rewarding if you get it right with no mistakes.  I could put this review on the Dreadful Crimes page, but really, I think it's practically a necessity if you're considering the game itself.  Well done, Ubisoft.  Sit, Ubi, sit.  Good dog.  *woof!*

I'd say that I wish that the friction between the characters was a little more believable - it seems like when you make your characters siblings, it's an excuse to have them behave towards each other however you want, then you can just wave vaguely at the implied backstory between the two and go, "No, it totally makes sense, everyone."  But for the most part it wasn't too grating.  I just didn't like Jacob too much.  Though he did have his moments.  He WAS charming.

All in all, it was a good one.  I mean, skip the collectibles, obviously, but other than that, a good game.  A good addition to the series.  Honestly, if it'd been Arno and Evie it might've been more fun.  Arno > Jacob.  Just sayin'.

Anyway, on to the modern . . . wait, what?  FREAKIN' EGYPT?  *sigh*  Well, alright then.  Back into the Animus we go.
