Assassins Creed Syndicate was for me a big improvement on it's predecessor Unity, which I found to be pretty bland. Syndicate takes the setting to Victorian London and honestly it's a great setting.

London in the middle of the Industrial revolution is quite impressive. You've got a mix of the slums and factories to the rich aristocratic areas around westminster and monuments recognizable to a lot of people like Big Ben and Buckingham palace. The Thames splits the city almost down the middle and is a hive of activity with steamboats chugging up and down the river. It really is one of the more impressive cities that has been recreated in an Assassins Creed game.

It being Victorian London you also have access to horse and carriages which you can use to get around. And with a new grappling hook item for quick climbing it is a lot faster and easier to get around the city in this game. You can also even hop onto one of the trains that move around London. Even your home base in this game is a train that moves around London.

Another first for the series is that you get to play with two main characters, twins Jacob and Evie Frye who set off for London to take down a high ranking Templar who is basically controlling the city. Jacob and Evie are quite likeable actually and probably equal Ezio as being the most likeable main characters for the AC series. Both characters generally play the exact same even though the game tells you Evie is better at stealth and Jacob at fighting. They both do have three unique skills each to unlock but as the rest of their skill tree is the same it doesn't make a huge difference.

One of the ways Evie and Jacob fight to control London is through creating and expanding their own gang. You can do side missions to expand your gangs territory some of which are fun but theirs not a huge variety of them. Your gang members can be upgraded and recruited to help you fight enemies which is useful.

The games story in general is ok. The main missions arent too bad but the best ones are the assassination missions you do at the culmination of each chapter. These follow on from the formula used in AC Unity where you are given a lot of freedom to go about the assassination but this game introduces unique kills which can be achieved by for example kidnapping an important NPC. 

The game does have a few negatives. It has the occasional bugs. I had the game freeze and crash a couple of times. A character was invisible in one cutscene which was one of the funnier bugs I saw. Also I bought the Gold edition of the game but found most of the DLC to be lacking. The exception was the Jack the Ripper DLC which is probably the only one worth getting. I was actually quite impressed with it as it introduces some new fear mechanics to terrorise enemies and that was quite fun. I would go as far to say if is probably the best DLC for an Assassins Creed game even though generally they have been quite poor.

Overall I feel this is a pretty good Assassins Creed game and I found that I quite enjoyed it. I've played every AC game up to Syndicate and I would say Black Flag is the only one I liked better than this one. It's not good enough to convert anyone who doesn't like Assassins Creed, games but it is worth a try if you have enjoyed any of them before.

I think this is my favorite creed game so far.  I own Origins, Rogue, and Black Flag.  After playing those, I was pleasantly surprised at the differences in this game.  My only complaint is that the controls are clumsy at times.  

Playing Frogger on the barges is a blast.
The zipline is cool.
The side missions are interesting with historical characters, or just the variations in play (like removing the crime evidence for Nigel).
Graphics are good.
Voice acting is good.
Size of world is generous.
Skills, perks and upgrades are done well.

I guess I have one more complaint.  I hate the time-sensitive scenes that are like Dragon's Lair from the 80s.  That is such a stupid way to design a game.  You shouldn't have a split second to jump into something or else have to reload and do the whole scene over.  If I had to do this in the real world, it would be easy, but this is a video game with limited view and clumsy controls.  Stop putting that in your games.

Good day to you dear reader! Since I recently completed this game almost 100%, I thought why shouldn‚Äôt I write a review for this great game. I must say that this is the best game from the AC series until 2017. Graphics, Detailing the environment, character models and vehicles, and of course the clothes are simply superbly made. Especially the details of clothes and the arsenal. The soundtracks and atmosphere in the game involuntarily send you to London in the XIX centuries. About the plot and additional tasks, I generally keep quiet. The gameplay, physics and animation are redone in some places and refined almost to the ideal. But the most important thing in the game is the hook cat (Aye. Spiderman) and the nature of the characters! Yes, it is the attitude of the characters to each other that make this game one of the best games in history. Why? Because every gesture, text, expression of faces and emotions make me get great satisfaction from the game. It's like watching a 66 hour Hollywood movie. About additional content, I can say that buy without looking back, they are worth the money. Additional content from this game I can safely compare with the additional content of The Witcher 3. Well, what can I write more? I strongly advise you to buy this game and play even if you have not played in the AC series of games before.

I keep coming back to this game thinking that somehow I'll end up liking it, but obviously that never happens. It's sad because this game had so much potential and I really, really want to like it but they messed it up. I mean, if you really like the Victorian Era then sure, maybe you'll like the game. But if you're a big fan of the AC franchise and/or hate extremely grindy games, don't waste your money -- you'll get bored faster than you can ask for a refund on Steam. 

The setting is perfect, but that's about it. It's a pretty game with pretty graphics set on a very well made map based on the Victorian Era city of London. However, the story is boring and almost irrelevant to the AC franchise, and while the gameplay itself is rather decent, it becomes extremely tedious when you realize how slow you actually level up. Indeed, it's one of those games that forces you to buy XP boosters if you don't want to complete the 20 thousand repetitive side-missions and activities scattered all over the map. No, there aren't 20 thousand side-missions and activities, but it'll sure as hell feel like there are. So if you value your pockets and your time then don't waste any of them with this game.

TL;DR - Boring Story, Grindy Gameplay. Don't waste your money.

Played in hopes of "modern day storyline" going somewhere. Felt like I only saw a few glimpses of that. Gameplay was overall "meh"... Nice graphics, but boring. I did not find too much difference in playing the two main characters. Story had potential, but didn't feel like it delivered. Couldn't bother going for 100%, since it seem like it would require doing dumb $h1t like driving on the sidewalks breaking thousands of lampposts and hoping for good RNG to be able to complete the "fighting perks", which is relying upon your NPC opponent doing specific stuff.

So, after around 40 hours of game play and the completion of a good portion of side quests and whole main story line i believe it's time to review the game!

To make it easier I have split the good and the bad and i'll make a conclusion at the end: 


The Good: 

- Decent graphics 

- Fairly good story-line with, finally a further story line in the 'modern' day. 

- Good character development (Especially considering in this game it has two protagonists)

- Very good 'villain' development, especially some of the 'Henchmen' Very good!

- Great depiction of Victorian London, all the little details and NPC dialog is a great touch

- A nice mix between historical figures with fictional one's (Quest givers ect) 

The bad:

- Some the 'Capes' and 'Outfits' do seem rushed and copies of previous games and of themselves. 

- The 'Rooks' - Now hear me out, it's great having them around when you're say... level 5 or 6 however once you have upgraded them to level 9 and have all the 'Gang upgrades' the game becomes VERY easy. Seriously. 

- I appreciate the wealth of missions the devs have to make and that it's an AC game however, a good 40% of the missions are simply *Steal this* or *Capture this*. Now, this is fun for a good few hours however, after hour 20 you get very fatigued by these. 

- The map. Although this is a 2015 game the map is tiny. Especially in comparison with games such as 'The Witcher 3'and 'Fallout 4'. The map is big enough for the game itself however, I've hit the invisible wall way too many times. 


Conclusion: 

This is a great game, especially for price I paid for it (I think it was around ¬£10.00), I have spent a good 40 hours on the game and honestly i really enjoyed it. I still think i have another 10 hours out of it before it becomes boring so for ¬£10.00 50 hours of game play is very good. 

The game is not the most polished game I have every played, some missions are very lazily made with a clear cut and paste from previous missions. The story overall is interesting and i enjoyed it, it is a refreshing change to be able to play as two people instead of one. 

This isn't AC Brotherhood good nor AC 2 ect however for a more modern AC its a solid 7/10. I wouldn't pay the ¬£30 they have it at now however ¬£20 is a fair price, if any cheap than its a steal. 

Hopefully this helps some of you dudes out :)

Overall Rating - 8/10

Performance - 6/10
          There are some pretty major problems with stuttering while in carriages, but otherwise it runs rather well on my computer.

Music - 10/10
          Utterly gorgeous. Enough said.

Visuals - 9.5/10
          Really nice, but the Thames is as disgusting as I'd imagine it was during the Industrial Revolution.

Gameplay - 8.5/10
          It's what you'd expect from AC, but with only one egregious tailing mission. The addition of a grappling hook was bloody incredible, though. Conquering London felt pretty cool, too.

Writing - 7/10
          Meh. If you've liked the others, this one is nice. If not, you'll survive by just skipping the cutscenes.

Jank Factor - 9/10
          Assassin's Creed is no stranger to glitches, and some may see this as a negative, but it's fucking hilarious to see NPCs straight up walking into walls, look confused and upset, and then do the same thing for like 30 minutes.

Love this game even though the game control can make you cringe sometimes when you're in a rush. The main story are kinda boring in my opinion. At the time of writing this edit of my review, I have completed the game's campaign, a number of the character side missions, the Jack the Ripper DLC, and parts of The Last Maharajah and The Dreadful Crimes. 

I still recommend this entry in the franchise, but a more complete playthrough has somewhat lessened my esteem of it in some places. My largest complaint at this point would be the repetitiveness of the gameplay. Though there is variety in the objectives and action of the main story missions, they generally follow a consistent structure across the game - Jacob investigates the target, then assassinates them, while Evie cleans up the mess left in the wake of Jacob's last kill. Access to the last two of the game's nine sequences is locked behind liberation goals - to access sequence 8, you have to liberate 3 districts, and to access sequence 9, you have to have liberated the entire city. This means that to complete the story, you have to play every single liberation activity; kill every Templar, kidnap every gang leader, free every child labourer. It's exhausting. Here, there is no variety beyond variation in level design and optional objectives. 

The assassinations are still a highlight, carrying over the 'black box' sandboxes from Unity. Hunting a mad doctor in Lambeth Asylum; infiltrating an armoured carriage in Waterloo Station; stopping a robbery at the Bank of England; sneaking into Parliament; outmatching theatrics at the Alhambra. They are awesome. A large area within which to hunt your target, explore your options, create opportunities for yourself. And while the repeating structure of it does make it somewhat lose its appeal, it is interesting to see from Evie's perspective the consequences of each of these kills. It's always interesting when Assassin's Creed explores these angles instead of overly romanticising the Assassins as they did in AC2. It's simultaneously good lore-building while also adding depth to the portrayal of the group in Syndicate; Jacob's relentless pursuit of the London Templars gives rise to snake-oil medicine merchants, destabilises the transport sector, collapses the economy, and drives a stake through the heart of Whitehall. 

The characters are a standout as well. Jacob and Evie Fyre, our twin protagonists, present a somewhat engaging duality to the story, with Jacob being a brutish young man who's desperate to make a name for himself both in the Brotherhood and in the wider city, while Evie wants to stop the Templars in a more long-term way, preferring stealth to combat. This duality is sadly not extended to the gameplay, where they are identical with identical animations and movesets, having only 1-2 unique abilities each that are of little impact. 

The music by Austin Wintory is also a standout, something I have changed my tune on. It's lively, energetic, and perfect in tone for the setting. And it is so unlike anything that has come in Assassin's Creed before. 'A Gauntlet Scherzo', 'Bloody Presto con Brio' and 'The Assassin Two-Step' are highlights for me. The only complaint I have music-wise is that for some unfathomable reason, Ubisoft decided to leave 5 'murder ballads' written by Wintory out of the game. 'Give me the Cure', 'The Late Pearl Attaway', 'The Tale of Twopenny', 'Feasting on a Lord', and 'Jokes Jokes Jokes' all have lyrics lamenting the deaths of Jacob's 5 main targets, and they are absolutely brilliant, but they aren't in the game. 

1868 London is an interesting open world. Like all AC open worlds, it lacks the ways you can interact with it to make it feel more 'real', however, it is visually arresting and enjoyable to explore. As I mentioned in the original version of this review, the variety in the level design across the map, from the tight valleys of Whitechapel to the slums and factories of Southwark and the churning waters of the Thames, is interesting. The addition of driving allowing you to speed across the city is welcome. 

----------

I would strongly recommend Jack the Ripper and The Dreadful Crimes. The former takes the tone in a fittingly darker direction than the light humour of Quebec's Syndicate. There is still an element of repetition, as it asks you to do revised versions of the Liberation activities from the main game, but the story is much more focused and divorced from world progress, and tells a very interesting tale of Evie hunting the eponymous killer and asking 'what differentiates an Assassin from a serial killer?'. The addition of non-lethal fear attacks reinforces that philosophy, and though it took me a while to grasp it, it did a lot to enhance the more stealthy gameplay aspects. As for the Dreadful Crimes, they play very similarly to the murder mysteries in Unity, with a few improvements. You'll be introduced to a murder scene, and asked to figure out who did the killing. There's clues to examine, suspects to interrogate, and i found it actually tested my logic capabilities. A lot of fun.

Ok. This time you are looking for a thing called the shroud.  You learn a little more about the universe and get to run around Victorian London.. and a little bit in WW1 London. The Ubi-verse starts expanding around this point chronologically as "Watch_Dogs" exists in the same world as Abstergo. So keep that in mind when playing both franchises. Far Cry games seem to only exists as things made my Abstergo, along with Tom Clancy games.

Have they given you freedom this time? Short answer no.  Tropes like the following are still holding the series back:
-- You can't do this until you become anon. . From cutting bells, to opening doors. or reaching way-points (You have a solution for this one called "Escape enemies" that works without making me feel silly)
-- Grapple cam not be used from moving vehicles. Don't expect any fun "Just cause" stuff here.  
-- 100% completion of missions still requires you complete side objectives in a specific way (Why not just reward us for being creative). 
-- Mission goals are not open enough in many cases and take creative choices out of your hands.
-- You can't choose the time of day when doing story missions, these seem to happen based on the missions design. So there is no use waiting for nightfall to do those. The Open World targets on the other hand can be done this way.
-- Weather is largely cosmetic, there is little or no difference in detection when approaching a target in the rain.

New Mechanics:
- New parkour transitions (A for up and B for down). However, quite frequently the B would be needed when crossing walls and gates and it would slow your momentum down substantially. . There are plenty of ways to improve parkour control in AC and this is not one of them.
- Evie and Jacob, you play as two characters, one stealthy and one more like a brute,
- grapple  / ip line, this almost feels like a super power and must save you from over 5 hours of climbing- If only it had more intuitive/ / consistent  targeting.
- Horse and Cart
- Trains (on rails you can't control)
- Steam Boats (on rails and sadly you can't control them)
- Gangs are back in a new way (not quite Brotherhood)
- Mini boses in each District. Not quite like crackdown, as they appear part way through your sacking of that district. If you run them down and defeat them at that point they die.
- Assassinations: Like Unity, but a bit more cinematic and forced. It feels like you are doing actions rather than making choices. Hopefully they learn to embrace systemic gaming in the future titles and rely more on mechanics and world design and give player multiple ways to assassinate (Hitman, still rules here)
- Outfits now give benefits, but are not able to be used as disguises like in "AC Liberation" -- Though some outfits detract from the charms of the characters.

Premium Content
- Some maps for collectibles are premium purchases now, so get those guides ready if you want to 

Economy
- Upgrade the train/gang and you earn more funds. I'm not sure if it is tied to the 
- Don't go collecting until you find the grapple
- Once you have finished the  Open World missions (mostly available at sequence 3), you will be able to max out your character and start earning enough money that it is not a problem for the rest of the game. 
- You will find yourself assassinating every thug in the street to get ammo, rather than buying it. 

Little Things that bothered me
-- Maps in WW1 England included floating pathways, whilst maps in the main game do not (This would have made going to the Thames a lot less daunting)
-- No Chest map available in WW1
-- That zip line to dive from London bridge to get that helix.
-- Helixes that seemed out of reach only to find out later that you needed the grapple to get them (Hence why you should wait to get that before you go collecting)
-- Non-sticky targeting during combat. You need to keep an eye on the white outlined enemy. Your character may counter punches in one direction and follow up with a combo but immediately after that they will switch back to a previously outlined target instead of remaining stuck on that new target. This felt unintuitive to me and often led my follow up combos to be landed on a blocking enemy who then punishes you. Most noticed in encounters of 4 or more. 
-- CPU hungry. I needed to lock my unlocked i5 processor so that the game would not over-use it. There was no impact to gameplay when doing this.  But unless you have some freezer to put your PC in, I recommend that you do this. Otherwise there will be the odd time your CPU will reach stupid temperatures.  Even with decent coolers attached.

Okay. This game is honestly really good. For the first 30 hours. Or whenever you 100% the campaign and skills for gangs and yourself. Once you 100% those things, it gets really boring. It really sucks. Just everything after the campaign, the skills, the gang wars, nothing is challenging anymore.

The parkour in this game is pretty on point. Partially inherited from Unity, they did a good job adjusting the animation which make the free-running more fluid. A grappling hook system is added so that you can climb up faster and go across streets without grounding, but the usage ratio is a little bit too much. I like the combat system, though the multi execution sometimes is hard to trigger. Music is subpar, nothing worth remembering. Story is actually bad.

Overall: 7/10
